fields.headline: Real man making relaxed return
fields.standfirst: Back in red and back at Anfield, Jon Brodkin meets Steve McManaman
fields.trailText: As snow fell outside England's hotel in Cheshire yesterday, Steve McManaman could have been forgiven for wishing he was back in Madrid. Checking flights, though, was far from the 29-year-old's thinking. On a week of anticipation for all England's players, McManaman has particular cause for excitement.
fields.body:
As snow fell outside England's hotel in Cheshire yesterday, Steve McManaman could have been forgiven for wishing he was back in Madrid. Checking flights, though, was far from the 29-year-old's thinking. On a week of anticipation for all England's players, McManaman has particular cause for excitement.

It is not just that an injury to Nick Barmby will give him the chance to reignite his international career on Saturday against Finland. With the match taking place at Anfield, McManaman returns for the first time to the club where he built his career. To add to the poignancy, England will be playing in red.

"To go back to Anfield would of course be a big thing for me," he says, recalling the emotional send-off he received from the Kop when he departed for Spain almost two years ago. "I've been back a few times to visit a lot of people, a couple of times to watch the team, but finally to pull on a shirt and play would be fantastic."

McManaman left Liverpool on a low after an injury-afflicted season, but he returns on a high, a European Cup winner and a player for whom respect has grown further as he has forced his way back into favour at the Bernabeu when all seemed lost. In clubs terms few can doubt his maturity and effectiveness. Yet his England career has been largely a tale of frustration.

Despite accumulating 31 caps since his debut against Nigeria in 1994, he has produced his best only in flashes. Impressive enough at Euro 96 to be identified as England's best performer by Pele, McManaman was a bit-part player at France 98 and started only the first game at Euro 2000 against Portugal before succumbing to injury.

Saturday promises to be his first start since and many will hope Sven-Goran Eriksson can find a way to bring out his undoubted talent consistently. McManaman hinted yesterday that Kevin Keegan's policy of giving him a free role was not ideal.

"Just to be given the ball and run everywhere on the pitch is a strange scenario," he says. "You've got other people you could be leaving in the mire. It's not as easy as saying: 'Give him the ball.' No one plays like that. Luis Figo and Rivaldo don't play like that. They have certain jobs to do and people try to get the ball to them as much as possible."

Under Eriksson tactics will be more rigid. Barmby may have been undroppable after his display against Spain but his ill-fortune is another man's gain and McManaman should fill the left midfield spot he occupies for Real Madrid, albeit with Chris Powell rather than Roberto Carlos behind him.

After training for the first time with Eriksson yesterday, McManaman sounded positive. "You can see he's a different manager," he says. "He was reserved and stood at the side looking on. It's good to do that, letting other people take training. Sometimes when you get too involved you don't see the big picture."

McManaman is as articulate as ever and increasingly at home in front of the prying eyes of photographers and reporters. Every day in Madrid, he says, he has to talk in front of the cameras. "The first 10 pages of every sports newspaper is dedicated to the team every single day," he explains. "If you wear a new pair of boots it's in the papers. If you drive a new car it's in the papers."

A few months ago, notwithstanding his goalscoring contribution to his club's European Cup final triumph, the papers lapped up revelations that Real's new chairman Florentino Perez was trying to force him out. McManaman refused to bleat and his patience was richly rewarded.

"It wasn't as dramatic as the newspapers put it," he says. "Admittedly I wasn't involved in any of the games pre-season but the manager, the players and the coaching staff were telling me not to worry and that it would soon filter out, which it did. It was a strange situation because when I went to the training ground every single day it was as if there was no problem at all."

Having come back from the dead with Real, McManaman must hope he can do the same for England's World Cup hopes.

fields.headline: Graham hits at Spurs 'smear campaign'
fields.trailText: George Graham yesterday accused Enic, the owners of Tottenham Hotspur who sacked him as manager last Friday, of leaking stories to the press as part of an ongoing campaign to smear his name.
fields.body:
George Graham yesterday accused Enic, the owners of Tottenham Hotspur who sacked him as manager last Friday, of leaking stories to the press as part of an ongoing campaign to smear his name.

Graham was responding to a story in the Daily Mirror yesterday which claimed Tottenham officials had launched an investigation after £18,700 in cash was found in a drawer in a White Hart Lane office.

However, within hours of the allegations appearing it became apparent that the money was collected from fines imposed on players and sent to a charity at the end of the season. This was later con firmed by Graham in a statement which said the club knew of the money and that the scheme to raise money for charity was done with the blessing of Tottenham officials.

Following Graham's acrimonious sacking, David Buchler, Tottenham's executive vice-chairman, accused him of not having the interests of the club at heart and of not being a team player after allegedly revealing confidential information about the club's finances.

Graham claims yesterday's revelations are the latest chapter in a campaign being waged against him by certain individuals linked to Tottenham.

Lawyers acting for Graham said: "Mr Graham is disappointed that the club should now be feigning concern and using this scheme as a pretext to try and denigrate his character in the newspapers.

"Having supposedly sacked him for revealing confidential information it is surprising that once again the club is prepared to run its affairs through the leak of internal club information to the press."

The lawyer's statement said the cash, collected by the club secretary John Alexander, was destined for the Richard House Trust Children's Hospice, after Great Ormond Street Hospital had benefited last year.

Graham said in the statement: "I am slightly surprised that the new owners should be expressing any concern to newspapers about a scheme which the club was fully aware of and which was so beneficial. I am delighted to have been able to play my part in raising these monies for charity."

Graham is consulting his lawyers about possible legal action against Tottenham following his dismissal.

The club last night attempted to defuse the row, saying: "The cash was not suddenly found in a drawer as the Mirror claims. It was kept in a strong box in the club secretary's office and obviously its purpose, existence and whereabouts were known. We were not asked to comment in advance, nor is the club aware of the source of this information. We are actively conducting our own investigation on that point."

fields.headline: Goram rushes to United's rescue
fields.trailText: Andy Goram is set to make a startling return to the European stage after Manchester United's urgent search for an experienced goalkeeper took them to the former Rangers and Scotland international who will be 37 next month.
fields.body:
Andy Goram is set to make a startling return to the European stage after Manchester United's urgent search for an experienced goalkeeper took them to the former Rangers and Scotland international who will be 37 next month.

Last night the Lancashire-born Goram was back in England finalising an ingenious loan move from Motherwell which could well see him in United's goal against Bayern Munich in the Champions League quarter-final early next month.

Uefa are believed to have stipulated that United could take a goalkeeper only on a straightforward loan - an arrangement originally rejected yesterday by Motherwell - but the Scottish club later agreed to part with their captain when United offered them £100,000 for his services on a three-month deal.

Goram's Motherwell contract expires this summer but he has effectively finished playing for them. After his Old Trafford spell he will revert to being a Fir Park player, but only for one day, before becoming a free agent.

Goram could make his debut a week on Saturday in the Pre miership at Liverpool with Fabien Barthez doubtful after suffering a thigh strain which forced him out against Leicester and makes him a spectator in France's two friendlies over the next week.

Raimond van der Gouw is also injured, leaving Sir Alex Ferguson with only the 19-year-old American Paul Rachubka to keep goal.

Pat Nevin, Motherwell's director of football, hailed the deal as a"clever piece of lateral thinking" by Ferguson.

Nevin said: "It's a perfectly sensible deal if you think about it. United needed a goalkeeper short-term and some one who has been there before and will be able to cope with the big atmosphere. They have got the right man and it is a fantastic move for him as well."

Meanwhile, Jonathan Greening's frustrating United career appears over after he asked for a transfer because of his lack of first-team opportunities. The versatile 22-year-old Greening, currently with England's Under-21s, made a rare start last on Saturday, only to be substituted at half-time.

The former York player was put up for sale just over a year ago but remained with United. Even now, he is highly unlikely to leave until the summer.

webTitle: Europe is a great, black hole for Labour politicians

fields.headline: Europe is a great, black hole for Labour politicians
fields.standfirst:
Election strategists must mark their territory before the Tories snatch it

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Election strategists must mark their territory before the Tories snatch it.
fields.body:
Manoeuvring to get away from an early election, William Hague distracts attention from what the contest will be about. He's playing a good hand, exploiting the government's inflexible haste without looking as though he's running scared. Plainly Mr Blair is about to switch the argument. Having said for three weeks that a May 3 election can happen because foot and mouth is under control, party managers are getting ready to say the opposite: that the election must happen now because the plague may not be any better under control in September. Delay now and you delay for ever, they've begun to murmur. There's a lot of disingenuous electoralism here, which Hague would be negligent if he did not challenge.

But it's not the biggest electoral issue inside the Conservative party. That place belongs to Europe. Europe, in fact, looms into focus all round. For the government, today's EU summit in Stockholm is one of many well carpentered planks in the bridge to May 3. Among the Tory high command, meanwhile, there are rumblings of anxiety about whether the issue will play as they have planned. For the country as a whole, the role of the election as prelude to a euro referendum deserves to be better understood.

Mr Hague has always seen Europe as big. Along with crime, asylum and tax, it's one of the four issues he thinks he can make sing. But some of his colleagues are no longer so sure. The so-called liberalising tendency in the party, adherents of Michael Portillo and/or Francis Maude, give voice to other thoughts. These people may be only marginally less Euro-sceptic than Hague is, but they're more sceptical about the impact of Europe on voting, and much more worried about the impact of another Labour landslide on the battle they really care about, the referendum.

The election, they know, is lost. But the referendum is not. Yet an election perceived to have been lost after a campaign that majored on Europe would send a calamitous signal. Unlike other Eurosceptics, Tory anti- Europeans do not have a strategy directed at preventing the referendum taking place by persuading Blair he can never win it. Hague's putative successors, if not Hague himself, are banking everything on the referendum as midwife to the rebirth of their party. But they face an election that threatens to pulverise their credibility. Another Labour landslide would make a referendum not merely likely but, I believe, politically very hard for the government to duck away from. If Hague has been smashed on Europe, it would also be decidedly easier to win.

These senior colleagues, rivals awaiting their moment, have another doubt. They aren't recognisable as belonging to something called the Tory left, so they weren't fastidiously much offended by Hague's nationalistic garbage on the subject of Britain becoming "a foreign land". But many top Tories were taken aback by how badly that keynote speech went down, even with the Sun. Nationalistic crudity, the only way Hague knows how to talk about Europe, turned out not to appeal even to an icon of nationalism. A clash is therefore developing between Hagueites still determined to play Europe big and hard, and others who would now prefer to let the election be lost on different things.

This has repercussions for Labour, who are assuming Hague will continue to do his piece. Mr Blair and Robin Cook anticipate the argument with relish. They see it as meat for their contention that the Tories are simply incompetent. The wilder Hague lines give them many ways of showing that this inadequate parvenu shouldn't be trusted.

Stockholm, they intend, will add to the unfavourable comparison with themselves. It will be flourished as proof of constructive engagement. It looks as though France, for Mr Jospin's own electoral reasons, won't allow Stockholm to be a Blairite triumph, with full-scale opening up of gas and electricity markets. But there will be enough to make the British case. The financial markets will like another dose of liberal reform, building on last year's Lisbon summit. The relentless ratcheting from one obscure EU meeting to another, which is usually the obsession only of anoraked aficionados, will be presented by the Blair machine, with justice, as progress in the right direction. Such is the unglamorous nature of EU business. But with an election coming, there are few limits to the sparkle that inventive propagandists will be able to bestow on the driest material.

If Hague chooses to make the frontal anti-EU case, all this will be a telling riposte. It can be used to distinguish the men of business from the man of Euro-madness. But that is not the only prospect on offer. If Portilloism gets its way, and Europe recedes from the Tory agenda, the challenge to Mr Blair becomes trickier. How will he use the issue of Europe in an active not reactive way? How far will he voluntarily go to make this election, in part, a quest for a mandate to hold the referendum and win it?

The easy answer is to say: no distance at all. Safety-first politics still dominates most Labour thinking, however luscious the majority the opinion polls seem to foretell. There's hardly a single Labour politician who can persuade him or herself that pushing Europe up front would win extra seats. An unnoticed lacuna in politics, indeed, is the absence of knowledge, let alone enthusiasm, concerning Europe of most Labour MPs. The place is a great black hole, which may not engage their active hostility but would find them at a loss in a gloves-off debate with the many sharp Tory Eurosceptics whose obsession has equipped them with formidable, if selective, expertise. Labour is mildly pro-European. It has yet to become the party of Europe.

On the other hand, the proliferating Tory divisions and confusions - not just Hague v Clarke but Portillo v Hague - present an opportunity which it would be criminal for a European prime minister to miss. Irrespective of how far Mr Hague chooses to jump towards the unacceptable extreme, Mr Blair has his own unique chance to define his victory as a victory, among other things, for his Europe policy, and thereby advance the referendum further into the realm of practical politics.

I have no doubt he wants to hold the referendum. Most people underestimate his personal commitment to resolving the misbegotten turmoil the Europe question has brought to modern British history. That's not to say he definitely intends to take the plunge. The gamble could look too great. But the election offers a massive opening to change the terms of trade and remake the odds. If the result is big, it needs to look like a signal for the next and bigger contest. The framework of the campaign is therefore vital. If Hague fails to oblige by offering an open target, let's hope Tony Blair doesn't shrink from inventing his own resonant language for popular endorsement. Seize the day.

webTitle: Comment: George Monbiot on the WTO

fields.headline: Gats' gaffes
fields.standfirst: The World Trade Organisation, which meets in Geneva today, wields enormous power yet is unaccountable
fields.trailText: The World Trade Organisation, which meets in Geneva today, wields enormous power yet is unaccountable.
fields.body:
A couple of years ago, I explained to a prominent Conservative that the World Trade Agreement would force us to import hormone-treated beef from the United States. She was outraged. "Who were the bloody idiots who let this happen?" she fulminated. "Er ... the Conservatives".

The party of national sovereignty had ceded its powers to an unelected body far more powerful and less accountable than the bogeyman of Europe, without a flicker of concern for the government's mandate. If any of the Tory ministers who were in power at the time can demonstrate that they actually read the agreement they signed, I would be happy to surrender, as a modest reward, the money the Guardian will pay me for writing this article. But I don't anticipate a rush of claimants.

One of the services delivered to the world by the anti-globalisation protesters is that no treaty can ever be approved so quietly again. Ministers and trade officials are now forced to justify some of their negotiating positions. That, however, is about as far as it goes. One hundred and seventy MPs have signed an early day motion calling for the impact of the General Agreement on Trade in Services (Gats) on the public sector to be examined. Parliament's international development committee has demanded a special commission. But the government has entered negotiations in Geneva this week without any sign that it has understood the concerns of its critics.

The current champions of globalisation are as dismis sive as the Tories were indifferent. "The people that stand outside and say they work in the interests of the poorest people," Michael Moore, head of the World Trade Organisation, confided last month, "make me want to vomit."

In a letter to the Guardian four weeks ago, Clare Short argued that it is "absolutely false" to suggest that the agreement will force the privatisation of the public sector. "No one," she claimed, "has proposed any free trade in public services." Those who claim that Gats will lead to privatisation are "conspiracy theorists".

There is no question that the Gats treaty is complicated and contradictory. As any corporate lawyer will confirm, its impact will depend upon its interpretation. This being so, almost any claim can be made about what it will or will not do. But in both the current agreement itself and in the public statements made by trade officials there is plenty to suggest that Short and Moore's glib dismissal of its opponents' warnings is a grave disservice to democracy.

The agreement excludes government services which are not "in competition with [private] service suppliers". This seems perfectly clear, until you remember that nearly every public service in Britain - health, education, transport, even prisons - now competes with private operators. As the World Trade Organisation has pointed out, "It seems unrealistic in such cases to argue ... that no competitive relationship exists between the two groups of suppliers." Member governments, it suggests, should "reconsider the breadth and depth of their commitments on health and social services". Writing about education, the WTO insists that "government monopolies" and subsidies are barriers to free trade. I don't know how this looks to Clare Short, but to me it looks rather like an agenda for privatisation.

Gats is certainly viewed by some of its key negotiators as a means of providing new opportunities for private operators. According to the European commission, "Gats is not just something that exists between governments. It is first and foremost an instrument for the benefit of business." Negotiating positions, Peter Mandelson insisted when he was secretary of state for trade and industry, "must reflect UK business priorities".

The director of the WTO's services division has pointed out that "without the enormous pressure generated by the American financial services sector, particularly companies like American Express and Citicorp, there would have been no services agreement".

Short and Moore's assurances about the reversibility of the treaty, about countries' capacity to stop the process where and when they want, and about the democratic nature of the proceedings also seem to rely on a selective reading of both the agreement itself and the events and statements surrounding it. Anyone who believes that the governments of developing countries are not bullied and marginalised by the rich nations during global trade talks has been looking the other way.

If Gats, as Short and Moore insist, is really about the right of nations to interact freely, then it must surely be attended by a free debate. This means that the men and women reshaping the world in Geneva today must start seeking to understand and engage with the complaints of their opponents. Otherwise we might, one day, have to explain to them that they were the bloody idiots who let it happen.

webTitle: First of a three-part series on local government

fields.headline: Does loss of power mean the death of the town hall?
fields.standfirst: In the first of a three-part series looking at the health of local government - vital to changing the state of public services - Roy Hattersley visits Birmingham, home of old, and new, civic virtues
fields.trailText: In the first of a three-part series looking at the health of local government - vital to changing the state of public services - I visit Birmingham, home of old, and new, civic virtues.
fields.body:
Modern local government began in Birmingham when the mayor and corporation bought the town gasworks and water company and used the profit from light and heat to rebuild the crumbling sewers. The mayor was Joseph Chamberlain and the corporation believed in his Civic Gospel of Improvement. For more than a hundred years, councillors of England's second city continued to act with what Chamberlain called "sagacious audacity" - which to them meant a continual increase in expenditure and activity.

At the height of its powers, the City of Birmingham owned hospitals, a bus and tramway company, more houses than any other landlord in the West Midlands, and a bank. It was the statutory police authority, managed what were wrongly called state schools, paid "relief" to the sick and unemployed and subsidised amenities of its own choice - parks, concert halls, allotments and museums - from rates which it levied at its own discretion. Birmingham councillors were not universally loved, but they were respected as men and women of authority.

Ever since the days of Joe Chamberlain's Liberal caucus, party politics has been an essential ingredient in Birmingham local government. Labour has been in tight control for 17 years. Now there are 67 Labour councillors, 28 Conservative and 18 Liberals. There are also five members of Justice, a group of Muslims who demand "freedom for Kashmir". Whatever relevance their policy has to municipal government, they reflect the ethnic pattern of the city's population. The 1991 census identified 13.5% of the population as Asian. Half were of Pakistani origin.

It is fashionable to suggest that strict party discipline has brought the council into disrepute. Sir Richard Knowles, Labour leader for 10 years, has a different explanation: "We have lost popularity because we have lost power." Whatever the reason for their disenchantment, the people of Birmingham are not enthused by municipal politics. The turnout in the last local election was 28%. The public consultation which preceded the city budget attracted audiences of five in Liberal Yardley and 20 in Tory Sutton Coldfield.

None of the meetings produced an outcry against the abandonment of, or reduction in, the caring services. The closure of day centres provoked barely a murmur of protest. Perhaps Birmingham has accepted the view of Sir Michael Lyons, Birmingham's chief executive and once a Labour councillor: "What the council is expected to do is just not sustainable on present resources." Or it may be that the people no longer expect local government to meet their real needs.

Birmingham local government is still big business. Its annual budget is more than £2bn. Some 43,000 employees crowd its payroll. But it has lost many of the powers which directly affect the lives and welfare of its citizens. Some council services were nationalised by Labour. Others were privatised by Conservatives. Both parties hedged about council powers with so many regulations that, over great areas of policy, local government became no more than an agent of Whitehall and Westminster. Ministers call the tune because they pay the piper. Birmingham raises 11% of its revenue from council tax. The Treasury provides 63%. That equation makes independence impossible.

Education is the one remaining service which gives city councils a popular appeal. The appearance of power deceives. "In reality," says Albert Bore, the council leader, "we are no longer an education authority. We neither directly provide the service nor set the standards".

Professor Tim Brighouse, the chief education officer, makes the same point in less apocalyptic language. "It is our duty to secure the provision of an education service. But it is a moot point how much we provide ourselves". The government's statement on The Role and Function of Local Education Authorities does not spare municipal feelings. It is not the authority's "role to run or intervene in schools".

Sir Richard believes that we are witnessing "the slow death of local government". Mr Bore insists that councils still have a meaningful role. "But it is not the role we have played over the last 100 years." Why, he asks, "do we have to be a direct provider of services? Once there was nobody else around. Now there is. We can engage others to provide what we want". He has a new civic gospel to replace what he calls, without noticeable nostalgia, "50 years of municipal benevolence". In pursuit of its objective he is promoting the biggest voluntary abdication of power in municipal history.

Radical

If all goes to plan, by 2002 Birmingham will have privatised its meals-on-wheels and half of its home-care service, transferred its elderly people's homes to a trust and split the direct labour department into four separate - and almost certainly privately owned - operations. More radical still, the entire stock of corporation houses (88,000 in all) will have been given away - together with their debts, which exceed £650m.

The extent of the Labour leader's aspiration has alarmed even David Roy, the leader of the council's Conservative minority. He neither balks at the privatisation of welfare services nor bridles at what amounts to the closure of the direct labour department, and he believes that the council employs "far too many people for the work we now do". But he "feels profoundly uncomfortable about selling all the houses". John Hemming, the Liberal leader, goes even further in his opposition to what he describes as "the contract culture" - the mistaken belief that municipal enterprise is inherently inefficient. From the luxury of opposition he argues that the council should keep the housing stock but run it more efficiently.

Improved efficiency, rather than greater democracy, was the object of Margaret Thatcher's local government reforms. Market forces were to exert their influence on councils through a system of compulsory competitive tendering which required, in effect, more and more services to be handed to private enterprise. Labour replaced competitive tendering with an obligation for councils to obtain "best value" - without always setting out the criteria against which best value is judged.

The scheme is now to be extended by what are known as public service agreements. Birmingham is negotiating with the government to determine 12 specific targets. They range from improving primary school results to reducing the numbers of domestic burglaries. A successful PSA, combined with what is called a best performance plan, will earn the city an extra grant of something like £28m. It will also give Whitehall a new influence over Birmingham policy. But the council shows little sign of resenting or rejecting Whitehall's ever increasing authority. The solution it proposes to the escalating housing crisis is a negotiated deal with central government built on the promise to reduce the city's powers.

Until the mid-seventies, Whitehall frantically encouraged council house building with lavish subsidies. Then the mood changed. Margaret Thatcher was not only against council house building, she was the enemy of "the council house culture". In the most socially significant decision of her premiership, she gave municipal tenants the "right to buy". Seventy five thousand Birmingham families took up the offer. The best properties were sold first and the worst were not sold at all. The council was left with the oldest and most dilapidated houses - and debts of £650m.

Estimates of how much it will cost to rehabilitate the housing stock vary from £1bn to £4bn. This year Birmingham received £80m from the housing investment programme. Almost half will be used to subsidise private properties. "As things now stand," says Mr Bore, knowing that he is stating the obvious, "the situation gets worse not better". His remedy - the sale of the whole housing stock - may work. Tony Blair is as opposed to council tenancy as Margaret Thatcher once was. Birmingham hopes that the government will clear its housing debt as the price of ending municipal dependency.

A year ago, after pressure from dissatisfied tenants, 3,000 properties on the Lea Bank estate were transferred to the ownership of an independent trust. Mr Bore plans to set up 12 more registered social landlords and divide the housing stock between them, assuming that tenant ballots endorse the change of ownership. The results of the polls are not in much doubt. The choice will lie between a pound a week rent increase linked to a programme of repair and renovation and a rent freeze which guarantees continued dilapidation. Seventy five per cent of tenants receive housing benefit. They can vote for a rent increase in the knowledge that it will be paid by the government.

Birmingham's Labour left argues that the government should clear the debt and leave the houses in council ownership. Perhaps it should. But the only hope of the Treasury paying off the debt lies in the council abandoning its role as landlord. Mr Bore could reluctantly accept the end of municipal tenancy as inevitable. But he endorses the government's determination to move the ownership of low-cost, rented houses from corporations to independent trusts. He has "thought very carefully" about the merits of council tenancy and decided that it "does not produce a proper social mix". His socialist heresy does not end there. Mr Bore has come to the conclusion that Birmingham's direct labour department is, by its nature, uncompetitive.

Sir Michael describes the soon-to-be privatised department as "always too big for an in-house operation" and "the victim of long-term poor management". That is only part of the story. Too often decisions have been taken in the interests of its employees rather than its customers - the people of Birmingham. Every estate echoes with unverifiable stories of petty fraud - repairs recorded as completed but not done. But the real problem is more fundamental. The public works department will lose £8.5m this year, and an estimated £14m next, because the council refused to accept the disciplines required for commercial survival.

Right-to-buy legislation reduced Birmingham housing stock by almost half. So, to protect the direct labour workforce, the council increased its repair and maintenance programme to a level which was neither affordable nor sustainable. Then the government insisted that all local authority contracts should be won by competitive tender. The direct labour department bid for its traditional work at hugely optimistic prices. A private builder who made such errors would have gone out of business within a year.

So would a privately owned care home that accepted the wage levels and conditions of service which the unions have negotiated with Birmingham council. Care assistants working for the social services department are paid double time and given a day's holiday in lieu if they work on Sunday. Staff who telephone in sick on Sunday morning receive the same compensation for "working" unsocial hours. The corporation cannot afford, but dare not abandon, such largesse. A private company will, the theory goes, reduce labour costs in ways no council could contemplate. In Birmingham, the civic ethic now embraces the disciplines of the market.

The enterprise culture was imposed on schools when "local management" forced the education authorities to compete against private providers for the supply of everything from exercise books to accountancy. Prof Brighouse is gratified by how little advantage Birmingham's headteachers have taken of the new freedom. He ought not to be surprised. The revival in the city's education system is, at least in part, the product of his six years in the city. Prof Brighouse describes his job, crushed between David Blunkett's increasingly detailed demands and the growing autonomy of individual schools, as "looking down the wrong end of a telescope at a Swiss watch with a spanner in my hand" - which does not suggest enthusiasm for the new regime. Labouring under that disadvantage, he has transformed Birmingham's education.

In his last major act as council leader, Sir Richard commissioned Ted Wragg of Exeter University to head an enquiry into "the present and future needs of education in Birmingham". It was a courageous decision. Sir Richard knew that the council's young Turks blamed him for a reduction in the education budget to £70m below the standard spending assessment, the government's estimate of what the city needed to invest in the future. The Wragg report's first recommendation was that "the council should give education top priority and appropriate standing". When the time came to appoint a new chief officer, Prof Brighouse seemed the right man to lead the renaissance. Education spending rose to £20m above the spending assessment. Improved examination results moved the city from virtually the bottom to a third of the way up the national league tables. No one is sure which has had the greater effect - money or Prof Brighouse's quirky but dynamic personality.

Education, once the city's neglected service, now pioneers new methods of promoting literacy and numeracy - including the University of the First Age, which offers extra teaching for 11 to 15-year-olds in conditions they find congenial rather than constraining. More important, at a time when teachers feel underpaid and undervalued, Prof Brighouse has lifted staff-room morale. His open antagonism to Chris Woodhead, the hugely disliked former chief inspector of schools, helped. So did his successful libel action against John Patten (a brief, but greatly despised, secretary of state) and the decision to donate his damages to school improvements. But it was the way in which he spent his early weeks in the job that won his spurs. He visited schools and talked to teachers. Even within its modern limitation, local government works best when it fulfils its historic destiny to be personal and intimate.

New civic gospel

.Prof Brighouse has made "partnership" with the government work. It is a special use of the word since one of the partners dictates how the other will behave. A white paper, Modern Local Government, leaves no doubt which of the partners is in charge. "There is no future in the old model of councils trying to plan and run most services". Instead they will be required "to promote the economic, social and environmental wellbeing of their areas". Birmingham has grasped - perhaps it even anticipated - one element in that stern injunction and elevated it to a new civic gospel. The idea that the corporation should actively encourage commercial development came upon the council gradually and was accepted by some councillors reluctantly and by others not at all.

Twenty-five years ago, in a contest which was more about prestige than prosperity, Birmingham beat London in the race to become home to the National Exhibition Centre. Its success was never in doubt. But, situated on the southern boundary, the NEC has not made much of a contribution to the city's economy. It was valued as a status symbol. At one meeting, where the triumph over London was discussed, the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra was offered as another example of provincial superiority. Everybody agreed that it needed a new concert hall. Nobody could think of a way to raise the money.

Someone suggested an approach to the European Community. Initial enquiries suggested that, although the regional development fund would not invest in a concert hall, it might provide money for something bigger and better. The result was the International Convention Centre in which the development fund invested £49.7m. The chamber of commerce and the local CBI thought it could be built next to, or as an extension of, the Exhibition Centre. But the council wanted it in the city centre. While Birmingham was still negotiating with Brussels, the old Victorian concert hall - not half a mile from Chamberlain Square and the town hall - burned down. The city centre was transformed. Almost a third of the council registered the Labour group complaint that Sir Richard was wasting time and money which should have been devoted to education.

The convention centre whetted the council's appetite for commercial development. Over 15 years the EU invested another £175m on tearing the city apart and putting it back together again, as well as more than £100m in social fund programmes for neighbourhood regeneration. The National Indoor Arena was built next to the ICC. The city took a third share in a Hyatt hotel which was thought necessary to accommodate the expected flood of visitors. Since then hotel building has become a Birmingham growth industry. Few pumps have ever been primed so successfully. Brindley Place and the associated restoration of the canal basin is now a civic showpiece of shops and offices. Seven thousand new jobs have been created in the area, as many as there will be at Rover's Longbridge factory in 2002.

The city's commitment to urban regeneration came to practical life in the spring of 1988 at a meeting between representatives of national and local government, business and the various planning professions. It was held at Highbury, once the home of the Chamberlains - a venue which was either prophetic or paradoxical depending on whether the new policy is regarded as a continuation of or a break with Birmingham's municipal tradition. From then on all plans for city generation were called "Highbury". The stated purpose of Highbury was "to explore the relationship between economic activity and investment and the physical environment". The council undertook to create the physical conditions for commercial growth in the city centre. Whether all the participants realised it or not, the civic gospel was taking on an economic dimension.

The results have been a spectacular success for local government as "facilitator" rather than provider. Three potential developers - Hammersons, Henderson's and Land Securities - competed with each other for planning permission to regenerate part of the old Bull Ring. The council persuaded them to come together in a partnership which will create 8,000 new jobs. The Alliance consortium, as it is now called, is part of the massive regeneration initiative in which the city council "brokers" partnerships between the private and public sectors. From the old GPO sorting office, which has become a vast shopping mall, to Fort Dunlop which now advertises "hotels, sports, eating, shops", Birmingham's economy is changing. The 200,000 jobs which were lost between 1975 and 1985 (more than in Scotland and Wales combined) are gradually being replaced as service industries take over from manufacturing. The council - or at least its leader - is changing to accommodate the new world.

Mr Bore's enthusiasm is instinctive. He is a technocrat by profession and, despite his leftwing past, a tycoon by temperament. Ironically, the Liberal and Conservative council leaders are beginning - despite their business backgrounds - to express fears that too much municipal time and effort is being spent on the city centre at the rest of Birmingham's expense. The Labour group has never disguised its doubts. Last May, Mr Bore was re-elected leader by a majority of one vote. The nature of the challenge that all but unseated him was confirmed by the quality of the near successful pretender. No one thought that Kevin Stacey had more ability than Mr Bore - just that he was different.

The dissatisfaction may be diminished by the publication of A New Partnership for Governance, a consultation paper on the future of local government in Birmingham which addresses old problems in new language. The determination "to tackle the deep seated problems of social exclusion" are an echo of Joe Chamberlain's belief that "an extension of the functions and authority" of Birmingham corporation would assist in "equalising the conditions of men". In common with the mood of the moment, Birmingham believes that "social exclusion is about much more than just material deprivation or lack of work and income".

That is not a recently acquired opinion. Long before such theories were fashionable, Birmingham was forming neighbourhood councils to provide a forum for popular discussion and dissent. Two years ago, a democracy commission, under the chairmanship of Sir Adrian Cadbury, ex amined ways of ensuring "greater democratic participation" in the city's affairs. A New Partnership for Governance is the extension of the same objective. It invites comments on everything from the way in which the neighbourhood renewal fund - planned to spend £44m in Birmingham in the next three years - should best be used, to the desirability of "greater use of referendums in making local decisions". It refers, in passing, to the national government's plans for greater local democracy. Birmingham has never thought it necessary to accept anyone else's advice.

Birmingham will soon have to decide if it is to be led by a directly elected executive mayor - one of several options which the Local Government Act requires it to consider. It could choose an elected council leader supported either by a cabinet or a council manager. Only a mayor will satisfy Birmingham's civic pride. England's second city will want to elect the first provincial executive mayor. The ghost of Joe Chamberlain still haunts the council chamber.

Cynics assume that Mr Bore hopes for the job. He is too intelligent to assume that, with his council record, he can win the Labour nomination. His support for an executive mayor is more political than personal, for he believes that he or she "would give a direction to activity which a leader cannot provide". Sir Michael, the chief executive, makes the same point in a less metaphysical and more critical form. "The idea of electing a mayor scores highly if you want to run the council like a business. It scores badly if the council is to be democratic local government". Running the council like a business is an increasingly popular notion in Whitehall as well as in Birmingham.

Businesses are, at least theoretically, unpolitical institutions and critics of the executive mayor idea suspect that it is intended to take party politics out of local government. Birmingham may become the testing ground for the idea that a man or woman without an acknowledged ideology is more likely to meet a city's needs than councillors who are elected on the party ticket. The bookmakers' favourite to become Birmingham's first mayor is Carl Chinn, a lecturer in community history, star of local radio and once a bookmaker himself. He stood in the 1983 general election as an independent in order to draw attention to what he regarded as discrimination against the turf accountant's trade. Apart from a couple of years in the Social Democratic party he has no political experience. That, and his high profile, make him, on some people's calculation, the man most fitted to lead England's second city when the new municipal constitution is in place.

Behind closed doors

Birmingham has already embraced half of the white paper's local government reforms. Departmental committees (in which members of all parties participated) have been replaced by a "cabinet system", in which an executive runs the city. The new system has irritated Labour traditionalists and infuriated Liberals and Conservatives who feel excluded from city management. The government's enthusiasm for municipal cabinets is based on its determination to end the system in which decisions were "taken behind closed doors by political groups, or even by small groups of key people within the majority party". In Birmingham, cabinets have produced exactly that result.

In other councils, the cabinet includes members of all parties. Not in Birmingham. Other cities allow journalists to attend cabinet meetings. Birmingham does not. The logic of the "scrutiny committees", which examine the performance of each department, requires them to be chaired by opposition members. In Birmingham they come from the majority Labour group. Undisputed power does not seem to have enthused every Labour council for the municipal task. Anita Ward, the majority whip, is examining the practicality and legality of "fining" absentees from council meetings by reducing their annual honorariums.

That is a sad commentary on a system which too often focuses more on arguments about council perks than the great issues of municipal government. Birmingham voters are clearly dubious about the value of local government. If the councillors themselves have doubts about the point of attending the council meetings, the whole system is in danger of death by neglect - at least in the great once all powerful cities where what we think of as local government was born.

Birmingham Facts & figures

 Granted city status in 1889

 Population around 1,013,400

 Ethnic minorities form 21.5% of population with Pakistanis forming the largest single ethnic minority group (1991 census)

 In February, seasonally adjusted unemployment figure stood at 34,162

 Birmingham has biggest housing department in England and Wales, managing 88,000 council houses

 State education was pioneered in Birmingham in the 1850s and there are now three universities and more than 450 schools in the city

 Birmingham has the largest public lending library in Europe

 Of the 11 constituencies that serve Birmingham, 10 are held by Labour MPs and one by the Conservatives

Labour replaced competitive tendering with an obligation for councils to obtain "best value" - without always setting out the criteria against which best value is judged. The scheme is now to be extended by what are known as public service agreements. Birmingham is negotiating with the government to determine 12 specific targets. They range from improving primary school results to reducing the numbers of domestic burglaries. A successful PSA, combined with what is called a best performance plan, will earn the city an extra grant of something like £28m. It will also give Whitehall a new influence over Birmingham policy. But the council shows little sign of resenting or rejecting Whitehall's ever increasing authority. The solution it proposes to the escalating housing crisis is a negotiated deal with central government built on the promise to reduce the city's powers. Until the mid-seventies, Whitehall frantically encouraged council house building with lavish subsidies. Then the mood changed. Margaret Thatcher was not only against council house building, she was the enemy of "the council house culture". In the most socially significant decision of her premiership, she gave municipal tenants the "right to buy". Seventy five thousand Birmingham families took up the offer. The best properties were sold first and the worst were not sold at all. The council was left with the oldest and most dilapidated houses - and debts of £650m. Estimates of how much it will cost to rehabilitate the housing stock vary from £1bn to £4bn. This year Birmingham received £80m from the housing investment programme. Almost half will be used to subsidise private properties. "As things now stand," says Mr Bore, knowing that he is stating the obvious, "the situation gets worse not better". His remedy - the sale of the whole housing stock - may work. Tony Blair is as opposed to council tenancy as Margaret Thatcher once was. Birmingham hopes that the government will clear its housing debt as the price of ending municipal dependency. A year ago, after pressure from dissatisfied tenants, 3,000 properties on the Lea Bank estate were transferred to the ownership of an independent trust. Mr Bore plans to set up 12 more registered social landlords and divide the housing stock between them, assuming that tenant ballots endorse the change of ownership. The results of the polls are not in much doubt. The choice will lie between a pound a week rent increase linked to a programme of repair and renovation and a rent freeze which guarantees continued dilapidation. Seventy five per cent of tenants receive housing benefit. They can vote for a rent increase in the knowledge that it will be paid by the government. Birmingham's Labour left argues that the government should clear the debt and leave the houses in council ownership. Perhaps it should. But the only hope of the Treasury paying off the debt lies in the council abandoning its role as landlord. Mr Bore could reluctantly accept the end of municipal tenancy as inevitable. But he endorses the government's determination to move the ownership of low-cost, rented houses from corporations to independent trusts. He has "thought very carefully" about the merits of council tenancy and decided that it "does not produce a proper social mix". His socialist heresy does not end there. Mr Bore has come to the conclusion that Birmingham's direct labour department is, by its nature, uncompetitive. Sir Michael describes the soon-to-be privatised department as "always too big for an in-house operation" and "the victim of long-term poor management". That is only part of the story. Too often decisions have been taken in the interests of its employees rather than its customers - the people of Birmingham. Every estate echoes with unverifiable stories of petty fraud - repairs recorded as completed but not done. But the real problem is more fundamental. The public works department will lose £8.5m this year, and an estimated £14m next, because the council refused to accept the disciplines required for commercial survival. Right-to-buy legislation reduced Birmingham housing stock by almost half. So, to protect the direct labour workforce, the council increased its repair and maintenance programme to a level which was neither affordable nor sustainable. Then the government insisted that all local authority contracts should be won by competitive tender. The direct labour department bid for its traditional work at hugely optimistic prices. A private builder who made such errors would have gone out of business within a year. So would a privately owned care home that accepted the wage levels and conditions of service which the unions have negotiated with Birmingham council. Care assistants working for the social services department are paid double time and given a day's holiday in lieu if they work on Sunday. Staff who telephone in sick on Sunday morning receive the same compensation for "working" unsocial hours. The corporation cannot afford, but dare not abandon, such largesse. A private company will, the theory goes, reduce labour costs in ways no council could contemplate. In Birmingham, the civic ethic now embraces the disciplines of the market. The enterprise culture was imposed on schools when "local management" forced the education authorities to compete against private providers for the supply of everything from exercise books to accountancy. Prof Brighouse is gratified by how little advantage Birmingham's headteachers have taken of the new freedom. He ought not to be surprised. The revival in the city's education system is, at least in part, the product of his six years in the city. Prof Brighouse describes his job, crushed between David Blunkett's increasingly detailed demands and the growing autonomy of individual schools, as "looking down the wrong end of a telescope at a Swiss watch with a spanner in my hand" - which does not suggest enthusiasm for the new regime. Labouring under that disadvantage, he has transformed Birmingham's education. In his last major act as council leader, Sir Richard commissioned Ted Wragg of Exeter University to head an enquiry into "the present and future needs of education in Birmingham". It was a courageous decision. Sir Richard knew that the council's young Turks blamed him for a reduction in the education budget to £70m below the standard spending assessment, the government's estimate of what the city needed to invest in the future. The Wragg report's first recommendation was that "the council should give education top priority and appropriate standing". When the time came to appoint a new chief officer, Prof Brighouse seemed the right man to lead the renaissance. Education spending rose to £20m above the spending assessment. Improved examination results moved the city from virtually the bottom to a third of the way up the national league tables. No one is sure which has had the greater effect - money or Prof Brighouse's quirky but dynamic personality. Education, once the city's neglected service, now pioneers new methods of promoting literacy and numeracy - including the University of the First Age, which offers extra teaching for 11 to 15-year-olds in conditions they find congenial rather than constraining. More important, at a time when teachers feel underpaid and undervalued, Prof Brighouse has lifted staff-room morale. His open antagonism to Chris Woodhead, the hugely disliked former chief inspector of schools, helped. So did his successful libel action against John Patten (a brief, but greatly despised, secretary of state) and the decision to donate his damages to school improvements. But it was the way in which he spent his early weeks in the job that won his spurs. He visited schools and talked to teachers. Even within its modern limitation, local government works best when it fulfils its historic destiny to be personal and intimate. New civic gospel .Prof Brighouse has made "partnership" with the government work. It is a special use of the word since one of the partners dictates how the other will behave. A white paper, Modern Local Government, leaves no doubt which of the partners is in charge. "There is no future in the old model of councils trying to plan and run most services". Instead they will be required "to promote the economic, social and environmental wellbeing of their areas". Birmingham has grasped - perhaps it even anticipated - one element in that stern injunction and elevated it to a new civic gospel. The idea that the corporation should actively encourage commercial development came upon the council gradually and was accepted by some councillors reluctantly and by others not at all. Twenty-five years ago, in a contest which was more about prestige than prosperity, Birmingham beat London in the race to become home to the National Exhibition Centre. Its success was never in doubt. But, situated on the southern boundary, the NEC has not made much of a contribution to the city's economy. It was valued as a status symbol. At one meeting, where the triumph over London was discussed, the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra was offered as another example of provincial superiority. Everybody agreed that it needed a new concert hall. Nobody could think of a way to raise the money. Someone suggested an approach to the European Community. Initial enquiries suggested that, although the regional development fund would not invest in a concert hall, it might provide money for something bigger and better. The result was the International Convention Centre in which the development fund invested £49.7m. The chamber of commerce and the local CBI thought it could be built next to, or as an extension of, the Exhibition Centre. But the council wanted it in the city centre. While Birmingham was still negotiating with Brussels, the old Victorian concert hall - not half a mile from Chamberlain Square and the town hall - burned down. The city centre was transformed. Almost a third of the council registered the Labour group complaint that Sir Richard was wasting time and money which should have been devoted to education. The convention centre whetted the council's appetite for commercial development. Over 15 years the EU invested another £175m on tearing the city apart and putting it back together again, as well as more than £100m in social fund programmes for neighbourhood regeneration. The National Indoor Arena was built next to the ICC. The city took a third share in a Hyatt hotel which was thought necessary to accommodate the expected flood of visitors. Since then hotel building has become a Birmingham growth industry. Few pumps have ever been primed so successfully. Brindley Place and the associated restoration of the canal basin is now a civic showpiece of shops and offices. Seven thousand new jobs have been created in the area, as many as there will be at Rover's Longbridge factory in 2002. The city's commitment to urban regeneration came to practical life in the spring of 1988 at a meeting between representatives of national and local government, business and the various planning professions. It was held at Highbury, once the home of the Chamberlains - a venue which was either prophetic or paradoxical depending on whether the new policy is regarded as a continuation of or a break with Birmingham's municipal tradition. From then on all plans for city generation were called "Highbury". The stated purpose of Highbury was "to explore the relationship between economic activity and investment and the physical environment". The council undertook to create the physical conditions for commercial growth in the city centre. Whether all the participants realised it or not, the civic gospel was taking on an economic dimension. The results have been a spectacular success for local government as "facilitator" rather than provider. Three potential developers - Hammersons, Henderson's and Land Securities - competed with each other for planning permission to regenerate part of the old Bull Ring. The council persuaded them to come together in a partnership which will create 8,000 new jobs. The Alliance consortium, as it is now called, is part of the massive regeneration initiative in which the city council "brokers" partnerships between the private and public sectors. From the old GPO sorting office, which has become a vast shopping mall, to Fort Dunlop which now advertises "hotels, sports, eating, shops", Birmingham's economy is changing. The 200,000 jobs which were lost between 1975 and 1985 (more than in Scotland and Wales combined) are gradually being replaced as service industries take over from manufacturing. The council - or at least its leader - is changing to accommodate the new world. Mr Bore's enthusiasm is instinctive. He is a technocrat by profession and, despite his leftwing past, a tycoon by temperament. Ironically, the Liberal and Conservative council leaders are beginning - despite their business backgrounds - to express fears that too much municipal time and effort is being spent on the city centre at the rest of Birmingham's expense. The Labour group has never disguised its doubts. Last May, Mr Bore was re-elected leader by a majority of one vote. The nature of the challenge that all but unseated him was confirmed by the quality of the near successful pretender. No one thought that Kevin Stacey had more ability than Mr Bore - just that he was different. The dissatisfaction may be diminished by the publication of A New Partnership for Governance, a consultation paper on the future of local government in Birmingham which addresses old problems in new language. The determination "to tackle the deep seated problems of social exclusion" are an echo of Joe Chamberlain's belief that "an extension of the functions and authority" of Birmingham corporation would assist in "equalising the conditions of men". In common with the mood of the moment, Birmingham believes that "social exclusion is about much more than just material deprivation or lack of work and income". That is not a recently acquired opinion. Long before such theories were fashionable, Birmingham was forming neighbourhood councils to provide a forum for popular discussion and dissent. Two years ago, a democracy commission, under the chairmanship of Sir Adrian Cadbury, ex amined ways of ensuring "greater democratic participation" in the city's affairs. A New Partnership for Governance is the extension of the same objective. It invites comments on everything from the way in which the neighbourhood renewal fund - planned to spend £44m in Birmingham in the next three years - should best be used, to the desirability of "greater use of referendums in making local decisions". It refers, in passing, to the national government's plans for greater local democracy. Birmingham has never thought it necessary to accept anyone else's advice. Birmingham will soon have to decide if it is to be led by a directly elected executive mayor - one of several options which the Local Government Act requires it to consider. It could choose an elected council leader supported either by a cabinet or a council manager. Only a mayor will satisfy Birmingham's civic pride. England's second city will want to elect the first provincial executive mayor. The ghost of Joe Chamberlain still haunts the council chamber. Cynics assume that Mr Bore hopes for the job. He is too intelligent to assume that, with his council record, he can win the Labour nomination. His support for an executive mayor is more political than personal, for he believes that he or she "would give a direction to activity which a leader cannot provide". Sir Michael, the chief executive, makes the same point in a less metaphysical and more critical form. "The idea of electing a mayor scores highly if you want to run the council like a business. It scores badly if the council is to be democratic local government". Running the council like a business is an increasingly popular notion in Whitehall as well as in Birmingham. Businesses are, at least theoretically, unpolitical institutions and critics of the executive mayor idea suspect that it is intended to take party politics out of local government. Birmingham may become the testing ground for the idea that a man or woman without an acknowledged ideology is more likely to meet a city's needs than councillors who are elected on the party ticket. The bookmakers' favourite to become Birmingham's first mayor is Carl Chinn, a lecturer in community history, star of local radio and once a bookmaker himself. He stood in the 1983 general election as an independent in order to draw attention to what he regarded as discrimination against the turf accountant's trade. Apart from a couple of years in the Social Democratic party he has no political experience. That, and his high profile, make him, on some people's calculation, the man most fitted to lead England's second city when the new municipal constitution is in place. Behind closed doors Birmingham has already embraced half of the white paper's local government reforms. Departmental committees (in which members of all parties participated) have been replaced by a "cabinet system", in which an executive runs the city. The new system has irritated Labour traditionalists and infuriated Liberals and Conservatives who feel excluded from city management. The government's enthusiasm for municipal cabinets is based on its determination to end the system in which decisions were "taken behind closed doors by political groups, or even by small groups of key people within the majority party". In Birmingham, cabinets have produced exactly that result. In other councils, the cabinet includes members of all parties. Not in Birmingham. Other cities allow journalists to attend cabinet meetings. Birmingham does not. The logic of the "scrutiny committees", which examine the performance of each department, requires them to be chaired by opposition members. In Birmingham they come from the majority Labour group. Undisputed power does not seem to have enthused every Labour council for the municipal task. Anita Ward, the majority whip, is examining the practicality and legality of "fining" absentees from council meetings by reducing their annual honorariums. That is a sad commentary on a system which too often focuses more on arguments about council perks than the great issues of municipal government. Birmingham voters are clearly dubious about the value of local government. If the councillors themselves have doubts about the point of attending the council meetings, the whole system is in danger of death by neglect - at least in the great once all powerful cities where what we think of as local government was born. Birmingham Facts & figures  Granted city status in 1889  Population around 1,013,400  Ethnic minorities form 21.5% of population with Pakistanis forming the largest single ethnic minority group (1991 census)  In February, seasonally adjusted unemployment figure stood at 34,162  Birmingham has biggest housing department in England and Wales, managing 88,000 council houses  State education was pioneered in Birmingham in the 1850s and there are now three universities and more than 450 schools in the city  Birmingham has the largest public lending library in Europe  Of the 11 constituencies that serve Birmingham, 10 are held by Labour MPs and one by the Conservatives

fields.headline: Avoiding a US recession
fields.standfirst:
Europe should look to its own future

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The US Federal Reserve's 0.5% cut in interest rates to 5% has yet to reverse the sharp decline in US stock prices. But then it should never have been intended to, since US share prices are now 50% higher than they were in December 1996.
fields.body:
The US Federal Reserve's 0.5% cut in interest rates to 5% has yet to reverse the sharp decline in US stock prices. But then it should never have been intended to, since US share prices are now 50% higher than they were in December 1996, when Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Fed, warned that markets were suffering from "irrational exuberance". The aim of lower interest rates is to prevent the slowdown in the US economy from slithering into a crash landing that would reverberate around the world. So far an actual recession (defined as two successive quarters of negative economic growth) has been avoided. But for how much longer?

Two factors make this US slowdown different from previous ones. First it has been preceded by a massive drop in share values. Forget percentages: in the last year, according to Business Week, $4.6 trillion in stock market wealth has vanished since the market peaked. People are that much worse off in terms of how they value their assets. No wonder investors are starting to think about building up their depleted savings again (and therefore stopping spending). Second, it is almost unprecedented for a US recession not to be preceded by a sharp rise in inflation: too much money chasing too few goods. This time there is too little money chasing too many goods because companies have been forced to cut their inventories and slash capital investment. The hitherto blameless Mr Greenspan has been criticised for following market sentiment instead of leading it, because the financial markets wanted an even steeper cut in interest rates. But it is not his job to rescue punters who thought the boom in share prices would go on for ever. And - so far - the economy has not gone into free fall. Consumer spending is still rising, albeit at a far more modest pace than before, and 135,000 new jobs were generated last month, hardly the sign of terminal decline. The trouble is that sentiment is very fragile. It only needs consumers to cut their spending by 3% or 4% for the house of cards to come tumbling down. In these circumstances the Fed must be prepared for further rate cuts and the Bush administration may be justified in spending some of its inherited budget surplus.

In these circumstances Europe should err on the side of expansion to ensure that her economy is insulated from any potential US downturn. The trouble is that the ECB, Europe's central bank, is facing a scenario that eurosceptics have long warned about. The medicine needed for Germany (Europe's biggest economy) is different from what most of the other countries need. Economies like France, Italy, Ireland and Spain are powering ahead and do not necessarily require lower interest rates as a stimulus - but Germany, which is expanding at a lacklustre rate - clearly needs a cut. The ECB is almost certainly disposed to keep rates on hold because - unlike the Fed - its mandate is to contain inflation and not to promote growth as well. This would be a mistake because the risk to inflation in Europe is small compared with the need to promote sustained economic growth in Europe in the wake of the US slowdown. Europe's economy is surprisingly self-sufficient and has a current account surplus (in contrast to a whacking US deficit). It is also in the throes of a technological revival - particularly in the wireless sector - that needs nurturing if the continent is to have any chance of emulating the technology-driven spurt in US productivity growth. The ECB should look forward to growth and not backwards at inflation.

webTitle: Comment: Ted Heath and the Hindujas

fields.headline: Ted and the Hindujas
fields.standfirst:
As an inquiry into Labour's Keith Vaz recommences, Richard Norton-Taylor and David Leigh look at the Tory politician no one's talking about

Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: As an inquiry into Labour's Keith Vaz recommences,  Richard Norton-Taylor and  David Leigh look at the Tory politician no one's talking about.
fields.body:
In all the continuing Tory hue and cry over the passport-hungry Hinduja brothers and their relationship with Messrs Vaz and Mandelson of New Labour, remarkably little attention has been paid to the strange and unsavoury case of Sir Edward Heath.

Yet it was the veteran former Conservative prime minister who was the first truly prominent figure in Britain to lend his name to those controversial Indian businessmen - and there is a strong case to be made that his intervention was a big factor in the first of the two British passports they obtained.

What is also remarkable, and illuminating of the Hinduja technique, is that - as we have now discovered - Sir Edward failed to reveal he had got a series of cash political donations from the multimillionaire Hinduja brothers while making those representations on their behalf. Not only did he choose not to declare the money on the register of members interests. He also did not disclose the payments to ministers or civil servants in the Home Office.

Officials were therefore unaware that while he was backing one of the Hindujas as suitable for British citizenship, he was obtaining benefits from them. He got no personal cash and Sir Edward maintains that, as he interprets the Commons' disclosure regulations, he was not in breach of them. But the undisclosed - and apparently undocumented - payments from the London-based businessmen under investigation in India over bribery allegations will undoubtedly cast a shadow over the last few weeks of the 84-year-old former prime minister's run-up to retirement after more than 50 years as an MP.

He could have openly declared the cash at the time, had he chosen to. But Sir Edward now appears instead as someone manoeuvred by a pair of rich men with their own agenda.

It was a little-noticed passage of the Hammond report into the "Dome-cash-for-passports" affair which revealed that between 1993 and 1996 Sir Edward lobbied on the Hindujas' behalf. They had already been turned down by the Major government, partly because of their involvement in the Bofors bribery scandal investigations in India and their consequent lack of "good character".

Then, on March 3 1997, as the Bofors inquiry hotted up, Sir Edward gave his name as a referee on GP Hinduja's resubmitted application for citizenship along with a second referee - senior Tory party official Basil (now Lord) Feldman. The Hindujas had also reportedly donated generously to Conservative headquarters' election campaigns. In those days, such donations to Tory central funds could be kept secret.

Their rejected 1991 application had been backed by two much less influential figures - a former middleman between Britain and the Shah of Iran, Sir Shapur Reporter, and Sir Jay Gohel, chairman of the Anglo-Asian Conservative Association. But following Sir Edward's intervention in March 1997, Andrew Walmsley, director of the nationality division of the Home Office, recommended reversing the previous stance and giving British citizenship to GP Hinduja, saying interest in the Bofors scandal had "lessened". Labour ministers accepted his advice after they came to power at the May 1997 election.

Despite the existence of Bofors allegations dating from 1988, Sir Edward had accepted a role as a trustee of a Hinduja institute of Indian history. The Dharam Hinduja Institute of Indic Research was set up in England in 1995 and Sir Edward says his role there lasted until 1998.

That post was unpaid. However, the Hindujas made donations to his constituency office in Bexley. "I knew they sometimes made them [the payments]. There was no regular arrangement," Sir Edward says. The money was "for the normal running of the constituency". He accepts that it was he who suggested to the Hindujas that they direct their money to the constituency.

Uncertainty surrounds the quantity. In January Sir Edward's spokesman, after making checks, described it as "a couple of thousand" between 1994 and 1995. But this month that was described as an "error". The money was redefined as a "small donation of less than a thousand pounds". Sir Edward told us his constituency had not kept records.

Asked why the Hindujas wanted to give him donations, Sir Edward replied: "Presumably they admire what I do in public life."

Sir Edward says he never discussed the Bofors affair with the Hindujas. "It seemed to be an internal Indian war."

Commons' rules at the time required MPs to declare "any relevant interest" when they communicated with ministers or "servants of the Crown". They also required registration of gifts by overseas or UK individuals and of regular financial sponsorship of MPs' constituency offices. Sir Edward says he interpreted the rules as meaning that he was allowed not to disclose the payments, because there was no regular system of sponsorship and he did not personally benefit. "I haven't got a financial connection with them," he says.

Sir Edward's help to the Hindujas extended back to 1987, when he phoned the editor of the US Forbes magazine which was planning an exposé. Jim Michaels, Forbes' editor at the time, told BBC Panorama earlier this month: "He was very polite and almost diffident, I would say close to being embarrassed, but he just wanted to tell me that he had known these people and that they were splendid people."

The following April, the Hindu newspaper was preparing to publish documents implicating the Hindujas in the Bofors arms bribery scandal. According to an Indian journalist, NR Ram, a former associate editor of the paper, GP Hinduja boasted that he could ask Sir Edward to use his good offices to offer the journalist interviews with then American vice president, George Bush, and the Chinese prime minister, if he dropped the story. Ram told Panorama "It was as crude as that. Not an outright bribe but for a journalist that would be some kind of favour."

The success of the Hinduja technique with Heath was part of a pattern in which the former premier has taken money from sources which he has sometimes been reluctant to detail.

He was rebuked for keeping out of the Commons register for a time the details of his payments from a communist Chinese firm, a Saudi group, an Indian-owned company in Dubai and a German bank, rather than disclose the exact amounts he was getting. Sir Edward has spoken sympathetically about the Chinese regime. He has also taken fees of up to £35,000 a time to speak at conferences organised by the Moonies, a controversial religious cult.

All this perhaps puts yesterday's announcement of fresh inquiries into Keith Vaz's wife's company's cash from the Hindujas, into a broader context.
