Uncertainty surrounds the quantity. In January Sir Edward's spokesman, after making checks, described it as "a couple of thousand" between 1994 and 1995. But this month that was described as an "error". The money was redefined as a "small donation of less than a thousand pounds". Sir Edward told us his constituency had not kept records. Asked why the Hindujas wanted to give him donations, Sir Edward replied: "Presumably they admire what I do in public life." Sir Edward says he never discussed the Bofors affair with the Hindujas. "It seemed to be an internal Indian war." Commons' rules at the time required MPs to declare "any relevant interest" when they communicated with ministers or "servants of the Crown". They also required registration of gifts by overseas or UK individuals and of regular financial sponsorship of MPs' constituency offices. Sir Edward says he interpreted the rules as meaning that he was allowed not to disclose the payments, because there was no regular system of sponsorship and he did not personally benefit. "I haven't got a financial connection with them," he says. Sir Edward's help to the Hindujas extended back to 1987, when he phoned the editor of the US Forbes magazine which was planning an exposé. Jim Michaels, Forbes' editor at the time, told BBC Panorama earlier this month: "He was very polite and almost diffident, I would say close to being embarrassed, but he just wanted to tell me that he had known these people and that they were splendid people." The following April, the Hindu newspaper was preparing to publish documents implicating the Hindujas in the Bofors arms bribery scandal. According to an Indian journalist, NR Ram, a former associate editor of the paper, GP Hinduja boasted that he could ask Sir Edward to use his good offices to offer the journalist interviews with then American vice president, George Bush, and the Chinese prime minister, if he dropped the story. Ram told Panorama "It was as crude as that. Not an outright bribe but for a journalist that would be some kind of favour." The success of the Hinduja technique with Heath was part of a pattern in which the former premier has taken money from sources which he has sometimes been reluctant to detail. He was rebuked for keeping out of the Commons register for a time the details of his payments from a communist Chinese firm, a Saudi group, an Indian-owned company in Dubai and a German bank, rather than disclose the exact amounts he was getting. Sir Edward has spoken sympathetically about the Chinese regime. He has also taken fees of up to £35,000 a time to speak at conferences organised by the Moonies, a controversial religious cult. All this perhaps puts yesterday's announcement of fresh inquiries into Keith Vaz's wife's company's cash from the Hindujas, into a broader context.

webTitle: Watchdog rebukes Hague over trust cash inaccuracy

fields.headline: Watchdog rebukes Hague over trust cash inaccuracy
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague was rebuked yesterday by a cross-party committee of MPs for making a formal declaration that he distributed profits from public speaking engagements to a charitable trust which was never established in law.
fields.body:
William Hague was rebuked yesterday by a cross-party committee of MPs for making a formal declaration that he distributed profits from public speaking engagements to a charitable trust which was never established in law.

In an embarrassing blow, the Commons committee on standards and privileges endorsed a report by the parliamentary standards watchdog which criticised the Conservative leader for failing to correct a "materially inaccurate" entry in the register of MPs' interests.

Conservative central office refused to comment on the report yesterday which was prompted by a Channel 4 investigation into Mr Hague's claim, in the register of MPs' interests in 1999 and 2000, that all fees from speaking engagements were to be paid into his trust.

The investigation, by the Mark Thomas Product programme, found that no money was paid into the William Hague Charitable Trust which was meant to distribute funds in the Tory leader's Richmond constituency.

Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner, stated in her report: "Mr Hague failed to respond correctly on eight occasions when required to check his entry, with the result that it continued in a materially inaccurate form for a considerable period - at least six months and arguably longer."

The committee's findings against Mr Hague, who has led the Tory charge in recent weeks against the Europe minister Keith Vaz, is the second time that the Tory leader has been reprimanded. In 1999 he failed to register the benefit of using Lord Archer's private gym.

Fraser Kemp, Labour MP for Houghton and Washington East, who formally lodged a complaint against Mr Hague, called on the Tory leader to apologise to the Commons.

The reprimand from the parliamentary watchdog, which will be an uncomfortable jolt to Mr Hague weeks before the election, highlights a mistake on his part rather than a deliberate attempt to hide payments.

"It should be emphasised that there is no evidence of any intention on Mr Hague's part deliberately to mislead the house and the public," Ms Filkin said.

The commissioner concluded that the trust was never formally established in law because of legal difficulties. Seven cheques, totalling £1,750, made out to the trust, were never cashed.

However, her report highlights a lack of organisation in Mr Hague's office and raises questions about the judgment of his private secretary, Lord Coe, who recommended that the Tory leader should establish the trust.

Ms Filkin said that Mr Hague's staff ignored two requests from the Tory leader to amend his entry in the MPs' register.

webTitle: Labour insider wins safe seat nomination

fields.headline: Door knocking in home town wins Labour insider seat nomination
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: A New Labour insider who took three months' unpaid leave to court Labour activists in the rock-solid constituency where he grew up has won the party's nomination without help from Downing Street or the Millbank machine.
fields.body:
A New Labour insider who took three months' unpaid leave to court Labour activists in the rock-solid constituency where he grew up has won the party's nomination without help from Downing Street or the Millbank machine.

Andy Burnham, 32-year-old special adviser to the culture secretary, Chris Smith, beat a union-backed challenger, Ian Wingfield, by a decisive 128 votes to 46 in Leigh, Lancashire, as rumours swirled around Westminster that Tony Blair was poised to "parachute" favoured supporters into safe seats at the last minute before the election.

Several Labour MPs are said to be prepared to step down to make way for candidates backed by Downing Street or party HQ in Millbank - in return for the prospect of knighthoods, peerages and jobs on quangos.

Regional Labour officials insisted that the Leigh party should broaden its original shortlist from four to six to include Mr Burnham and Jenny Smith, a union official. But last night Mr Burnham insisted he had been neither helped nor hindered by Millbank.

"My legitimacy has always been with the members and the fact that I am local. Working the doorstep [in the constituency] paid off in the end," he said after a Tuesday night meeting where all six contenders faced questions.

As the expected May 3 election looms, a number of seats are falling vacant at the last minute, when pressure of time allows Labour's national executive committee to impose shortlists in consultation with local activists

MPs are divided about the leadership's ability to parachute in a favoured candidate in an era when selection is done by a one member one vote ballot.

Mr Blair is believed to be particularly anxious to find a seat for the Tory defector, Shaun Woodward.

Current rumour focuses on the Welsh seat of Ogmore, where Sir Ray Powell, the local MP, is 72.

In Durham North, Kevin Jones, an organiser for the GMB union, had the nomination sewn up so well that aspiring Blair aides quickly melted away.

Robin Corbett's Birmingham Erdington seat has attracted the interest of Mr Blair's economics adviser, Derek Scott, T&G union official, Karen Livingstone, and the New Labour journalist Sion Simon.

But they will face strong competition from local candidates, Brian Seymour-Smith and Ray Woods.

webTitle: Unexplained figures in Vaz's political life

fields.headline: Unexplained figures in Vaz's political life
fields.standfirst:
New inquiry likely to focus on family company and minister's alleged close relationship with Hindujas

Special report: election countdown
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: New inquiry likely to focus on family company and minister's alleged close relationship with Hindujas.
fields.body:
The minister for Europe, Keith Vaz, has thus far technically escaped unscathed in the political heat over his relationship with the Hinduja brothers. But his links to them and their eponymous charitable foundation could yet reveal the smoking gun so desired by his Tory harriers as the parliamentary standards commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, announced a renewal of her inquiries into his affairs.

Ms Filkin's terrier instincts are certain to lead her to insist on a thorough inquiry into this connection - particularly as she was thwarted by the minister's lawyer, Geoffrey Bindman, from completing her investigation into this aspect of Mr Vaz's affairs in her last inquiry.

At the centre of the new investigation will be Mapesbury Communications, a company registered at Mr Vaz's home address with his wife, Maria Fernandes, as its sole shareholder and his mother, Merlyn, as a director.

Mr Vaz told Ms Filkin during the last inquiry that he now knew nothing about the company. He told her predecessor, Sir Gordon Downey, that it had been set up to provide funds for his parliamentary office. He explained to Ms Filkin that his wife and mother had changed the role of the company and it had nothing to do with him.

He also told her that he had never received any donations from the Hinduja brothers - and both the committee and the comissioner believed him.

But when his wife did send the company accounts and they were examined by Robert Sheldon, the chairman of the standards and privileges select committee, it was revealed that Mapesbury had received £1,196.10 from the Hinduja Foundation to organise a parliamentary reception. This, in 1995, was one year after the company was set up.

The foundation's accounts also show that the money was paid.

Accounts at Companies House describe Mapesbury's principal activities as publishing and public relations. In 1995, it had turnover of £3,200; in 1996, turnover had risen to £14,647; but in 1997, general election year, turnover was zero. In 1998, it soared to £73,764. In 1999, the last year reported to Companies House, turnover was £51,428.

Mr Vaz has never declared Mapesbury in the register of members' interests, claiming the company has only ever been used by his wife.

He said last night that he had checked with the registrar of members and Sir Gordon Downey and had been advised that he did not need to list the company on the members' register of interests.

He added: "I have never received any benefits or payments from Mapesbury."

In her inquiry, Ms Filkin questioned Mr Vaz about Mapesbury in connection with the provision of calendars to his office - part of a donation from Sarosh Zaiwalla, the City lawyer, whom Mr Vaz recommended for an honour. Her conclusion on Mr Vaz's refusal to cooperate over this was pointed. "Mr Vaz has not, despite my repeated requests, provided me with any information to enable me to establish the precise sources of the company's income or where it goes to [and, in particular, whether Mr Vaz's office derives, or has derived, any benefit from it]."

Ms Filkin concluded: "I remain of the view that Mr Vaz could, and should, have been more candid and forthcoming in answering my questions about Mapesbury Communications. This is a company originally established by him with the express purpose of receiving his non-parliamentary income and for using the proceeds to support his office."

Mr Vaz is also known to have had more than a passing acquaintance with the Hindujas. He made inquiries of behalf on both of SP and GP Hinduja on the progress of their passport applications - but was cleared of any undue influence by the recent Hammond inquiry.

The Hinduja brothers were particularly adept at writing detailed and sophisticated letters to lobby ministers over issues and were persistent in getting support for their charitable foundation.

The government is still behind the minister. Tony Blair last night signalled his determination to stand by Mr Vaz against what Downing Street regards as a witch hunt by Tory MPs and the media. "It's one allegation and investigation after another and our sense is that these people are just moving to the next one," the prime minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, told reporters.

But this investigation leaves Mr Vaz fighting an expected election on May 3 with still many questions unaswered about his conduct.

fields.headline: Robinson, Vaz face new inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was last night facing fresh pre-election embarrassment as Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner, re-opened her investigation into the financial affairs of the Europe minister, Keith Vaz. She also announced inquiries into whether the former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson, had misled parliament.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was last night facing fresh pre-election embarrassment as Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner, re-opened her investigation into the financial affairs of the Europe minister, Keith Vaz. She also announced inquiries into whether the former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson, had misled parliament.

The double blow to Tony Blair came after Ms Filkin said she would investigate complaints from Tory frontbench spokesmen that both the minister and the ex-minister had hidden facts from MPs.

Andrew Lansley, the shadow minister for the Cabinet Office, has complained that Mr Vaz had not disclosed that the Indian businessmen the Hinduja brothers had given £1,200 to Mapesbury Communications, a company run by the minister's wife, Maria Fernandes.

The money is said to have been for a parliamentary reception. Mr Vaz had denied he had received any money from the Hindujas and last night was insisting that he had made no personal gain from the money.

Mr Robinson is facing inquiries into whether he misled the former standards commissioner, Sir Gordon Downey, over a £200,000 payment which it is alleged he solicited from discredited Labour tycoon Robert Maxwell. At the time, Mr Robinson denied any record of the payment - which he said was recorded in his now bankrupt company, Hollis Industries, by mistake.

The complaint lodged by David Heathcoat-Amory, shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, followed disclosures in the Daily Mail on Monday that an invoice for £200,000 marked paid to Mr Robinson had been discovered by inspectors appointed by the Department of Trade and Industry to investigate the affair. The newspaper alleged that the report had been kept secret by the trade secretary, Stephen Byers.

The fresh inquiry into Mr Vaz comes only a week after the minister was cleared of all but one allegation - that he recommended a lawyer friend, Sarosh Zaiwalla, for an honour without disclosing that his office had received two small donations from him - by the Commons standards and privileges committee.

The committee report, however, caused a furore after it was revealed that Ms Filkin had been unable to complete her inquiries into eight allegations after the MP's lawyer, Geoffrey Bindman, refused to answer her questions. One of her unresolved areas was an investigation into Mapesbury Communications where Mr and Mrs Vaz refused to provide full details of the firm's finances.

Tony Blair last night dismissed calls to sack Mr Vaz and attacked the Tories for making fresh allegations against him."He has my support," the prime minister said.

Mr Blair added: "I am not going to dismiss a minister when the allegations that the opposition make against him are investigated and found to be wrong."

Mr Blair plans to demonstrate his confidence in the minister for Europe by taking him to this weekend's EU summit in Stockholm.

Labour MPs are divided over Mr Vaz's conduct. A number expect Mr Blair to quietly drop him after the election.

In a fresh statementlast night, Mr Vaz said he was "surprised" that the Conservatives had chosen to take up the issue of Mapesbury Communications - which was his wife's company - with Ms Filkin.

He said the evidence to the standards and privileges committee showed he had checked with both the registrar of members and the then standards commissioner, Sir Gordon, whether he should register the company.

"They confirmed that this was not necessary. I have never received any benefits or payments from Mapesbury," he said.

Meanwhile, letters from lawyers acting for Mr Byers and Mr Robinson have stopped WH Smith distributing copies of a book by the investigative journalist Tom Bower about the former paymaster general upon which the Mail's allegations were based.

webTitle: Lords urge legal use of cannabis

fields.headline: Lords urge legal use of cannabis
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Progress towards a cannabis-based medicine for conditions it can allegedly help, such as multiple sclerosis, is too slow, a House of Lords committee said yesterday.
fields.body:
Progress towards a cannabis-based medicine for conditions it can allegedly help, such as multiple sclerosis, is too slow, a House of Lords committee said yesterday.

It urged the government to change the law so doctors can legally prescribe cannabis derivatives as soon as they are scientifically approved.

The Lords select committee on science and technology has re-entered the fray after receiving the brush-off from the government in November 1998, when it recommended that doctors should be allowed to prescribe cannabis derivatives; a finding the government rejected.

Yesterday the committee published a ten-page report on the progress towards producing a legitimate medicine from the drug.

The Medical Research Council has commissioned two trials from scientists to establish the principle that cannabis derivatives can help relieve pain. However, the committee is concerned that it may take a long time for anything practical to emerge from trials.

The committee is more encouraged by the progress being made by the GW Pharmaceuticals, which is about to embark onthe large-scale trials of cannabis-based treatments.

The report says the government's attitude lately has been more encouraging, following a period in which it feared that "permitting therapeutic preparations of cannabis to be prescribed would be interpreted by the public as a move towards allowing recreational use".

Lord Perry of Walton, a committee member, said yesterday that he hoped there might be a cannabis-derived medicine on the market within two years.

However, he was alarmed by a decision by the licensing body, the Medicines Control Agency, that past evidence on the toxicity of the cannabis derivative cannabidiol was not good enough. Additional testing could slow development of a licensed medicine by two to three years.

fields.headline: Scotland the brave
fields.standfirst:
Scottish Conservatives and Liberal Democrats have both gained from devolution, but Labour still holds the reins of power

Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Scottish Conservatives and Liberal Democrats have both gained from devolution, but Labour still holds the reins of power.
fields.body:
Scotland is increasingly becoming another country, at least in terms of public policy, with free higher and further education, its teachers awarded a 23% rise over three years and free care for the elderly. Political cycles are also different. A UK general election is imminent while the Scottish parliament is about to celebrate its second anniversary - mid-term of its first four years.

We live in an age of multi-layered governance. Scotland now has four levels: local, the Edinburgh parliament sitting at Holyrood, Westminster and Europe. Two, the parliament and the European parliament, are elected by proportional systems: the "additional member system" and a "closed list" respectively. Local authorities and the Commons are elected first past the post.

Outside local government Scotland has 209 national representatives. Labour has more seats than votes. At the 1997 election, it won 45.6% of the Scottish vote but returned 56 out of 72 MPs, 77.8% of seats. This has all kinds of implications. It allows Scottish Labour to think and talk in a majoritarian voice and making Scottish Labour essential to the unionist politics of UK Labour. In 1964 and 1974 Labour's majority depended on Scotland; it might again.

This new, expanded political class consists of 209 slots filled by 196 individuals, 13 of whom have "dual mandates" between Holyrood and Westminster. A popular perception about those elected to the Scottish parliament is that they are younger and from more diverse backgrounds than Westminster members, but this is not true. There are more women at Holyrood: 48 versus 12 at Westminster and Holyrood is less Labour, due to PR. But otherwise they are remarkably similar. Average age of both is mid to late 40s and both have a high intake of ex-councillors and public sector backgrounds.

All Scotland's political institutions draw from the same pool of people prepared to stand for national office and set themselves apart from the rest of us. And yet a sense of difference about Holyrood continues and it cannot just be explained by the high number of women. It may have to do with the culture of the new parliament with its less adversarial style; another reason is the decline on the Labour benches of a manual, male working-class tradition and the rise of a public sector professional class.

Scottish Conservatives and Liberal Democrats have both gained from devolution. Tories gained some parliamentary representation after the 1997 Commons' wipe-out; the Lib Dems have won influence and a share in government. The two "micro" parties, the Scottish Socialists and Scottish Greens, have both prospered; it is no accident that these are Scotland-only organisations and fully autonomous.

Labour has to contend with the possibility of PR for local government and the selling off of council houses, bringing about the end of labourist Scotland. It has to develop a pro-active agenda in the Scottish executive, something to which the styles of the late first minister Donald Dewar and his successor Henry McLeish have been ill-suited. It has to learn a new language of governing, which acknowledges the realities of coalition. The problem here is less Tony Blair than Labour's successful chancellor, Gordon Brown, and his very Westminster view of devolution. The Scottish question for Labour is not about Tony but whether Gordon can let Scotland go its own way.

The Scottish Nationalists face issues as difficult. In a 70-year existence they have never actually won a national election in Scotland. The SNP has undoubtedly matured as a political force in the first two years of devolution, but still has no strategy for winning power, let alone independence. In many respects the Nats are still a traditional social democratic party. In opposition, they support every demand for extra public spending irrespective of the executive's generosity. This is not a politics of preparing for government; instead they court interest groups.

The other issue for the SNP is the national question. What might independence mean in an age when the European Union is more influential but when there is nervousness about multiple identities (particularly Britishness)? Alex Salmond was a sort of Kinnock figure as leader in terms of the changes he brought about. His successor John Swinney, is a safe, bank manager figure and under him there is little real indication that the party is ready to make tough choices.

Where does this all leave the "new Scotland"? Struggling to find a voice. Scottish politics historically featured a less questioning attitude to authority. A paradox of devolution so far has been an increase in the institutionally top-heavy nature of Scottish public life. Indeed, devolution has been very good for the Labour quangocrats and "civic society professionals" who position themselves as champions of the people as new bodies and task forces have been set up.

We should not be surprised by this. Scottish post-war politics, for all the myths of Red Clydeside, has been remarkably top-down, with few citizen-led initiatives. The dream of Scottish self-government was always meant to be about more than getting another layer of time-serving politicians, but about remaking politics and society. Two years on, the Scottish parliament has proved that it can speak with a different voice; it is time for it to let Scotland breathe and speak a little more.

webTitle: UK under pressure over foot and mouth tactics

fields.headline: UK under pressure over foot and mouth tactics
fields.standfirst:
UK under pressure over foot and mouth tactics

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The government's strategy for combatting the foot and mouth outbreak will come under renewed scrutiny today after a decision by the Dutch authorities to vaccinate thousands of animals to prevent the disease spreading in the Netherlands.
fields.body:
The government's strategy for combatting the foot and mouth outbreak will come under renewed scrutiny today after a decision by the Dutch authorities to vaccinate thousands of animals to prevent the disease spreading in the Netherlands.

The vaccination policy, authorised by farm minister Laurens-Jan Brinkhorst, has so far been rejected by Britain and the rest of the EU.

An emergency meeting of the EU's veterinary committee has been called for tomorrow to discuss the crisis.

Around 17,000 animals in a one kilometre ring immediately round the Dutch outbreaks in the villages of Olst and Oene in the east of the country and at Oosterwolde 15 miles away will be slaughtered, but in a further zone all animals will be vaccinated to control the spread of the disease.

Once all disease has been eradicated, all vaccinated animals will be killed and removed "in an orderly fashion", the Dutch government said.

Pressure to adopt similar tactics has come from senior British vets who believe the slaughter policy will not stop the spread of the disease.

The government, which has not explicitly ruled out vaccination, believes it would prolong the time for which Britain could not export animals because of the loss of the country's disease-free status.

The extent of the crisis in Britain was revealed by the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, yesterday.

He said there was no longer any market for the millions of lambs being born, leaving thousands of farmers facing destitution. The export market for lambs is worth £78m a year.

The knock-on effect of the crisis on tourism and rural businesses had forecasters warning yesterday that it could help to knock 0.7 percentage points off economic growth this year.

The Centre for Economics and Business Research (CEBR), a consultancy firm, said that along with the stockmarket crash, foot and mouth would help to reduce growth this year to 2%, after last year's 3% expansion. The government has already paid out £70m to farmers for compulsorily slaughtered animals and the bill for those being killed now will be another £300m.

The number of cases rose to 430 with 36 new cases reported yesterday, 21 of them in Cumbria. The number of animals to be destroyed passed 420,000 - the same number in four weeks of this outbreak that had to be destroyed in six months of the 1967 epidemic.

Giving evidence to the Commons agriculture select committee, Mr Brown said the whole subsidy system based on numbers of sheep on farms would have to go.

Two thirds of trade was overseas so farmers' income would have to be supported while the trade was reorganised. An early retirement scheme for farmers would be offered.

"Because of the sheep breeding cycle we are in for a very long haul before farmers have anything to sell next year," Mr Brown said.

But while farming and the tourism industry are suffering, consumers could see an unexpected side benefit in the form of lower borrowing costs.

The CEBR said it believed that the Bank of England would be forced to shave 0.75 percentage points off borrowing costs, taking rates down to 5%, in order to offset the economic slowdown.

In the Commons, Tony Blair said he would push on with local elections - and by implication a general election - on May 3.

Challenged by William Hague at question time, Mr Blair said that cancelling local elections would send out a signal that Britain was "closed for business", which would have damaging consequences for the tourist industry, already badly hit by the crisis.

"I simply ask: postpone until when?", Mr Blair told Mr Hague. "One month, two months, six months? In 1967 this disease went on for eight months."

fields.headline: MPs rubbish waste strategy
fields.standfirst: Meacher hit by accusation of woeful inadequacy
fields.trailText: A damning indictment of the government's "unimaginative and uninspiring" waste strategy was made by an all-party committee of MPs yesterday.
fields.body:
A damning indictment of the government's "unimaginative and uninspiring" waste strategy was made by an all-party committee of MPs yesterday.

The report criticises Whitehall for paying only lip service to a "woefully inadequate" policy of buying recycled products and using recycled paper.

It also warns that unless ministers organise more effectively, large scale incineration could be introduced in the UK through the back door.

The environment sub-committee's criticism is a blow to the environment minister, Michael Meacher, who won a battle with the Treasury to force councils to recycle 25% of all rubbish by 2005 and 33% by 2015. MPs are completely unimpressed by his efforts - saying that councils should aim for 60% as already achieved in parts of Belgium, or 45% as in Austria.

The report warns: "Sorting out waste continues to be a low priority for this government and the Waste Strategy 2000 underlines the truth.

"Although the Waste Strategy 2000 does set in train some improvements, it is woefully inadequate to bring about the step change required in the way we think and deal about waste. Minimisation should be at the heart of the strategy but is paid only lip service. Quite simply, the strategy is an awkward and underfunded compromise when this area is crying out for leadership and ambition from the government.

"We made clear what the government needed to do in our 1998 report but they appear to have passed over the more difficult decisions, failed to provide clarity in other areas and simply left gaps elsewhere."

The report is severely critical of the move towards incineration - warning against letting unfair subsidies and help from the government's private finance initiative fund, huge new incinerators by the "back door". It says that the government is leaving the door open to a big expansion of large scale incineration of household waste. The report also says a new incineration tax - starting at £12 a tonne and rising to £25 a tonne - should be introduced on all waste sent to be burned.

The report reserves some of its severest criticism for the existing £12 a tonne landfill tax and the "convoluted and ineffective" landfill tax credit scheme investigated by the Guardian last year. The committee had received two large dossiers from the newspaper - which are reproduced on the paper's website - as part of its evidence.

It says landfill tax should rise to £25 a tonne by 2006 and calls for a radical review of the landfill tax credit scheme and the replacement of the private regulator, Entrust, which monitors the scheme.

The scheme - which involves the redistribution to environmental bodies of some £350m donated by waste operators in lieu of tax - was found by the Guardian to have been dominated by the waste industry.

The MPs call for the government to ban waste operators for having any say where the money goes and for far more cash to be redirected to schemes minimising, re-using and recycling waste.

The report quotes the Guardian directly in recommending that the private regulatory body, Entrust, which is dominated by people from the waste industry, should be scrapped and replaced with a new public body.

Next week the chief executive of Entrust, Richard Sills, is being summoned to appear before MPs for contempt. He is alleged to have interfered with a witness giving evidence to MPs about the internal workings of the body.

fields.headline: Judge lays into 'undermining of judiciary'
fields.standfirst: Politicians accused of sending law in wrong direction
fields.trailText: The second most senior judge at the Old Bailey bowed out yesterday with a diatribe against the government and opposition for turning the criminal justice system into a "political football".
fields.body:
The second most senior judge at the Old Bailey bowed out yesterday with a diatribe against the government and opposition for turning the criminal justice system into a "political football".

Judge Neil Denison, the common sergeant, used his valedictory speech to attack political correctness, which he said eroded freedom of speech and open discussion, and lambasted the government for a barrage of legislation which took away judges' discretion and independence.

The 72-year-old judge let loose in the famous court number one, packed with judges, barristers, clerks and court staff, as he prepared to retire from the bench after 40 years in the criminal law.

"It is time for me to hang up the strange object which sits upon my follicularly-challenged head, which I call my wig, because I do not like the direction in which the criminal justice system seems to be heading in this country," he said.

Although his words suggested he was retiring early, the Lord Chancellor's department said he was going at the normal retirement age.

Judge Denison extended his attack to Lord Irvine's department, criticising its expansion at a time of cutbacks in the courts.

When he attempted to peer into the future, he said: "I do not like much of what I see. I see a court service with ever increasing layers of administration; a head office in the shape of the Lord Chancellor's department which is constantly expanding with whole sections whose only raison d'etre is the collation and distribution of statistics to other sections."

There was, he said, a "positive plethora of glossy magazines being produced at heaven knows what expense. All this at a time where the real place of work - the courts - is subjected to continued and accumulative cuts".

Judge Denison said there was a shortage of court clerks and ushers.

Security at the Old Bailey had also been reduced, although it was recently stepped up again after a defendant leapt from the dock and punched Judge Ann Goddard in the face. "Any savings are more than offset by the loss in court time."

Judge Denison said he saw the bar itself being put under pressure with fees being cut. "The system of silk (appointing Queen's Counsel) is being attacked on the totally spurious ground that it is elitist to honour leading members of the profession."

The judge said he could foresee Britain heading down the American road, with more prosecutors being salaried and the establishment of a public defender's office. "Any reputable American lawyer would say it's a road which should be avoided."

He saw the criminal justice system being treated by both government and opposition as a political football with new criminal justice acts becoming an annual event.

Each had a more complicated system of sentencing which restricted the discretion and therefore the independence of judges.

"Over all this hangs the cloud of political correctness. In some of its more lunatic aspects it is merely ridiculous.

"But behind it, there seems to me to be something sinister, which is shown by the effect that already there are certain areas and topics where freedom of speech in the sense of allowing for open and frank discussion is being significantly eroded."

He added: "So I think it is time to go before I am labelled a dinosaur."

Judge Denison was called to the bar in 1952, became a QC in 1980, and was appointed a judge five years later. He became common serjeant, the Old Bailey's second senior permanent judge, in 1993.

 A fast track extradition deal with Spain was signed yesterday by the home secretary, Jack Straw. The agreement could mean that criminals wanted in Britain who are hiding in Spain could be brought back within three weeks. Among the 36 extradition requests that Britain has currently lodged with Madrid are applications for the return of a murderer, drug dealers, and also alleged terrorists.

webTitle: G2: Sir Edward Heath meets Tony Benn

fields.headline: When Ted met Tony
fields.standfirst:
Politically, they have little in common: a former Tory prime minister and a left-leaning ex-cabinet minister of the Labour party. But Sir Edward Heath and Tony Benn share half a century of service in parliament and, come the next election, both will stand down. Michael White brings them together to discuss the end of an era that stretches from Hitler and Churchill, through Nixon and Kissinger, to Hague and Blair

Hear audio clips from the discussion

But Sir Edward Heath and Tony Benn share half a century of service in parliament and, come the next election, both will stand down. Michael White brings them together to discuss the end of an era that stretches from Hitler and Churchill, through Nixon and Kissinger, to Hague and Blair.
fields.body:
Sharp at four on a sunny winter's afternoon, the Guardian turns up with Tony Benn on the doorstep of Sir Edward Heath's London home, a terraced Belgravia house within sight of the garden wall of Buckingham Palace. It may seem an unlikely meeting, but the two have shared the past half-century in parliament. And when the coming election is called, both will retire from the Commons. Neither will go to the Lords.

Heath, the former Conservative prime minister (1970-74) and bete noire of the Tory right, was first elected for Bexley - now Old Bexley and Sidcup - in the general election of February 23 1950. Unlike Benn, he has unbroken service. The Labour ex-cabinet minister (1964-70 and 1974-79) reached the Commons via a byelection in Bristol South East a few months later, but briefly lost his seat twice.

Though Heath, at 84, is the elder by nine years and has always been the more senior politician, their paths have crossed many times during careers of great influence on our times. My plan is to explore the changes they have seen in the past 50 years.

Both veterans have just come from the now-weekly session of prime minister's question time. "My God, it is awful now, isn't it," says Heath, by way of an opener. "I'm afraid I dozed off," confesses Benn. "I've done it once or twice now. I can't bear it."

They agree about much of what is wrong: they both dislike the replacement of 15-minute sessions on Tuesdays and Thursdays with Blair's single 30 minutes on Wednesdays, just as they disliked the move in the 60s from specific questions to general ones designed to trip up the PM rather than elicit a detailed answer.

As to how to remedy the problem - or others we discuss - there is rather less agreement, though outright disagreement is politely avoided. It is just possible to imagine that the former Viscount Stansgate regards the former Mr Heath as a technocrat at heart, not very interested in the democratic questions that preoccupy him; and that, in return, Benn is regarded as a bit of a gadfly.

But it is all very polite, a bit like watching the great theatrical knights in old age - Olivier, Gielgud or Richardson - circling each other's eminence on the stage, warily but not unkindly. The unspoken eloquence of their pauses is worthy of Pinter himself.

They agree that 1956 was a turning point in postwar history, chiefly because the US thwarted the secret Anglo-French plan to recapture the newly nationalised Suez Canal by invading Egypt in collusion with Israel. As chief whip, Heath was one of just four British ministers in the know.

By 1956, Winston Churchill, who liked Heath enough to give him two of his own paintings (they hang on the wall of his other home in Salisbury), had finally retired as prime minister at 80. Anthony Eden, his dashing, doomed successor, wanted to make his mark. "Some of us understood it beforehand and always believed he [Eden] was wrong in what he was doing," says Heath. "I told him so privately; never discussed it publicly. But he didn't share that view, so they carried on. By the end of it [when US pressure on sterling forced a withdrawal from the canal after six days] Macmillan [then chancellor] certainly realised it meant the end of that period. That is why he supported our entry into Europe in 1961."

He does not have time to add that President De Gaulle of France vetoed his own efforts to negotiate British entry into the then four-year-old European common market, and that he only got us in when he was prime minister 12 years later. Benn intervenes: "Because he [Macmillan] saw the Americans let us down. I went to see Walter Monckton [minister of labour] privately at the time of Suez to see if he could head it off. Collusion was the thing, the deal between the French and British; it was the first time since the war or subsequently when the American president simply vetoed a British manoeuvre."

As ever, Benn is making contemporary political points. He points out that in the 60s Harold Wilson, the Labour prime minister, had refused US appeals to send a token British force to fight in Vietnam. "But otherwise, am I wrong in saying all British governments since 1945 have done what the Americans wanted ?"

"I wouldn't go that far," replies Heath, who rarely goes as far as Benn. "On Vietnam I wouldn't play with them either. I didn't play with Kissinger over India [the 1971 war with Pakistan], where he wanted us to go in. And I didn't play when he wanted to go into Cyprus, when he wanted to go in with the Israeli [Yom Kippur] war."

In its efforts to re-equip the Israeli armed forces, the US was forced to fly supplies in via the Azores: retaliation for the Suez affair, one might be tempted to murmur. Heath does not. He is busy recalling the speech he made at President Richard Nixon's side on the White House lawn at that time. "My remark was that there is no special relationship between Britain and the United States. What there was, was an historic relationship that was much stronger. A special relationship you can break up at any time if you reach a stage of disagreement. An historic relationship is there all the time."

Again, the reproach to less perceptive successors hangs in the air, unstated. Benn is less reticent. "We do not have an independent [nuclear] deterrent," he interjects. "Americans lend us Trident, the United States controls our intelligence. If we were to go against American policy we would be seen to be a non-nuclear power. If we are locked into star wars [President Bush's missile defence plan] against the opposition of most of the countries of Europe, this is going to test the nuclear relationship to the full."

These questions have a habit of coming full circle. Benn, who addresses his old rival as Ted (a gesture that is not reciprocated), remembers daring to ask Churchill a question about nuclear relations with the US in the early 50s and being ticked off by Clem Attlee, the former prime minister. "You shouldn't have asked that question, because I'm the only one who knows anything about it," the party leader told him.

"But that was real. Something else is happening which is more fundamental than the points Ted is mentioning. Modern politics is about the marketing of personalities. We are invited to be spectators of what the great and the good do. I think that has infected the house," says Benn. "I agree with Ted, PM's questions are awful. It could easily be stopped if the prime minister, when he got to a question from the leader of the opposition, said, 'That's an interesting point. I will have a look.' The whole thing would collapse."

It is not that they are against progress. They both think the modern select committee system is an important development and are glad that MPs are better paid (until the 60s they paid for their own stamps) and have staff and offices in which to work - although it diminishes the collegiate atmosphere, the time MPs used to spend together simply talking. One problem, says Heath, is that MPs come in expecting to be ministers within three years. His old patron, Harold Macmillan (PM from 1957 to 1963) waited 17 years before he got a job, he says. But you were made a whip within a year of being elected, I counter, and were chief whip by 1955. "Eleven months, I was very quick," he concedes, without the need for further justification.

"I had to wait 14 years," interjects Benn. "You were a whip under Winston, were you?"

Heath: "Yes, I was."

Benn: "Well, there you are."

Benn then complains that ministers spend "less and less time dealing with executive matters, and just go round opening things and closing things and tripping up over things and all the rest of it". "Pure propaganda," says Heath, which brings Benn around to his childhood in a political household (his father had also been a cabinet minister), watching the rise of Hitler.

"I bought Mein Kampf when I was about eight and I still read it. It's an astonishing book. He said democracy inevitably leads to Marxism. Work that one out!" His point is that "if you don't do people justice, they'll go for a demagogue. Any nation that loses confidence in democracy will be seduced. That's the thing that makes me worry about the fall in turnout in America." He mentions the Nuremberg rallies.

Heath remains silent. As an Oxford student of modest origins and progressive instincts, he took himself off to Germany to inspect Hitler at close quarters. Making his way to Nuremberg in 1937, his memoirs report, he witnessed the Führer walking to the podium, "his shoulder brushing mine as he went past". "This experience subsequently dominated my political life," Heath would one day write, confirming him as an anti-appeaser, later (after he had returned to Germany in battle) as a passionate European, convinced that only a Europe "united, free and democratic" would be safe from the demons of ultranationalism.

The conversation moves on. But we come back to it via what both the old warriors agree is a disturbing tendency towards global interventionism by the US, with Britain tagging along in its wake.

Heath: "What is happening alarms me because this Labour government is jumping back 50 years and trying to exert its influence in the world in what is really a colonial atmosphere and system ... There was a parliamentary commission which went out to China and produced a report which was really incredible. It was a report of a colonial power telling its colony what it's got to do. The way we have [also] intervened in Sierra Leone is really colonial."

"I agree with Ted," says Benn. "Just as the 19th century was characterised by the British empire and the 21st by the American empire, that is domination of a military kind nobody has ever contemplated. Britain is now piggy-backing on American power to pretend we have the power. We don't have the power to do anything about Saddam Hussein."

Benn sees Britain trying to find a place in a changing world. "On Europe I understand exactly what Ted feels; I respect him; he's been consistent. He saw wars that split Europe, that destroyed it, and wants to bring it together. No nonsense about convergence criteria [for entry into the euro]. To him it's a political thing.

"If only we could explore the options without it being said that Ted wants the Brussels commission to give instructions to every parking meter. Or that he says we are anti-European, which I'm not. Let's have a rational debate, if only the House of Commons could have a serious debate about Europe."

Heath: "All my debate is rational."

Benn: "I know, Ted. I have never doubted you were - are - a model for us all."

Heath perks up. He recently spent a fruitful day discussing Europe with Oxford dons. "The fact is it is a political question, first and foremost. But what we have to realise is that we can't stand outside and keep saying we are going to come in," he says sharply. "And Blair made this ghastly mistake, he went on and on. And finally the German chancellor blew up and said, 'Prime minister, this is our union and we decide what will happen. And you can't do it for us. That was when Blair took his first crack and he's been mainly quiet since then."

Going into Europe late and then telling them what to do "drove them absolutely mad. I didn't do it; that's why I'm still respected in most of Europe. I recognised that you have got to show them that you are part of them before you can start influencing them in a particular direction."

Benn starts to intervene, then Heath asks him his only direct question of the session. "Does your prime minister really think he has got his party lined up ?"

"I don't know," Benn replies. "If you want advice about the prime minister's thoughts, don't come to me. I am not privy."

The Blair cabinet "are under tremendous pressure, to which they give way the whole time, from the press," says Heath. This is one of his recurrent dislikes because what he sometimes calls the "foreign-owned press" (Rupert Murdoch and Conrad Black) are so hostile to Europe.

I ask what is wrong with the press. "Everything. We have the worst press in the world; the people who have now captured the press are of that calibre, that outlook. I had lunch with one of its editors a short time ago and said, 'You know, it's the influence of the owners and editors on the press that is causing the trouble.' He said, 'The public take it from us, not you.' "

"Like the medieval church," chips in Benn. Heath says he doesn't want to discuss individuals - and then does. "If you take the question of Murdoch, he declared that he was supporting the Labour party and, if you look at his papers, they couldn't be more opposed, supporting the Tory party indirectly."

Benn says he is constantly amazed at the media's failure to report what matters to the people who turn up at public meetings. "I have done five with over 1,000 people, on Palestine, the sale of council houses, cuts in Hackney, globalisation." And he contradicts Heath's notion that, in the good old days, Lords Beaverbrook and Northcliffe separated the news from the comment columns. "A slightly dreamy view of the past," he ventures.

I ask Heath if the press and electorate should have been told when Churchill suffered a stroke in 1953 while he was still in charge. It elicits a very Heath-ish: "No, why should you have done?" As with Suez, very few were in the know, including both the Queen and Heath, as deputy chief whip. "We were able to handle the situation extremely well." And Churchill recovered. "I shall never forget the party conference at Margate. We had this great rally and there was Winston. The chief whip sat behind him and the speech went splendidly. Then we got to this thing where he turned over the page and started reading the same thing again.

"The chief whip looked at me and said, 'Sorry, this is the end.' But Churchill then said, 'I seem to have heard this somewhere before. Perhaps I should turn on.' So he turned over the page and went on. He lasted 18 months after that."

When I later telephone Heath to clarify a few points, I ask what his most important achievements were. Getting into Europe he calls only "a major achievement", which surprises me. He rattles off reform of the tax system; freeing up the housing market to cope with modern needs; the abortive 1971 Industrial Relations Act, a better deal for the unions that broke it than they got from the next Tory government. There were also changes to the immigration laws that, he says, stopped the issue being a "continuous sore" - a reference to Enoch Powell, whom he bravely sacked for his "rivers of blood" speech in 1968.

Benn's answer to the same question on the phone is that he is glad to have campaigned early for reforms that eventually prevailed - "acorns which became trees", as he puts it. Lords reform, of course; freedom of information; gay rights; a trade boycott against apartheid South Africa. Even public ownership is creeping back into fashion, he suggests. "I get letters from people who say, 'I have never agreed with a word you said in your life, Mr Benn,' but then proceed to repeat what I said. You are glad you didn't give up when everyone else gave up."

Great figures of their time? I ask them both. This is a hard one for politicians, among whom - even the most virtuous - ego is a significant component in any 50-year career. Heath does not mention you-know-who, his nemesis from Finchley. But he is loyal to his friends. "Eden has been underestimated because of Suez. What he did in the 30s and early 50s [as foreign secretary] was excellent diplomacy." As for Macmillan, "opinions differ; most of it is wrong". But his stock too will recover.

Benn deplores personality politics, though he has a formidable political personality himself. So he cites speeches instead: Nye Bevan on western rearmament in the 50s, warning that it would lead to a witchhunt against socialists; the young Iain Macleod (who died after three weeks as Heath's chancellor in 1970) famously attacking the great Nye in his maiden speech. Powell was "always worth listening to. People said he had the best mind in parliament until he made it up." In 1968 even Robert Maxwell had made a brilliant speech on the Soviet invasion of his native Czechoslovakia. "People listened, as they did to an ex-miner talking about a pit disaster, because he spoke from his own experience."

Which is why, when Heath and Benn rise, as they shortly will, to make valedictory Commons speeches, old friends and enemies alike will sit quietly and listen. Churchill and Nye, Mao and Nixon, Khrushchev and De Gaulle - a major link between the Commons and its past is about to be severed. Who else can still claim to have brushed shoulders with Hitler?

fields.headline: Travelling from Cyprus to Jordan
fields.trailText: I have booked a two-week holiday to Cyprus in September this year. I would like to find out if it's possible to take a trip from Cyprus to the "rose red city of Petra" in Jordan. Can anyone help?

Jane Collins

fields.headline: Burning the candle
fields.standfirst: This week, Milly rediscovers the art of working all day and drinking all night, and even remembers to track down a pint of Guinness  on St Patrick's Day. But once again, the week ends with a parting at the airport
fields.trailText: Week 16: Coogee This week, Milly rediscovers the art of working all day and drinking all night, and even remembers to track down a pint of Guinness on St Patrick's Day. But once again, the week ends with a parting at the airport
fields.body:
If you remember the end of my last report (and if not, why not?!) I was pretty convinced I wouldn't make it into work on time - and my suspicions were proved correct. Brian heard our house phone ring 16 times, followed by my mobile - all of which I slept through - before he shook me into consciousness in time for me to realise that I was already half an hour late. Oops.

Still, I somehow made it in within half an hour (which is an impressive feat, believe me) and worked for 10 hours - thank goodness it was an easy day. When I got back, Brian showed me his round-the-world itinerary - he's leaving Coogee in five days time. I always knew he was going, but it came as a bit of a shock. It made me realise how short a time I've got left also - thinking of travelling on again fills me with the same mix of nerves and excitement that I had before I left England, although at least I now know that everything will be alright. That evening I made it to the cinema despite the strong call of my bed - and the light comedy 'Miss Congeniality' was just what I needed after the stress of the last few days when everybody has been leaving.  

On Friday the day dawned absolutely perfect - barely a cloud in the sky. I took full advantage of my morning off by walking down the hill to the beach. I'm getting braver with the water, and went in up to my waist..! My evening function was for a company that designs Italian suits - the time which flew by uneventfully. After work at 2am we all piled across the road to our local - sometimes I think we keep that place in business. That's one great thing about my hotel: we work all day together but we also see each other socially, staff and supervisors alike.

I eventually made it back to Coogee at 6am, but not before nearly losing my wallet. I'd fallen asleep on the bus and in my dazed state had got off without checking to see if I had everything. Luckily mine is the last stop, so I ran back to discover my wallet on the bus floor where I'd been sitting. The driver was so concerned about my (in)ability to look after myself that he then drove me almost all the way home, cautioning me about some of the strange guys who are around. As if I haven't seen them already...

Saturday March 17, as you should all know, is St. Patrick's Day - a celebration that should never pass without a pint of Guinness.  I had the whole day off, and Brian is only here for a little while longer, so I forced him (not that he needed much persuasion) to enjoy an evening's drinking with me. I don't mean to make you jealous, but it was yet another perfect day. We began our evening in our apartment, where I made cinnamon bread banana toasties (it's been a while since I've had to use my culinary skills because of working at the hotel) but I made Brian promise we'd have one Guinness somewhere - it would be rude not to.

We headed to the enormous Coogee Bay Hotel, which used to be a frequent haunt of mine when I was a hosteller; however, like the other backpacker spots, I'd hardly been back since I became a semi-resident. After dragging Brian off the pokie machines (card gambling on the computer. I'll say it again - these things are dangerous, do not touch) we got someone to take a picture of us and the black stuff, and my evening's mission was accomplished. I woke in the early hours of the following morning just in time to watch the sun rise in vivid colour over the back of our house. It gave me a happy feeling as I went back to bed.  

The next day I would describe the weather as... OK, you don't want to hear it. You could always move to Australia, you know... Before work Brian and I headed into the city to further his quest to spend the last of his Australian money. It's not a hard task. That evening at work was a girl's bat mitzvah - the most extravagant thing I've ever seen. I was responsible for a table of children all aged between 11 and 14, and they were completely crazy. These kids are going to on average two of these things a week, though they all said this was going to be a hard one to beat. It was certainly an eye-opener for me.  They were so cheeky and energetic that it made a pleasant change from the other functions I've worked at.

After work, we all went across the road again - well, you've got to wind down somehow and I'm getting into the swing of going out every night. We stayed there until closing time then - it being Sunday - we had to settle for a 24-hour pool hall as the next available option. In Sydney you can always find places that are open - fantastic for people who work unsocial hours like us. It really is a party city. I returned to Coogee at 6am. Again.  

I now have the luxury of two days off work. I even managed to get some exercise that first day with a walk along the coastal path that runs from Coogee to Bondai, where I enjoyed all the lovely views of the various bays and beaches that accompany it. That evening, Brian and I went out for dinner to La Spiaggiata, a permanently busy restauraunt on Coogee Bay Road. I had a really gorgeous, really reasonably priced pasta dinner, which explains why it's always so unbelievably packed in there. For the rest of the evening a group of us (some ex-hostel, others picked up along the way) headed to a pub in Bondai as it was Brian's last night in Australia.

I think the weirdness of actually returning home hit both of us the next day as we sat on the beach before Brian's flight. I think that in some ways home can be one of the hardest places for a traveller to go. It's difficult to imagine seeing familiar faces and people again - partly because they're no longer so familiar to you. Again, it made me reflect on my next five months of travel (I always knew six months wouldn't be enough...), as well as the temporary nature of the relationships you build when you're constantly on the move.  Brian and I both think of Coogee as our home, so in some ways it's going to be difficult to leave - although I can't wait to see more of the world...

I had the entertaining sight of watching Brian try to walk around with his ridiculously over-sized bag. Seriously, you'll probably only need half of what you plan to pack. Yet again I found myself seeing someone off at the airport - as if I didn't have enough of it last week.  That night I returned to my eerily empty room and wondered how I'd fill my penultimate week in Coogee. How will I get up in time for work without Brian to wake me?  I guess I'll just have to throw myself into my job...

  Until next week (when Josh joins me again, woohoo!),
Milly

PS Quick note: don't try to change tour dates with AAT Kings as I did this week. For the privilege of putting my Ayres Rock tour back two months they charged me $85. Grrrrrrrr.

fields.headline: Russia retaliates against US 'spy' expulsions
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Russia
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Moscow has expelled 50 US diplomats after the Americans sent home 51 Russian diplomats it accused of spying.
fields.body:
Moscow has expelled 50 US diplomats after the Americans sent home 51 Russian diplomats it accused of spying.

Igor Ivanov, Russia's foreign minister, had earlier condemned the expulsion as a "political act" for which Washington had no grounds.

It was the first direct official response from the Russian government to the news that the US had ordered the immediate expulsion of six diplomats and the departure of 45 others by summer.

"There are no and have been no grounds for this," Mr Ivanov said in a statement read over state-controlled ORT television.

"If anyone had any questions or doubts, this could easily have been settled along... special channels and by special contacts," he said, referring to the "well-established" ties between Moscow and Washington.

The expulsion, the largest since the collapse of communism, follows the arrest in Washington last month of a suspected Russian spy, the FBI agent Robert Hanssen, who is accused of passing information to Moscow for the past 15 years, an official confirmed to US news agencies.

In the initial phase of the expulsion, six members of the Russian embassy staff in Washington were declared persona non grata and asked to leave the country yesterday.

Most of the rest of the group have been asked to leave because the US says that Russia is maintaining too many intelligence officers at its embassy. The current number of active Russian intelligence operatives in the US is thought to be around 450.

The expulsion will plunge relations between Washington and Moscow to a new low. There has already been resentment that Mr Bush has delayed meeting the Russian leader, Vladimir Putin, and a bitter diplomatic row over the US decision to meet an envoy from the rebel Chechen government, an action which Moscow claims will only encourage Chechen terrorism.

The Russian ambassador to the US was summoned to the state department yesterday and was told by the secretary of state, Colin Powell, that the suspected spies had to leave the country.

Though there have been occasional arrests and expulsions of spies on both sides in recent years, such incidents have not threatened US-Russian relations in a serious way.

The new expulsions could be different both because of their number and because of the US administration's fury at the scale of Mr Hanssen's alleged betrayals, which are said to include telling Russia about the existence of an elaborate US spying tunnel dug deep under the Russian embassy complex.

Mr Hanssen is currently in custody in an undisclosed secure location while prosecutors grapple with the difficulty of preparing an indictment which does not reveal important state secrets. There has been speculation that he may be prepared to plead guilty to a range of spying charges in return for assisting US intelligence agents.

Six Russians who picked up documents left by Mr Hanssen have already left the US.

The last incident on this scale occurred in 1986 when President Ronald Reagan expelled 80 Soviet diplomats.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Dee
fields.trailText: I went out on the Barrier Reef from Cairns last year, and also had a fear of water - in fact I had never even jumped into a swimming pool before I was so scared! - but for some reason I decided that I was going to go scuba diving and I just did it. It was the most amazing experience I have ever had and I really recommend it.
fields.body:
Hi Sue -

I emailed you a while ago (about Bali I think) - and it's amazing that you seem to be going exactly where my husband and I went last year for our honeymoon (but we did it a bit more quickly!) Like Gay and Jeremy, I went out on the Barrier Reef from Cairns and also had a fear of water - in fact I had never even jumped into a swimming pool before I was so scared! - but for some reason I decided that I was going to go scuba diving and I just did it. It was the most amazing experience I have ever had and I really recommend it. There's nothing so satisfying as facing a fear and coming out the other side with a great memory!

Enjoy the rest of your stay in Oz!

fields.headline: More ethnically diverse counsellors needed
fields.trailText: Extra funding is needed to boost the number of trained counsellors from ethnically diverse backgrounds, says a new report. David Mitchell reports.
fields.body:
Extra funding is needed to boost the number of trained counsellors from ethnically diverse backgrounds, a new report from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation has urged.

The report, carried out by the Scottish Ethnic Minorities Research Unit at Heriot Watt University in Edinburgh, looked at Asian people's perceptions and experiences of counselling services among 10 voluntary sector providers in Glasgow, Leeds, Bristol and London.

It found that most mainstream counselling agencies offer black and Asian clients only a limited choice when it comes to the type of counsellor, language used and location. Many offer counselling in English only and tend to rely on their counsellors learning about the significance of cultural and religious issues from their clients.

But, while most counselling agencies acknowledge the importance of having a culturally diverse workforce, few are investing any effort in encouraging black applicants for training courses.

Few agencies are also specifically targeting black and Asian communities when actively promoting their services because of their long waiting lists and concerns about their ability to meet any increase in demand.

"Given that the agencies were located in areas with a relatively dense population of minority ethnic people, the low use of most agencies' services by black people, including Asian people, was disturbing," the report concludes.

By contrast, the few black-led counselling agencies believe it is important to have a deep understanding of the cultural and religious background of their clients and are able to provide counselling in a number of languages.

"The tendency of most mainstream agencies to trust that these agencies would cater to the needs of clients who did not speak English was worrying, given the very limited number of black-led agencies," the report says.

The report calls for agencies to improve their services by liaising with agencies whose work brings them into contact with black people, encouraging more self-referrals through a targeted outreach and publicity strategy, and providing more flexible services such as drop-in services and surgeries in black-led agencies.

Counselling should be made more appropriate by increasing the number of trained counsellors from diverse communities, training existing counsellors and involving experienced black counsellors or professionals. Agencies should also carry out ethnic monitoring, examine the long term impact of their services on black clients and organise focus groups with black clients to obtain feedback.

"Black communities too have a role in promoting awareness and acceptability of counselling services by examining their own attitudes to mental health and encouraging people from their communities to seek appropriate support with psychological difficulties and stress," the report stresses.

Gina Netto, assistant director of the Scottish Ethnic Minorities Research Unit and co-author of the report, said the study had found a high incidence of mental health problems in the Asian community, the most extreme manifestations being a higher than average rate of suicide and self-harm among young Asian women.

"Counselling services are very relevant in preventing the deterioration of mental ill-health to the point at which it reaches crisis proportions. If they are to be used by Asian and black communities, they have to be accessible and appropriate to their cultural needs," she said.

The Commission for Racial Equality said it welcomed the report and hoped voluntary sector counselling providers would take its findings on board.

"This is not unusual. It is what we would expect from the general background and lack of understanding that has been highlighted by the Stephen Lawrence inquiry and the subsequent debate across the public and voluntary sector," said spokesman Chris Myant.

"Like so many services dedicated to individuals in need of help, wider issues of responding to diversity of needs are often obscured by the service culture of the people involved. Important nuances and subtleties are missed and people are not coming forward because the service is not tuned in to cultural understanding and language."

The British Association for Counselling and Psychotherapy, which trains, registers and accredits counsellors and psychotherapists, said it was aware of the problems and had set up a special division to deal with race equality issues.

"We are doing our best but funding is the key. Many of the potential candidates from minority ethnic backgrounds are finding it difficult to survive the training because they don't have the resources. What is needed is more resources to provide bursaries," said spokesman Phillip Hodson.

fields.headline: City living
fields.trailText: The hot weather may persude you that the last thing you want to do is spend the weekend in the city, but there are plenty of ways to enjoy the summer without skipping town
fields.body:
The hot weather may persude you that the last thing you want to do is spend the weekend in the city, but for all the die-hard town mice out there, Britain's urban hot spots can be just as attractive when the sun's shining. Whether you're sampling squid-ink spuds in Belfast, exploring Birmingham's Jewellery Quarter or taking advantage of the liberal licensing laws in Glasgow's October Cafe, there are plenty of ways to enjoy the summer without skipping town

Belfast

What's so funny about peace, love and understanding?
The most BMWs in Britain and squid-ink spuds? Fiachra Gibbons doesn't recognise the New Belfast.

Birmingham

Precious gem
As ministers from Nato gather in Birmingham, Chris Arnot explores the Jewellery Quarter's mix of new bars and Georgian architecture.

Bournemouth

BoMo on sea
Did New Labour expect to find a genteel backwater when they booked their conference here? This is New Bournemouth, and Julian Evans suddenly feels his age

Cardiff

Cool Cymru
The Welsh capital now brims with self-confidence and style. Peter Morgan enjoys the new-found freedom of the city

Edinburgh

Auld one's the best one
A new generation of confident consumers, entrepreneurs, architects and planners have taken the little pool of delight that is the Festival and splashed its starjuice into the unlikeliest crevices.

Glasgow

Geeza break, pal
Glasgow is a city brimming over with beauty, simmering with artists and writers. The swaggering energy and humour of the people here will lift your spirits.

Leeds

Yorkie bars
Why go clubbing in a city where your designer trainers share the same fashion blacklist as a pair of plimsolls and no one wears winter coats? Southern softie Emma Brockes attempts to large it in Leeds.

London

Time honoured
Even before the dome, Greenwich could boast one of the most spectacular theme parks in Europe. John Cunningham follows in the footsteps of Pepys, Wren, Dickens - and Mandelson.

fields.headline: Bitter pill for ailing Japan
fields.standfirst: Unless the government implements the tough remedies it has proposed, the financial sector is unlikely to recover soon, says Jonathan Watts
fields.trailText: Unless the government implements the tough remedies it has proposed, the financial sector is unlikely to recover soon, says Jonathan Watts in Tokyo
fields.body:
April was supposed to have been the cruellest month for Japan, according to the legion of doomsayers who were recently prophesying that stock markets, banks, the cabinet and even the Mir space station would all come falling down in the next few weeks.

This Chicken Licken' forecasting has its origin in a 10-year accumulation of pessimism that has left many thinking that no matter how bad things have got, the worst is yet to come.

In part, this mood has been created by the prolonged problems of the banking sector, which has been struggling under a mountain of bad loans since the bursting of the bubble economy at the end of the 1980s.

For the past 10 years, the government has done everything possible to avoid the pain of dealing with this problem. At first, it prescribed tranquillisers - permitting dodgy accounting practices that allowed the banks to hide the scale of the bad loans even as they grew.

When they became impossible to ignore during the crisis of 1998, the prescription was anaesthetic - pumping many billions of yen of public funds into ailing banks to numb the pain of loan write-offs. Progress was made, but slowly, and the effect of those measures has worn off in recent weeks as a fall in the stock market has eroded the value of bank shareholdings and weakened their capital adequacy ratios.

The ratings agency Fitch IBCA warned earlier this month that it was considering a downgrade on 19 Japanese banks. This was enough to send their share prices plunging and to resurrect fears of a new crisis. Faced with a meltdown of confidence in the financial sector and under increasing international pressure, Japan's financial authorities have suddenly indicated a willingness to grit their teeth and face the pain that has been put off for so long.

In a summit with US President George Bush on Monday, prime minister Yoshiro Mori promised to promote the disposal of non-performing loans. The ruling party announced plans to set up a private sector fund to buy up bank shareholdings. The Bank of Japan cut interest rates to zero in a move designed to spur reform of the financial sector.

The man in charge of reform - Hakuo Yanagisawa, head of the financial services agency, shocked many when he said banks should write off their bad loans - estimated at between 30,000bn and 80,000bn yen (£170-450bn) - in one go.

In a sign of the growing aggressiveness, the huge UFJ banking group - comprising Sanwa Bank, Tokai Bank and Toyo Trust and Banking - announced plans to double its write off of bad loans to 113,000bn yen (£6.4bn).

Hopes that Japan's financial sector is ready to bite the bullet helped the Nikkei index of the Tokyo stock exchange to rebound by 912 points on Wednesday - the seventh largest single-day gain in its history. But the gloom-mongers are already warning that optimism is premature. The pain ahead, they say, will be too much to bear for a government that faces a tough upper house election in July.

Disposing of bad assets means bankruptcies and job losses on a massive scale. One European diplomat warned that Japan faced an "unemployment bloodbath" if it pushes ahead with financial surgery. The degree of the suffering ahead was underlined by the Nomura research institute, which warned in its latest report that that aggressive restructuring of all bank portfolios could lop 1.1% off economic growth in the latter half of fiscal 2001, accelerate deflation and push the jobless rate over 5%.

Yesterday, the government was already showing signs of backtracking on its previously tough stance. Finance minister Kiichi Miyazawa said tax incentives should be given to banks that pursue write-offs, while Yanigisawa backed away from an earlier statement in which he indicated that the whole problem should be solved by September.

This suggests that more expensive painkillers will be paid for by taxpayers, while action is delayed again. So the 11-year banking sickness looks set to linger on, which means this April is unlikely to be the cruellest month for weak banks, loss-making companies and millions of employees. But as long as the surgery is put off, Japan's prophets of doom will still feel justified in saying "the worst is yet to come".
