fields.headline: Mayoral race under way
fields.standfirst: The Democratic contenders for Rudy Giuliani's throne face an unusual dilemma, says Jane Martinson
fields.trailText: The Democratic contenders for Rudy Giuliani's throne face an unusual dilemma, says Jane Martinson in New York.
fields.body:
It was an oddly low-key start to an oddly low-key race. The prize was to lead a city that considers itself the centre of the universe and the hotel ballroom was decked with campaign posters. They said "mebq".

Several observers at the launch of the first official contender in the race to become the mayor of New York looked puzzled, until someone explained that it meant "most experienced, best qualified". Alan Hevesi had decided to use his two-term record as a city comptroller - a sort of state accountant - as the basis for his campaign.

Of more interest to political observers was the fact that the Democrat also chose to praise the incumbent mayor, a man many of his party believe to be the Antichrist.

Mr Hevesi hedged his enthusiasm for Rudy Giuliani but it was there and obvious all the same. "In large part - not for everyone yet, and not everywhere - our city is going in the right direction," he said, after eight years of Giuliani's stewardship. "Some people want to pretend that's not true: they root for bad things to happen in our city on Rudy's watch becuse they don't like Rudy Giuliani personally, or just because he's a Republican. I say that is wrong."

The three other men all expected to compete against Mr Hevesi for the Democratic nomination all rushed to criticise his comments. Yet , while the speech said a lot about Mr Hevesi, it said a lot more about Mr Giuliani and the dilemma facing the Democratic contenders for his throne.

Polls consistently show that, while New Yorkers may abhor some of the tough measures taken against the poor or the sick by the mayor, they love the fact that the city has boomed under his tenure. Crime is down, house prices are up, jobs and tourism are booming. Showing similarities with his third-way brothers in Britain, Mr Hevesi even praised the fact that "the squeegee men are off the streets" on Tuesday.

Significantly, his speech in a Manhattan hotel failed to elicit a response from a largely silent band of supporters. Democrat party members, who will elect their candidate in September, two months before the actual election, are far less supportive of Giuliani's means or his ends than the population at large. The four Democratic candidates, all seasoned but fairly lacklustre politicians, must steer a course between this hatred and the public's support for what Giuliani has achieved.

Marshall Whittman, a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute, says, "The spectre of Rudy is haunting this race. Although he isn't on the ballot, he might as well be."

In many ways, this is the Democratic party's election to lose. The people who have flocked to a successful New York over the past decade have largely been Democrat supporters, according to census figures released last week. The Hispanic and Asian populations in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx have expanded more than any other section of society. Meanwhile, the non-Hispanic white population, who tend to vote Republican, has continued to decline.

Chung Seto, a spokeswoman for the state Democratic party, said after Mr Hevesi's launch this week: "We are confident that the Democrats are going to win in November."

Party cynics fear that this optimism may have to rely on the success of the man expected to declare himself as the, er, Republican candidate.

Michael Bloomberg, a man as brash as his rivals are boring, has been a Democrat for most of his life. He is expected to announce his intention to run as the Republican successor to Mr Giuliani before the end of May.

Neither Mr Bloomberg's lifestyle nor his political behaviour have marked him out as an obvious Republican contender. When asked why his marriage had failed, the billionaire head of the eponymous media business said: "I like to go out and party." The 59-year-old's charitable donations included $5,000 last year to the National Abortion and Reproduction Rights Action League. As one head of the New York Conservative party sniffed: "We have endorsed pro-choice candidates, but there is a difference between pro-choice and pro-abortion."

His estimated $4bn fortune will of course help the party overcome such difficulties. And in the race to succeed the radical Mr Giuliani, a man who is not cut from the same cloth might just win.

webTitle: Beckham promises to raise the volume for England

fields.headline: Beckham promises to raise the volume for England
fields.trailText: David Beckham says he is ready to speak up as captain of England in Saturday's World Cup qualifier against Finland. Beckham, not renowned for his vocal talents, said today that he had learned a lesson from the best-known skippers in English football.
fields.body:
David Beckham says he is ready to speak up as captain of England in Saturday's World Cup qualifier against Finland. Beckham, not renowned for his vocal talents, said today that he had learned a lesson from the best-known skippers in English football.

"I've learned from playing for some great captains like Bryan Robson, Roy Keane and Tony Adams. I've been told I have to talk more, on and off the pitch. I am a quiet person - but I can become a leader, I know that," Beckham said.

"It's a big deal for me to be captain. I haven't lost confidence in my form or my ability to be skipper. That is the most important thing for me at the moment. If I play well and contribute on the pitch, then I can keep the armband.

"As long as I am doing well, and working hard, which is something that's never been in doubt, I think I deserve to keep it. It's down to the manager about whether I do keep the captain's role, but I think being made captain for, the World Cup qualifiers is something that's more concrete."

When asked about playing this Saturday's match at Anfield, Beckham said he didn't expect a barracking from the crowd. "I don't think real England fans will give me stick at Liverpool," he said. " For me to walk out with the England team and look at a Kop which will see thousands of fans cheering for the whole team would be something special."

However, Beckham revealed that the consistent abuse he receives from away fans in the Premiership does affect him. "I'm more worried about my family", he said. "It's sad that they can't go to a game without me worrying about whether there will be any problems going in or coming out of the ground."

webTitle: Central Lancashire students kept off Cumbria campus over foot and mouth

fields.headline: Central Lancashire students kept off Cumbria campus over foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Hundreds of students have been told to stay away from the Cumbria campus of the University of Central Lancashire following a foot and mouth outbreak on its farm.
fields.body:
Hundreds of students have been told to stay away from the Cumbria campus of the University of Central Lancashire following a foot and mouth outbreak on its farm.

One suspected case was noted on the farm that is adjacent to the Cumbria campus earlier this month and within two days, 80% of the animals had the disease - leading to the slaughter of 650 sheep and 450 cattle.

"It was incredible," said a spokesperson for the college. "It spread so fast - it was very disturbing for staff and students. The animals all had to be slaughtered and they weren't taken away for three days. Now we are in the disinfection process."

The campus, which caters for 700 full time students, has told one third of its students to stay away and follow their courses by post and email.

A college spokesperson said: "Obviously, students can't be around the farm where we had the outbreak, but there are further worries about another farm we have 13 miles away from the college."

The university is still trying to grasp the full implications to students and the institution. One consequence might be that students have to re-sit exams.

Meanwhile, other agricultural colleges meanwhile remain extra vigilant to protect themselves from the epidemic.

The vice-principal of Sparsholt College in Hampshire, Meredith David said that all vehicles to enter the campus are hosed down with disinfectant. Furthermore, disinfecting mats are placed strategically around the college to ensure students are not a risk.

"We do land based and agriculturally based degrees," said Mr David "and two weeks ago, when we had a suspected case - which was cleared 24 hours later - the full weight of the crisis struck us. We have taken every precaution, and will continue to until it is no longer necessary. We must be responsible to industry and students."

The principal of Harper Adams University College in Shropshire, Wynne Jones says whilst his college is being vigilant, the cost implications of the outbreak were very worrying. He said that the foot and mouth epidemic could cost his college up to a third of a million pounds.

"This is our centennial year at Harper Adams, and because of that a great many conferences and short courses had been planned. We've had to cancel all of them, and that alone has taken about £150,000 off our gross income.

"We have had some staff staying in halls of residence because their own homes are in restricted areas, and in the long term we are going to have huge problem with student debt.

"About 55% of our students are the sons and daughters of farmers, and these farmers are looking at up to two years without income. Students will struggle to pay fees and accommodation bills under those circumstances."

Agricultural students usually spend their Easter holiday on farms delivering the spring lambs. This year they will face quite a dilemma: should they stay at college and hope their families and employers can cope without them, or should they go to farms knowing they run the risk of not being allowed back on campus for the summer term?

webTitle: Glasgow to open war crimes centre

fields.headline: Glasgow to open war crimes centre
fields.trailText: The UK's first centre for the study of war crimes and genocide is to be launched at the University of Glasgow in June.
fields.body:
The UK's first centre for the study of war crimes and genocide is to be launched at the University of Glasgow in June.

Headed up by Professor Peter Vanezis, the centre for international assistance will research and help to resolve human catastrophes around the world.

It will include a core group of ten professors on its committee and over 100 experts internationally. Already, the United Nations and what Professor Vanezis calls 'key players in the forensic field' have lent their support to the centre.

Over the last year, tragedies in Rwanda, Kosovo, Chechnya, and the Congo all had to be investigated. Uncovering crimes and clues about the criminals is important for countries trying to come to terms with their past and for prosecutions in the new international court of human rights. The new centre should put Britain at the head of that international work.

"When a UN commissioner visited us, he had trouble thinking about any similar institution anywhere in the world. The UK has certainly played a pioneering role in human rights of the years, and I think this will show its continuing interest," said Professor Vanezis.

For Amnesty International, any higher profile for the investigation of human rights abuses is an important step forward.

"We welcomes the creation of this department and study of this increasingly important area of international law. We hope that similar projects will be set up by all the major law schools around the world," said Christopher Keith Hall, Legal Adviser of the International Justice Project, Amnesty International.

Professor Vanezis and his colleagues already investigate human rights abuses around the world, including the 'disappeared' in Chile and cases of torture.

"Because of funding problems, we are not as proactive as we'd like. We are hoping we can help and educate people about forensic work, setting up courses actually after crises in affected countries and also in England. It might be possible to have undergraduate courses," he said.

webTitle: Skull is new link in chain of human evolution

fields.headline: Skull is new link in chain of human evolution
fields.trailText: A 3.5m-year-old skull unearthed in Kenya could be about to throw the story of human origins into confusion once again.
fields.body:
A 3.5m-year-old skull unearthed in Kenya could be about to throw the story of human origins into confusion once again.

Human lineage has been linked to an ancestral genus called the Australopithecines, creatures closer to modern humans than to modern apes, who roamed the savannahs and the Rift Valley of Africa more than 3m years ago. But a report in Nature today describes a new species - Kenanthropus platyops - with a much flatter face than any Australopithecine.

"Kenyanthropus shows persuasively that at least two lineages existed as far back as 3.5m years," said Meave Leakey of the Kenya national museum, who worked with her daughter Louise, Fred Spoor of University College, London, and others to analyse the fragments of fossilised bone.

The skull was found at Lake Turkana in Kenya. It shares several features with modern chimpanzees, but has a large, flat face, with high cheeks and small teeth. Teeth size and face shape are linked to the way an animal eats. Researchers think that Kenyanthropus and Australophithecus could have had separate diets, and co-existed peacefully without competing for the same resources.

And it once again raises the question: where did humans come from? "It revolutionises the way we look at human ancestry. We have found a very flat-faced 3.6m-year-old hominid which represents something quite different to what we know to have existed at that time," Louise Leakey told Reuters in Nairobi yesterday. "It doesn't simplify the picture at all. But it does confirm that the evolutionary tree was far more bushy earlier on than we had appreciated."

Researchers found fossils of more than 30 individuals in 1998 and 1999. The most crucial, however, was the telltale skull of a small-brained, human-looking individual.

Humans and chimpanzees shared a common, unknown ancestor who lived in Africa about 5.5m years ago. French anthropologists this year made controversial claims to have found traces of an older link in the human chain, but anthropologists are more sure of fossil fragments of a human-like creature called Ardepithecus from 4.4.m years ago. The next convincing fossils - found widely in central and east Africa - are in the Australopithecus family. One line from this family was believed to have evolved into the genus Homo between 3m and 2m years ago, with modern Homo sapiens the only survivors.

But the new find has muddied this clear picture. "It now seems clear that between 3.5m and 2m years ago there were several human-like species, which were well adapted to life in different environments," said Daniel Lieberman of George Washington University, writing in Nature. "It will be quite a while before we can confidently determine the position of Kenyanthropus platyops in the human evolutionary tree."

webTitle: Aston pulls out of merger talks with Birmingham

fields.headline: Aston pulls out of merger talks with Birmingham
fields.trailText: The possibility of a merger between Aston and Birmingham universities came to a definitive end yesterday, when Aston University withdrew from the negotiations which have spanned the past two years.
fields.body:
The possibility of a merger between Aston and Birmingham universities came to a definitive end yesterday, when Aston University withdrew from the negotiations which have spanned the past two years.

When the talks began in 1999, collaboration between the two institutions was proposed. But discussions soon moved on to the possibility of the full integration of the two HE providers. This would have resulted in the production of one of the largest universities in the UK, with a student body of 30,000.

After withdrawing from yesterday's negotiations, a spokesperson for Aston said: " The Aston council was convinced that current timing and circumstances are not opportune for fully realising the two present vice-chancellors' shared vision for a new integrated institution, or that integration with Birmingham University on any other terms would be in the best interests of Aston's staff and students."

Birmingham's vice-chancellor Professor Maxwell Irvine, was said to be "disappointed" on behalf of the university. He said: "Many people in both universities, and in Birmingham itself, will be disappointed that we've missed this opportunity of equal partnership.

"Our door remains open to Aston, although we have no doubt that full integration offered the most potential for us both. Any other form of collaboration would be a second best choice. "

Members of Aston's guild of students had previously voted two-to-one to oppose the merger, and while some staff supported the possibility of a merger, a great many were against the project, due to fears of job losses.

The AUT, which is the officially recognised academic union in both Aston and Birmingham said: "AUT branches in both universities had expressed concern, the plans and the implications of those plans were not at all clear.

"We are pleased that the recent uncertainty about academic implications and job uncertainty have come to an end with the end of these talks."

fields.headline: Aiming higher
fields.standfirst: As new doctorate-level qualifications show, ELT studies are continuing to evolve, says John Norrish
fields.trailText: As new doctorate-level qualifications show, ELT studies are continuing to evolve, says John Norrish.
fields.body:
Over the past half century we have seen a gradual professionalisation of ELT, and a growing desire among teachers to become better qualified and thus to move up a professional ladder in a business which, in spite of its maturity, remains conspicuous for its lack of a career structure.

The Post Graduate Certificate in Education (PGCE) in TESOL, sadly axed in 1992, was initiated in 1957. The first private qualification, for practising teachers, introduced in the late 60s, was the Royal Society of Arts Diploma in TEFL (now the University of Cambridge Local Exams Syndicate DELTA), to which was added a basic Certificate course for beginners. Also in the 60s, some British universities took up an idea from the United States, the taught Masters degree. Since then the MA, MSc and MEd have become a cornerstone of the profession, at least for those who wish to advance into the ranks of Director of Studies or more prestigious teaching appointments.

Masters are taught courses, generally lasting a year full time, or two or more part time, with distance elements, frequently online, an increasingly popular option. Besides offering exposure to new ideas through teaching, they give an opportunity for students to write a 10,000 to 20,000 word dissertation, on a topic they would like to investigate or place into some conceptual framework. Nowadays these courses generally offer some form of research training to facilitate data collection and analysis for the written work.

As the number of professionals with the Masters level qualification rises, so does the need for a further academic rung on the ladder. This was provided up to about 10 years ago in British universities by the PhD degree. One problem with working at this level, however, is that the qualification was (and still is) usually focused on research, and can thus be understood as a preparation for work in research and academic life. There are few taught elements at this level, although as with MA courses students are usually offered a course of research training.

It has long been recognised that a good researcher or academic is not necessarily a good practitioner, but there was little alternative above the MA level to develop a professional but also scholastic approach. However, in 1992 ideas imported from both the US and Australia began to surface in Britain. The academic influences were from, among others, Schön, with his ideas of reflective practice, and Kolb's experiential learning. There was also a desire among professionals in education in general to undertake further and more detailed work in their area without wishing to leave it for the groves of academe.

In that year the first Doctor of Education (EdD) opened registration in Britain. Since then it has become one of the most popular professional doctorates at this level, with about 36 institutions offering it to date.

The aim of these courses is to improve students' professional practice by encouraging a research sensibility and the conduct of research, often focusing on their own professional context. The courses are aimed at advanced practitioners who wish to move up in their profession but who do not wish to become researchers or academics.

The Institute of Education in London, for example, in its course aims to "develop both high level research and inquiry skills and an understanding of the nature of professionalism, and students are given the opportunity to undertake specialist studies in a field of their choice".

The qualification is now offered in a number of institutions known for their TESOL or Applied Linguistics interests.

But what effect, if any, does this change in the focus of doctoral level degrees have on prospective employers and opportunities? It is probably too early to arrive at any definite conclusions here. One effect it has had on the more "traditional" research oriented PhD is that it is now possible to negotiate a less academic and more professional orientation. Indeed, this development raises for discussion the entire nature of academic work and practical versus research-based knowledge.

One thing is certain, however, and that is that it is increasingly possible for professionals to follow a post-MA level course of study and to gain a further qualification in their spare time, while holding down a demanding professional position.

Universities are now more flexible than ever in accommodating advanced students' constraints of time and place. Modular degrees - either face to face or partly on-line - are now readily available. Students can take a period of time away from their desks and complete a part of a degree, then return to work and later return to complete a further element of study.

Both PhD and EdD courses are given full time, usually over a period of two or three years, or part time, up to six years in some institutions. At a time of increasing demands for professional flexibility and adaptability, these kinds of doctoral courses look very attractive.

 John Norrish teaches at the Institute of Education, London.

webTitle: Business needs to clean out its ears and start listening

fields.headline: Business needs to clean out its ears and start listening
fields.standfirst: John Simmons explains what the global merger of English with other cultures means for native speakers
fields.trailText: John Simmons explains what the global merger of English with other cultures means for native speakers.
fields.body:
There is an assumption behind the concept of "English as the global language" that comes dangerously close to arrogance, which in turn leads to complacency. Yet if we see different languages of the world as being in commercial competition, English simply cannot afford to be complacent about its current role and future place in the world. The facts are disarming. All the evidence points to English being the most widely used language in the world today - more people are learning English as a second language than speak it as a first language. This seems to reinforce the view of English as an unstoppable language juggernaut.

So is the "global triumph of English" inevitable? And if so, is that entirely desirable? For many native English speakers these may seem strange questions to ask. Of course we want English to dominate - after all, we're so bad at speaking other languages that it seems a sound business strategy to get the rest of the world to use English. But what is this English that the rest of the world will be using? There is no doubt that as the century advances, English will become less and less shaped by the cultures of English-speaking nations. English will become the second language of more and more people. The chances are that even though future meetings between, say, Chinese, British and Indian people might be conducted in English, the advantage of empathy will lie with the Asian English speakers.

English in 2050 will be very different from that spoken today, just as 50-year-old newsreels seen today show how far the language has evolved in our life span. With technology changes - such as digital broadcasting, texting on mobile phones, the growth of emails, as well as the internet - English is going through a period of accelerating evolution.

Part of this evolution is "Fusion English", in which the language is subject to the mingling of cultural influences from different parts of the world. Go into a coffee bar and ask for a "latte". Watch car advertising and get the "Spirito di Punto". Fusion language imports new words from other languages into common English usage and exports English words into other languages. This international trade in words goes beyond the European languages to land phrases on far-flung shores, such as "tasuku forsu" (Japanese for task force).

In this fluid situation there are short-term opportunities for English-speaking countries to use their English language fluency to gain business advantage. English is in effect an invisible export within everything we sell. But we are mistaken if we imagine that our "mastery" of current English will give us a continuing advantage in the future.

The longer term presents the real challenge. We see two seemingly conflicting trends at work. First, the worrying inflexibility and incompetence of native English-speakers to learn other languages and understand other cultures. Second, the amazing adaptability of the language itself. In other words, English changes rapidly even if native English-speakers do not. If we are to exploit our current language advantage, the paradox is that we need to become better at understanding other languages and other cultures. We have to see English (in all its forms) as a new language to learn.

As part of this necessary flexibility we need to loosen our approach to the use of English in business. We need to use words as we speak them, and stop hiding behind the barriers of professional jargon and outdated stuffiness that keep businesses remote from their audiences. We must not just allow, but positively encourage "employees" to bring more of their individual personalities to work through the words that they write and speak. All businesses are becoming brands, and brands are increasingly realising that they need to embrace both consistency and diversity - and to see that there is not necessarily a conflict between the two. It's a difficult game, but we have to learn to play it well. Brands need to be both global and local, strongly authoritative and engagingly vulnerable, and to make effortless transitions between each.

All this throws up enormous opportunities as well as challenges for everyone working in business. Businesses have to use language to communicate. Through language they need to engage with customers and potential customers. That takes language skills. Do our companies have those skills? They should have, as long as they think of such skills as coming from the development of brains and senses to be constantly receptive to new influences and ideas, rather than from a deep knowledge of plain words.

In Britain the "Little Englander" has to depart; so too does little English. Let us learn to become world citizens of English. We need to see English as a great world language just being born, not as an old man eager to instruct the world in his old ways.

 John Simmons is director of the London-based brand consultancy Interbrand, and author of We, Me, Them And It: The Power Of Words In Business (Texere). He was due to speak at the RSA/Bloomsbury conference, World Speak, on March 23.

fields.headline: ELT Diary
fields.trailText: Visa advice | No peace dividend | Vintage research
fields.body:
Visa advice

Under new rules that come into effect in Britain next month, it will become an offence for language schools, colleges, universities and members of staff to give immigration advice to students unless they are authorised to do so under the Regulation of Immigration Advice and Services. The new legislation is intended to stamp out "back-street" immigration advisors who exploit asylum seekers, but the effects will be felt across Britain's ELT sector. Any institution that wants to continue to advise individuals and support them in their visa applications will now have to comply with a stringent code of practice.

No peace dividend

ELT providers in Northern Ireland blame the ongoing political instability for the sector's poor performance compared with the ELT in the Republic of Ireland. The Irish Times reported that the ELT sector in the north generated only $4.5m last year, less than 1% of the total raised in the Republic. Tony Ridgeway, director of Queen's University TEFL centre told the newspaper that while the sector had grown since the ceasefire was called almost four years ago, it remained very sensitive to setbacks in the peace process.

Vintage research

A 20-year study carried out by a linguistics researcher at the University of Arizona into the words used by wine writers to describe the effects of wines on their noses and palates reveals that a whole new set of metaphors and adjectives have come into usage, but that the vocabulary still lacks any obvious meaning. However, Dr Adrienne Lehrer defends those who describe wines as "in-your-face", "diplomatic" and "hedonistic". "They are pushing back the language, they are making up metaphors," she says.

Russian out

Estonia's parliament has rejected a bill that sought to preserve Russian-medium education. Under the current law all schools must switch to Estonian by 2007.

 max.delotbiniere@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Murder that is a threat to survival
fields.standfirst: Biodiversity cannot be protected unless language genocide is halted, argues Tove Skutnabb-Kangas
fields.trailText: Biodiversity cannot be protected unless language genocide is halted, argues Tove Skutnabb-Kangas.
fields.body:
Habitat destruction through logging, the spread of agriculture and use of pesticides, and the economic and political vulnerability of the people who live in the world's most diverse ecoregions are recognised as the main causes of the disappearance of biodiversity. What is less widely understood is the link between diminishing global biodiversity and the disappearance of languages.

While new trees can be planted and habitats restored, it is much more difficult to restore languages once they have been murdered. And languages are being murdered today faster than ever before in human history. Even the most optimistic prognoses claim that only half of today's 6,000-7,000 spoken languages will exist by 2100. The media and educational systems are the most important direct agents in language murder today.

Most of the world's languages are spoken by relatively few people; the median number of speakers of a language is probably 5,000-6,000. There are fewer than 300 languages with more than 1m native users; half of all languages have fewer than 10,000 users, and a quarter of the world's spoken languages and most of the sign languages have fewer than 1,000 users. More than 80% of the world's languages exist in one country only.

A simple comparison, based on numbers and extinction rates, shows that linguistic diversity (LD) is disappearing relatively much faster than biodiversity (BD). Optimistic estimates claim that 2% of biological species but 50% of languages may be dead or moribund - no longer learned by children - in 100 years' time. According to pessimistic but realistic estimates, 20% of biological species but 90% of languages may be dead or moribund in 100 years.

People might say: so what? It might be better for world peace if we all speak a few big languages and understand each other. But language diversity is decisive for the future of the planet. LD and BD are correlated: where one type is high, the other one is too, and vice versa, even if there are exceptions. David Harmon of Terralingua, an international non-profit organisation devoted to preserving the world's linguistic diversity, has compared the 25 countries that have the most endemic languages with the 25 that have the most higher vertebrates. Sixteen countries (64%) are on both lists. According to Harmon, "it is very unlikely that this would only be accidental". He gets the same results with flowering plants and languages, butterflies and languages - a high correlation between countries with biological and linguistic megadiversity.

New research shows mounting evidence that the relationship may also be causal: the two types of diversities seem to enforce and support each other. According to a recent United Nations environmental programme report, threatened languages store the knowledge about how to maintain and use sustainably some of the most vulnerable and most biologically diverse environments in the world. It has taken centuries for people to learn about their environments and to name the complex ecological relationships that are decisive for maintenance of biodiversity. When indigenous peoples lose their languages, much of this knowledge also disappears: the dominant languages do not have the ethno-biological and ethno-medical vocabulary, and the stories will not be translated.

If the long-lasting co-evolution that people have had with their environments is suddenly disrupted, without nature (and people) having enough time to adjust and adapt, we can expect a catastrophe. If during the next 100 years we murder up to 90% of the linguistic (and thereby mostly also the cultural) diversity that is our treasury of this historically developed ecological knowledge, we are also seriously undermining our chances of life on Earth.

Like the loss of BD, the loss of LD is dangerous reductionism. As we see in increasingly dramatic ways, such as the spread of species that are more resistant to antibiotics and herbicides, monocultures are vulnerable. The potential for the new lateral thinking that might save us from ourselves in time lies in having as many and as diverse languages and cultures as possible. We do not know which ones have the right medicine. For this, multilingualism is necessary. Indigenous and minority people need to have a chance to maintain their own languages and learn dominant languages.

But instead of fostering and supporting multilingualism through the education system, schools participate in linguistic genocide, as it has been defined in the United Nations Genocide Convention (Articles IIb and IIe and its Final Draft Article III1). Pirjo Janulf shows in a recent study that of those Finnish immigrant minority members in Sweden who had had Swedish-medium education, not one spoke any Finnish to his or her own children. There are no schools or classes teaching through the medium of the threatened indigenous or minority languages. The transfer to the majority language group is not voluntary: alternatives do not exist, and parents do not have enough reliable information about the long-term consequences of the various choices. There is also a wealth of research and statistics about the mental harm that forced assimilation causes in education and other areas.

fields.headline: Languages go to top of the class
fields.standfirst: Chaz Pugliese assesses France's bid to make multilingualism a reality in schools
fields.trailText: Chaz Pugliese assesses France's bid to make multilingualism a reality in schools.
fields.body:
Next month the official launch of France's high-profile European Year of Languages (EYL) campaign - part of the Europe wide initiative to promote language learning - will take place in Paris. Much of the credit for galvanising the public behind EYL is being claimed by the education minister, Jack Lang, who has made language learning the central focus of his education policy since he took office a year ago. But state schools are concerned that they are being burdened with a promise to relieve France's sense of linguistic incompetence without sufficient resources to see the policy through.

Last June Mr Lang announced a package of reforms aimed at lowering the age at which children start learning a second or foreign language - from age six by 2004 and from age five by 2005. But in January the minister announced that he was speeding up his policy by bringing forward the start of language classes for six-year-olds to the 2001-2002 school year, starting this autumn. He also announced the introduction of a new test of pupils language skills when they enter their first year of collège (at 11).

These policies are linked to a widespread perception among the public that the French are bad at languages, and that the quality of language training currently on offer in school is poor. Ask anyone in France if they think language learning in school is satisfactory and the answer is likely to be negative. Nevertheless, more than 50% of the population believe they can use a foreign language comfortably. For those uncomfortable with a foreign language, class size, unrealistic syllabuses, a lack of resources and, more than anything else, a late start are all likely to be blamed.

Mr Lang's reforms are only the latest in a series of government initiatives to improve language teaching. Since 1998 students have had the opportunity to begin learning a foreign language at the age of 10 (in 2000, 85% did so in their last year of primary school. Learning a first foreign language is mandatory at 11, and a second language is introduced at 13. Moreover pupils can pick from as many as 14 languages, 75% of them take two languages through their last year of school, and 12% try their hand at three languages.

Mr Lang has portrayed his drive for multilingualism as a necessary challenge for French national identity. He has also pointed out that far from being a monolingual country, France is enriched by speakers numerous regional languages, such as Basque, Occitan, Catalan and Corse, and the new policy officially acknowledges these languages.

Studying a second language from as early as five-years-old would represent, in Mr Lang's words, "an efficient way of forging a link between the pupil's culture and other surrounding cultures". Multilingualism is also seen as an antidote to the dominance of English: already a staggering 88% of pupils at collège elect to study English as their first foreign language, while German is chosen by only 11%, with other languages such as Spanish and Italian lagging far behind.

But not everyone is won over by la réforme, and it has drawn wide-ranging criticism. Some are claiming that the policy is aimed at bolstering Mr Lang's popularity in the run up to next year's national elections.

Others are prepared to give him the benefit of the doubt. Laurent Quintard, vice-secretary general of SNUIPP, the primary school teachers' union, supports Mr Lang's multilingual principals, but adds, "Once again we have to point out the discrepancy between the measures announced and the resources the minister wants to deploy. It is not enough to make foreign languages mandatory if schools have no qualified teachers."

Because teacher training is notoriously expensive, previous ministers of education have tried to meet their commitments to language education by using teachers with little competence in the target language - and in many cases with no specific training.

Jacqueline Quienart, a primary schoolteacher and past president of TESOL France explains how this system works. "At the moment three types of teachers are doing the job: language assistants, people from outside the school, like parents, collège teachers doing overtime (on average 1 to 5 hours a week) or primary schoolteachers accredited to teach a second language," she says, "But in the latter case, the teaching skills are not actually tested."

"We can no longer rely on those willing to work on a volunteer basis," adds Mr Quintard, "so obviously an effort has to be made to train the teachers." In response Mr Lang has said that he will recruit a sufficient number of teachers with language skills by 2003. He has also announced that he will have 1,850 language assistants in place for the beginning of the 2002 academic year, up from 1,000 this year.

Teachers and teacher trainers are also sceptical about the assumption that young children can pick up a second, or even a third language, effortlessly. "The younger the better does not necessarily seem the case," says Line Audin, an English teacher at the National Institute for Teacher Research. "Despite it being very attractive and popular in France, this formula fails to distinguish between what's learnt at a very young age, and what's learnt later."

Researchers agree that exposing young children to a foreign language provides them with a window on different cultures early on in life, but there is no consensus on whether this exposure promotes better and faster language acquisition.

Many teachers also fear that implementing the new policy will actually end up reinforcing the dominance of English, the very thing crticised by the minister, who is fond of saying that if he were a dictator, "I'd probably ban English from primary school".

webTitle: Take pride in your languages - no matter how faltering

fields.headline: Take pride in your languages - no matter how faltering
fields.trailText: The Council of Europe is putting the finishing touches on its initiative to give learners a single standard by which to measure their linguistic accomplishments.
fields.body:
As France speeds up its drive to increase the number of languages being learnt in schools, the Council of Europe is putting the finishing touches on its new initiative to give language learners a single standard by which to measure their linguistic accomplishments, and to give them the confidence to use their languages to move around Europe.

The European Language Portfolio (ELP), which is being launched to coincide with European Year of languages, is designed to break down language barriers and to encourage holders to feel proud of their language skills, no matter how faltering.

The Council of Europe has developed a blueprint for the document, which it wants national governments to reproduce and distribute in primary and secondary schools as well as to adult learners. The Portfolio consists of a "Language Passport", where holders fill in their competences based on a six-level, common framework - a "Language Biography" for keeping a personal record of language learning, and a "Dossier" for storing samples of work and certificates.

According to Robin Davis, from the British ELT provider Bell International, who has helped to develop a Europe-wide Portfolio designed for adult learners, the Portfolio will help individuals to build up a more comprehensive view of their learning than offered by exams alone.

"The new belief is that learners will learn more effectively if they are more aware of how they learn," says Davis. "The Passport section is designed to get them to think about what language learning experience they've had in the past and what worked best."

The Portfolio is also designed to help users reassess even the lowest level of skill they may have in a language. The standardised layout has space for up to six languages to be recorded, and users are encouraged to enter as many languages as possible.

So far Jack Lang in France has been the most enthusiastic support of the Portfolio, and it is being distributed to primary and secondary schoolchildren this year. Italy and Portugal are keen to follow suit, and Russia has printed 5m copies of its Portfolio.

For more information got to the Council of Europe's website

webTitle: Top comprehensive to set up new technology academy

fields.headline: Top comprehensive to set up new technology academy
fields.trailText: England's top-performing comprehensive, Thomas Telford, is putting £1m into establishing one of the government's new city academies.
fields.body:
England's top-performing comprehensive, Thomas Telford, is putting £1m into establishing one of the government's new city academies.

The Shropshire school is ploughing £1m made from its successful online GNVQ course in information and communication technology into setting up the new academy, on the site of the TP Riley school in Bloxwich, Walsall. The Mercers' Company, joint founders of Thomas Telford, are also providing £1m.

The school, set up in 1991 as a city technology college, is hugely oversubscribed and selects pupils within ability bands. Last year it became the first comprehensive where 100% of its pupils achieved five or more good GCSEs.

It will work in partnership with the new city academy, which will also specialise in technology, and will incorporate many of its innovations, including students being taught up to 35 hours a week, 10 reports to parents each year, an online curriculum and a maximum class size of 24.

From September 1,000 schools will be paying £3,000 each to using the Thomas Telford Online ICT course. Currently nearly 500 do.

Kevin Satchwell, headmaster of Thomas Telford, said: "This is just the beginning. We have aspirations to support the establishment of other city academies and specialist schools, particularly in the West Midlands.

He believed it was the first time a state school had put £1m towards the establishment of another school. King's College, Guildford, the first "privatised" state school, is funded by 3Es, the business wing of the Kingshurst city technology college in Solihull.

Plans for two more city academies, the first to specialise in business and enterprise, are being set up in Bexley, Kent, and Southwark in south-east London. The Bexley city academy intends eventually to incorporate a primary school as well as a secondary, another first.

fields.headline: Outbreak could affect A-levels
fields.standfirst:
Teenagers facing restrictions on field trips

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Thousands of teenagers taking GCSEs and A-levels in geography and biology this spring could be unable to complete their exams because of restrictions to field trips caused by foot and mouth disease, the chief inspector of schools warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Thousands of teenagers taking GCSEs and A-levels in geography and biology this spring could be unable to complete their exams because of restrictions to field trips caused by foot and mouth disease, the chief inspector of schools warned yesterday.

Giving evidence to MPs on the education select committee, Mike Tomlinson, chief of Ofsted, the schools inspectorate, admitted that he was more worried about the impact of the outbreak of foot and mouth disease than teacher shortages on forthcoming public exams.

Asked whether youngsters' exam performance was likely to be affected by the teacher shortages - the worst for a decade - Mr Tomlinson said: "Clearly the exam data for this summer will be of interest to everyone. But there is no evidence at all that it will be adversely affected [by the teacher shortages].

"What is more worrying is that in certain subjects like geography and biology, foot and mouth disease is seriously affecting fieldwork. There are some real concerns here".

Fieldwork is now a compulsory element of these exams and usually takes place around Easter, often at designated fieldwork centres in rural areas.

Mr Tomlinson explained later that with many parts of the countryside now out of bounds, exam boards and the qualifications and curriculum authority were holding urgent discussions about the potential impact of the restrictions on schools, colleges and their pupils.

Although he admitted it was "an emerging issue", he said it would be wrong to "talk it up into a crisis". "Of course, the worry then is how that will impact on their overall grades. Clearly it would be a worry for the pupils", he said.

The foot and mouth crisis had also affected the work of Ofsted, he revealed. Inspectors had already been given guidance not go into areas declared off limits to visitors, and two school inspections had had to be deferred because of the outbreak.

Mr Tomlinson was giving evidence to the all party Commons committee during one of two annual sessions by which parliament holds Ofsted to account.

It was the first time he had appeared before the committee since taking over from his controversial predecessor Chris Woodhead.

The Joint Council for General Qualifications, which represents the examining boards, said it was taking the issue of foot and mouth disease seriously and had published guidance to schools on fieldwork restrictions earlier this month.

It admitted that an increasing number of field centres were cancelling courses, while fieldwork being organised by individual schools and colleges was also being affected.

Where course work had to be submitted for this year's exams, "in many cases it will be possible to carry out appropriate work in the local area, or even on the school site itself", the guidance said.

The JCGQ said that figures on the number of candidates taking the exams were not yet available.

However, last year 37,112 pupils took geography at A-level and 251,605 at GCSE, while for biology there were 54,840 candidates for A-level and 48,715 for GCSE.

webTitle: Job satisfaction falls for public workers

fields.headline: Job satisfaction falls for public workers
fields.standfirst: Nurses, teachers and civil servants face more stress says survey
fields.trailText: Job satisfaction among Britain's 6m public sector workers has fallen sharply over the past decade as rising levels of stress have made work less enjoyable for doctors, nurses, teachers, lecturers and civil servants, said research published yesterday.
fields.body:
Job satisfaction among Britain's 6m public sector workers has fallen sharply over the past decade as rising levels of stress have made work less enjoyable for doctors, nurses, teachers, lecturers and civil servants, said research published yesterday.

The study from Andrew Oswald and Jonathan Gardner of Warwick University found that an increase in depression, strain, sleep loss and unhappiness during the 1990s had made employment more pressurised and less enjoyable in the public realm.

While public sector workers began the 1990s with far higher levels of job satisfaction than those in the private sector, the Warwick University research showed that this gap had been virtually eroded by 1998, which was a year of stringent control of government spending.

"We expect these trends to continue. I anticipate that things have got worse in the years to 2001, judging by the information we have been able to glean from other sources," Professor Oswald said.

"I think this is very serious for Britain. Job satisfaction has dropped dramatically in the public sector throughout the 90s. Stress has risen quite dramatically."

Prof Oswald said his view was that the decline in job satisfaction was linked to rising stress. "The very heavy increase in workloads in the public sector has made workers much less happy", he said.

The Guardian this week carried interviews with more than 200 workers from all parts of the public sector. Prof Oswald said that it was clear from the responses that those who chose jobs in the public sector did so because they were attracted by the "intrinsically interesting nature" of the work.

"Our evidence suggests that job satisfaction premium has collapsed."

All groups of public sector workers have become less satisfied at work over the past decade, a period in which they have faced extra bureaucracy, pressure to meet targets as well as the introduction of working practices from the private sector.

The steady decline in satisfaction was particularly evident in the NHS, higher education and those working for local government.

The sample of 5,000 workers was re-interviewed each year through the 1990s, with stress levels assessed by the answers to 12 standard questions used to measure mental distress and psychological ill health.

Overall, the researchers found that job satisfaction was u-shaped in age, with initial contentment at work during teenage years disappearing by the age of 25.

Job satisfaction was lowest when people were in their 20s and 30s - the period when people struggle to balance work with their family commitments - and highest among staff in their 50s and 60s.

Recorded job satisfaction was higher among women than among men, lower among blacks than whites, slightly lower in union workplaces than non-union ones, high in small workplaces, and highest of all in not-for-profit organisations.

The self-employed also said that they enjoyed their work, according to theWarwick University research.

Measured by educational attainment, the study found that those workers with no qualifications were most satisfied with their jobs.

"It is Britons with university degrees, surprisingly, who report the lowest levels of satisfaction at work", Prof Oswald said.

fields.headline: Carbone's Boro move falls apart
fields.trailText: Benito Carbone's free-transfer move to Middlesbrough from Bradford collapsed this afternoon after Boro refused to offer the Italian anything more than a one-year contract.
fields.body:
Benito Carbone's free-transfer move to Middlesbrough from Bradford collapsed this afternoon after Boro refused to offer the Italian anything more than a one-year contract.

Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond had decided to let Carbone leave the club on a free transfer, in order to save almost £350,000 on wages to the end of the season.

Boro then matched Carbone's salary demands, although it is believed the 29-year-old had opted to take a small pay cut on the £40,000-per-week he was being paid by City.

Carbone even passed a medical earlier today in anticipation of the move, but negotiations finally broke down after the two parties failed to agree on the length of contract.

Carbone's chequered history in the Premiership included an abortive spell at Aston Villa last season. But when Richmond annouced the signing of Carbone as "the most exciting in the history of the club", it was hoped he would settle down.

But the Italian forward has continued to be linked with numerous clus throughout the season, and has scored only six goals in all competitions this season.

webTitle: Once they wanted to help others. Now they want to be Britney Spears

fields.headline: Once they wanted to help others. Now they want to be Britney Spears
fields.standfirst: Consumer culture has filled the vacuum left by the decline of patriotism, socialism and religion, laments Madeleine Bunting
fields.trailText: Consumer culture has filled the vacuum left by the decline of patriotism, socialism and religion, laments Madeleine Bunting.
fields.body:
Public service is a concept which means little to anyone under 20. The idea of taking up a career out of a sense of public duty or inspired by a sense of service to the state are absurdly irrelevant. What used to draw people into the public sector was a neat combination of need and aspiration  security and idealism.

Neither holds true now.

The purpose of career and personal ambition have been reframed in the last 30 years and, increasingly, government policy to improve public services will bump up against cultural shifts which have transformed the relationship between personal identity and work.

What the public sector has famously offered is security. To the generations born in the shadow of the depression or those who were the first in their family to benefit from the widening postwar education system, the offer of a secure job and a pension was a step up the social ladder.

Now, after a period of economic growth and a tighter labour market, the need for security is less of a priority for a younger generation. Whats more, the public sector no longer provides the same degree of security anyway; these Birmingham teenagers are keenly aware of the insecurity generated by inspections, public scrutiny and accountability.

The three great sets of ideals which motivated the willing and often highly educated workforce of the expanding welfare state have all been bankrupted in recent decades: patriotism, socialism and Christianity all provided distinctive contributions to a sense of public purpose which have defined the lives of thousands of public servants. Questioned, scrutinised, debunked: these big three can no longer rally a new generation to devote their lives to the common good.

It was patriotism which framed the lives of the British upper middle class to take up jobs in the civil and colonial service, the army,the judiciary and the upper echelons of the public sector. It was an establishment ethos which was paternalistic and elitist, but it ensured the public sector could attract some of the countrys best educated, and there was a well-trodden path from Oxbridge to Whitehall. And it wasnt just the upper middle class who were motivated by patriotism. The armed forces have always drawn on powerful reserves of working class patriotism.

The ideals of socialism and its promotion of human rights powerfully influenced the postwar political consensus. Thousands entering public services in the 1960s, were inspired by a belief in progress  that many problems, from health inequality to prisoner rehabilitation, could be solved by the state. It was an era of unprecedented confidence in the state to deliver a better world.

Christianity may have steeply declined but its language still permeates the public sector  words such as "service" and "vocation". A belief in altruistic, self-sacrificing service was a central thread running through the lives of many public servants and inspired great respect amongst those who encountered it.

But from the 1960s onwards, secularisation introduced a new concept of duty to oneself along with a language of personal emotional needs and fulfilment which has powerfully reorientated the individual towards a preoccupation with self. Personal identity has been severed from any wider collective context such as class, creed or nationality.

The decline of these collective identities - of nation, faith and ideology - has left a vacuum which has been taken over and exploited by consumer culture.

The most powerful collective identities now are those we buy: DKNY or CK mean more to your average teenager than any government service. Where once socialism offered the promise of a better world, now Gap does. Nike sells its flash on the heroic myth of near-superhuman individual effort and achievement. Where once, every seven-year-old girl wanted to be a teacher or a nurse, now they want to be Britney Spears. We have a culture of individual aggrandisement and self-promotion in which self-effacing service has no place.

But neither does loads of money. Consumer culture is reformulating itself in a neat bid to dodge the accusations of materialism and the backlash against it. The drive now is not to accumulate possessions but to accumulate experiences, as illustrated by the 16-year-old aspiring actor who wants to escape the "trap" of teaching and Seema Parmars scorn for a "safe job". A generation raised on PlayStation is accustomed to constant and high levels of stimulation.

Government pronouncements indicate concern at this commercialisation of identity and the distortions it generates. Jack Straw laments the walk-by culture and Gordon Brown talks of civic renewal and Tony Blair repeatedly emphasises individual responsibility.

But the governments voice is drowned out by a consumer culture which is primarily focused on your relationship with yourself rather than a relationship with a wider collective: it is typified by the

LOreal slogan: "Because youre worth it." Brands are monikers to establish belonging, but they are about exclusivity so they exclude as many as they include. Besides, DKNY is belonging to what?

In that quest, a vision of the common good to which a new generation can subscribe is strikingly absent.

webTitle: Parents given a voice in childcare

fields.headline: Parents given a voice in childcare
fields.standfirst: Can public services be delivered in new ways? Lucy Ward visits a pioneering scheme in Corby
fields.trailText: Can public services be delivered in new ways? Lucy Ward visits a pioneering scheme in Corby.
fields.body:
"Were going to have long grass where children can run and jump and hide. Children have a right to play without treading on condoms and syringes." Margy Whalley, research director at Pen Green centre for under-fives and their families in the former steeltown of Corby, waves her hands like a conjuror over a plain architects model of a planned new extension to the centres battered 1930s building.

A government cash injection of £3.3m will create not only new facilities for babies, toddlers and teenage parents (commoner than average in the struggling Northamptonshire town), but a grassy enclosed play area where children can rampage about in safety.

Pen Green, housed in the old brick comprehensive school built to serve the children of Corbys original steelworkers, is the base for two of the initiatives boasted of most proudly by a Labour government stung that its public sector successes rarely win the attention afforded to its failures. The centre, founded in 1983  just after the steelworks closed  and quietly making a difference for local families ever since, has been granted early excellence centre status and funds in recognition of its work providing both quality childcare and support for the jobless and low-income families of the area.

More recently, the centre has also become home to, and main partner in, one of the trailblazing first tranche of the governments Sure Start projects  aimed at providing better services of all kinds for children under four and their families. For the buggy-pushing parents flooding in and out of Pen Green and its two outposts on estates across the town, the catchy labels invented by Labours policy wonks may have little meaning.

But for Dr Whalley and her colleagues, that is as it should be: the aim of Sure Start, in particular, is to ensure families receive a seamless service of parenting help, health care and advice, childcare and other support without falling through the gaps between competing or conflicting agencies.

For the government, Sure Start epitomises efforts to shake up public service performance by combining highly tailored local delivery with centralised standard-setting: often skirting traditional powerbases such as local authorities in the process. Local councils are highly involved in the Corby project and its fellow 60 pioneering Sure Start schemes around the country, but are obliged to cooperate with other agencies and work towards nationally set targets.The ex-steel town, the subject of a scattergun array of aid projects in the 1980s, already boasts a history of collaboration between public and voluntary sector agencies.

The most successful example of other flagship government initiatives  such as early years development and childcare partnerships, designed to incorporate childcare provision and tailor it to local needs  demonstrates similar collaborative approaches, but elsewhere years of competitive grant-bidding have provoked rifts instead. Here is where Downing Street wants Whitehall to bash heads together and where its dreams of a new form of delivery will be tested.

"At the beginning, people kept saying this way of working is going to open up a can of worms," Dr Whalley says. "But opening cans of worms is what this has been about, and thats why weve had such a high level of parental involvement."

The list of partners involved in the Corby Sure Start, from the Pen Green Centre to Northants county council, social services and the health authority to local schools and childminders, is enough to make the eyes glaze over with agency fatigue. The difference from past initiatives, however, is the prime role played by parents, who themselves conducted the initial survey asking what was needed.

Childcare gaps

The research found that, for the 898 families with children under four in the projects catchment area, priorities included local and accessible facilities to allow parents with young children to meet, play, study and take a break from home pressures.

The study also identified gaps in childcare, aggravated by the nine different shift patterns practised by the factories such as Weetabix, Asda and Finnegans Famous Cakes whose low-paid agency jobs have replaced steel manufacturing. Family life for youngsters was found to be pockmarked by major illness, change of address or job, divorce, unemployment or parental access problems, while health problems, child mortality and domestic violence were all significantly above the national average.

The consultation was vital, according to project manager Bernie Caffrey, if Sure Start was to be more than another welfare sticking plaster. "Sure Start is working when parents dont feel they are being done to, that they are just recipients of welfare state handouts, but that they and their community have ownership of what is going on."

The results of the process include daily drop-in sessions with play activities for children and advice for parents on parenting and child behaviour; respite care for 80 families; "baby matters" groups with baby massage, clinics and discussions; a safety equipment loan scheme; reading, story-telling and computing sessions; and weekly advice sessions covering legal help, housing, welfare and services for children with special needs.

All are offered not only at Pen Green but at newly opened satellite centres in a house and flat on two Corby estates beset by crime, drug problems and vandalism. At Wick Close House, opened in January 2000, one drop-in session is punctuated by the whoops of toddlers pedalling round the yard and others miraculously demanding the healthy fruit and cracker snacks on offer. Mothers, including 33-year-old Rachel Walker, whose five children range from 15 to one, can all recite by heart the text of one childrens book, "Brown bear, brown bear, what do you hear?"

"Id be lost without this place, really," says Rachel, a daily inhabitant of the Wick Close sofa who got educational support for her autistic son with the help of staff at the centre. "The kids went on a trip to the seaside and it was the first time they had seen the sea. They love the reading, the toys  I think they like the snacks best." At Ripley Walk, a flat also equipped with toys and comfortable armchairs, lone parent Stef Joseph  studying to be a creche worker with Sure Start encouragement  enthuses: "The centre is brilliant, its like a second home. Ive met neighbours here I never met without it."

Breadline wages

The parents' - and workers' - enthusiasm is genuine, though the alleviation of the poverty affecting their children must depend as much on the breadline wages paid by many local employers as on the help even well-funded support services can give. Sure Start can help harness parents' aspirations through their children, but it is difficult to see how those youngsters will ultimately move out of the poverty trap without other interventions to boost employment and training.

For those running the government's programmes, the strength of the latest initiatives is that they build on existing successes ground down over the under-funded Tory years.

Trevor Chandler, head of the Pen Green centre, points to its track record of integrating its services and listening to parents, saying: "The government initiatives have helped us develop what we were doing anyway, allowing us to do it in a more comprehensive way."

Whether or not the government gets the credit it deserves, the pressure to make the programmes work is huge. Despite the efforts of numerous agencies and so many past aid programmes residents are experience "zone fatigue", Corby is still struggling.

"We are not going to get this money again if we don't make it work this time," says Dr Whalley. "It has got to be grounded in what the community wants."

"We are not going to get this money again if we don't make it work this time," says Dr Whalley. "It has got to be grounded in what the community wants."

fields.headline: Gerrard injury worry for England
fields.trailText: There was mixed fitness news from the England camp today after Steven Gerrard succumbed to another back injury which prevented him from training, just as David Seaman finally returned between the posts.
fields.body:
There was mixed fitness news from the England camp today after Steven Gerrard succumbed to another back injury which prevented him from training, just as David Seaman finally returned between the posts.

Gerrard woke this morning with a stiff back, only 24 hours after claiming he expected to be fit for this Saturday's crucial World Cup match with Finland at Anfield. The Liverpool midfielder took no part in the day's training, but he did do light jogging, completing a few laps of the pitch in the company of the England medical team.

"Clearly the coaching staff and medical staff are being very careful with Steven because everyone is fully aware of his injury history," said FA spokesman Adrian Bevington today. "He will be monitored and reassessed before and during training tomorrow morning and then Mr Eriksson will give an update on his injury position on Friday afternoon."

Gerrard's place in Saturday's team must now be doubtful, particularly considering Sven-Goran Eriksson's insistence that players must train 48 hours before a match if they are to be considered for selection.

No such worries for Arsenal keeper Seaman, however, who came through his training session unscathed. Seaman had been out with a back inflammation had forced him to miss Arsenal's Premiership encounter with Aston Villa on Sunday. But Bevington said: "David took part in a full session today without any problems and he will train again tomorrow."

webTitle: French teacher tells of racist abuse by schoolchildren

fields.headline: French teacher tells of racist abuse by schoolchildren
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Frederique Ganneval quit her job over the stress of being racially abused by her pupils for being French, an industrial tribunal heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Frederique Ganneval quit her job over the stress of being racially abused by her pupils for being French, an industrial tribunal heard yesterday.

Miss Ganneval, 33, a teacher, claimed she often had insults hurled at her by children in and out of the classroom. She was repeatedly called a "fucking frog" and a "French whore" by pupils at Sir Charles Lucas School in Colchester, Essex. But she told the hearing none of the children involved was ever punished, though she made numerous reports.

Miss Ganneval who taught French at the school for nearly two years said she also had her car vandalised by pupils.

She was eventually diagnosed as suffering from anxiety and depression, she told the hearing in Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk. Her GP advised her to resign and she did so last June.

Miss Ganneval has now launched a legal battle for compensation from the school and Essex county council. She claims she was constructively dismissed because she was a victim of racial discrimination, and is demanding compensation for abuse suffered as well as for loss of earnings.

Miss Ganneval told the tribunal the abuse started soon after she joined the school on a temporary posting in September 1998 before she got her permanent job there in January 1999.

Miss Ganneval said the school's head teacher, Caroline Hobbs, reacted to her initial complaints by holding an assembly about racism.

She said that in July 1999 she was circled by pupils riding bicycles and yelling racist abuse as she left the school. When she reported the incident, she was simply advised not to walk back to her car alone.

Her friend Maria Cascon, a Spanish teacher at her former school in Ipswich, said she remained friendly with Miss Ganneval after she got her job in Colchester and witnessed the abuse she had to put up with when she visited her and they went for a walk in the town.

The hearing was adjourned to a later date.

fields.headline: PSG riled by Uefa ban
fields.trailText: Paris St-Germain are considering an appeal after Uefa gave them a hefty fine and a ban on playing their next three European games at the Parc des Princes because of crowd trouble at their Champions League match against Galatasaray last week.
fields.body:
Paris St-Germain are considering an appeal after Uefa gave them a hefty fine and a ban on playing their next three European games at the Parc des Princes because of crowd trouble at their Champions League match against Galatasaray last week.

Crowd disturbances broke out at half-time, and the match was stopped for 26 minutes following a second-half pitch invasion. More than 50 spectators were injured and 17 hospitalised. PSG were fined 1m Swiss francs, and Galatasaray 200,000 (£82,000), "given the Turkish club's lack of cooperation in controlling their fans".

In a statement released through their website, PSG said: "The club understand Uefa must take strong and exemplary measures to avoid
new offences. But the responsibility of the Turkish fans has not been taken enough into account. We must recall the referee decided to stop the match because of the invasion of the pitch by Turkish fans."

Uefa said PSG's next three European games would have to be played at least 300 kilometres from Paris. PSV Eindhoven must play their next European home match at least 100km from the Philips stadium after crowd trouble during their Uefa Cup fixture against Kaiserslautern.

Another unhappy French club, St-Etienne, will appeal to the French National Olympic Committee today against a seven-point penalty for fielding players with fake European Union passports.

They are in danger of relegation from the first division after the French league's ruling.
The punishment was confirmed on appeal on March 2 but Monaco and Metz, found guilty of the same offence, were not given a points penalty.

The Hibernian manager Alex McLeish yesterday completed the signing of the 31-year-old French midfielder Frédéric Arpinon on a free transfer, but denied that he had been signed as a replacement for Russell Latapy, who will quit the Edinburgh outfit when his contract expires at the end of the season.

Airdrie's prospective manager Ian McCall claims he could take the club into the Scottish Premier League within three years. McCall is being lined up as the Diamonds' new boss by a consortium who are in talks, which must be concluded this week, with the liquidators KPMG about taking over the First Division club.

webTitle: Foot and mouth spreads to Ireland

fields.headline: Foot and mouth spreads to Ireland
fields.standfirst:
• First case in the republic
• UK farmers warned to look out for bombs

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: A case of foot and mouth disease was confirmed in the Irish Republic today for the first time since the outbreak started in Britain.
fields.body:
A case of foot and mouth disease was confirmed in the Irish Republic today for the first time since the outbreak started in Britain.

Officials from the department of agriculture across the border in Northern Ireland were engaged in emergency talks today as evidence of the disease was confirmed in County Louth.

It had been hoped that restrictions on the movement of animals could be eased given the length of time elapsed since Northern Ireland's single case of the disease was uncovered at a farm in south Armagh. But today's confirmation falls within the surveillance zone around the farm at Meigh.

Irish agriculture minister Brid Rodgers was expected to brief the Stormont executive on the developments later today.

It comes as a severe blow to a country which had desperately battled to remain disease-free.

As well as banning major sporting fixtures on home soil, the Irish government also banned horseracing teams from travelling to Britain and has been openly critical of Britain's handling of the crisis.

The Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, told the country's parliament: "I have to inform the House that the results of two of the tests have proved positive. This is a major disappointment, given the intensity of efforts of all sections of society here to keep the disease out of Ireland."

He said the outbreak - at Jenkinstown, close to the Co Louth border with Northern Ireland - meant the republic had to prepare as soon as possible on how to handle the disease at national level.

Opposition parties in the Dail pledged full support for all government efforts to combat the disease.

In Britain, the number of cases stood at 435 overnight with 40 more cases confirmed yesterday. The environment minister, Michael Meacher, warned the disease may run into May and beyond.

The first cull of apparently healthy animals took place today.

Around 1,300 animals at a farm at Dornock, near Annan, Dumfries and Galloway, were taken to a disinfected slaughterhouse where they were being killed on the grounds that they were within two miles of an infected farm.

 Farmers have been warned to beware of possible letterbomb attacks by animal welfare extremists enraged by the cull of healthy animals. The National Farmers' Union has circulated the warning through its regional offices.

"They're telling us to be aware of any unexpected packages which may arrive, and not to open them if we have any doubts. It seems they have been told that anyone speaking out in favour of the cordon sanitaire operation could be getting some unwelcome attention," said Marilyn Ivings, an Oxfordshire farmer.

The warning does not appear to be based on specific threats by militants, or on police intelligence, but rather on a general fear that the crisis has inflamed opinion. "Obviously with the cull going on, some animal activists don't support it, so we have been telling our people to be on the lookout," said a spokeswoman.
