fields.headline: Russia reacts angrily to 'spy' expulsions
fields.standfirst: High-ranking but anonymous Kremlin sources consider the US expulsions to be a hostile act that could have damaging repercussions for relations between the two superpowers, writes Amelia Gentleman
fields.trailText: High-ranking but anonymous Kremlin sources consider the US expulsions to be a hostile act that could have damaging repercussions for relations between the two superpowers, writes Amelia Gentleman
fields.body:
Russia reacted with anger to news that Washington was on the brink of expelling around 50 Russian diplomats, describing the reports as evidence of the resurrection of cold war "spy mania".

High-ranking but anonymous Kremlin sources said that if the reports proved to be true, Moscow would consider it "an extremely hostile act" that would have "inevitable consequences" for Russian-US relations. Undisclosed security sources told one Russian news agency that the Kremlin could retaliate by expelling "hundreds" of US embassy officials.

The only official response from the Kremlin was issued by President Vladimir Putin's foreign policy advisor Sergei Prikhodko, who said: "If the reports from Washington are true, this will cause deep regret". "Any kind of spy-mania campaign and hunting for enemies are a regrettable relapse into a cold war era."

The issue was set to be debated in the Russian Duma later, as part of a more general debate on the state of US-Russian relations; the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, said that his department would only make an official statement once the position had been carefully studied.

Irina Khakamada, one of the leaders of Russia's Union of Right Forces political faction, said that the public way in which events had been handled in America - with the media informed of the developing expulsion row - was a sign that relations between Russia and the US were seriously deteriorating.

"In practice, the handling of such spy matters between countries has traditionally been done in secret. If these relations are made public - then that is one of the signs of a cooling relationship, in this case between America and Russia," she said.

The communist speaker of the Duma, Gennady Seleznyov, said tit-for-tat expulsions were expected. "We are establishing what were the reasons behind this and who these people were. I think that once this is done, believe me, we will find a reason for the expulsion of exactly the same number of diplomats."

The US ambassador to Moscow, James Collins, visited the foreign ministry this morning for brief talks on bilateral relations, but declined to make any comments to reporters after the meeting.

The affair comes as the latest and most dramatic example of strained relations between the new US administration and Mr Putin's government.

In the last few days Russia's decision to press ahead with military cooperation with Iran prompted strongly voiced disapproval from America. The Russian foreign ministry reacted to this by accusing the Pentagon of reverting to confrontational cold war language.

Although it drew back from commenting on the developing spy scandal, the Russian foreign ministry did issue a statement on a separate row developing between the two countries, angrily denouncing a US decision to meet representatives from the breakaway region of Chechnya as an "unfriendly step".

"We are frankly surprised by how stubbornly the American side insists on having meetings with representatives of the Chechen terrorists," a statement read. "Official contacts with Chechen terrorists are an openly, unfriendly move and prompt us to question its true intent."

In an interview published in several newspapers today to mark the end of Mr Putin's first year in charge, the president remarked that the turbulent relations between the two countries should not be over-dramatised. "As for the new US administration's policy towards Russia, it's not worth such drama. In any country a new leadership always rethinks the former policies."

fields.trailText: March 23: The Daily Mail has scooped this year's British Press Awards newspaper of the year award.
fields.body:
The Daily Mail has scooped this year's British Press Awards newspaper of the year award.

The NUJ has written a stiff letter to the editorial board of Express Newspapers to protest at perceived editorial changes, after allegations that the Northern & Shell boss intervened in editorial matters.

The Audit Bureau of Circulations is under fire after a "climbdown" in a ruling which could have resulted in all Emap's car magazines being banned from ABC membership.

A study of 140 journalists who have reported from war zones will show they have experienced post-traumatic stress syndrome similar to that of soldiers in combat.

The BBC is said to be mulling over a new current affairs show called Four by Four, which will showcase people's different points of view.

fields.headline: Procter & Gamble cuts 9% of workforce
fields.trailText: 5pm: Procter & Gamble is taking the axe to 9% of its workforce with the loss of 9,600 jobs, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Procter & Gamble is taking the axe to 9% of its workforce with the loss of 9,600 jobs.

P&G's marketing departments around the world are expected to be hit hard by the job cuts.

The redundancies come on top of measures already taken by the household goods giant to streamline its operations to focus on core brands.

In combination with the cuts already outlined under P&G's restructuring programme, today's announcement means the company will shed 17,400 jobs in total.

P&G says the new measures will further reduce overheads and manufacturing costs.

It expects to make savings of £277m-£416m after-tax each year by financial year 2003/04.

Of the 9,600 jobs to be lost - 40% will come from the US and 60% from its operations around the world.

Two-thirds of the reductions will come from non-manufacturing roles across all levels - likely to include marketeers - and a third will come from manufacturing projects.

"This program is right for the long-term health of our business and is the next step in our plan to restore long-term growth.

"It's one element of a three-part growth plan to focus on big brands and big opportunities, consistently deliver superior consumer value, and create a more cost-competitive, productive organisation," said P&G president and chief executive A G Lafley.

fields.body:
The Chicago Tribune has no doubt that the mass expulsion is linked with the interrogation of Robert Hanssen, the senior FBI agent sensationally arrested last month and accused of spying for the Soviet Union and Russia.

It predicts that US embassy staff in Moscow will be kicked out, in the time-honoured tit-for-tat tradition: "But more significantly, officials said, the action signals a tougher line by the new US administration on what is seen as vastly expanded Russian intelligence gathering activity in the United States, marked most recently by the arrest of Hanssen, a senior FBI counterintelligence official charged with spying for the Soviets and then the Russians for 15 years."

The Tribune offers a splendidly colloquial comment by an unnamed US official who says that the larger batch of Russians to be expelled will not formally be declared persona non grata, but will be "given a couple of months to clean out their lockers and hit the showers".

The Los Angeles Times notes a sharp deterioration in US-Russian relations: "Just Tuesday, the Russian foreign ministry reacted angrily to remarks by US defence secretary Donald H Rumsfeld, who called Russia "an active proliferator" because of its exports of rocket and nuclear technology to states such as Iran and North Korea. The Russian government accused Washington of making 'groundless, cold war-style accusations' and suggested that the new US administration had not adjusted to an era of nonconfrontation with Russia."

In the capital, the Washington Post detects that the expulsions fit "a pattern of hard-line foreign policy choices by the Bush administration. Last week, President Bush took a tough stance against North Korea, indicating that the United States was not eager to pursue missile talks. The administration also has signaled that it intends to push ahead with plans for missile defence despite opposition from Russia, China and some European allies."

The New York Times also notes a new hostile tone in the Bush administration's dealings with Russia: "Just last weekend, defence secretary Donald H Rumsfeld accused Moscow of heavy involvement in spreading weapons to dangerous nations, while his deputy, Paul Wolfowitz, said that the Russians 'seem to be willing to sell anything to anyone for money'. Russian officials angrily responded that the charges were reminiscent of the cold war."

The Boston Globe tries to unravel the murky skein of events which led to the expulsions: "FBI officials have said that they received word last fall of a spy within their ranks. In October, a senior Russian diplomat at the United Nations, Sergei Tretyakov, defected with his family to the United States. Several counterintelligence analysts have speculated that Tretyakov led the Americans eventually to Hanssen, but FBI director Louis J Freeh has denied this."

In President Bush's home state of Texas, the Houston Chronicle reports that at least one Russian embassy official has already left the USA: "Russia last week hurriedly recalled press attaché Vladimir Frolov from its embassy in the United States amid speculation that he was involved in espionage and was a handler for Robert Hanssen, a veteran FBI agent accused of spying for Moscow. Although the expulsions ordered Wednesday were triggered by Hanssen's arrest on Feb. 18, it was not clear whether those being expelled were directly linked to him, a source said."

The racy tabloid New York Post headlines the expulsion of "Russkie" spies. The paper notes that the Russians have been told to reduce their diplomatic establishment to the same size as the American contingent in Moscow.

But, it goes on, "The Post's sources said that administration officials took the drastic action because the Hanssen case showed them how deeply the Kremlin had penetrated US intelligence. And they no longer have confidence in their ability to monitor Russian spy activities in the United States, the sources added."

fields.headline: PR Week
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 23
fields.trailText: The National Clinical Assessment Authority has named its first director of communications.
fields.body:
The health watchdog set up in the aftermath of the Dr Harold Shipman trial, the National Clinical Assessment Authority, has named its first director of communications as Kate Cinamon.

Organisers of Bejing's bid to host the 2008 Olympics are searching for a PR agency to help improve China's image in Europe.

Nintendo Europe has appointed Cake to handle pan-European consumer and corporate PR.

Radio Times gas picked Mission 21 to handle its PR.

British Airways World Cargo has picked Golin Harris London to handle corporate PR.

The Ministry of Defence has baffled the defence lobbying sector by issuing guidelines on acceptable behaviour in securing a lucrative government contract.

Avalon PR, the agency behind Popstars, is to handle media relations for a European tour by Playboy founder Hugh Hefner.

Staff at the government-backed UK Online centres are to be trained in PR techniques to help promote the service.

fields.headline: BBC hits back in row over Kray film
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: The BBC is adamant that Reggie Kray's relatives will not benefit from next week's documentary about him, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC says it has been given written assurances by the production company behind next week's BBC1 documentary featuring Reggie Kray's last interview that no licence fee money will go to relatives of the legendary gangster.

The corporation was responding to fierce criticism following reports it has paid up to £280,000 for a documentary that includes a "revelatory" death-bed interview with Kray.

Kray, who died last year of cancer, had been approached directly by several broadcasters for a final interview.

These included ITV, which was interested in doing a Tonight special report on the east end criminal.

The BBC deal has also become embroiled in controversy because the documentary is executive produced by Bill Curbishley, a friend of Reggie's widow, Roberta Kray.

Reggie Kray - The Final Word, which is due to go out next Thursday on BBC1, has been made by independent producer Mission Television.

"Mission have confirmed in writing to us that no money was paid to Reggie or Roberta," a BBC spokeswoman said.

BBC producer guidelines allow for the payment of disturbance fees, which involve sums usually not exceeding £400, to cover the costs and lost earnings of people contributing to documentaries.

But the BBC spokeswoman insisted the Krays had not even received this payment. "Reggie and Roberta were paid nothing - not even a disturbance fee."

However, she did not know the details of the contract for Mr Curbishley, who arranged the deathbed interview with Reggie and took it to Mission TV.

Mr Curbishley served a prison sentence in the 1960s for armed robbery before moving into the music business.

The spokeswoman could not comment on whether he had been paid.

But the spokeswoman stressed that while he would have an executive producer credit for the documentary Mr Curbishley had not had editorial control over its content.

"He had no editorial involvement in the content of programme," the spokeswoman said.

"He is credited as an executive producer in the contract because he set up the interview."

The film's executive producer is deputy controller of documentaries and investigations David Mortimer.

"He has editorial responsibility for the film," the spokeswoman said.

She added that reports that the BBC paid £280,000 to Mission TV for the Kray documentary were "on the high side".

The ball park figure for similar length documentaries was £150,000-£200,000, she said.

fields.headline: Open to the elements
fields.standfirst: Ayurveda, one of the oldest medical systems in the world, is suddenly the next big thing in alternative health. Hollywood celebs and wealthy Brits are all talking about their 'doshas'.  Laura Barton finds out what it's all about
fields.trailText: Ayurveda, one of the oldest medical systems in the world, is suddenly the next big thing in alternative health. Hollywood celebs and wealthy Brits are all talking about their 'doshas'. Laura Barton finds out what it's all about.
fields.body:
Gopi Warrier is taking my pulse. We are speeding along in the back of a car, Regent's Park is blurring past, brilliant in the February sunshine. Do I like hot or cold weather, he asks. How do I feel if I have missed my lunch? Or if I'm too hot? What sort of illnesses do I suffer? Am I close to my family? Warrier, chairman of the Ayurvedic Company in Great Britain, is trying to assess my dosha, in a casual, lunchtime sort of a way. He concludes I am vata-kapha.

It's nice to know one has a dosha: they are, after all, this season's must-have accessory. The sort of clutch-bag of the medical world. Madonna, Demi Moore and Gemma Kidd have all been flaunting theirs. The doe-eyed supermodel Christy Turlington has even launched Sundari, a beauty range based on Ayurveda.

Warrier looks appalled by the sudden Ayurveda hysteria. He would rather it were not treated as the latest item on the cosmetic counter to be listed in the stockists pages of Vogue and Cosmo, alongside anti-cellulite creams and bio-thermal wraps. He raises his head a little defiantly. "Ayurveda should be sacred and noble, not practised by beauty therapists on the high street," he says.

Ayurveda, indeed, has a sacred and noble history. Part of the Vedas, the divine texts of Hinduism, it dates back 3,500 to 4,000 years, and is deemed to be the world's oldest complete medical system. Ayurveda's literal translation is "the science of life", and its aim is not only to treat ailments symptomatically but to prevent illness and sustain life. Its roots are intertwined with those of yoga and meditation, and both play a fundamental role in ayurvedic treatment.

The essential belief of Ayurveda is that the entire universe, from stag beetles to tea roses, is made up of five elements: air, fire, water, earth and ether - collectively termed panchamahabhutas - and the three doshas: vata, pitta and kapha. The theory is that we can achieve perfect health by balancing the three within ourselves.

The three doshas are, apparently, like ingredients or humours, although Warrier says that the ayurvedic notion of humours pre-dates that of the Greeks. Doshas dictate everything about us, from the colour of our hair to the type of illnesses we suffer. They are even responsible for the foods we crave, our relationships and the things we like to do. We all contain elements of vata, pitta and kapha, but generally we have one - or sometimes two - dominant doshas.

Roughly speaking, vata corresponds to air, pitta is fire and kapha is water. Vata's physiological role is said to be related to the body's energy and nervous system; pitta governs digestion and metabolism; kapha oversees phlegm, moisture and lymphatics. Exacerbation of a particular dosha, through eating the wrong foods or living the wrong physical or emotional lifestyle, will lead to illness.

Taking the pulse is the key to determining your dosha. The physician will examine the radial artery pulse, found at the root of the thumb, and, if healthy, it will seem strong and regular. Ayurvedic practitioners compare the unhealthy pulse to the movements of particular creatures. A vata pulse resembles the path of a snake, swift and thread-like; the pitta pulse is frog-like and erratic; the kapha pulse is at a deeper, swan-like pace.

In July, the first ayurvedic hospital outside India opened in Stamford Brook, west London. Since then, Warrier says, it has received more than 100,000 inquiries, and has treated more than 500 people. Admission generally requires a letter from a GP, but Warrier says that it is increasingly treating people who have found the hospital of their own accord. He estimates that treatments cost between £500 and £1,000 a day, not counting additional costs such as food and board. Perhaps the most surprising thing about the Ayurvedic hospital, therefore, is that it operates as a charity, providing treatment free of charge.

At present there are 30 beds in the hospital, with seven ayurvedic physicians, three western GPs and six therapists in attendance. It offers treatments such as shirodhara (herbal oil dripped on to the head), vasti (enema using medicated oils) and abhangya (herbal body massage) for all manner of complaints including skin diseases, rheumatoid arthritis, and depression. A typical ayurvedic assessment would include an initial diagnosis. Subsequent treatment might include herbal medicines, massage, steam bath or even detox by panchakarma.

Warrier believes that ayurvedic products should only be available from established manufacturers, and lambasts western herbal companies that sell products he says that have no clinical or toxicological proof of effectiveness. "If champagne can only come from the Champagne region of France, then ayurvedic medicines should only come from the parts of the world which have traditionally practised Ayurveda. Ayurvedic practitioners should be properly trained, otherwise it is the theft of an intellectual property and exploitation of a developing country."

This is Warrier's other bugbear. In India, ayurvedic doctors must obtain a university degree to qualify. "In the west you get a lot of charlatans," he says. "People who go to India for a massage and come back claiming to be ayurvedic therapists." To this end, a three-year BA in ayurvedic studies has been launched at Thames Valley University. The course includes the fundamentals of anatomy, physiology, botany and the pharmacopoeia of Ayurveda, and practical training in detoxification, yoga and meditation.

There are those who think it is all rubbish. A report last November by the House of Lords select committee on science and technology concluded that alternative and complementary therapies had little evidence to support their beneficial claims. Indeed, the report attacked Ayurveda and Chinese medicines. "They didn't even have the decency to talk to us," Warrier says, wielding his own clinical evidence. He believes it is the bogus practitioners who have earned Ayurveda a dubious reputation, and claims that all herbal medicines used at the hospital conform to government regulations.

Warrier stuffs my hands full of samples of ayurvedic medicines and oils, so that all the way home my handbag rattles with capsules, hair oil, burn cream and massage oil. It is a day or two before I use them. They sit on my desk in glass bottles labelled "Sri" and tubs saying "Kof-N-Kold". It is hard to describe how the shampoo smells; sort of like the taste of chewed grass - but it leaves my hair soft. The massage oil needs to be warmed before use, but it is more than worth all the messing about in the kitchen. And the Kof-N-Kold tablets have guarded me in a week in which all of my flatmates have succumbed to the sneezes.

Which body type are you? Identify your dosha

Vata
Elements: air and space

Vata people are restless with twitchy, active minds. They tend to be slightly built, a little pigeon-chested, and have dull, dark hair and eyes. Their skin is dry and rough, sometimes chapped. Vatas are indecisive, erratic and emotionally insecure. They are easily anxious, talk quickly and have poor memories. Vata types suffer from stiff joints, rheumatic problems and constipation. They also have a tendency towards insomnia and depression. They make good artists and enjoy travelling, plays, stories and dancing. Their dreams are shifting and nightmarish. Vatas are solitary and rebellious. Fond of sweet foods, they should try to eat regularly, using spices such as cumin, fennel and ginger and steering clear of cold foods and coffee.

Kapha
Elements: water and earth

Kapha types are big-boned, often overweight, with a pale, smooth complexion. Their hair is lustrous and wavy and their eyes wide and attractive. A kapha needs a lot of sleep, has a rational mentality and speaks and moves slowly. These are calm, loyal people who enjoy sailing, business matters and flowers. Emotionally they are very secure, and experience romantic, sentimental dreams. Kaphas can suffer from sinus problems, excessive mucus, lethargy and nausea. Kapha people should avoid oily, unctuous foods, dairy products, sugar and meat. Hot spices such as cayenne and cinnamon will help improve the metabolism. Basil will stimulate the mind.

Pitta
Elements: fire and water

Pitta people are of average build and have a ruddy complexion or red hair, with moles, freckles or acne. They tend to go grey or bald early in life, and often have green or very piercing eyes. They are intense, argumentative and precise, with a critical, sharp intelligence. They make good leaders. At their worst they can be irritable and passionately angry. Pitta types enjoy sports, hunting and politics, and have colourful, vivid dreams. They should avoid foods such as chillies, sesame oil, pepper and alcohol, which are too sour, pungent or salty. Fennel and mint will soothe pittas.

webTitle: Dr Ann Robinson answers your queries

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.standfirst: Dr Ann Robinson  on prostatitis, excessive sweating and getting fit without jogging
fields.trailText: On prostatitis, excessive sweating and getting fit without jogging.
fields.body:
Pelvic pain

For two years I have suffered from prostatitis and been given antibiotics. It helps for a while, then the symptoms return. Have you any advice?

For those who don't know, the symptoms you refer to are pain when passing urine, a strong urge to urinate frequently, pain when ejaculating and generalised pelvic pain felt in, around and above the penis, and deep inside the back passage. Any man can have a one-off bout, usually due to a urinary tract infection in which bugs from the bladder get into the prostate. This is an acute bacterial prostatitis, and can be cleared up with antibiotics.

If you're very prone to recurrent urinary tract infections or your immunity is impaired, you may get several bouts of prostatitis (aka chronic bacterial prostatitis); each time there will be bacteria in your urine and antibiotics will work. Bacterial prostatitis is, however, quite rare. Far commoner is chronic pelvic pain syndrome, in which there are no bacteria in your urine or prostate but the same upsetting symptoms. Antibiotics don't usually work. The prostate gland is inflamed, probably because urine refluxes into it. Hot baths and ejaculating often help.

Drugs that help to shrink enlarged prostates (eg finasteride) and painkillers are worth a try. Treatments ranging from pollen extract pills to microwaving the prostate via a probe inserted through the penis have been tried. Hot and bothered

This may sound like a trivial complaint, but I am completely unable to cope with being hot. webTitle: Dea Birkett meets IVF doctor Ian Craft

fields.headline: The crafty professor
fields.standfirst: When he helped a 60-year-old woman get pregnant, Ian Craft became Britain's most controversial IVF doctor. Now he's back in the news again.  Dea Birkett meets him
fields.trailText: When he helped a 60-year-old woman get pregnant, Ian Craft became Britain's most controversial IVF doctor. Now he's back in the news again. Dea Birkett meets him.
fields.body:
"Have You Asked About Laser Assisted Hatching?" The notice hangs over the leather sofa, between the marble busts and overlarge arrangement of dried flowers. Tasselled curtains frame a mighty stone fireplace in which flickers a fake fire. All is the quiet of soft furnishings.

Then into this calm scuttles our protagonist, a small silver-haired gentleman, with baby-pink puffy skin that seems as if it has never seen the sun. He is dressed in what could be his old school uniform - a red striped tie, maroon sweater and permacrease trousers - and waves a blue spotted handkerchief. "Can I be of assistance to you?" he begs, his leather-gloved hands hovering eagerly over my hugely pregnant belly. Then, sensing my alarm and presuming it's to do with the gloves, he adds, "I have some rubber ones as well."

The great advantage, he explains, is that he - Professor Ian Craft - is one of the few obstetricians who do their own epidurals: "I could do yours." I hope he's joking. I am here, after all, as a journalist, even if a heavily pregnant one. "Natural conception?" he asks. "Well ..." I stutter.

The small crowd in the waiting room are stony-faced. There's the infertile patient with her sister, whose hand she is holding tightly, as if to prevent her tumbling from the soft leather sofa. There's the egg donor with her mother, both extremely overweight. And there's the professor, who hurries me through to a larger room next door, with rather nice flock wallpaper, where a bench is lined with a row of fearsome-looking instruments, all metal, all sharp. If it wasn't for the Assisted Hatching notice, we could be characters from a real-life game of Cluedo, and one of these sinister, shiny instruments could be the murder weapon.

But, despite appearances, this is not the set for an Agatha Christie mystery. It's the London Fertility Centre in Harley Street, where life is created, not destroyed. This room, the professor explains, is where the eggs are removed. The fat woman will be coming in here soon.

We scurry back into the waiting room, where the small cast of characters has now been joined by a doctor dressed entirely in surgeon's greens, whom the infertile woman is hugging. Our return is so the professor can flick through the pages of today's Daily Mail, which lies on the central carved table, searching for any mention of his name.

The Mail has had a bit of a thing about the professor since 1997, when he treated Britain's oldest mother, Elizabeth Buttle, who gave birth at 60 after lying about her age. Last year his clinic knowingly treated 56-year-old Lynne Bezant with donor eggs, making her Britain's oldest mother of twins. The donor has now claimed in the Mail that she requested that her eggs went to a younger woman, and is threatening to sue. Behind almost every controversial case concerning reproductive technology emerges the name of Professor Craft.

Unlike his rivals in the profession, he remains remarkably hands-on. He boasts that he performed 168 embryo transfers last year. In the hush of his clinic, under his bird-like blue eyes, the untreatable are treated. The lepers of the infertility world come to be warmed by the fire in his waiting room. For here, things happen that other clinics refuse to contemplate.

This is the philosophy of reproduction according to Professor Craft. On surrogacy: "When you are born without a uterus and you sometimes haven't got a vagina, or you've only got the bottom one third of it ... they're not freaks. Just the pack of cards they had was slightly different from normal. They could reproduce very successfully from surrogacy." On implanting multiple embryos: "If a woman had got six embryos, and she's 41, I'd be prepared to put them in. The chance of her having triplets is not zero, but almost zero. But she's more likely to have the only child she can ever have." On sex selection: "I cannot see that it would terribly unbalance society. If one day a high-street pharmacist found a kit which effectively allowed only the male semen to be used, is this government going to ban it?"

We have walked across the road, to his mews, as the professor cannot sit still; his body and brain flutter around his small home. "I think I'm a sympathetic person to women. I think they have much more of a cross to bear in life than men, right? If men had to menstruate, civilisation would have stopped, it would have stopped. ... I tend to get passionate inside. Whether it's about music, opera, birdwatching, you know. That's me. I'm passionate about things. I stand up for principles ... Now going back to your question about number of embryos ..." "Well ..." I say, and again get no further.

Sixty-three-year-old Ian Logan Craft is ripe for amateur psychoanalysis, and everyone has their pet theory as to why Crafty, as those in the profession call him, is as he is. One insider puts it down to his failing the 11-plus; since then, he has been determined to prove himself. Another said he is driven by a need to impress his father, a Barclays bank official and devout Methodist who died two years ago. So here's my lowly attempt at dissecting the professor's thought processes: he's lonely.

The professor lives by himself in uncontrolled clutter, having separated from his wife Jackie six years ago. But, as all lonely people, he is determined to prove he isn't lonely at all. In fact, I will be amazed at how full of friendship and activity his life is. He shows me photos of his two grandchildren, propped up next to those of the first triplets born through IVF 17 years ago - a Craft production. Among the chaos of his home, every invitation he has ever received is on display. He takes down a card from a friend and reads it to me, to demonstrate how loved he is. It is three years old.

He's a joiner. He belongs to The Zoological Society, the RNLI, English Heritage and the Walpole Society, and is a Patron of British Art at Tate Britain. But when I ask him what it means to be a patron, he's not sure. "I like artistic things. I'm a life member of Durham Cathedral. I'm trying at the moment to help the Deaf Blind Association. I go to Glyndebourne because I love music. I went to the proms 43 times last year. I've seen the Tempest twice. I'm going out tonight. There's a symphony written for me. In fact, there's a picture of a human embryo on the front of the CD." I note that the piles of junk mail are all opened. A less lonely person would put them straight in the bin. This paper clutter makes him feel as if he's in demand.

I have other evidence to support my theory. He wanted me to like him. In fact, he desperately wanted me to like him. He was determined to put his best side forward. "I just want to make people happy. I've always loved that old Scottish song, 'If I can help someone as I'm passing along, my life will not be in vain.' " But my analysis is confounded by the simple fact that he does so much to affront others. He doesn't set out to win friends and influence people; he knowingly sets out to offend. Despite his high success rate, he has no supporters in the small world of reproductive technology.

Most regard him as a hurdle towards wider acceptance of new techniques. He goes too far, they say, leading to legislation being enacted to prevent his kind of extreme practices. If he didn't do what he did, then there would not be the caution towards assisted conception that exists today.

But there is another way of looking at it. Once the tabloids have splashed on a 56-year-old having twins, they cannot retell the tale. If, next month, a 52-year-old has twins, it's no longer news. The reproductive goalposts have shifted. Professor Craft sets the pace and others trot along behind. Without his risk-taking, we would still all be suspicious of even simple IVF on a 30-year-old. During the debate over the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act 1990, a move to limit treatment to married couples was defeated by a single vote.

Already the professor is late for his next patient, for whom he is probably their best and last chance. But he doesn't want to leave me. I try to extricate myself by going to the toilet, but he follows me in. "I'm just very innovative. You pay a price for being a pioneer," he says as I wash my hands.

By the time I'm back at my desk, there's an email waiting. "Dear Dea, It was good to see you this morning ... If you want me to come and put the epidural in, please call ... it was good to talk. Yours sincerely, Professor Ian Craft, FRCS, FRCOG."

webTitle: Sarah Boseley on meeting our death

fields.headline: Sarah Boseley
fields.standfirst: On why we are so unprepared to meet our deaths, and the epidemic of meningitis in Burkina Faso
fields.trailText: On why we are so unprepared to meet our deaths, and the epidemic of meningitis in Burkina Faso.
fields.body:
The year before he died, inspired by Californian sunshine and hallucinatory substances, Aldous Huxley wrote a counterpoint to Brave New World. His last novel, Island, describes a remote and idyllic civilisation of happiness, peace and harmony underpinned by a fusion of Buddhism, mind-altering drugs, free love, self-knowledge and other heady philosophies that were taking off in the early 60s.

For 21st-century tastes, Island is probably unpalatably sentimental and idealistic, but one episode has lingered in my mind. It is the story of a woman's death and her attempt, aided by her family, not to block out what is happening with painkillers, tubes and curtains, but to be fully aware of her life coming to an end.

It's not the quasi-religious experience that stayed with me, but the notion of looking death in the face and being prepared for. Because we are not. As religion has loosened its grip on us and hell has lost its terrors, so we have backed away from death to the point where many of us hardly believe it is going to happen.

So it is pretty nasty when it does. Probably it happens in hospital and there may be medical attempts to keep someone alive just that bit longer. This sort of death could not be more traumatic and we are worse prepared for it than for anything else in our lives.

It is hard all round. Doctors and nursing staff don't find it much easier than relatives to decide when it is time to stop keeping somebody alive. So we end up with acrimony and recriminations and unfathomable distress. It is unforgivable to write "Do Not Resuscitate" in a patient's notes without discussing it with them or their family, but it has happened because of the modern conspiracy of silence over death.

We have already had guidelines from the British Medical Association on withdrawing and withholding treatment from patients who are about to die, but doctors keep phoning the General Medical Council for advice, so it is about to consult on some of its own. They are unlikely to look very different.

There aren't any easy answers and I doubt whether a new set of rules will make anybody happier. Nor are advance directives the solution. It is fine to write a note saying "For God's sake pull the plug if I end up on a life-support machine", but the bravest have been known to change their mind at the last. Isn't there a case, then, for the un-medicalisation of death and for re-integrating it into our lives? Now that we don't see death all around us any more we badly need to talk about it long before it happens and keep on talking about it so that those closest to us know our minds.

Personally, I would go for a tropical island and hallucinogenic drugs, but failing that, I'd like to be tube-free, at home, with my family. But I reserve the right to change my mind.

It looks as though the new vaccinations have kicked meningitis C into touch, for which all parents will be truly grateful. Scientists are working on a vaccine for the other UK strain, meningitis B, and when they crack it, a disease that used to kill a few hundred children a year will have been conquered. It is more than unsettling, then, to hear that nearly 600 have already died in a meningitis epidemic in Burkina Faso in West Africa that broke out in January.

Burkina Faso is in the meningitis belt - a group of African countries, including Chad and Nigeria, which are struck by regular epidemics. In Burkina Faso they hit every three years and the one in 1997, killed 4,000.

The aid agencies have gone in, but Burkina Faso's epidemic has this time coincided with those in Ethiopia, Benin and Chad. There is a vaccine against the A strain, which causes these epidemics, but stocks are running out and health officials say 7.5m in Burkina Faso alone need to be vaccinated.

The populations of the meningitis belt need vaccinating before the regular epidemics hit, but a combination of African governments that cannot afford basic healthcare and do not want to admit to epidemics that might put off visitors, together with western countries who think Comic Relief day is probably doing their bit for African children means it just doesn't happen, and a disease our children enjoy protection from will just go on killing elsewhere.

fields.headline: Marathon man
fields.trailText: I doubt I will ever again beat a five-time Olympic gold medallist into 369th place at a half marathon in a smallish city in southern Spain.
fields.body:
Maybe it was the cheese sandwiches. Maybe it was the unusual training regime: beer, late nights, lack of sleep. Or maybe it was simply the god of running smiling down upon my rather unimpressive body. Either way I doubt I will ever again beat a five-time Olympic gold medallist into 369th place at a half marathon in a smallish city in southern Spain. The scene for your correspondent's miraculous triumph was Murcia - a town a few miles from the Mediterranean coast whose 322,911 population opened up its arms and its toilets to a troop of British runners from the Flora London Marathon.

Among our throng were Sir Steven Redgrave, his wife Ann, a melee of journalists and assorted celebrities. It was my first test at this distance and with the Spanish heat it was always going to be hard work. Looking back now it is all slightly hazy and surreal. Some things whizz by, others are in slow motion. My running fell into the latter category. Despite this, I can reveal a few flashbacks of the 13.1-mile jog: the desperate search for a pre-race toilet, the unedifying experience of being passed at three miles by a trio of grandfathers, and the odd experience of the Spanish man who kept on shouting "Come on Steve" at me.

But from this haze comes three top tips. First: cover your nipples. All regular runners will tell you of the need for a couple of strategically placed plasters to prevent terrible rubbing and bleeding. Secondly, rub Vaseline under the arms and any other interesting areas which could be subject to friction. And thirdly, do not daydream - keep your eyes on the road and avoid discarded water bottles, stray dogs or fallen bodies which could cause embarrassment. Having done this, go on to beat an Olympic champion and collect your cheese baguette and medal at the end. All this is true and I am proud that the record states: David Munk: 1:51:47, place 368. Sir Steven Redgrave 1:51:53, place 369.

fields.headline: Trinity Mirror Digital chief quits
fields.trailText:
3.15pm: Managing director David Clarke has quit following last Thursday's strategic retrenchment, reports Amy Vickers.
Oct 26: Graham Mead to head IC Network
<A HREF=" http://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,4153056,00.html">Mar 16: Trinity Mirror cuts back net spend
Mar 15: Newspaper giant puts website up for sale
fields.body:
David Clarke, managing director of Trinity Mirror Digital, has quit following last Thursday's strategic retrenchment.

Mr Clarke, the former boss of Virgin Net, is not thought to have another job to go to.

Graham Mead, managing director of the IC Network, will now take the reins of Trinity Mirror's embattled new media division.

Mr Mead took on his current role in October after six months as managing director of the regional websites.

Before that he had spent a number of years working directly for Trinity boss Philip Graf in various marketing roles.

Mr Mead said his erstwhile colleague's decision to leave was "very straight forward".

"It was a shared view that it was no longer appropriate for him to manage the business now the strategic direction is very different from how it was when he joined," Mr Mead explained.

Mr Clarke came on board in April 1999 to launch the internet service provider IC24 and expand the new media department.

After the merger with Trinity, the division evolved into Trinity Mirror Digital and employed 300 people.

It is now being cut back dramatically - up to a third of staff are facing redundancy as Trinity Mirror looks to sell the ISP and close its websites.

After breaking the news to its employees, Trinity Mirror Digital sent two-thirds of them home and said it would be in touch before April 15 with a decision on their fate.

fields.headline: Orange launches new service
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: Orange is to bridge the gap between Wap and 3G handsets by launching a 'GPRS' service in the UK. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Mobile phone operator Orange is to bridge the gap between Wap and 3G handsets by launching a "GPRS" service in the UK this summer.

The France Telecom-owned company today said it was making "strong progress" towards launching the high-tech 3G network after paying billions of pounds for transmission licences across Europe.

But it gave no deadline for a launch, and instead promised that GPRS, or general packet radio service, will be introduced in the UK and France.

GPRS offers "always on" internet access and faster transfer of data such as emails, but not the video images, games and entertainment which 3G promises.

The announcement came as Orange unveiled its annual results, which showed a net loss of £815m, virtually unchanged from last year.

However, the boom in text messaging helped revenues climb 59% to £7.5bn and the customer base increased 68% to 30m people, with the UK supplying 9.8m of that total.

The results were in line with analysts' expectations, but the level of debt at telecoms operators continues to concern investors.

European telecoms companies spent £50bn on mobile phone licences in the UK and Germany alone last year, and France Telecom today said its debt had soared from £9bn to £38bn.

fields.headline: Spices prove a hot date on ITV
fields.trailText: 2.15pm TV overnights: Raw Spice pushed ITV to number one in last night's ratings war, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Raw Spice, the documentary about the Spice Girls before they were famous, pushed ITV to number one in last night's ratings war.

Early footage of the unpolished yet fiercely ambitious girls drew 9.4m viewers - almost 40% of the available audience - at 8pm, according to unofficial overnights.

The documentary, produced by Neil Davies and Matthew Bowers, was shown last night after four years of legal wrangling.

The film was the subject of disputes with former members of the film's production company and with Victoria Beckham, who tried to prevent it from being screened.

Many Raw Spice viewers stayed tuned to ITV, giving the Hunt a 34% of audience share at 9pm.

The two-part drama about love in rural England starring Amanda Holden pulled in 7.6m viewers.

And Ms Holden beat off competition from John Cleese in the Human Face.

The second part of the BBC1 documentary series brought in only 4.8m viewers and a 21% audience share.

The evening's other top performer was new Channel 4 drama Teachers.

The first episode, starring former This Life actor Andrew Lincoln, was watched by 2.5m viewers - a 14% audience share - at 10pm.

The raunchy drama gained a healthy inheritance from ER, which had 2.7m viewers and a 12% share.

webTitle: Oscar race too close to call

fields.headline: Oscar race too close to call
fields.trailText: With only three days to go, the Academy Awards looks set for what could be one of the closest and most unpredictable Oscar nights in its 73 year history
fields.body:
With only three days to go, the Academy Awards looks set for what could be one of the closest and most unpredictable Oscar nights in its 73 year history. If industry insiders are to be believed, several of the major categories are still too close to call. This reflects a haphazard run of award ceremonies - including the Golden Globes and the Baftas - that have conspicuously failed to anoint a clear favourite to sweep the board in the way that American Beauty did last year.

Of the principal categories, only the Best Actress Oscar appears secure, with Julia Roberts the runaway favourite to win for her role in Erin Brockovich. By contrast the crucial Best Film award remains torn in a three-way tug-of-war between Gladiator, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon and Traffic.

A few weeks ago Gladiator appeared to be edging in front in the opinion of many, but recent whispers on the Hollywood grapevine suggest that Ang Lee's martial arts epic and Steven Soderbergh's drug saga might still pip it to the post. The confusion surrounding the Best Film award is mirrored in the Best Director category. Ang Lee and Ridley Scott (for Gladiator) are thought to be the joint favourites. Meanwhile it is assumed that Soderbergh's two nominations (for Traffic and Erin Brockovich) will split the vote and count against him.

There is similar doubt over the winner of the Best Actor award, with Cast Away star Tom Hanks and Gladiator's Russell Crowe thought to be neck and neck in the Academy voting. But a report in Variety suggests that the initially unfancied Ed Harris may yet prove to be Oscar's dark horse. In recent weeks Harris appears to have been gaining support for his role as the anguished abstract-expressionist painter Jackson Pollock. "If you were just going on acting chops, he would get it," reckons Time magazine critic Richard Schickel.

As Hollywood braces itself for what could be a night of shocks, the Academy Awards are already raising memories of another controversial contest of recent months. "This year's race for the Oscars might turn out like last year's battle for the presidency: a close race until the very end when all hell breaks loose." The Academy is no doubt hoping that none of their voters live in Florida.

webTitle: New offensive in Macedonia shatters recent calm

fields.headline: New offensive in Macedonia shatters recent calm
fields.standfirst: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Macedonian troops have launched a new offensive against ethnic Albanian rebels in the hills above the country's second city.
fields.body:
Macedonian troops have launched a new offensive against ethnic Albanian rebels in the hills above the country's second city.

Artillery fire and mortars were heard shortly after 9am in Tetovo, shattering more than 24 hours of calm. The attack came 10 hours after a deadline for the rebels to either leave Macedonian territory or to surrender had expired.

In Tetovo police shot two men dead in the street. State radio said they had tried to ambush the police position with grenades.

There was further violence elsewhere. Police reported that one officer was wounded by a rocket-propelled grenade just outside Skopje - the second incident targeting a policeman in or near the capital in the last 24 hours.

Elsewhere near the capital eight police officers were pinned down in an ambush, said officials.

The Macedonian president, Boris Trajkovski, said yesterday that it was necessary for the country to take control of its border.

Negotiations for a peaceful settlement were still possible, he said, but only through parliament and other established institutions, not through direct negotiations with the rebels.

Police had claimed that a "sweep and search" movement through the rebel-occupied area preceded the attack. An official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that those insurgents who were not arrested fled without a fight to the Kosovo border.

The rebels offered no comment on the police claims and agency reports said that the scene behind insurgent lines remained the same as before the offensive began. Fortifications and roadblocks were in place and there was no sign of mass retreat.

Rebel sniper positions two-and-a-half miles from Tetovo's centre were manned, casting further doubt on the police claims.

The EU expressed support for the government's position.

"The message from the West is very clear - the extremist groups must lay down their weapons," said the Swedish foreign minister, Anna Lindh, who is in Skopje on behalf of the EU.

The rebels say that they are a home grown movement fighting for greater rights in Macedonia, where ethnic Albanians are outnumbered by Slavs by three to one.

However, the government claims that the rebels are linked to fighters across the border in Kosovo and aim to break off northern Macedonia to form an independent ethnic Albanian state.

Although ethnic relations with the majority Slavs have been relatively free of trouble, substantial numbers of the ethnic Albanian minority feel they are being treated as second-class citizens. The struggle appears to have radicalised a large segment of ethnic Albanians.

In a last-minute concession, the rebels yesterday declared a ceasefire and called anew for talks to end the conflict peacefully.

"We, the general staff of the National Liberation Army (NLA), announce a unilateral cease fire and we open the road for dialogue so heads can cool down and to find the best solution," said Ali Ahmeti, the political head of the NLA, in a taped television broadcast in neighbouring Kosovo.

He said the ceasefire was open ended, but warned that the struggle would continue in the event of an attack.

The government ignored the offer.

fields.headline: Why Nato is ignoring Macedonia
fields.standfirst: A Washington-led desire to stay out of the latest Balkan conflict has prevented the alliance from fulfilling what many see as its obligations in the region, writes Simon Tisdall
fields.trailText: A Washington-led desire to stay out of the latest Balkan conflict has prevented the alliance from fulfilling what many see as its obligations in the region, writes Simon Tisdall.
fields.body:
Emergency measures to deal with the ethnic Albanian insurrection in Macedonia, announced yesterday by Nato ambassadors in Brussels, are unlikely to dispel concern that the alliance is not doing enough to prevent what is, potentially at least, another Balkan conflagration.

Nato has been criticised by the Macedonian government and by Serbia's President Vojislav Kostunica for failing to react quickly and decisively after the insurgency spread westwards from Serbia's Presevo valley, on Kosovo's border, towards Tetovo in Macedonia over the past two weeks.

The Russians have also been noisily making their feelings known. The foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, accused Nato of presiding over a "hotbed of extremism" in Kosovo during a visit to Skopje, the Macedonian capital, this week.

Like Kostunica, Ivanov is keen to make the political point that Nato's 1999 Kosovo intervention has simply destabilised the region.

More disturbingly for Nato, much criticism has come from its own side, with the alliance's leading member, the US, coming under particular attack. The 5,000-strong US contingent of K-For in south-eastern Kosovo is accused in particular of failing to curb the growth of Albanian gunmen crossing the border into Macedonia, for fear of taking risks.

In response to this furore, Nato announced yesterday that yet more K-For troops would be redeployed to the Kosovo border and that cooperation and military coordination with the Skopje government would be increased.

It was also disclosed that the US is providing the Macedonians with aerial photos, military intelligence and unidentified "military hardware", and that Britain had decided to send an eight-man military liaison team to Skopje.

But that is as far as it goes. George Robertson, the Nato secretary general, Donald Rumsfeld, the US defence secretary, and Geoffrey Hoon, the British defence secretary, have all repeatedly stressed that no Nato troops will be sent to assist the Macedonians.

In other words, there will be no direct intervention, as in Kosovo, even though the Macedonian government appears both to want and need outside help and is a member of Nato's Partnership for Peace programme.

This policy has led many to ask whether Nato is making the same mistake as previously in the Balkans, when the west failed to prevent large-scale loss of life and ethnic cleansing in Bosnia and Croatia in the 1990s.

This time, it is argued, there is even less excuse, since Nato already has 42,000 troops on the ground. It is not that the means are lacking. What is absent is the will.

The reasons why Nato refuses to get more deeply involved are several - and they go to the heart of western peacekeeping problems in the Balkans.

One relatively simple argument is that a military commitment in Macedonia could undermine K-For's capabilities in Kosovo, where trouble regularly occurs in Serb enclaves such as Mitrovica in the north and in the Presevo buffer zone.

A Nato decision to join the fight with the ethnic Albanians inside Macedonia would be likely to infuriate the predominantly Albanian population of Kosovo, which could then turn on Nato and UN personnel.

It is also pointed out that K-For has no mandate from the UN for operations in Macedonia.

These reasons for keeping out, while practical in nature, are hardly conclusive, however. Newly democratised Serbia is no longer the threatening enemy it was when Slobodan Milosevic was still president.

Serb forces are now working alongside K-For in the Presevo valley. In Kosovo itself, most ethnic Albanians do not support the extremists, as last year's local elections showed. An "uprising" against Nato does not seem likely. Meanwhile, a UN mandate in Macedonia could easily be obtained, given the almost universal opposition to the Albanian insurgency.

Is there a moral objection, then, to Nato intervention?

The ethnic Albanians who comprise the self-styled National Liberation Army (NLA) in Macedonia state that they are fighting for equal rights with the Slavic majority which, they say, discriminates and oppresses them. Through this argument they appear to hope that they can win western sympathy, as did the Kosovars in 1999.

However, nobody in the west seriously argues that the disadvantages faced by minority ethnic Albanians in Macedonia, although not insignificant, can be compared with the excesses visited upon their kith and kin by Milosevic's thugs in Kosovo.

On the contrary, Macedonia has long been held up as a model of intercommunal cooperation. In reality, it is argued, the relatively few insurgents are trying to gain by the gun what should properly be obtained through negotiation and the ballot box.

In such circumstances, there is no moral objection to intervention. In fact, the opposite holds true. Nato would be politically and morally justified in going to the support of Macedonia's democratic majority, comprising as it does both ethnic Macedonians and ethnic Albanians. But still it does not do so.

A more murky explanation for Nato's reluctance is to be found in reports that western countries, principally the US and Britain, aided, trained and armed the very gunmen who are now fighting in the Tetovo hills.

This assistance, reportedly funded by the CIA, was given before the Kosovo intervention. To move against these people now, it is claimed, would be to admit both that the west had created a "monster" that it could not now control (the Serbs and Russians would love that), and that it has definitively failed to establish a law-abiding civil society in Kosovo.

All these explanations may have elements of truth. But, in trying to explain Nato policy, they ignore the fundamental political and military flaw within the alliance itself.

The bottom line is that Nato is not an association of equal partners. It is a US security organisation to which others belong. Nato does not do anything, or go anywhere, without an OK from Washington, especially not into a war zone in the Balkans. And what Washington wants is decided by the administration in charge.

Looked at from this perspective, and given the recent changeover at the White House, it is easy to see why direct intervention in Macedonia is out of the question at the moment.

President George Bush was elected partly on a pledge to pull US troops out of the Balkans, not get more deeply involved. Bush is also committed to reviewing, with a view to running down, US commitments to peacekeeping operations round the world.

The US has already begun a rundown of its troops in Bosnia. Washington has long been terrified at the prospect of getting sucked into what it calls the "Balkan quagmire". Intervention in Macedonia is seen exactly in that light.

Intervention could involve US casualties. This evokes the "body bag syndrome". In other words, the political cost of losing soldiers overseas in "other people's wars" is deemed unacceptable.

Nor is there an "exit strategy" - secretary of state Colin Powell's famous dictum. A commitment to Macedonia would necessarily be open-ended.

More broadly, nobody in the w est seems to be able to agree what should be done about Kosovo in the long term. Should it become independent or be returned to Serbia? The prospect of Macedonia also becoming a virtual Nato protectorate, and perhaps Montenegro, too, is a very unwelcome one to Washington

For all these reasons, Bush and his advisers oppose the sort of direct intervention in Macedonia that could snuff out the insurrection before it spreads and becomes a full-scale civil war. Knowing that full well, America's European allies cannot, and will not, act.

The US may be right, of course. The measures being taken now could work and the crisis may be defused. But it is a gamble. Furthermore, in highlighting these paralysing constraints on Nato's collective ability to act, the Macedonian crisis has also fuelled the argument in favour of developing a separate EU-led European "army" and, perhaps, one day, abolishing Nato altogether.

Like Kostunica, Ivanov is keen to make the political point that Nato's 1999 Kosovo intervention has simply destabilised the region. More disturbingly for Nato, much criticism has come from its own side, with the alliance's leading member, the US, coming under particular attack. The 5,000-strong US contingent of K-For in south-eastern Kosovo is accused in particular of failing to curb the growth of Albanian gunmen crossing the border into Macedonia, for fear of taking risks. In response to this furore, Nato announced yesterday that yet more K-For troops would be redeployed to the Kosovo border and that cooperation and military coordination with the Skopje government would be increased. It was also disclosed that the US is providing the Macedonians with aerial photos, military intelligence and unidentified "military hardware", and that Britain had decided to send an eight-man military liaison team to Skopje. But that is as far as it goes. George Robertson, the Nato secretary general, Donald Rumsfeld, the US defence secretary, and Geoffrey Hoon, the British defence secretary, have all repeatedly stressed that no Nato troops will be sent to assist the Macedonians. In other words, there will be no direct intervention, as in Kosovo, even though the Macedonian government appears both to want and need outside help and is a member of Nato's Partnership for Peace programme. This policy has led many to ask whether Nato is making the same mistake as previously in the Balkans, when the west failed to prevent large-scale loss of life and ethnic cleansing in Bosnia and Croatia in the 1990s. This time, it is argued, there is even less excuse, since Nato already has 42,000 troops on the ground. It is not that the means are lacking. What is absent is the will. The reasons why Nato refuses to get more deeply involved are several - and they go to the heart of western peacekeeping problems in the Balkans. One relatively simple argument is that a military commitment in Macedonia could undermine K-For's capabilities in Kosovo, where trouble regularly occurs in Serb enclaves such as Mitrovica in the north and in the Presevo buffer zone. A Nato decision to join the fight with the ethnic Albanians inside Macedonia would be likely to infuriate the predominantly Albanian population of Kosovo, which could then turn on Nato and UN personnel. It is also pointed out that K-For has no mandate from the UN for operations in Macedonia. These reasons for keeping out, while practical in nature, are hardly conclusive, however. Newly democratised Serbia is no longer the threatening enemy it was when Slobodan Milosevic was still president. Serb forces are now working alongside K-For in the Presevo valley. In Kosovo itself, most ethnic Albanians do not support the extremists, as last year's local elections showed. An "uprising" against Nato does not seem likely. Meanwhile, a UN mandate in Macedonia could easily be obtained, given the almost universal opposition to the Albanian insurgency. Is there a moral objection, then, to Nato intervention? The ethnic Albanians who comprise the self-styled National Liberation Army (NLA) in Macedonia state that they are fighting for equal rights with the Slavic majority which, they say, discriminates and oppresses them. Through this argument they appear to hope that they can win western sympathy, as did the Kosovars in 1999. However, nobody in the west seriously argues that the disadvantages faced by minority ethnic Albanians in Macedonia, although not insignificant, can be compared with the excesses visited upon their kith and kin by Milosevic's thugs in Kosovo. On the contrary, Macedonia has long been held up as a model of intercommunal cooperation. In reality, it is argued, the relatively few insurgents are trying to gain by the gun what should properly be obtained through negotiation and the ballot box. In such circumstances, there is no moral objection to intervention. In fact, the opposite holds true. Nato would be politically and morally justified in going to the support of Macedonia's democratic majority, comprising as it does both ethnic Macedonians and ethnic Albanians. But still it does not do so. A more murky explanation for Nato's reluctance is to be found in reports that western countries, principally the US and Britain, aided, trained and armed the very gunmen who are now fighting in the Tetovo hills. This assistance, reportedly funded by the CIA, was given before the Kosovo intervention. To move against these people now, it is claimed, would be to admit both that the west had created a "monster" that it could not now control (the Serbs and Russians would love that), and that it has definitively failed to establish a law-abiding civil society in Kosovo. All these explanations may have elements of truth. But, in trying to explain Nato policy, they ignore the fundamental political and military flaw within the alliance itself. The bottom line is that Nato is not an association of equal partners. It is a US security organisation to which others belong. Nato does not do anything, or go anywhere, without an OK from Washington, especially not into a war zone in the Balkans. And what Washington wants is decided by the administration in charge. Looked at from this perspective, and given the recent changeover at the White House, it is easy to see why direct intervention in Macedonia is out of the question at the moment. President George Bush was elected partly on a pledge to pull US troops out of the Balkans, not get more deeply involved. Bush is also committed to reviewing, with a view to running down, US commitments to peacekeeping operations round the world. The US has already begun a rundown of its troops in Bosnia. Washington has long been terrified at the prospect of getting sucked into what it calls the "Balkan quagmire". Intervention in Macedonia is seen exactly in that light. Intervention could involve US casualties. This evokes the "body bag syndrome". In other words, the political cost of losing soldiers overseas in "other people's wars" is deemed unacceptable. Nor is there an "exit strategy" - secretary of state Colin Powell's famous dictum. A commitment to Macedonia would necessarily be open-ended. More broadly, nobody in the w est seems to be able to agree what should be done about Kosovo in the long term. Should it become independent or be returned to Serbia? The prospect of Macedonia also becoming a virtual Nato protectorate, and perhaps Montenegro, too, is a very unwelcome one to Washington For all these reasons, Bush and his advisers oppose the sort of direct intervention in Macedonia that could snuff out the insurrection before it spreads and becomes a full-scale civil war. Knowing that full well, America's European allies cannot, and will not, act. The US may be right, of course. The measures being taken now could work and the crisis may be defused. But it is a gamble. Furthermore, in highlighting these paralysing constraints on Nato's collective ability to act, the Macedonian crisis has also fuelled the argument in favour of developing a separate EU-led European "army" and, perhaps, one day, abolishing Nato altogether. webTitle: Clause 67 is an essential part of NHS reform

fields.headline: Clause 67 is an essential part of NHS reform
fields.trailText: The clause will help protect cancer research, prevent commercial abuse of patient data and keep patients better informed about their own treatment, writes Lord Hunt.
fields.body:
Clause 67 of the health and social care bill provides important new powers to safeguard patient care.

It will, for example, allow us to maintain existing cancer registries, one of our best weapons in the fight against cancer.

It will prevent the commercial abuse of patients data, protect the NHS and allow patients to be kept better informed about their own treatment.

The clause has three purposes. It will allow essential work such as medical research or the monitoring of diseases to continue. The bill will ensure doctors can share patient information if doing so will benefit patients and the public and, critically, only when there is no reasonable, practicable alternative.

Our prime objective is to safeguard existing programmes such as cancer registries, which help develop more effective treatments for cancer.

Cancer registries provide information on the incidence of cancer in the population and on death rates and survival rates. This information is vital for planning cancer services and for monitoring their effectiveness. Cancer registries are also essential for research into the causes of cancer.

The NHS depends upon information for understanding and improving the health of the public, increasing life expectancy and raising quality of life. Without information, important research work grinds to a halt.

Information about patients is therefore a precious and irreplaceable resource. Patients trust doctors and nurses. They share their most intimate secrets with them in confidence.

The NHS has enjoyed the privilege of using this information for decades, and has accomplished much good, but it has done so in the absence of the informed consent of patients. This cannot continue.

Over the years, the NHS has, with the best of intentions, slipped into a tradition of paternalism, where the benefits of science and research have been seen as somehow self-evident, regardless of the wishes of patients.

The government has made it clear that from now on the fundamental principle governing the use of patient information by any part of the NHS or research community must be informed consent.

But the NHS cannot deliver informed consent overnight, it will take several years. This is the why clause 67 contains a power to support key activities where it is presently not practicable to gain consent.

First, it allows essential work to continue while the NHS develops systems based on informed consent or that cannot reveal the identity of the patient.

Use of this power will be governed by robust safeguards. Some of these are set out in the clause and others are being developed by a working group that includes representatives from the Patients Association, the General Medical Council and the British Medical Association.

Decisions to use this power will be made as part of an open and consultative process and the agreement of both houses of parliament after full debate.

There is no question of information being used for anything other than combating disease and safeguarding public health.

Second, clause 67 aims to prevent commercial interests profiting inappropriately from NHS and patient information. It enables the government to regulate the use of this sort of information for "marketing or other promotional activity" only.

Again, use of the power will need the approval of both houses of parliament after full debate.

Finally, the clause provides a basis in law for patients to receive more information about their care and treatment. Patients should be kept informed at every stage of their treatment. These powers will allow doctors and consultants to copy patients into the correspondence sent between them ensuring patients are kept informed at every step of their treatment.

fields.headline: Keith Vaz and Geoffrey Robinson
fields.standfirst:
Elizabeth Filkin, the Commons standards commissioner, yesterday announced two new - but separate - investigations into the conduct of two of the Labour party's high-profile figures. Matthew Tempest explains
Special report: Life in parliament
fields.trailText: Elizabeth Filkin, the Commons standards commissioner, yesterday announced two new - but spearate - investigations into the conduct of two of the Labour party's high-profile figures. We explain why Keith Vaz, minister for Europe, and Geoffrey Robinson, the former paymaster general, are back in the news.
fields.body:
Why is Keith Vaz being investigated again  wasn't that finished weeks ago?
A report into alleged links between the Europe minister and the billionaire Hinduja brothers was indeed published a fortnight ago. Of the 18 complaints about his conduct, one was upheld, seven dismissed and 10 not proceeded with for lack of evidence.

What is the latest allegation against Mr Vaz?
A story in the Sunday Times alleged that although Mr Vaz claimed he had never received money from the Hindujas, the brothers did give £1,200 to Mapesbury Communications, a firm run by Mr Vaz's wife, to fund a visit to the UK from an Indian religious leader in 1995. This story led Tory MP Andrew Lansley to make a complaint to Elizabeth Filkin, the Commons standards commissioner, who has now reopened her investigation.

And what sparked the other investigation into Mr Robinson's conduct?
Last Monday, the Daily Mail began its serialisation of a book by the investigative journalist, Tom Bower, which claims Mr Robinson misled parliament over an alleged £200,000 payment in 1990 from the disgraced media tycoon Robert Maxwell.

What form will the inquiries take?
Ms Filkin looks into allegations against sitting MPs but has no powers to force MPs to respond to her inquiries, other than naming and shaming them if they fail to do so. Complaints can only be investigated when raised by a fellow MP  leading to accusations of petty point scoring between the two main parties.

Why is the trade secretary Stephen Byers involved?
Mr Byers has threatened to sue the Daily Mail because the book serialisation relating to the conduct of Mr Robinson also accuses Mr Byers of "burying" a department of trade and industry report into this original dispute. If  and that's a big if  the case reaches court, it will be the first time a serving cabinet minister has appeared in a libel case.

Why is WH Smith involved in the controversy?
WH Smith is refusing to stock the book by Mr Bower for fear it contains a libel. Booksellers can be sued for libel in books they sell under British law - but Waterstones has agreed to stock it.

What is expected to happen next?
Ms Filkin's last investigation into Mr Vaz took nearly 18 months to complete - a fact which she blamed on Mr Vaz's failure to provide "full and accurate answers" to some of the questions she posed. This time Westminster insiders suspect Mr Vaz will be culled in a post-election reshuffle before any report is published. Unless the Daily Mail can produce an authenticated invoice for the £200,000, Mr Robinson looks set to be cleared.

Meanwhile, the likelihood of Mr Byers appearing in court with the Daily Mail is remote. Although the paper is sticking by its story "100%" and Mr Byers has instructed his solicitors to proceed with an action, it is expected that one side will eventually back down.

webTitle: Please still come to the Lakes, tourists urged

fields.headline: Please still come to the Lakes, tourists urged
fields.standfirst:
Main industry loses £6m this week as visitors stay away

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Apart from the smell of burning fleece and the for sale signs outside farms, the odd thing about the Lake District during the foot and mouth crisis is that the hedges are wonky.
fields.body:
Apart from the smell of burning fleece and the for sale signs outside farms, the odd thing about the Lake District during the foot and mouth crisis is that the hedges are wonky.

This is because the gardening is being done by gourmet chefs. As 50 jobs a day are lost in Cumbria, employers are sending desperate staff to prune the topiary.

A crowd of 400 protesters, who had been laid off or face redundancy, yesterday gathered in the cobbled passageway of Keswick job centre to rally the government.

Riding teachers in jodhpurs lined up beside climbing instructors, chefs, landladies with spaniels, and guidebook writers in waterproofs.

They carried banners saying "Help." They wanted compensation, government subsidies, tax relief for their businesses and no May 3 election. They also wanted to get on American television to tell US tourists there were plenty of museums still open for business.

But as the number of diseased farms in Cumbria rose to 137 and soldiers helped dispose of growing carcass mountains, Keswick looked deserted. The mannequins in shop windows were naked.

Tourism in Cumbria, one of the area's chief industries, has lost around £6m this week as visitors stay away from the roads strewn with disinfected mats. Locals say they can no longer afford to pay council tax and feed their children. Some landladies are surviving on less than £10 a week.

Kate Low, 54, runs a guest house in Keswick with her husband, Dave. They have one visitor, and have lost £2,000 revenue this month. Mr Low applied for a job driving lorries this week and Mrs Low is looking for work. "I'll do anything except lifting old people. I am trained to do office work, but who is going to take me on now?"

The couple can not afford to spend more than £7 a week on food, and are living on supplies from the guest house freezer. "We buy a newspaper once a week. We sit by the fire with one lamp on and only switch the television on to watch the news.

"We can't afford to advertise the guest house for next year. If the outbreak hits the Fells, we are finished for six months. We will have lost the season. Tony Blair hasn't the foggiest idea what is going on here."

David Jackson, 31, a gourmet chef, has spent the week cutting hedges because there was no one at his hotel to eat his five course dinners. "In the last three weeks, my wife and I are down £500 on our monthly earnings. I would normally make £15,000 a year to provide for three children. The difficulty is not knowing when things will get any better."

John Walker, an art gallery owner and spokesman for the newly formed Cumbria Crisis Alliance, said: "We haven't seen anything like this since the second world war. This is a disaster. We need information to get through to people that there are things to do in the Lake District. Please come to the Lakes."

fields.headline: Avalon waiting as Playboy king comes to town
fields.trailText: 2pm: Playboy boss Hugh Hefner has hired Popstars PR firm Avalon PR to handle his 75th birthday celebrations, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Playboy founder Hugh Hefner, whose Bacchanalian parties have become the stuff of legend, is coming to London to celebrate his 75th birthday.

Mr Hefner will visit the capital in May as part of a European "grand tour" taking the Cannes Film Festival and visits to Milan and London.

Avalon PR, the public relations company that worked on TV show Popstars, has been appointed by Playboy Enterprises to handle media relations for Mr Hefner's tour.

Avalon last year ran a campaign in to raise the Playboy's profile that coincided with the launch of Playboy casinos.

"The Bunny's Back" campaign saw 400 wannabe bunny girls - eager to don the corset, fishnet tights, bow tie and floppy ear uniform - lining up in Leicester Square to audition.

When the Playboy bandwagon hits London, Mr Hefner will hit the town. He will be shopping, eating and partying his way around London, with ample opportunity for photo opportunities and media interviews.
