fields.headline: Disloyal citizens face persecution
fields.standfirst:
Those who oppose Mugabe's government may lose their jobs or even their lives, writes Chris McGreal

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Those who oppose Mugabe's government may lose their jobs or even their lives, writes Chris McGreal in Harare.
fields.body:
Acting chief Nembire's letter was chillingly frank. There are four teachers in his area, and he doesn't like their politics. He wants them out; not just out of his schools but the area under his responsibility.

The reply from Zimbabwe's education ministry was equally sinister. It agreed that the teachers should go. Amid the high profile murders of white farmers and the nightly attacks on opposition supporters in Harare's townships, a quieter purge is underway of ordinary Zimbabweans who want rid of President Robert Mugabe's government.

Some opposition supporters are fired from the police and civil service. Others suddenly find it hard to buy traders licences or to keep their jobs as municipal bus drivers.

In chief Nembire's fiefdom it is teachers who are the target. The chief's at times ungrammatical letter to the education ministry is a revealing account of why he wants rid of the four teachers. He is, he says, a member of the ruling Zanu-PF while the teachers are allegedly in contact with a local opposition leader, an R Shanya, who was a target for the ruling party's thugs during last years parliamentary elections.

"We have face serious problems with teachers of Nembire school through political activities at our area which is not good to us," the chief writes. "Even myself, I am Zanu PF member. I don't want any party to my area. Our MP, Kasukuwere S, told us to hand over our case to minister Gezi to assist us to remove dangerous teachers. They are in connection with R Shanya who was beaten by Zany PF [at the] time of elections."

The chief's letter says that the district administrator, the highest government post in the area, told him to "take action to get them away".

The education ministry's director of schools, LC Bowora, raises no objections. "You are advised that the ministry's position is that teachers who are not wanted within their employment environment, for whatever reason, should be assisted to transfer to other areas," he wrote.

webTitle: All over bar the tears in France's sleaze trial

fields.headline: All over bar the tears in France's sleaze trial
fields.trailText: France's most lurid postwar sleaze trial ended in Paris yesterday with former French foreign minister Roland Dumas facing two years in jail and a multimillion-franc fine if he is found guilty of misusing funds from the oil company Elf-Aquitaine.
fields.body:
France's most lurid postwar sleaze trial ended in Paris yesterday with former French foreign minister Roland Dumas facing two years in jail and a multimillion-franc fine if he is found guilty of misusing funds from the oil company Elf-Aquitaine.

Mr Dumas, 78, is accused of forcing Elf to employ his ex-lover, the former lingerie model Christine Deviers-Joncour, 53, in a high-paid job with next to no duties.

The couple are alleged to have wallowed in Elf's largesse, buying a multimillion-pound Left Bank flat and lavish gifts for each other with company funds.

The trial was the culmination of a seven-year judicial investigation, led by the crusading judge Eva Joly, into Elf's affairs between 1989 and 1993.

Mr Dumas denies illegally receiving Fr64.5m (£6.2m) in commissions paid by Elf in the early 1990s and profiting from the money the company gave his lover to lobby him in connection with the controversial sale of six frigates to Taiwan by another state-controlled firm, Thompson, in 1991.

Mr Dumas' lawyer said yesterday that French politics did not work in the way that the prosecution had suggested.

"Do you have such a contempt for politics that you think everything is a fix-up, that any minister can call up to have a friend appointed to this or that senior position?" Jean-Rene Farthouat shouted at the prosecution. "

There are procedures! There is a system!"

But Ms Deviers-Joncour has admitted taking money from Elf in return for trying to influence Mr Dumas's decisions.

The state prosecutor, Jean-Pierre Champrenault, asked for a two-year prison sentence and a Fr2.5m (£240,000) fine for Mr Dumas and a three year term - with one year suspended - and a Fr1M fine for Ms Deviers-Joncour.

He urged the judge to impose the maximum sen tence of five years in jail on Elf's former chief executive Loik Le Floch-Prigent, and his number two, Alfred Sirven, allegedly the mastermind of a Fr400m Elf slush fund.

He described the affair as being inspired by "mafia-type logic", arguing that by offering him signs of their generosity to his mistress Elf bosses wanted to put Mr Dumas in their debt.

For two months the case has been an unmissable soap opera in France, with its tales of high-living, sexual betrayal, slush funds, dubious arms sales, and a host of larger-than-life characters.

Leading them has been Mr Dumas, an ageing roue who turned up to court each day in an elegant suit, leaning on a cane. With the rakish charm of Alan Clark and the sexual allure of Michael Heseltine, he was described by one French newspaper as "the prince of intrigue in François Mitterrand's palace".

Then there is his former lover, who wrote a book about herself called the Whore of the Republic. But during the trial she claimed to be a reformed character.

Mr Sirven, for his part, was at his luxury villa in the Philippines when the rest of the accused faced the music in January.

Nicknamed "le grand absent" by the French press, he had been on the run from Interpol for four years. But, in the middle of the trial, he was melodramatically arrested and extradited to France.

He boasted that he knew enough secrets to "blow up the republic 20 times", but so far he has refrained from doing so, deciding to say nothing in court.

Behind the soap opera, though, is a more serious story - one of state corruption. France has been knee-deep in sleaze since the president, Jacques Chirac, was implicated last autumn in a kickback scandal involving his RPR party while he was mayor of Paris.

The Elf trial has now highlighted Socialist corruption during the same period.

The judges are expected to return a verdict in May.

fields.headline: Glamour revels in launch success
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: Conde Nast has rushed out an extra 50,000 copies of Glamour after the launch issue sold out in many high streets. By Claire Cozens.
Useful link: Glamour website
fields.body:
Conde Nast has rushed out an extra 50,000 copies of Glamour after the newly-launched magazine sold out in more than a third of WH Smith's high street branches.

The magazine launched on March 8 with a print run of 647,000 and backed by a £5m marketing campaign.

Early figures suggest the circulation of the first issue will be over 400,000, twice Conde Nast's original target of 200,000.

"Newsagents told us last week they had sold out in a lot of their branches and we thought we can't have that," said Simon Kippin, publisher of Glamour.

"WH Smith are saying they have never seen anything like it. It's now the third biggest seller of all their magazines, including weeklies."

Its succes will come as a surprise to some industry observers, who predicted Glamour would struggle in a highly competitive marketplace that has recently claimed the scalps of Minx and Frank.

The timing of the launch made it particularly difficult, coming just two weeks after Time Inc's In Style magazine made its UK debut.

The magazine's A5 format also raised eyebrows when it was first revealed.

Conde Nast managing director Nicholas Coleridge has described the launch of Glamour as "the most ambitious and controversial magazine project of my 12 years at Conde Nast".

Glamour's website is also being hailed as a success. Within two days of launch glamourmagazine.co.uk had registered almost 80,000 page impressions.

fields.headline: The cost of whistleblowing
fields.standfirst: Even in the new culture of openness that employees are told now exists, blowing the whistle on wrongdoing can often mean suspension and blighted career prospects, writes Maggie Murray
fields.trailText: Even in the new culture of openness that employees are told now exists, blowing the whistle on wrongdoing can often mean suspension and blighted career prospects, writes Maggie Murray.
fields.body:
Blowing the whistle on a colleague or raising awareness of bad practice takes courage, even in the new culture of openness that employees are told now exists.

For the individual who decides to challenge the status quo, the implications of the decision to highlight wrongdoing may mean, at best, a period of stressful suspension, and, at worst, blighted career prospects.

Last year, Sian Caiach, a consultant orthopaedic surgeon, raised concerns that a fellow doctor at the Prince Philip hospital in Llanelli was using NHS time and resources to treat private patients. An audit commission investigation substantiated some of her claims and found that the hospital was subsidising private patients and had lost income of £7,500.

Since that time, Ms Caiach has not worked and has been on what is described as extended maternity leave for almost eight months. She is also the subject of an investigation by the Royal College of Surgeons after allegations were made about her clinical practice.

"It has been an intensely unpleasant, stressful and distressing experience. With the knowledge that I now have of what can happen to someone who raises awareness in these circumstances, it would be an extremely close call as to whether I would be prepared to do the same again. It is not just your own personal victimisation but the effects on those around you. It is hard to hide the psychological distress," she says.

Bunny Pinnington, a school nurse, also knows the cost of blowing the whistle. Over three years ago, while working in a Swansea school for children with profound disabilities, she was given a do-not-resuscitate (DNR) instruction for a child, by the head teacher. She alleges that this was done without consultation with the child's grandparents, who were the child's carers, and against the medical opinion of the child's consultant.

"I can't put into words what I have gone through after I raised this issue. I was still working and so was the head teacher. It was intolerable and the subtle isolation and stress was immense. Everybody seems to close ranks and those with power seem to win in these cases. You find that there is very little support; you are on your own. After taking sick leave and then returning, I raised the same issue again and was suspended," she says.

In November last year, the Welsh assembly announced that there would an in-depth inquiry into the issues surrounding the care plans of children with special needs in Wales. Although ministers at the assembly did not feel that the events at the Swansea school warranted a public inquiry, there was a commitment to "urgently take forward this inquiry" because of the importance of the general issues that had been raised. Ms Pinnington's case is the subject of a preliminary appeal before the employment appeals tribunal in April.

Geoffrey Hunt, who has carried out extensive research on whistle blowing, both in social services and the health service, says there remains considerable secrecy in public and private organisations.

"Managers are still not listening, or [they are] victimising, those who raise concerns. At the moment, Freedom to Care, the organisation founded to give support to whistleblowers, is looking at the case of a senior nurse working in residential care. She was an experienced and well thought of practitioner, but when she raised questions about low standards, she was demoted and has now resigned in protest," he says.

"Residential care is an area where we see a lot of wrongdoing and a lot of victimisation. I would say that, in many ways, despite public disclosure legislation, the situation is no better. There has been a limited cultural acceptance that those people play an important role in highlighting serious concerns, but there is still a pervasive climate of fear."

In July 1999, the Public Interest Disclosure Act came into force after concern over a number of high profile cases, such as the north Wales child abuse scandal and the inquiry into the baby deaths at Bristol Royal Infirmary.

Caroline Miller of Public Concern at Work, the charity that campaigned for the legislation, says it is designed to protect people who raise concerns that are in the public interest.

"It covers a wide range and could be used for instance where there are issues surrounding abuse within an institution, or fraud. There have been several notable successes under the act. The reason for our existence is to change the culture so that it is safe to raise concerns," she says.

She adds. "The act is a lever but the culture is changing very slowly. Interestingly, the cases that have gone forward under the act tend to be in the private sector, but the majority of calls we receive on our helpline are from the public sector."

One of the problems, according to the organisation, is that there has been almost no publicity about the legislation.

"It was a private members bill and it has been very much left to us as a small charity to try to publicise how the legislation can help," says director Guy Dehn.

"At the moment the government is spending £5m telling people that they have the right to a paid annual holiday. We would say that most employees are probably aware of this but that they are very unlikely to understand their rights under the public disclosure legislation."

And, he points out, the legislation cannot stop unscrupulous employers harassing employees who speak out if no one knows about it or uses it.

"The importance of whistleblowing is that it is a way of emphasising the importance of bearing witness to something that needs to be brought out into the public domain. If the legislation were properly publicised, it would result in employers realising that it is not in their interest to try to cover things up."

 Public Concern at Work can be contacted on 020 404 6609.

fields.headline: Through the looking glass
fields.standfirst: Jason Fraser looking smug; Janet Street-Porter looking embarrassed; Vanessa Feltz looking like a lost sheep. Monkey joins the throng at last night's British Press Awards
fields.trailText:
12.30pm: The British Press Awards provided some great photo opportunities, shame Media Monkey forgot the camera.
Guardian writer honoured
Mar 21: Monkey at the RTS awards
fields.body:
 Surplus to requirements it seems. As guests arrived at last night's British Press Awards they were ushered to a champagne reception. Alas the room was empty - save four or five forlorn-looking blokes. It transpired that it was the "overspill" room for the main pre-dinner drinks party. Only timid Sun editor David Yelland could find the room "buzzing" with excitement.

 The Express (nil points) showcased its newest acquisition paparazzo, Mr Jason Fraser. The £1m-a-year picture editor looked suitably flush and not a little pleased with himself, but fled just as Monkey was trying to get out his long lens. A banana daiquiri to the first person to supply us with a fuzzy shot of Mr Fraser adjusting his dress in the gents.

 Considerably less shy than Mr Fraser was Independent on Sunday editor Janet Street-Porter. Dressed strikingly as ever, Ms Street-Porter's eye-catching gold top became even more of a talking point when it came undone at the back. After a couple of discreet attempts to re-tie a bow with one hand, Janet gave up and let it all hang out, so to speak. A golden banana to the woman who shows such pluck - it will go nicely with her skimpy top.

 Everyone's favourite celebrity Vanessa Feltz was clocked nursing her freebie red Schaeffer pen box and looking like a lost sheep. Was she keen to befriend the media that only last week took great pleasure in baiting her? Well she wasn't there by accident, having called up and begged Press Gazette to give her a ticket at the last minute - she is after all a columnist for OK! magazine. Monkey spotted her on a mission to the Daily Mail tables - no doubt desperate to congratulate columnist of the year Lynda Lee Potter and thank her for her kind words on Celebrity Big Brother last week.

 Ms Feltz was later spotted sidling up to awards host Michael Parkinson, whose dry wit was not wasted on the audience earlier in the evening. Cries of disbelief erupted from the crowd on hearing Parky's quip about the ability of reporter of the year, the Sun's John Kay, to write "knock 'em dead stories". Cue music.

 Thank goodness for the loud techno music at the end of the awards when an eerie silence descended in the place after the Daily Mail was named newspaper of the year. A muted clap accompanied Paul Dacre's trip to the stage to snatch the award as all around open mouths, raised eyebrows and headshaking ensued.

 Other talk: Where in God's name was Kelvin MacKenzie, especially considering TalkSport sponsored two awards?

 Snaps that Monkey wishes we had to show you:
1. A worried looking Rebekah Wade - aka Sideshow Bob - sandwiched between an effervescent Piers Morgan and Guardian columnist Marina Hyde wearing a very chesty outfit.
2. Piers Morgan rushing up to David Yelland and Paul Dacre attempting to bang their heads together.
3. Humbled City Slicker James Hipwell trying his hardest to avoid former colleagues, having been told in no uncertain terms by Piers's deputy, the stern Tina Weaver, not to approach anyone at the Mirror - in case he "poisoned their minds against Piers".

fields.headline: Ann Sothern
fields.standfirst: She starred as a girl called Maisie
fields.trailText: Of all the brassy, hip-swinging, sassy blondes of the 1940s, Maisie Ravier, as embodied by Ann Sothern, who has died aged 92, was the most beloved.
fields.body:
Of all the brassy, hip-swinging, sassy blondes of the 1940s, Maisie Ravier, as embodied by Ann Sothern, who has died aged 92, was the most beloved. At that period, when film fans wrote letters addressed to "Maisie, USA", they went straight to Sothern's dressing room, so popular and famous was her alter ego.

From 1939 to 1947, Ann Sothern played footloose showgirl Maisie in 10 movies, and on radio for five years. The radio show always opened with the clicking of Maisie's high heels, followed by a long wolf whistle and a man's voice saying, "Hi-ya, babe! Say, how about a lit- " A sharp slap, "Ouch!" Then Maisie, in Brooklynese tones, would reply, "Does that answer your question, buddy?"

Ann Sothern, who was born Harriette Lake in North Dakota, was trained as a classical singer by her concert-soprano mother. But she found her temperament and voice were more suited for musical comedy. On Broadway, she soon rose from small parts to leads in Ziegfeld shows under her real name.

In 1933 she went to Hollywood, where she spent six years at various studios playing light-hearted heroines in mostly B pictures. However, she did have a chance to shine opposite Eddie Cantor in Kid Millions, and as Mimi, Maurice Chevalier's showgirl mistress, in Folies Bergère. In Trade Winds (1938), for United Artists, Sothern, as detective Fredric March's dumb blonde sidekick, stole the picture from the leading lady, Joan Bennett.

Her performance gained the attention of MGM, who considered Sothern perfect to play the title role in Maisie. The studio had bought the 1935 Wilson Collison novel Dark Dame as a vehicle for Jean Harlow. After Harlow's premature death in 1937, it was shelved. When the MGM offer came, Sothern was shooting Hotel For Women at 20th Century-Fox, but when she accepted the offer from MGM, Darryl F Zanuck, head of Fox, removed her part out of pique.

Sothern's comic vitality and warmth gave an added dimension to the character of the scatterbrained, accident-prone but resourceful blonde heroine. In each of the series, which included Congo Maisie, Maisie Was A Lady, Gold Rush Maisie and Swing Shift Maisie, she would start off alone, broke, irritable and vulgar, gradually making friends and money, and becoming charming and well-groomed, usually helping others out of fixes.

With the Maisie movies, MGM had another hit series to add to Dr Kildare, Andy Hardy and Tarzan, and Ann Sothern had little time for other roles. However, her charm, pleasant singing voice and good looks were well used in musicals such as Lady Be Good (1941) and Panama Hattie (1942). She displayed dramatic talent in the all-female Cry Havoc (1943), as a warm-hearted army nurse in Bataan.

Perhaps her best film was Joseph L Mankiewicz's A Letter To Three Wives (1948), for 20th Century-Fox. In this stringent and witty social comedy, Sothern plays a radio soap writer, married to intellectual schoolteacher Kirk Douglas, who despises his wife's work. She is particularly effective in the dinner party scene, when she has to try to please both her husband and her sponsors.

After playing Jane Powell's actress mother in Nancy Goes To Rio (1950) and Anne Baxter's wise-cracking roommate in Fritz Lang's The Blue Gardenia (1953), she retired from films, retaining her popularity on TV in 104 episodes of Private Secretary, which she produced herself. She later sold the rights for more than $1m. Sothern also held the rights of the equally popular The Ann Sothern Show, in which she played the assistant manager of a swanky New York hotel. "I think Hollywood has been terrible to me," she once commented. "Hollywood doesn't respond to a strong woman, not at all. I was too independent. How dare a woman be competitive or produce her own shows?"

Recurring hepatitis kept her off the screen for some years in the 1950s. During a particularly bad time in her life, she befriended the film actor Richard Egan, under whose influence she converted to Catholicism. Previously, she had been married to two minor screen actors, both of whom she had appeared with in films: Roger Pryor and Robert Sterling (aka socialite William J Hart). Her daughter by the latter, Tisha Sterling, became an actress. (She had a leading role in Coogan's Bluff with Clint Eastwood.)

In the 1960s, having put on a great deal of weight in the interim, Sothern returned to the big screen playing blowsy hookers in three films: Lady In A Cage (1963), tormenting rich widow Olivia de Havilland; in Sylvia (1965), with Carroll Baker; and Chubasco (1967), in which she ran a brothel visited by real-life lover Richard Egan. In The Best Man (1964), she was a sententious and dangerous political committee woman. "It did Adlai Stevenson great harm not having a wife and trying to be funny all at the same time," she warns an unmarried presidential candidate - which could well have been a reference to Gore Vidal, who adapted his play for the screen.

Apart from some schlocky movies in the 70s and 80s, she was nominated for a best supporting actress Oscar for her role as the friend and confidante of elderly sisters Lillian Gish and Bette Davis in Lindsay Anderson's The Whales Of August (1987). A few years ago, Ann Sothern remarked: "Sometimes I'll watch an old movie on TV and once in a while one of mine will come on and I'll watch it. And you know something? I'm always amazed at what a lousy actress I was. I guess in the old days we just got by on glamour."

Those who remember Sothern with affection would violently disagree.

 Ann Sothern, film actress, born January 22 1909; died March 15 2001

fields.headline: Timeline of US 'spy' expulsions
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Russia
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The US president, George Bush, has ordered 50 Russian diplomats to leave their embassy in Washington DC, accusing them of spying for Moscow. If all 50 leave it will be the largest expulsion of since the collapse of the cold war.
fields.body:
The US president, George Bush, has ordered 50 Russian diplomats to leave their embassy in Washington DC, accusing them of spying for Moscow. If all 50 leave it will be the largest expulsion of since the collapse of the cold war.

Some past expulsions of foreign diplomats by the US government include:

 Aug. 21, 2000: The US government ordered two Congolese diplomats to leave after two American diplomats were expelled from Congo. The Congolese government accused the Americans of making statements inconsistent with their diplomatic role.

 Feb. 19, 2000: The state department ordered a Cuban diplomat to leave after linking him to a US immigration official who had been arrested on spy charges.

 December 1999: A Russian diplomat was ordered to leave after he was accused of picking up transmissions from a listening device discovered in the same building as the office of then-secretary of state, Madeleine Albright.

 December 1998: Three Cuban diplomats were ordered to leave after they were linked to a spy operation in which 10 people were arrested in Miami.

 May 1996: The United States ordered a Sudanese diplomat to leave in retaliation for his government's refusal to surrender suspects in an attempt to assassinate the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak.

 October 1986: Ronald Reagan ordered 80 Soviet diplomats to leave in batches of 25 and 55. The second move was partly in retaliation for the expulsion of five American diplomats from Moscow after the original US expulsion of 25 Soviets. It also was designed to bring the size of the Soviet Embassy staff in Washington and consulate staff in San Francisco "to parity" with the US contingent in Moscow and Leningrad.

webTitle: Arts: The British Free Cinema movement

fields.headline: Dreams were made of this
fields.standfirst: Free Cinema made less of a splash than the Nouvelle Vague. But Britain's version of the New Wave was just as remarkable, says Andrew Pulver
fields.trailText: Free Cinema made less of a splash than the Nouvelle Vague. But Britain's version of the New Wave was just as remarkable, says Andrew Pulver.
fields.body:
What, precisely, is it about Margate? Maybe it's the combination of windswept edge-of-the-world bleakness and the forlorn remnants of out-of-season frivolity, but the Kent seaside town's amusement arcade, Dreamland, appears to exert an uncanny fascination over film-makers with an eye for irony. The arcade - with its mocking "Welcome to Dreamland" sign - is the central image of Last Resort, the new asylum-seeker romance from Pawel Pawlikowski.

But 45 years earlier, the same arcade formed the subject matter for Lindsay Anderson's landmark 12-minute film O Dreamland. Shot in 1953, O Dreamland was the spearhead of Free Cinema, Britain's contribution to the flood of new waves that swept the global film industry in the years after the war. Pawlikowski films the modern Dreamland and its serried ranks of slot machines with a metaphoric cast; Anderson's Dreamland belongs to a different era, a compendium of model torture shows and fairground attractions, paced by patient lines of daytrippers.

O Dreamland didn't make a public impact until three years later - in 1956, in fact, as part of the inaugural Free Cinema programme at London's National Film Theatre in February of that year. Screening with it were two other low-budget British short films: Together - a 50-minute fiction by Lorenza Mazzetti and Denis Horne, about deaf-mute brothers living in London's East End - and Momma Don't Allow, a mostly documentary account of teens dancing to Chris Barber at the Fishmonger's Arms in Wood Green, co-directed by Karel Reisz and Tony Richardson. Tonight, the NFT plans to recreate the event by screening the three films once again.

Free Cinema was a commendably high-minded phenomenon, taking its cue largely from the inspirational Anderson, a prolific journalist whose work appeared regularly in Sight and Sound magazine as well as Sequence, the journal he helped found in 1947. Three decades later, in 1977, Anderson explained the opportunistic origins of the Free Cinema movement.

In 1955, he was unable to get his own films distributed, yet claimed some influence in the Oxbridge-educated coterie that dominated the BFI's experimental production programme. So he helped Italian art student Mazzetti to finish her deaf-mute film after co-writer Horne quit the project. With like-minded friends he pushed for a screening for Together at the NFT, along with his own already-completed documentary. Later Free Cinema programmes in 1957 and 1958 brought choice short films from Europe, including Roman Polanski's Two Men and a Wardrobe, and François Truffaut's Les Mistons.

Though its reputation has waned since, under the dismissive attacks of successive generations of critics anxious to puncture Anderson's self-assurance, Free Cinema has genuine claim to being a valuable, if undernourished, phenomenon. The same names recur on the credits, including Anderson himself, cinematographer Walter Lassally, and the multi-faceted John Fletcher. Other friends followed up with press articles - notably Gavin Lambert's piece in the spring issue of Sight and Sound, a magazine of which he happened to be editor.

Lambert demonstrated the se riousness of the Free Cinema mission - quoting DH Lawrence and Dylan Thomas, citing Zavattini, the great scenarist of Italian neo-realism, and acknowledging John Grierson and Humphrey Jennings, Free Cinema's documentarist forebears. In his article, Lambert also provided the most succinct and articulate expression of Free Cinema principles. "In the broadest sense," Lambert asserts, "[they] are films of protest . . . The camera-eye they turn on society is disenchanted, sad, occasionally ferocious and bitter."

Anderson's principal inspiration, however, was Jennings's lyrical formalism. In a 1954 essay, he praised Jennings - maker of home-front documentaries such as Fires Were Started and Listen to Britain - as "the only real poet the British cinema has yet produced". In Jennings's films, Anderson discovered a "style based on a peculiar intimacy of observation" and "a pattern of relationships and contrasts, endlessly varying, but each one contributing to the rounded poetic statement of the whole." Anderson sought to emulate this combination of idiosyncratic observation and meaningful juxtaposition in O Dreamland.

In fact, a pointed kind of documentary is the heart of all three original Free Cinema films. O Dreamland - somewhat infected with public-school distaste for Britain's brutish soul - follows the Jennings template of juxtaposition and statement. Momma Don't Allow, with its engaging jazz score, melds observation of teen rituals with a near-wordless narrative that gradually emerges from the surrounding vérité.

Together is the most narratively ambitious: again, hardly a word is spoken as the two principal characters, both deaf-mutes, make their way among East End children cavorting untutored for the camera. They make an instructive comparison with Last Resort: Pawlikowski, a documentary-maker by trade, plants a sense of actuality in his film by harnessing a range of vérité camera styles - juddering close-ups, video surveillance, hidden shooting positions - that achieves a similar, if considerably more fluid, effect.

Free Cinema's outspoken self- regard aroused hostility. Seeking to cultivate a generation gap, Anderson warred in print with Grierson, the godfather of the 30s documentarists, who responded by calling Free Cinema "baby stuff" and writing a series of ripostes, again in Sight and Sound, through 1954 and 1955. More contemporary critics too - Gilbert Adair and David Thomson - have weighed in. And no one in the technical side of the industry shed a tear when Free Cinema declared itself finished in 1959, after a screening of Karel Reisz's We are the Lambeth Boys.

So how should we judge Free Cinema now? Though its output was small, its claim as a pioneering example of New Wave is valid. The thirst for greater authenticity and a desire to break out of the studio, was the motor behind every New Wave film-maker. Even if it lacked the thematic sophistication of the French Nouvelle Vague, or the counter-culture robustness of the Hollywood auteurs, Free Cinema was a remarkable, ambitious phase in British film-making culture that should be treasured.

Free Cinema's key failure was its inability to translate its precepts into feature films. No such loss of nerve afflicted the European contingent: history records a vast range of original films, from Truffaut's The 400 Blows to Polanski's Knife in the Water. Richardson, Reisz, and Anderson, meanwhile, filmed books and plays of stolid, less-than-inspiring toughness, and the chance was lost. But their Free Cinema films are archeological fragments of a notion that verged on genuine magnificence.

 The Free Cinema Special Event is at the NFT, London SE1 tonight at 6.30pm. Box office: 020-7928 3232.

webTitle: Safety net for children's chat rooms

fields.headline: Safety net for chat rooms
fields.standfirst: New guidelines should help protect children from predators who stalk the web.  Hazel Southam  reports
fields.trailText: New guidelines should help teachers and parents protect children from predators who stalk the web.Hazel Southam reports
fields.body:
It's been a big week for internet safety. On Tuesday, the Home Office's internet crime forum published Chat Wise, Street Wise, a report highlighting the dangers posed to young people using chat rooms. And industry insiders report that the government is set to announce a spring internet safety summit.

But from today, chat rooms will be safer. At least, they will be if you follow an eight-point guideline issued by the Department for Education and Employment.

The new guidelines, written for the DfEE by the internet safety agency, Childnet International, are aimed at parents and teachers, but also send a message to the industry.

They recommend that children only use chat rooms that are moderated by a known moderator. They highlight the use of rooms that have topics advertised in advance, as the BBC does. And they warn against the use of rooms with advertising or other links that can draw children away from a group environment.

Safety is at the top of the list with checks for safety issues and password verification so that adults cannot pose as children.

One in five children who use computer chat rooms have been approached by paedophiles, according to the head of the internet crime forum. Detective chief superintendent Keith Akerman said: "There is clearly a problem out there of which parents are not yet fully aware. The aim of this report is to highlight the dangers and suggest ways the risk can be reduced."

But not all chat rooms are dangerous places, are they? Many are simply full of kids talking about their favourite bands and TV soap stars?

"If a parent went into a chat room, they might think it's harmless fun," says Stephen Carrick-Davies, of Childnet International, who wrote today's guide. "It's a good way to relax and have fun. We don't say that chat rooms should be shut down. They are here to stay and they have good educational opportunities.

"But the key thing that parents need to be aware of is that children have to lie to get online. It only works by giving an alias."

This means that people can pose as anyone else. I could call myself Bugs Bunny in a chat room. The potential for disaster is becoming clearer.

According to an NOP poll last November, almost 5m seven-to-16-year-olds in the UK use the internet and a quarter of those use chat rooms. But 10% have heard things in these rooms that embarrassed or upset them.

The main danger is that an adult may try to develop an inappropriate relationship offline with a child.

Last October, Patrick Green, 33, a divorced exports clerk from Iver Heath in Buckinghamshire, was sentenced to a five-year jail term for abusing a 13-year-old girl. He had met her in a chat room called Younger Girls for Older Men and exchanged messages with her for two months before meeting her.

He was arrested in Cumbria on his way to meet another 14-year-old girl he had met online and arranged to spend a weekend with. Judge Christopher Tyrer described him as a "predator" and ordered him to remain on the sex offenders' register for life.

Childnet is now lobbying the government to make enticement on the internet a recognised crime.

Last month, seven members of a global child pornography ring were jailed for distributing more than 750,000 images of child sex abuse. The club, which police believe had been operating for at least five years, required new members to provide 10,000 new images of child pornography as an entry fee.

The Wonderland Club involved the rape of boys and girls live on camera and the torture of children as young as two months. The images were so appalling that the National Crime Squad officers who had to look through them had compulsory counselling. To date, only two of the 1,236 Wonderland victims have been traced. It is feared that one of the two has been murdered.

Police and probation officers now fear that a wave of internet porn is sweeping the country, encouraged by light sentencing, some as lenient as 80 hours' community service. webTitle: Ad campaign on foot and mouth

fields.headline: PM unveils £10m advertising campaign to tackle tourist fears
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Tony Blair is launching a £10m global advertising campaign to assure foreign visitors over foot and mouth, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's desperate attempts to assure foreign visitors Britain is not "closed for business" will be reinforced with a £10m global advertising campaign about the foot and mouth crisis.

The British Tourist Authority, the body responsible for promoting UK tourism abroad, is preparing the campaign in a bid to stop the economic crisis in rural areas deepening.

With large swathes of Britain already closed to the public, the government is getting increasingly concerned foreign tourists will stay away.

In the Commons yesterday Mr Blair said postponing the May 3 local elections would send out a signal that Britain was "closed for business", damaging a tourist industry already hard hit by the crisis.

The government today launched a press and radio public information campaign in England and Wales setting out rules for visiting the countryside and how to access further guidance.

The crisis now threatens the start of the tourist season at Easter. Last year overseas tourism generated £863m in March and £1.1bn in April.

But it could be another month until the campaign launches, with campaign strategy unlikely to be finalised until the end of next week.

The BTA is seeking to appoint a marketing consultant and advertising agency to produce the campaign.

A spokesman for the BTA said the information-based campaign will attempt to allay confusion about foot and mouth for tourists and show there are many attractions open in the UK.

But he said a campaign to restore the reputation of the country as a tourist destination will not be viable until the crisis nears its end.

Tourism minister Janet Anderson has been visiting the US to calm holidaymakers' fears about visiting the UK.

The BTA's US offices have taken calls from tourists confusing foot and mouth with BSE and are asking if they need to bring their own food to the country.

Related stories

Feb 27: Foot and mouth hits tourism

fields.headline: Chronicle of a death foretold
fields.standfirst: Indira: The Life of Indira Nehru Gandhi by Katherine Frank, HarperCollins
fields.trailText: I shall never forget boarding an Air India plane at Heathrow 17 years ago to find the entire cabin crew in tears. They had just heard that Indira Gandhi was dead. When we landed at New Delhi the plane was surrounded by police. In the distance smoke rose over the old city, where Hindu mobs were massacring Sikhs in reprisal for Indira's assassination. Next day I sat with friends, watching the lying-in-state on television. Later there was Rajiv Gandhi, shimmering in the heat haze as he walked seven times around his mother's pyre. I can remember every detail of that week with absolute clarity: like so much else about India, it was utterly indelible.
fields.body:
I shall never forget boarding an Air India plane at Heathrow 17 years ago to find the entire cabin crew in tears. They had just heard that Indira Gandhi was dead. When we landed at New Delhi the plane was surrounded by police. In the distance smoke rose over the old city, where Hindu mobs were massacring Sikhs in reprisal for Indira's assassination. Next day I sat with friends, watching the lying-in-state on television. Later there was Rajiv Gandhi, shimmering in the heat haze as he walked seven times around his mother's pyre. I can remember every detail of that week with absolute clarity: like so much else about India, it was utterly indelible.

As Katherine Frank suggests in this excellent biography, the carnage that broke out after the assassination - more than 2,000 Sikhs were slaughtered in Delhi alone - was a depressing indication that Indira Gandhi's great mission in life, inherited from her father, had failed. For the Nehrus were dedicated to the notion of a secular state in which no creed or caste would dominate, and where the religious card that had beggared and bloodied the country could no longer be played. India was to be a democracy of distinction. Jawaharlal Nehru spent himself endlessly in this cause, and his daughter gave her life for it. The story of Indira Gandhi is a chronicle of what, between them, they achieved.

The book is dominated by three tremendous figures: Mahatma Gandhi, part saint, part humbug, and unrelated to Indira; Nehru, the highly Westernised (Harrow and Cambridge) Kashmiri agnostic who steered his country into and through independence; and Indira, the most tragic figure of the three because her life was cut off some distance short of her goal. The Mahatma achieved the seemingly impossible by shaming the British into leaving his country alone; Nehru gave India a sense of moral purpose and a truly democratic structure, unique throughout the rest of the old colonial world.

Indira wanted to carry this on, and to do more. She had a strangely sympathetic relationship with Margaret Thatcher, and it's easy to see why: both were strong-minded women with a clear sense of purpose who succeeded in a male-dominated profession, and both cherished deeply unattractive sons. There, however, the resemblance ends. Can anyone imagine the Grantham Grasper doing voluntary relief work in pestilential refugee camps, as Indira Gandhi did during Partition?

Two lesser characters helped shape Indira's destiny. One was her Parsee husband Feroze Gandhi; they became estranged, yet she still felt a responsibility for him. The other was her younger son Sanjay, a nasty piece of work whose every deed was fuelled by self-interest, and who increasingly influenced his adoring mother into actions that strayed from the Nehru tradition. But the main figure in her life was her father, who not only doted on her (as she did on him) but used her as a substitute confidante after the death of her mother.

She became his consort, and found herself slowly being lowered into the snakepit of Indian politics, as well as accompanying him on all his official journeys abroad. And although she never admitted it, the relationship became a burden: until Nehru died, when Indira was 47, she could not feel that she was her own woman.

As Frank makes plain, Indira Gandhi was an imperfect woman. She bore grudges, had a notoriously acid tongue and a "legendary genius for silence" that she learned from the Mahatma as a child, and which, like him, she used to intimidate. She could be ruthless, as when she imposed the Emergency on a nation descending into chaos (it worked, despite all the hand-wringing by ignorant liberals in the West). She was once caught out in a case of electoral malpractice, and paid for it under examination by the Shah Commission, which was itself later discredited.

On the other hand, she went to the country in due time, knowing that in the wake of the Emergency she would be defeated; everyone predicted the end of democracy in India, but she was a Nehru, and there was never any chance of that. After two years of Morarji Desai and a reversion to chaos, the country was glad to vote her back in. She also masterminded the Green Revolution, which made India self-sufficient in food.

She died as she had lived, dedicated to her ideal. After the secessionist thug Bhindranwale had fortified the Golden Temple in Amritsar so that it was desecrated when the Indian army stormed it, the chances of her being murdered were very high; she knew this, and started planning her funeral. The intelligence service advised her to get rid of the Sikhs in her security detail, but she refused: India, she insisted, was a secular nation. Beant Singh and Satwant Singh remained on duty at her residence, where one morning they shot her. She died bravely, and with her dignity intact. India is now in very different hands, and all who care about that country must tremble for the future of its secular democracy.

webTitle: Coppola loses $20m compensation for lost Pinocchio

fields.headline: Coppola loses $20m compensation for lost Pinocchio
fields.trailText: In a case that is seen as a precedent to what constitutes an agreement between a film company and a director, Coppola will lose the compensation that he was awarded by a jury in 1998
fields.body:
In a court case almost as labyrinthine and complex as his finest films, and costing just as much, the director Francis Ford Coppola has lost a multimillion-dollar battle with Warner Brothers over the making of a film about Pinocchio.

The case is seen as a precedent to what constitutes an agreement between a film company and a director.

Three judges of the California court of appeals sitting in Los Angeles ruled that Warner Brothers was entitled to tell its rivals at Columbia that it already had rights to a Coppola film of Pinocchio, thus warning them off.

The ruling means that Coppola loses a $20m (£14m) award he was given by a jury in 1998.

The saga dates back to 1992 when Coppola, now 61 and the maker of such films as the Godfather series and Apocalypse Now, signed a certificate of employment with Warner Brothers, who hoped to make a live action film of the tale.

But the film did not go ahead, and in 1994 Coppola entered discussions with Columbia. Warner Brothers fired off a letter to its rivals informing them that it already had rights to a Coppola film. Columbia did not make its planned film, and in 1995 Coppola sued Warner Brothers for "tortious interference".

In 1998 a jury awarded Coppola $80m against Warner Brothers - $60m in punitive damages and $20m in compensation.

It decided that Warner Brothers had falsely claimed to have a deal, thus depriving Coppola of his chance to make the film with Columbia.

A judge later dismissed the $60m but left Coppola with $20m in compensatory damages.

Warner Brothers appealed against the ruling and Coppola also appealed to have the $60m award restored. Now the appeals court has decided against Coppola on both counts.

In an 18-page ruling, the court said the Warner Brothers letter did not give grounds for an action.

"We conclude that a reasonable attorney, considering the facts before the court, would believe that Warner had a legally tenable claim in any Coppola Pinocchio project and that such claim was not totally and completely without merit," the judges said.

Warner Brothers had spent around $350,000 on the film and had worked for about two years with Coppola on the project.

Fred Cohen, of Horvitz and Levy, who handled the appeal for Warner Brothers, told the Hollywood Reporter: "The studios are going to be very relieved by this decision. After the jury's verdict, people were nervous about sending these kinds of letters putting others on notice of their rights. This opinion says they don't need to worry about trying to resolve matters informally without a lawsuit."

Variety headlined its report of ruling "Francis Floored".

Coppola's lawyer, Robert Chapman, said he believed that the jury had made the correct decision.

The case will now go to the supreme court, a lengthy procedure.

There are various screen versions of Pinocchio, the most famous being the 1940 Oscar-winning Walt Disney film. A sequel, Pinocchio and the Emperor of the Night, was made in 1987 and a live action version, The Adventures of Pinocchio, directed by Steve Barron, appeared in 1996 in a New Line production with Martin Landau, Jonathon Taylor Thomas, Dawn French and Griff Rhys Jones.

In a Japanese sci-fi film called 964 Pinocchio the hero is a sex slave.

fields.headline: Lord Alli joins Murdoch venture
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: Elisabeth Murdoch has lured Lord Waheed Alli and ex-BBC man Paul Hamann to her production company, writes Jason Deans.
Feb 22: Foster quits Carlton
fields.body:
Elisabeth Murdoch has signed up Planet 24 founder and former Carlton executive Lord Waheed Alli and former BBC head of documentaries Paul Hamann to her new production company.

Lord Alli, who quit Carlton TV last year, is expected to be chairman of the venture, with Mr Hamann taking up the post of creative director for factual.

Michael Foster, former managing director of content at Carlton, has also been linked to the company.

Former Royle Family producer and Lucky Dog managing director Kenton Allen has already joined as creative director for entertainment.

Ms Murdoch is also said to be looking for a drama head for her as-yet-unnamed company.

She is reported to have secured an output deal with former employer BSkyB, as well as the format rights to Australian reality show Single Girls.

Ms Murdoch quit as managing director of Sky Networks in May last year.

Related story

fields.body:
Sharp at four on a sunny winter's afternoon, the Guardian turns up with Tony Benn on the doorstep of Sir Edward Heath's London home, a terraced Belgravia house within sight of the garden wall of Buckingham Palace. It may seem an unlikely meeting, but the two have shared the past half-century in parliament. And when the coming election is called, both will retire from the Commons. Neither will go to the Lords.

Heath, the former Conservative prime minister (1970-74) and bete noire of the Tory right, was first elected for Bexley - now Old Bexley and Sidcup - in the general election of February 23 1950. Unlike Benn, he has unbroken service. The Labour ex-cabinet minister (1964-70 and 1974-79) reached the Commons via a byelection in Bristol South East a few months later, but briefly lost his seat twice.

Though Heath, at 84, is the elder by nine years and has always been the more senior politician, their paths have crossed many times during careers of great influence on our times. My plan is to explore the changes they have seen in the past 50 years.

Both veterans have just come from the now-weekly session of prime minister's question time. "My God, it is awful now, isn't it," says Heath, by way of an opener. "I'm afraid I dozed off," confesses Benn. "I've done it once or twice now. I can't bear it."

They agree about much of what is wrong: they both dislike the replacement of 15-minute sessions on Tuesdays and Thursdays with Blair's single 30 minutes on Wednesdays, just as they disliked the move in the 60s from specific questions to general ones designed to trip up the PM rather than elicit a detailed answer.

As to how to remedy the problem - or others we discuss - there is rather less agreement, though outright disagreement is politely avoided. It is just possible to imagine that the former Viscount Stansgate regards the former Mr Heath as a technocrat at heart, not very interested in the democratic questions that preoccupy him; and that, in return, Benn is regarded as a bit of a gadfly.

But it is all very polite, a bit like watching the great theatrical knights in old age - Olivier, Gielgud or Richardson - circling each other's eminence on the stage, warily but not unkindly. The unspoken eloquence of their pauses is worthy of Pinter himself.

They agree that 1956 was a turning point in postwar history, chiefly because the US thwarted the secret Anglo-French plan to recapture the newly nationalised Suez Canal by invading Egypt in collusion with Israel. As chief whip, Heath was one of just four British ministers in the know.

By 1956, Winston Churchill, who liked Heath enough to give him two of his own paintings (they hang on the wall of his other home in Salisbury), had finally retired as prime minister at 80. Anthony Eden, his dashing, doomed successor, wanted to make his mark. "Some of us understood it beforehand and always believed he [Eden] was wrong in what he was doing," says Heath. "I told him so privately; never discussed it publicly. But he didn't share that view, so they carried on. By the end of it [when US pressure on sterling forced a withdrawal from the canal after six days] Macmillan [then chancellor] certainly realised it meant the end of that period. That is why he supported our entry into Europe in 1961."

He does not have time to add that President De Gaulle of France vetoed his own efforts to negotiate British entry into the then four-year-old European common market, and that he only got us in when he was prime minister 12 years later. Benn intervenes: "Because he [Macmillan] saw the Americans let us down. I went to see Walter Monckton [minister of labour] privately at the time of Suez to see if he could head it off. Collusion was the thing, the deal between the French and British; it was the first time since the war or subsequently when the American president simply vetoed a British manoeuvre."

As ever, Benn is making contemporary political points. He points out that in the 60s Harold Wilson, the Labour prime minister, had refused US appeals to send a token British force to fight in Vietnam. "But otherwise, am I wrong in saying all British governments since 1945 have done what the Americans wanted ?"

"I wouldn't go that far," replies Heath, who rarely goes as far as Benn. "On Vietnam I wouldn't play with them either. I didn't play with Kissinger over India [the 1971 war with Pakistan], where he wanted us to go in. And I didn't play when he wanted to go into Cyprus, when he wanted to go in with the Israeli [Yom Kippur] war."

In its efforts to re-equip the Israeli armed forces, the US was forced to fly supplies in via the Azores: retaliation for the Suez affair, one might be tempted to murmur. Heath does not. He is busy recalling the speech he made at President Richard Nixon's side on the White House lawn at that time. "My remark was that there is no special relationship between Britain and the United States. What there was, was an historic relationship that was much stronger. A special relationship you can break up at any time if you reach a stage of disagreement. An historic relationship is there all the time."

Again, the reproach to less perceptive successors hangs in the air, unstated. Benn is less reticent. "We do not have an independent [nuclear] deterrent," he interjects. "Americans lend us Trident, the United States controls our intelligence. If we were to go against American policy we would be seen to be a non-nuclear power. If we are locked into star wars [President Bush's missile defence plan] against the opposition of most of the countries of Europe, this is going to test the nuclear relationship to the full."

These questions have a habit of coming full circle. Benn, who addresses his old rival as Ted (a gesture that is not reciprocated), remembers daring to ask Churchill a question about nuclear relations with the US in the early 50s and being ticked off by Clem Attlee, the former prime minister. "You shouldn't have asked that question, because I'm the only one who knows anything about it," the party leader told him.

"But that was real. Something else is happening which is more fundamental than the points Ted is mentioning. Modern politics is about the marketing of personalities. We are invited to be spectators of what the great and the good do. I think that has infected the house," says Benn. "I agree with Ted, PM's questions are awful. It could easily be stopped if the prime minister, when he got to a question from the leader of the opposition, said, 'That's an interesting point. I will have a look.' The whole thing would collapse."

It is not that they are against progress. They both think the modern select committee system is an important development and are glad that MPs are better paid (until the 60s they paid for their own stamps) and have staff and offices in which to work - although it diminishes the collegiate atmosphere, the time MPs used to spend together simply talking. One problem, says Heath, is that MPs come in expecting to be ministers within three years. His old patron, Harold Macmillan (PM from 1957 to 1963) waited 17 years before he got a job, he says. But you were made a whip within a year of being elected, I counter, and were chief whip by 1955. "Eleven months, I was very quick," he concedes, without the need for further justification.

"I had to wait 14 years," interjects Benn. "You were a whip under Winston, were you?"

Heath: "Yes, I was."

Benn: "Well, there you are."

Benn then complains that ministers spend "less and less time dealing with executive matters, and just go round opening things and closing things and tripping up over things and all the rest of it". "Pure propaganda," says Heath, which brings Benn around to his childhood in a political household (his father had also been a cabinet minister), watching the rise of Hitler.

"I bought Mein Kampf when I was about eight and I still read it. It's an astonishing book. He said democracy inevitably leads to Marxism. Work that one out!" His point is that "if you don't do people justice, they'll go for a demagogue. Any nation that loses confidence in democracy will be seduced. That's the thing that makes me worry about the fall in turnout in America." He mentions the Nuremberg rallies.

Heath remains silent. As an Oxford student of modest origins and progressive instincts, he took himself off to Germany to inspect Hitler at close quarters. Making his way to Nuremberg in 1937, his memoirs report, he witnessed the Führer walking to the podium, "his shoulder brushing mine as he went past". "This experience subsequently dominated my political life," Heath would one day write, confirming him as an anti-appeaser, later (after he had returned to Germany in battle) as a passionate European, convinced that only a Europe "united, free and democratic" would be safe from the demons of ultranationalism.

The conversation moves on. But we come back to it via what both the old warriors agree is a disturbing tendency towards global interventionism by the US, with Britain tagging along in its wake.

Heath: "What is happening alarms me because this Labour government is jumping back 50 years and trying to exert its influence in the world in what is really a colonial atmosphere and system ... There was a parliamentary commission which went out to China and produced a report which was really incredible. It was a report of a colonial power telling its colony what it's got to do. The way we have [also] intervened in Sierra Leone is really colonial."

"I agree with Ted," says Benn. "Just as the 19th century was characterised by the British empire and the 21st by the American empire, that is domination of a military kind nobody has ever contemplated. Britain is now piggy-backing on American power to pretend we have the power. We don't have the power to do anything about Saddam Hussein."

Benn sees Britain trying to find a place in a changing world. "On Europe I understand exactly what Ted feels; I respect him; he's been consistent. He saw wars that split Europe, that destroyed it, and wants to bring it together. No nonsense about convergence criteria [for entry into the euro]. To him it's a political thing.

"If only we could explore the options without it being said that Ted wants the Brussels commission to give instructions to every parking meter. Or that he says we are anti-European, which I'm not. Let's have a rational debate, if only the House of Commons could have a serious debate about Europe."

Heath: "All my debate is rational."

Benn: "I know, Ted. I have never doubted you were - are - a model for us all."

Heath perks up. He recently spent a fruitful day discussing Europe with Oxford dons. "The fact is it is a political question, first and foremost. But what we have to realise is that we can't stand outside and keep saying we are going to come in," he says sharply. "And Blair made this ghastly mistake, he went on and on. And finally the German chancellor blew up and said, 'Prime minister, this is our union and we decide what will happen. And you can't do it for us. That was when Blair took his first crack and he's been mainly quiet since then."

Going into Europe late and then telling them what to do "drove them absolutely mad. I didn't do it; that's why I'm still respected in most of Europe. I recognised that you have got to show them that you are part of them before you can start influencing them in a particular direction."

Benn starts to intervene, then Heath asks him his only direct question of the session. "Does your prime minister really think he has got his party lined up ?"

"I don't know," Benn replies. "If you want advice about the prime minister's thoughts, don't come to me. I am not privy."

The Blair cabinet "are under tremendous pressure, to which they give way the whole time, from the press," says Heath. This is one of his recurrent dislikes because what he sometimes calls the "foreign-owned press" (Rupert Murdoch and Conrad Black) are so hostile to Europe.

I ask what is wrong with the press. "Everything. We have the worst press in the world; the people who have now captured the press are of that calibre, that outlook. I had lunch with one of its editors a short time ago and said, 'You know, it's the influence of the owners and editors on the press that is causing the trouble.' He said, 'The public take it from us, not you.' "

"Like the medieval church," chips in Benn. Heath says he doesn't want to discuss individuals - and then does. "If you take the question of Murdoch, he declared that he was supporting the Labour party and, if you look at his papers, they couldn't be more opposed, supporting the Tory party indirectly."

Benn says he is constantly amazed at the media's failure to report what matters to the people who turn up at public meetings. "I have done five with over 1,000 people, on Palestine, the sale of council houses, cuts in Hackney, globalisation." And he contradicts Heath's notion that, in the good old days, Lords Beaverbrook and Northcliffe separated the news from the comment columns. "A slightly dreamy view of the past," he ventures.

I ask Heath if the press and electorate should have been told when Churchill suffered a stroke in 1953 while he was still in charge. It elicits a very Heath-ish: "No, why should you have done?" As with Suez, very few were in the know, including both the Queen and Heath, as deputy chief whip. "We were able to handle the situation extremely well." And Churchill recovered. "I shall never forget the party conference at Margate. We had this great rally and there was Winston. The chief whip sat behind him and the speech went splendidly. Then we got to this thing where he turned over the page and started reading the same thing again.

"The chief whip looked at me and said, 'Sorry, this is the end.' But Churchill then said, 'I seem to have heard this somewhere before. Perhaps I should turn on.' So he turned over the page and went on. He lasted 18 months after that."

When I later telephone Heath to clarify a few points, I ask what his most important achievements were. Getting into Europe he calls only "a major achievement", which surprises me. He rattles off reform of the tax system; freeing up the housing market to cope with modern needs; the abortive 1971 Industrial Relations Act, a better deal for the unions that broke it than they got from the next Tory government. There were also changes to the immigration laws that, he says, stopped the issue being a "continuous sore" - a reference to Enoch Powell, whom he bravely sacked for his "rivers of blood" speech in 1968.

Benn's answer to the same question on the phone is that he is glad to have campaigned early for reforms that eventually prevailed - "acorns which became trees", as he puts it. Lords reform, of course; freedom of information; gay rights; a trade boycott against apartheid South Africa. Even public ownership is creeping back into fashion, he suggests. "I get letters from people who say, 'I have never agreed with a word you said in your life, Mr Benn,' but then proceed to repeat what I said. You are glad you didn't give up when everyone else gave up."

Great figures of their time? I ask them both. This is a hard one for politicians, among whom - even the most virtuous - ego is a significant component in any 50-year career. Heath does not mention you-know-who, his nemesis from Finchley. But he is loyal to his friends. "Eden has been underestimated because of Suez. What he did in the 30s and early 50s [as foreign secretary] was excellent diplomacy." As for Macmillan, "opinions differ; most of it is wrong". But his stock too will recover.

Benn deplores personality politics, though he has a formidable political personality himself. So he cites speeches instead: Nye Bevan on western rearmament in the 50s, warning that it would lead to a witchhunt against socialists; the young Iain Macleod (who died after three weeks as Heath's chancellor in 1970) famously attacking the great Nye in his maiden speech. Powell was "always worth listening to. People said he had the best mind in parliament until he made it up." In 1968 even Robert Maxwell had made a brilliant speech on the Soviet invasion of his native Czechoslovakia. "People listened, as they did to an ex-miner talking about a pit disaster, because he spoke from his own experience."

Which is why, when Heath and Benn rise, as they shortly will, to make valedictory Commons speeches, old friends and enemies alike will sit quietly and listen. Churchill and Nye, Mao and Nixon, Khrushchev and De Gaulle - a major link between the Commons and its past is about to be severed. Who else can still claim to have brushed shoulders with Hitler?

webTitle: In brief: Meryl Streep joins Spielberg's Minority Report

fields.headline: Meryl Streep joins Spielberg's Minority Report
fields.standfirst: Plus: Kidman goes to the dogs for von Trier; Kathy Bates lives it up in About Schmidt; Jason Alexander gets shallow for the Farrelly brothers; Jude Law to take a bite of Hannibal?
fields.trailText: Plus: Kidman goes to the dogs for von Trier; Kathy Bates lives it up in About Schmidt; Jason Alexander gets shallow for the Farrelly brothers; Jude Law to take a bite of Hannibal?
fields.body:
 Meryl Streep has signed on to take a small role in the Fox/DreamWorks production Minority Report, which begins shooting this week with Steven Spielberg in the director's chair. Set in an Orwellian future where prospective criminals are tracked by a rampant police state, Minority Report is based on a Phillip K Dick short story and stars Tom Cruise. The role marks something a renaissance for Streep. The Oscar-winning actress recently completed work on Adaption, the new film from Being John Malkovich director Spike Jonze, and last week signed to play the schizophrenic mother of Gwyneth Paltrow in Daughter of the Queen of Sheba.

 Still smarting from both her split with husband Tom Cruise and a knee injury she sustained on the set of Moulin Rouge, Nicole Kidman has clearly elected to throw herself into her work. The Aussie actress has just signed on to star in Dogsville, the new film from maverick director Lars von Trier. Set in a small Midwestern town in the 1930s, Dogsville will co-star Stellan Skarsgard and Katrin Cartlidge, who both collaborated with von Trier on his award-winning Breaking the Waves. Production will begin this autumn, after the end of the scheduled SAG strike and as soon as Kidman has finished acting in Stephen (Billy Elliott) Daldry's British-set The Hours in London.

 Oscar winner Kathy Bates will star opposite Jack Nicholson in About Schmidt. The Misery star will play a hippyish mum who clashes with the starchy father of her son's fiancee. Nicholson will play the disapproving dad in the film which will be helmed by Alexander Payne, director of the brilliant 1999 satire Election.

 Seinfeld graduate Jason Alexander is to join the cast of the Farrelly brothers' comedy Shallow Hal in which Jack Black plays a superficial skirt-chaser who falls in love with an overweight lass with a heart of gold (played by Gwyneth Paltrow in a fat-suit). Alexander - who played the lowly, venal George in the long-running TV sitcom - will co-star as Black's best friend.

 The Hannibal franchise looks set to continue. Producer Dino De Laurentiis is reportedly laying the ground for a prequel to his record-breaking horror flick, and has commissioned Ted Tally to write a script loosely based on Thomas Harris's novel Red Dragon (previously filmed as Manhunter). The movie's casting could well have buffs choking on their sandwiches. Rumours suggest that Dino is gung ho for Jude Law to play the young Hannibal Lecter.

webTitle: Row over major housing association shake-up

fields.headline: Row over major housing association shake-up
fields.trailText: Housing associations are on a collision course with their regulator over controversial proposals to overturn more than a century of tradition by introducing professional board members. Matt Weaver reports.
fields.body:
Housing associations are on a collision course with their regulator over controversial proposals to overturn more than a century of tradition by introducing professional board members.

High profile scandals and the increasingly complex nature of housing associations have prompted the housing corporation to propose a shake-up of the way associations are governed.

The plans, published yesterday, have already prompted a fierce response for threatening to wreck the voluntary ethos of the sector - seen as one its greatest assets.

The way housing associations are governed has remained largely untouched since the 19th century when the first housing associations were formed. Board members can now be paid a maximum of only £50 a year, but few even go this far.

The housing corporation set outs a range of options for paying members, from increasing the £50 limit for the larger organisations to allowing all associations complete flexibility on how much they pay board members.

Aiming to improve the standard of probity in the sector, the plans come after a series of scandals in the sector, which culminated earlier this month when Liver housing association board was criticised for proposing to pay £837,000 in a severance deal for its chief executive.

In the past 10 years housing associations have become bigger and more complex businesses and have raised nearly £20bn in private loans since 1988. In addition, they are set to take over the bulk of local authority housing in an ambitious transfer programme.

The paper says: "The governing bodies of some housing associations face the challenge of controlling riskier, more diverse organisations in a more demanding operating environment.

"Some say that our current regulatory restrictions, such as our limitation on executive board members, are hindering the development of effective governance."

The corporation concedes that the plans are highly contentious and that some will see them as a "move away from the voluntary ethos of the sector".

Clare Hepworth, chairwoman of Durham-based Three Rivers housing association, opposed the plan. "One of the movement's greatest strength is that it is voluntary. I can look the tenants in the face and think I'm not getting paid, it is crucial to the integrity. Health trust members get paid and look at the problems in the health service."

She added: "What is the problem that paying board members would solve? It is presumptuous and arrogant to assume that Liver's board would have made a different decision if their board members had been paid."

But Mark Lupton, policy officer at the Chartered Institute of Housing, claimed that housing associations needed a "radical shake-up" of their 19th century structure.

fields.headline: Telewest results beat expectations
fields.trailText: 9.15am: Cable operator Telewest has emerged from a nightmare year by posting pre-tax earnings of £247m, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Cable operator Telewest has left a nightmare year behind after reporting results that were ahead of market expectations.

The UK's second largest cable company reported widening losses for 2000 after making the painful transformation into a digital business, but climbed above analysts' earnings targets.

Adam Singer, chief executive of Telewest, said the company was on the right track following a year of acquisitions and management changes.

"If Telewest were human, it would have been the equivalent of changing jobs, moving house, getting married and giving birth all in one year. It was a tough year but the results show that we made it," he said.

Earnings before interest, taxes, amortisation and depreciation rose 11% to £247m, topping forecasts and supplying some good news for the UK cable industry.

Telewest confirmed it had reached its target of 500,000 digital subscribers this month, up from 377,000 at the end of last year. It did not give a goal for the rest of the year.

The all-important churn rate figure, or the proportion of customers who leave the service, fell 2.7% to 26% after the company revamped its much-maligned customer service operations.

Despite the improvement in churn, analysts will want to see that figure fall further and are hoping for fewer technical faults with the digital service.

Mr Singer also promised there would be no repeat of the disastrous events that hit the company last year, when a shortage of components for set-top boxes paralysed its digital service.

"The set-top box supply problems that caused us to pause our marketing last summer are history," added Mr Singer.

But the pre-tax loss for 2000 deepened from £530m to £701m, due to the cost of buying pay-TV company Flextech and rival firm Eurobell and the launch of the digital service.

Telewest recently shored up its growing debt - which now stands at £4.4bn - by restructuring its overdraft facilities

However, Telewest delivered strong revenue growth, climbing 42% to £1.1bn.

Cable is a potential money-spinner, as it can offer "bundled" services which combine telephone, internet and digital through a single cable line.

But in terms of their digital services, Telewest and close rival NTL remain far behind BSkyB, which has over 4.6m customers, and ONdigital, which has just over 1m.

NTL has set itself a target of 1.25m digital subscribers for its digitalplus service by the end of the year.

Rumours of a merger between NTL and Telewest have become a stock market staple, but it is more likely that both companies will co-operate over joint purchasing of set-top boxes and approaching regulatory issues.
