fields.headline: About King of the Kippax
fields.standfirst: Editor Dave Wallace introduces you to a blue-blooded fanzine, for the fans, by the fans
fields.trailText: Editor Dave Wallace introduces you to a blue-blooded fanzine, for the fans, by the fans.
fields.body:
A painful birth

In the mid-eighties there was hooliganism, the Heysel disaster, the Bradford fire, the threat of ID cards, Colin Moynihan (remember him?), Margaret Thatcher, away fans banned at Luton etc, etc. Reporting throughout the media failed to reflect the experiences of the ordinary football fans who weren't thugs or anarchists, as you might think, but passionate football experts with a valid point of view which was given little opportunity to express itself.

I was reading general fanzines like Off The Ball and When Saturday Comes, and in 1987 I joined the FSA, where I was an active member.

I was an occasional writer to the local press, the City programme, and a collector of football memorabilia, but I was frustrated by the current image of the football fan in the media, as it didn't fit my own experience of funny, articulate, peacefully partisan, terrace 'regulars'. Encouraged by friends in the FSA, I decided to start a fanzine for my beloved Manchester City, but was beaten to it by Blueprint, City's first fanzine. No problem, I thought, I'll just send my contributions to them.

However, on the opening day of the 88/89 season at Hull there was no City 'zine on the streets. The vital deadline had been missed. I resolved to do better. I had to go it alone.

My mate Tony offered to arrange inexpensive printing. I borrowed £500 from the bank, and King Of The Kippax was born. It takes its name from that vast terrace, now rebuilt and seated, which was the voice of Maine Road, and Colin Bell, who was THE King of the Kippax. And it was royal because it was a fanzine for all blue-blooded City fans.

First exposure

September 24th 1988. Barnsley away. We won 2-1. I was on my own and I nearly bottled out from selling. But I'd sunk my dosh into it, the loan had to be repaid, and, anyway, it was all my own work, and I thought it was a good read! I sold 80 on the first day. Wow! It was off the ground.

My wife, Sue, helped with the production - typing and doing cartoons - and she still does, taking a more active role with selling as well - more of a co-editor now. We wanted to publish regularly, with up-to-date and balanced views, hitting the major issues; reflecting on events; supplying information and, most of all providing a platform for the fans to express themselves. And they did.

We gradually built up a pool of regular contributors, and sellers too. Then we had subscribers, from all over the world. It was fascinating to read the many stories of how people became Blues, how they followed from afar, or travelled hundreds of miles to see the Blues play.

We produced four issues in the first season of our existence, six in the second, and by 90/91 we were up to seven issues. This year, as last, will see nine issues produced. This is entirely due to the many, varied and wonderful contributions we receive.

Fanzine format

Regular features include How Was It For You?, It's A Fix, KK Editorial, Ged Sounds Off, The Cat, Burfield and the off-the-wall, but strangely on-the-ball, imaginative creations of Colin Nicholls.

We see our role as encouraging fans to write about their own experiences, their hopes, fears and funnies, and then doing our best, with limited facilities, to present their articles attractively. We produce our own cartoons, ground diagrams, progress charts etc. and mostly readers seem to approve. Certainly we are never short of contributions, and are continually impressed by the high quality.

Interestingly, whenever a regular bows out, for whatever reason, someone new seems to pop up in their place. Most of what is sent in is published, but there are no guarantees. Time and space are the biggest enemies, and it's often our own stuff which is edited out first!

Fanzine friends

Over the years our family and friends have learned to fit in with the fanzine. Births, deaths and marriages, sickness, holidays and birthdays have all been scheduled to suit fanzine deadlines at one time or another!

The friends we have made through the 'zine are special to us. Maybe we don't say often enough how much they are appreciated. But they know they are, we hope! We've met celebs, and helped to make some too - ones who have written for us have been inspired to bigger and better things, which is very gratifying.

The content has ebbed and flowed with the fortunes, and (mostly) misfortunes of Manchester City. We've campaigned, consoled, celebrated, commiserated, communicated, co-operated, confessed and congratulated, all within the pages of KK. One thing's for sure, it's never been boring!

Fanzine finance

This season we've been forced to increase the price, to £1.50 (over 40 pages A4) due to production costs - ie. not just the printing but running costs in general, like phone bills, computer bills, paper, storage, books, newspapers, videos, distribution etc.

We shy away from paid advertising, apart from occasionally, for a special reason, as there are adverts galore in every professional mag, and we don't choose to sacrifice a fan's effort for the sake of a commercial product. So, the price reflects the cost.

KK had been £1 for over ten years, and recently we were in danger of having to subsidise it ourselves. We think the hours and hours we put into the production should be enough contribution from us, without raiding the kids' piggy banks!

Fanzine future

We always think the next issue will be the last. But the contributions roll in, we're fired up again, and off we go! The fanzine movement, I suspect, has peaked and many are closing down. But at City we have FOUR fanzines of excellent quality. Each with its own characteristics, as you would expect from City fans. ALL better than the Stretford Rangers lot.

Whether, in this time of football plc mania - with official publications on the increase, and access to players and management undreamed of in fanzine circles - the home-made quality of the fans' own productions will continue to appeal is anyone's guess. But we're working on our next issue now, and wondering how we're going to get all the contributions in, again. Why not read it and see what you think?

Available from

25 Holdenbrook Close, Leigh, WN7 2HL

e-mail: kippax.editor@opeluk.net

website: www.kingkippax.fsnet.co.uk

fields.headline: Advertising slump hits Capital
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Capital Radio shares have taken a hammering after the radio group issued a profit warning, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Shares in Capital Radio took a hammering this morning after the UK's largest commercial radio group issued a profit warning.

Capital, home of Chris Tarrant and Dr Fox, said in a trading statement poor advertising revenues would produce a 10% fall in full-year profits.

The news sparked a run on Capital's shares, which tumbled 22% to a two-year low of 192.5p by late morning.

"It is too early to forecast the level of profits for the year as a whole," Capital said in its statement.

"However, a continuation into the second half of the current conditions in our advertising markets would be likely to result in reported profits for the year being at least 10% lower than last year."

The radio sector was thought to be well protected against an advertising downturn by some analysts.

However, Capital is clearly facing a similar situation to that of ITV, which has been hit hard by an advertising slump.

These fears filtered through to Capital's listed rivals, with shares in GWR falling 10% and Chrysalis down 3.4%.

Radio shares have taken a battering over the past week as analysts voiced concerns that commercial stations were not taking enough audience share from the BBC.

Instead, new commercial players are taking listeners away from older, more established rivals.

Capital's last full-year results, for the 12 months to September 2000, registered a pre-tax profit of £30.25m.

fields.headline: See you in hell, Yankee
fields.standfirst: Although we usually just ignore the goings on at the Old Trafford Swamp, here's a piece from the latest edition by one of KK's regulars, John Burfield, on the Rags linking up with the New York Yankees
fields.trailText: Although we usually just ignore the goings on at the Old Trafford Swamp, here's a piece from the latest edition by one of KK's regulars, John Burfield, on the Rags linking up with the New York Yankees.
fields.body:
There've only been a few occasions when my surroundings have robbed me of the power of speech. I'm not talking about places that have evoked great solemnity, like Dachau or Kanchanaburi, or instances where fear took hold - but places where the sheer noise and level of activity induce a kind of temporary sensory overload.

This eventuality has been largely confined to the day of arrival in certain "Third World" cities (Bangkok, Guanzhou and Varanasi all did it to me), but not exclusively. The same thing happened the first time I went to New York (1988), when, with two mates, I flew late into JFK, and then got an express bus to the "delightful" (least it was then) Port Authority Bus Terminal off 8th Avenue, arriving at about 11pm on a muggy June night.

Suffice to say that 18 relatively tranquil years in Devon, or even 6 in Liverpool, had done nothing to prepare me for the assault on the senses that wandering blindly through a teeming mass of junkies, hookers, down-and-outs, pickpockets and neglected mental patients (all topped off by a screaming police siren soundtrack) provided. It was several hours before silent bewilderment gave way to a semblance of composure again.

Anyway, this is turning into a long-winded yarning session, so we'll move straight to the next evening, when for want of anything better to do, we decided to go to a baseball match. No, not the Yankees, but the Mets at Shea Stadium. I had no preference at the time, just the Mets happened to be at home. Outside, stalls selling memorabilia (or monumental tat, if you'd prefer) lined the pavement. We stopped at one. Laid out were Mets baseball shirts, $25 dollars a shout.

"One of those please", I said pointing.

"You don't want one a dose", said the sharp eyed stall owner, clocking our accents, "You want one a dees", and he hauled a box of last year's stock up off the floor.

"Dees are special commemorative shoits" he lied. "Only thoity five dollars".

"Great", I said like the mug punter that I undoubtedly was. "Here you go".

The interesting part, though, was when I asked if he had any Yankees gear too (cos I thought I might as well buy one of each).

His mood darkened.

"Dose arrogant f'cks! I'd rather eat my own shit, than sell their stuff! Try one a dose udder guys" he said, gesticulating at the other stall holders.

Well, I did, and, after each hastily laying out a sprinkling of last year's Mets gear, when they saw us coming, with the original price replaced by something higher, they all said pretty much the same thing.

Anyway, admittedly Shea Stadium was probably not the best location to canvass opinion on the Rags, sorry the Yankees, but interestingly I found the same sentiments expressed all over the States. The parallels between the "pride of American baseball" and the "pride of Singapore Experience" are remarkably alike.

Don't knock it 'til you've tried it though, so I later went to see the Yankees as well, and, after buying a baseball cap this time, discovered that the similarities between the Rags and the NYY extended to inside the stadium as well. People eating popcorn, no atmosphere, long periods of silence and choreographed (there's that word again) cheering prompted by a giant electronic screen, that flashed up things like "Go team go" at periodic intervals.

In fairness, the Mets experience was little better. Like all American sports, the condensed action on the telly is way more exciting than the stop-start, boring, commercial-breaked reality. Baseball sucks, the Rags suck, and my precious Yankees cap has regrettably joined my Nike sweat shirt in the great jumble sale in the sky.

Congratulations to United. Not only have they helped the Yankees become America's most hated baseball team on this side of the Atlantic as well, but they're leaving me with nothing to wear.

fields.headline: No 10. Manchester City
fields.standfirst: Steve Parish, the Blue Vicar, contributor, seller, and keeper of the subs for King of the Kippax, Manchester City's best-selling fanzine, spills the beans on his club
fields.trailText: Steve Parish, the Blue Vicar, contributor, seller, and keeper of the subs for King of the Kippax, Manchester City's best-selling fanzine, spills the beans on his club.
fields.body:
Who are yer?

Few deny Man City fans the accolade of "most loyal". "Most perverse" might be more accurate. For when City suffered two relegations in three years and were struggling in the Second Division, they could still attract crowds of over 30,000. Back-to-back promotions brought Premiership football back to Maine Road, but those who miss the day trip to Grimsby may not have long to wait.

Off the field, new chairman David Bernstein, whose French Connection connection made him financier-friendly, and a more active board have arrested the growing debt and slow decline under the late Peter Swales and the false dawn under Francis Lee.

Low point

Picking a low point out of recent years would be like scraping the barrel for yet another piece of rotten apple. Losing 1-0 to Bury at home was my personal nadir.

High point

High points are numerous for fans of a certain age who can remember European trophy nights, winning the League, and (my personal best moment) Tommy Booth's late goal that sent us to the FA Cup Final in 1969. That just about beats the moment when Paul Dickov's equaliser went in at Wembley in the Second Division play-off final in 1999.

Now

At the moment, a combination of poor tactics, poor players, and poor refereeing decisions leaves us hovering over a swift return to the First Division.

Last match

Bradford City away. We took a first-half lead, then let Bradford back in with two early second-half goals. We grabbed an equaliser, but that leaves us four points adrift of the team above. Worse, it's the second successive match we've started to play like a doomed team.

Even worse, Premiership football seems to have attracted an unwholesome breed of new drunken fan singing right-wing songs, culminating in racist chants at Bradford and attacking a Muslim youth club after the game. But by and large, City fans aim to be noisy but friendly, and one bloke got arrested for challenging the racists and ending up in a fight.

Next match

Aston Villa at home. Yet another we must win.

Sore point

"Teams in this position get no luck". Cobblers. Teams get in this position because of poor luck and disgraceful refereeing decisions (eg: Danny Tiatto's goal of the season against Middlesbrough disallowed for offside against a player not interfering - no argument about this, the situation was a dead ringer for a "not offside" diagram in the FA referees' guide).

Rivals

Can't think of anyone.

Kit

By Le Coq Sportif. Trad sky blue is now replaced by "laser blue". Home kit's not too bad but Day-Glo yellow socks and a silver shirt put the away kit in the barf category (though it's sold well).

Mascot

The charming alien Moonchester, whose affable nature is occasionally challenged by more aggressive animals (often wearing animal mascot costumes).

Players rated

The current hero is usually each latest signing until he proves to have feet of clay. Shaun Goater's cult hero status has evaporated, and Danny Tiatto will be player of the year.

Colin Bell remains City's best-ever outfield player, though if Peter Schmeichel can have a medal (for what?) then Bert Trautmann should be Sir Bert. Opposition player probably most welcome at Maine Road is Niall Quinn (not least for sussing Alan Ball).

Players hated

Joe Royle seems to keep his own little list, but no-one is currently the boo-boys' particular target. An all-time villain (as opposed to plain incompetents) would be hard to pin down: Nigel Clough was a waste of space and money, but Nicky Summerbee is the only one still playing likely to get jeered on his return. From other teams, obviously anyone from Trafford Rovers, but Alan Shearer also attracts a fair amount of abuse. Fair enough.

The ground

Maine Road has largely kept up with its facilities but not the numbers (from a non-Wembley English record of 84,000 to its present 34,000). The Kippax Street stand used to be the home fans "end", except it was a whole side. Its three-tier replacement has been superseded by the North Stand as the main noise-generator, partly because the away fans get a corner of the North Stand, plus an open tier of seats known as the Gene Kelly Stand (singing in the rain ... ). Sadly, there's a nasty bottleneck there after the game - watch out for a police force keen to justify use of horses. A new 48,000 stadium close to City's origins in East Manchester beckons in 2003.

Atmosphere

Deadly at the moment. The non-singers at home make it impossible to recreate the away feel, and even the singers are depressed. A whole repertoire of regular away songs goes unsung at home. Blue Moon will usually emerge, and the Invisible Man song ("We are not, we're not really here...") but it's an effort.

Other attractions

Getting a pre-match pint is OK. There are no home-only pubs, though one or two are a bit hairy, but the giant Parkside on Lloyd Street is not intimidating (apart from the guys "collecting for charity" on the door - give them a donation and they'll be charitable with you).

There are several decent chippies - the one on Yew Tree Road behind the Kippax is best value. Balti pies inside the ground are £1.95, but don't forget Rusholme's Curry Mile is only 10 minutes walk away.

Big Helen no longer rings her famous bell but collects donations outside the development club.

The Royle Out campaign

There isn't one. No-one likes the thought of having to find yet another manager; the optimists still think we'll survive and we always knew fourth from bottom would be success this season while the pessimists think he'll be the ideal manager to get us promoted again if we do go down. Given the state we were in, he gets immense credit for taking on a job that others bottled, but his tactics for the top flight and ability to manage real class players are persistent doubts. He's said he'll retire in a couple of years. If we were doing well, he might change his mind, but if we go down and don't start well next season, he might be expected to do a John Aldridge.

Chant of the moment

"25 years and we're still here" is a defiant response to Rag taunts about us going 25 years without winning a major trophy. Strangely, United fanzines seem more obsessed with City than vice-versa.

Other fanzines

City till I Cry, Chips and Gravy, and Bert Trautmann's Helmet, plus MCIVTA the online fanzine (Manchester City Info Via the Alps - don't ask): subscribe to that at mcivta@tollbar.u-net.com.

(A recent highlight: One fan took his four-year-old son to Maine Road for the first time for the Southampton match, and reported that with just 10 minutes to go and City losing 1-0 his son shouts out as loud as can be: "When are we going, Dad?" The bloke in front turns round to him and explains that he's got another 50 years of this to come. He's one of us now.)

Websites

Blueview welcomes other non-abusive fans: http://boards.rivals.net/default.asp?sid=914&p=16&forumid=4501

King of the Kippax's own website is: www.kingkippax.fsnet.co.uk

fields.headline: City firm launches mobile marketing blitz
fields.trailText: 11.30am: A City firm has launched what is believed to be the first text message campaign targeted at the over-50s, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
If you thought text messaging was a curious habit of the younger generation, think again - a City firm has launched what is believed to be the first SMS campaign targeted at the over-50s.

It is also the first time a traditional institution has used text messaging to market itself.

Deutsche Bank's fund management firm, DWS, has teamed up with mobile marketing experts Flytxt to break ranks from the traditional way of generating customer interest.

A number of customer relationship campaigns are planned, including a game whereby customers can guess assets under management and the introduction of fund purchase receipts by SMS rather than paper.

Sending out confirmation messages to its 3m customers will cut DWC's costs by 80%.

"We have recognised that the meteoric rise of text messaging has opened up a new channel for us to communicate with our clients and agents," said Torsten Barnitzke, head of e-commerce at DWS.

Flytxt launched in November last year and currently works with Smash Hits and Channel 5.

fields.headline: Novelist quits 'imperial' contest
fields.trailText: Indian novelist Amitav Ghosh has withdrawn his book from the Commonwealth Writers competition because he objects to the idea of his work being classified as "commonwealth literature" when the prize is only open to books written in English.
fields.body:
Indian novelist Amitav Ghosh has withdrawn his book from the Commonwealth Writers competition because he objects to the idea of his work being classified as "commonwealth literature" when the prize is only open to books written in English.

Ghosh announced his decision yesterday in a letter to The Times of India, in which he argued that the name "Commonwealth" for a literary or cultural grouping could "only be a misnomer" so long as it excluded the many languages that sustained the cultural and literary lives of those countries.

The writer, whose book The Glass Palace was picked as the Eurasia regional winner and was eligible for the main £10,000 prize, to be awarded in Ghana next month, said he had been unaware his work had been submitted for the competition by his publishers.

"So far as I can determine, The Glass Palace is eligible for the commonwealth prize partly because it was written in English and partly because
I happen to belong to a region that was once conquered and ruled by imperial Britain. Of the many reasons why a book's merits may be recognised, these seem to be the least persuasive," he said.

Ghosh, author of best-selling English novels including The Circle of Reason and The Shadow Lines, said he would be betraying the spirit of his latest work if he allowed it to become a part of "that particular memorialisation of empire that passes under the rubric of the commonwealth".

While he was gratified that the jury had liked the book, an epic novel dealing with colonial rule in Burma and Britain, he was strongly opposed to being entered in the first place.

Publisher HarperCollins UK admitted it was unaware of his views when it recommended the book for the prize.

Diana Bailey, programme manager for the Commonwealth Foundation, said she felt Ghosh's view was a "misunderstanding of what the modern Commonwealth prize meant". But she added discussions were going on about including works not in English.

The Daily Star reports that Manchester United have made a £22m move for Rivaldo. The paper says that Barcelona chairman Joan Gaspart has admitted receiving a bid, and quote Rivaldo as saying: "It is flattering to be linked with a club like Manchester United. fields.headline: Clause 67 is all about control freakery
fields.trailText: Tony Blair claimed the NHS plan would transform the way the health service worked but all the key components will be changes for the worse, writes Dr Liam Fox
fields.body:
Last July, Tony Blair launched Labour's NHS plan. He claimed it would transform the way the health service worked. The legislative changes required to implement the key elements of the plan are contained in the health and social care bill, which went through its committee stages in the Commons last month.

It is true the health and social care bill will transform the NHS. Unfortunately, all the key components will be changes for the worse. Interest groups from across the NHS have voiced their anger at what the government is proposing.

The bill is typical of Alan Milburn and New Labour. The health secretary claims, absurdly, that it decentralises the work of the NHS. In reality it does the opposite. The bill concentrates enormous powers in the health secretary's hands. It allows him far-reaching scope to hire and fire staff to all positions in the NHS. It lets him decide how confidential patient information should be used. And it abolishes community health councils (CHCs), the only independent patient watchdog scrutinising the work of the NHS.

The politicisation of the NHS has profoundly damaged its effectiveness. People who should be selected for their expertise are chosen instead for loyalty to their political masters. Clause 20 of the bill reinforces this insidious trend.

Clause 67, governing the disclosure of patient data, is worse still. In the first place, the national plan did not even mention the issue. Mr Milburn is widely believed to have included it in a fit of pique over a case he lost in the high court.

The secretary of state's powers to divulge data at his discretion seriously undermines patient confidentiality, the cornerstone of public trust in the NHS. Is this clause really designed to protect the NHS and patients, or do ministers want to protect their own backs?

These measures could easily become an excuse for the suppression of politically inconvenient data. The explanatory notes to the bill suggest, for example, that regulations could prohibit the use of anonymised patient information that is being used for a purpose "which is detrimental to the operation of the NHS". With a government as obsessed with stifling criticism as this, how far will it go in taking up the powers available to it?

The bill says Mr Milburn will be able to use his new powers only in the "public interest". But how will the government define the public interest? The usual terms are "act of war" or "major infectious epidemic". Is the government aiming to extend these to include preventive medicine and medical research?

Many organisations certainly fear the worst, judging by the widespread and intense criticism that has been heaped on the government over clause 67. The quality of research carried out by pharmaceutical companies will be impaired. This will have knock-on effects: their work is a key source of independent, up-to-date information on drug use. Work to monitor the safety of medicines will also suffer. And the UK's highly respected research and development sector will be undermined.

Worse still, not only does the bill allow the government to prevent the use of important and beneficial non-personal data, it also allows the secretary of state to divulge identifiable health data whenever he chooses. This provision could bring the medical profession into conflict with the law. Doctors could find themselves having to choose between breaking their pledge of patient confidentiality and breaking the law.

Mr Milburn's conduct over clause 67 has been bizarre, even by his own standards of self-contradiction. He told patient groups in January last year: "The days have gone when the NHS could act as a secret society. It cannot operate behind closed doors. It cannot operate in the dark. It has to take patients into its confidence." I fail to see how the bill will generate any confidence among patients.

It is little wonder the bill has been so roundly condemned. The government's response has been depressing, if predictable. Mr Milburn denies that any of the consequences I have outlined will occur. Unfortunately, he has declined to explain why such draconian powers are needed. Nor will he say how he plans to use these powers. No wonder people fear the worst.

If the government feels it has been given a rough ride on clause 67, that is nothing compared to the drubbing it has received over plans to CHCs.

We Conservatives created the CHCs. They have, frankly, been a thorn in the side of successive governments. But that is the reason they must be kept, since in doing so they have been fighting for patients' rights. CHCs have their faults, indeed they admit this themselves. But this is a compelling argument for reform, not abolition.

Unfortunately, the government does not see things that way. It regards CHCs as hostile not helpful. Labour cannot cope with criticism. And the only remaining independent voice in the NHS is that of the CHC movement.

Next Monday will be a sad day indeed. That is when the CHCs compile casualty watch - a detailed record of how long patients have been waiting in casualty. The only group celebrating the demise of casualty watch, and the CHCs more generally, will be the small-minded occupants of the Department of Health.

As things stand, the government's proposals on hiring and firing, use of confidential data and the abolition of CHCs, is set to enter the statute book soon. The bill is passing through its stages in the Lords. However, if we in the Conservative party have our way none of these three elements will see the light of day. We will oppose the bill in the Lords unless all these proposals are removed from it.

Dr Fleur Fisher told the Observer at the time of the bill's committee stage that it was a "totalitarian approach, it is not democratic. It is total control freakery. The immense width of its powers are scary. It's like waking up and finding you are in 1984." As the bill has passed through its various parliamentary stages, the accuracy of her analysis becomes increasingly clear.

webTitle: Private jails to take young offenders

fields.headline: Private jails to take young offenders
fields.trailText: Plans to triple the number of teenage criminals held in privately-run secure training centres were unveiled by the home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday in a £250m "root and branch" shake-up of the juvenile secure custody system.
fields.body:
Plans to triple the number of teenage criminals held in privately-run secure training centres were unveiled by the home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday in a £250m "root and branch" shake-up of the juvenile secure custody system.

The four-year plan drawn up by the government's youth justice board, which will see the number of places for teenagers in privately-run prisons rise from 130 to more than 400, is designed to ensure that teenage girls are not held in adult prisons and that more 15- and 16-year-old boys are held outside the prison system.

The shake-up of the juvenile custody system will also include 20 places to care for jailed young mothers and pregnant teenage offenders.

The plan, to be implemented by the youth justice board, chaired by Lord Warner, aims to ensure that 80% of juvenile offenders are held within 50 miles of their homes.

Lord Warner also confirmed that Portland young offenders' institution in Dorset will no longer hold anyone under the age 18 from April next year but insisted the change was to hold younger inmates closer to their homes rather than as a result of allegations of brutality over many years.

More places are also expected to be used at Hollesley Bay Colony in Suffolk to reduce the pressure on the troubled Feltham young offenders' institution in west London.

Although the number of places for teenage offenders is being increased in the private sector, ministers do not expect it to lead to more youngsters being held in custody.

Mr Straw said the introduction of anintensive supervision and surveillance programme for hardcore teenage offenders, and better use of bail supervision schemes, should ensure that the overall number did not increase.

The extra prison places no longer used for teenage offenders will accommodate adult prisoners.

The programme will see an expansion of the existing private units at Rainsbrook, Northamptonshire (32 places), and at Medway, Kent (32 places), and new units at Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire (80 places), Brentwood, Essex (40 places), and at an unidentified site in north west England (60-80 places).

The youth justice board is also trying to buy the former Glenthorne secure unit near Birmingham from the Department of Health to use as a 40-place detention and training centre, and is looking at several sites to provide a further 100 places in Wales.

The effort will include a £20m programme to improve education, training and other programmes.

Lord Warner said he hoped the improved conditions would help reduce suicides. He justified the use of privately-run units by saying that recent social services inspectorate reports had endorsed the quality of care in the independent sector.

webTitle: Watchdog rebukes Hague over trust cash inaccuracy

fields.headline: Watchdog rebukes Hague over trust cash inaccuracy
fields.trailText: William Hague was rebuked yesterday by a cross-party committee of MPs for making a formal declaration that he distributed profits from public speaking engagements to a charitable trust which was never established in law.
fields.body:
William Hague was rebuked yesterday by a cross-party committee of MPs for making a formal declaration that he distributed profits from public speaking engagements to a charitable trust which was never established in law.

In an embarrassing blow, the Commons committee on standards and privileges endorsed a report by the parliamentary standards watchdog which criticised the Conservative leader for failing to correct a "materially inaccurate" entry in the register of MPs' interests.

Conservative central office refused to comment on the report yesterday which was prompted by a Channel 4 investigation into Mr Hague's claim, in the register of MPs' interests in 1999 and 2000, that all fees from speaking engagements were to be paid into his trust.

The investigation, by the Mark Thomas Product programme, found that no money was paid into the William Hague Charitable Trust which was meant to distribute funds in the Tory leader's Richmond constituency.

Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner, stated in her report: "Mr Hague failed to respond correctly on eight occasions when required to check his entry, with the result that it continued in a materially inaccurate form for a considerable period - at least six months and arguably longer."

The committee's findings against Mr Hague, who has led the Tory charge in recent weeks against the Europe minister Keith Vaz, is the second time that the Tory leader has been reprimanded. In 1999 he failed to register the benefit of using Lord Archer's private gym.

Fraser Kemp, Labour MP for Houghton and Washington East, who formally lodged a complaint against Mr Hague, called on the Tory leader to apologise to the Commons.

The reprimand from the parliamentary watchdog, which will be an uncomfortable jolt to Mr Hague weeks before the election, highlights a mistake on his part rather than a deliberate attempt to hide payments.

"It should be emphasised that there is no evidence of any intention on Mr Hague's part deliberately to mislead the house and the public," Ms Filkin said.

The commissioner concluded that the trust was never formally established in law because of legal difficulties. Seven cheques, totalling £1,750, made out to the trust, were never cashed.

However, her report highlights a lack of organisation in Mr Hague's office and raises questions about the judgment of his private secretary, Lord Coe, who recommended that the Tory leader should establish the trust.

Ms Filkin said that Mr Hague's staff ignored two requests from the Tory leader to amend his entry in the MPs' register.

webTitle: UN urges Britain to don the blue beret in Sierra Leone

fields.headline: UN urges Britain to don the blue beret in Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, says he is sorry that British troops in Sierra Leone are refusing to serve under the UN flag.
fields.body:
The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, says he is sorry that British troops in Sierra Leone are refusing to serve under the UN flag.

He has also questioned the value of Britain's much-trumpeted training of the Sierra Leone army.

Asked by the Guardian if he was disappointed with Britain's refusal to wear UN colours, he said: "Yes, I do think it would be preferable if they were operating under the UN flag given that Britain is a permanent member of the [security] council and Britain passed the resolution establishing the force in Sierra Leone."

A handful of British officers are attached to the UN headquarters team in Sierra Leone but London has insisted on independence for its troops.

Britain has 800 troops in the west African country, scaled back from the 5,500 it had there last year.

The Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, has repeatedly called on Britain to join the UN force, claiming that refusal undermines the world body.

Mr Annan, however, praised British forces for providing a "big psychological boost" to the UN force at a critical stage last year. "They have been helpful, but it would have been ideal if they would have been under the UN," he added.

The British troops are training government troops for a push into rebel-held territory. But UN military advisers have told Mr Annan that this training will not have much impact.

"You can give these recruits some rudimentary training, some very basic training, but you cannot train soldiers in six weeks and down the line they will have to be given further training," he said.

UN officials are braced for a difficult and bloody campaign and stress that they need high-calibre soldiers to sustain the drive into rebel areas.

Mr Annan said: "I cannot say we are ready to do it today but, once we are up to strength, I think we will be able to work with the [Sierra Leone] government to expand its authority throughout the country."

Mr Annan, expected to confirm in New York today that he will seek a second five-year term as secretary general, needs success in Sierra Leone to counter the damage done to the UN's reputation as a peacekeeper by the disasters in Rwanda and the Balkans, and the divisions within its Sierra Leone force.

But the dominant issue on Mr Annan's agenda is the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

He was meeting the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, in New York last night, where he said he would urge Tel Aviv to end its economic embargo of Palestinian territories, and to drop the precondition of an end to violence before any talks with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat.

Mr Annan, who is to attend an Arab summit in Jordan next week, said: "Our recommendation is that Israel should ease the economic squeeze on the Palestinians and have both sides work together to decrease the violence."

"I know that prime minister Sharon is insisting that chairman Arafat must end the violence before he moves forward on other fronts. But these things are linked," he said.

"The longer this thing goes on the more radicalised and frustrated the Palestinians become and, of course, they also have a lot of support in the Arab world which tends to radicalise the Arab streets."

He discerned two causes for the Arabs' radicalisation: the revived Palestinian uprising, and the continuing sanctions against Iraq.

Mr Annan is optimistic that a deal on Iraq is possible this year if the US and Britain define the terms for lifting sanctions. He said that American and British bombing raids to enforce the continued imposition of no-fly zones had been high on the agenda when he met an Iraqi delegation last month.

"There are reviews going on of this Iraq policy among the council members [the US and Britain] and we will wait to see what the outcome of these will be."

fields.headline: Prisoners seek right to vote
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: Three prisoners yesterday launched a high court battle for the right to take part in elections in a test case which could end in MPs being expected to court the votes of 52,000 convicted inmates in England and Wales.
fields.body:
Three prisoners yesterday launched a high court battle for the right to take part in elections in a test case which could end in MPs being expected to court the votes of 52,000 convicted inmates in England and Wales.

The case, which is privately believed in Whitehall to have a good chance of succeeding, is being brought under the Human Rights Act which guarantees the right to participate in the democratic process and could overturn a ban on prisoners voting which has been in force since 1870.

Edward Fitzgerald QC, representing the three inmates, who include an arsonist and a man convicted of manslaughter, both serving life, and a drug smuggler, told the high court yesterday it was illegitimate to use disqualification from the vote as punishment.

He said it was illogical that those who were found guilty and jailed lost the right to vote while those who were also convicted but not imprisoned could still take part in elections. He argued that among western liberal democracies the trend was in favour of allowing prisoners to vote with a ban on voting in only eight European countries.

But Rabinder Singh, opening the case for the home secretary, argued that those who were subject to a democratic form of government had to abide by its laws. "A democratic society can reasonably take the view that those who break its laws sufficiently seriously be sentenced to prison, forfeit the right to take part in the government of that society while they serve their sentences." He insisted the loss of the right to vote was part of their punishment.

In a statement issued outside the court, one of the three prisoners, Anthony Pearson, the drug smuggler, said: "The ban on prisoners voting means MPs do not have to pay attention to prisons and the issues raised by prisoners. This leads to issues such as the poor state of health care for prisoners being neglected. While I accept that criminals must be punished, I cannot accept that it is just for me to die in custody, or to be denied the rights of others in a democratic society - to vote my MP in or out and to represent me in parliament."

The Home Office already partly conceded the case this year when it extended the right to vote to prisoners on remand awaiting trial, in time for the general election.

Last night the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdicombe, claimed it was a "silly case" of the kind she had warned would happen when the government decided to incorporate the European human rights convention into British law.

fields.headline: New threat to Murdoch DirecTV takeover
fields.trailText:
10.45am: News Corp may be locked out of the US satellite TV market if its main takeover targets merge, reports Dan Milmo.
Mar 5: Murdoch will not bid for Echostar
Mar 2: News Corp denies takeover crisis
Mar 2: Merger on verge of collapse
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch is facing the prospect of being locked out of the US satellite TV market amid rumours his main takeover targets could merge.

Mr Murdoch is hunting DirecTV but the General Motors-owned company is now being chased by his second choice, Echostar, according to the Financial Times.

The tycoon will pull off his biggest ever deal if he manages to bring DirecTV into his News Corporation empire.

But shareholders at DirecTV's holding company Hughes Electronics are unhappy with the terms of the deal.

News Corp insiders have said DirecTV is the priority but added Echostar is the obvious choice should a deal break down

Today's reports of an Echostar approach for DirecTV would be a blow for Mr Murdoch, who was forced to abandon a merger with Echostar four years ago.

The News Corp chairman needs a US presence in his Sky Global Networks satellite TV company, which has interests in every major market apart from the US.

However, analysts today said Mr Murdoch still had a chance, as US regulators would be very tough on a merger between Echostar and DirecTV.

fields.headline: Votes for prisoners
fields.standfirst:
Loss of liberty should not end civil rights

Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: Slowly but surely over the last 25 years the rights which prisoners automatically enjoyed in progressive states like Sweden have been extended to the UK.
fields.body:
Slowly but surely over the last 25 years the rights which prisoners automatically enjoyed in progressive states like Sweden have been extended to the UK. Most of these have come through rulings of the European court of human rights in Strasbourg: the right of access to solicitors, MPs and the media. Unjustified restrictions on correspondence have been lifted. The right to legal representation for serious breaches of prison disciplinary rules upheld. Yet few states have been as grudging in extending these rights as the UK. Gyula Knetchel, who wanted to sue the prison department for the loss of a leg, was refused access to a solicitor until Strasbourg intervened. Now lawyers representing three inmates are seeking a further advance in the high court this week: the restoration of prisoners' right to vote.

Stand by for all manner of arguments against the change. Surely, as Lord Bassam, the home office minister, told the Lords last year, prisoners have forfeited their "moral right" to vote? Not in the eyes of the United Nations human rights committee, nor article 25 of the international covenant of civil and political rights that it monitors. As the high court heard yesterday, 19 European states already allow prisoners to vote and a further eight extend it to certain categories of sentenced offenders. The UK has lifted the ban on remand prisoners and made it easier for the unsentenced to register. But over 50,000 sentenced prisoners are barred. Yet it cannot be emphasised too often, the purpose of prison is the deprivation of liberty, not the disenfranchisement of its inmates. The prison reform trust (PRT) is right to have campaigned for the restoration of this right, which was lost by an 1870 act. One benefit of the move would be to make MPs more involved in prisons. A PRT survey found some had never visited even their local prison. If this high court bid - using the new human rights act - fails, Strasbourg must come to the rescue.

fields.headline: Gibraltar clouds EU air control
fields.trailText: Spain's dispute with Britain over Gibraltar was blamed by the European commission president Romano Prodi yesterday for blocking agreement on a "single European sky", where air traffic congestion and the delays and cost they inflict on travellers should be a thing of the past.
fields.body:
Spain's dispute with Britain over Gibraltar was blamed by the European commission president Romano Prodi yesterday for blocking agreement on a "single European sky", where air traffic congestion and the delays and cost they inflict on travellers should be a thing of the past.

Creating the single sky is one of Mr Prodi's aims for the EU economic summit which opens in Stockholm tomorrow, but he admitted yesterday that the row between London and Madrid would prevent it happening.

Britain blames the Spanish EU transport commissioner, Loyola de Palacio, for implicitly recognising Spain's claim to the Rock by excluding its airport from the unified control system she has proposed rather than letting the two states work out an agreement.

Britain and Spain dispute the status of the airport, which is build on reclaimed land not forming part of the original territory ceded to Britain in the 1713 Treaty of Utrecht. Spain does not recognise it as a regional airport.

Mr Prodi said he had been forced to read the treaty in the original Latin to understand the row.

"Europeans need this [unified air control system], so we can get rid of delays and congestion," he said.

Air traffic control problems are responsible for half the delays suffered by European fights.

More than a quarter of flights within the union were delayed by more than 15 minutes last year.

Current air traffic management is based on a fragmented patchwork of national air spaces, each with its own systems, standards and working practices

 The home secretary, Jack Straw, signed a deal yesterday to speed up the extradition of British fugitives from Mediterranean hideaways in Spain. They could be returned in as little as three weeks.

Thirty-six requests by Britain for the return of people accused of serious crimes, including terrorism, murder and drug-dealing, are outstanding.

fields.headline: Audience breaks free of E4's Chained
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Controversial E4 reality gameshow Chained has not proved arresting viewing, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Controversial E4 reality gameshow Chained has not proved arresting viewing, slumping to an audience of just 16,000 on its second outing.

Chained has one man constantly tied to five women, with one of the latter thrown off the show each week until only two remain.

The programme, which is fronted by former Big Brother housemate Melanie Hill, has already prompted one story in the Sun claiming the final remaining couple were filmed having sex.

But the saucy subject matter has not yet translated into ratings, judging by the first two outings for Chained, which is broadcast on the Channel 4 pay-TV service from 11.10-11.55pm.

On its Monday night debut Chained drew just 59,000 viewers and a 1.6% share of multi-channel viewing, according to unofficial overnights.

But on its second outing last night the show's ratings slumped to just 16,000 and 0.4% of the available audience in multi-channel homes.

Sky Premiere had more success on Saturday night with the first UK television airing for the digitally remastered version of Star Wars.

The film, which will be followed on consecutive Saturdays by the three other Star Wars movies, was on between 8pm and 10.05pm and brought Sky Premiere its best audience so far this year.

Star Wars, which has been retitled Star Wars IV: a New Hope following the release of prequel the Phantom Menace, had 1m viewers and a 9.8% share of multi-channel viewing.

Sky Premiere's previous highest rating this year came from Will Smith movie Wild Wild West, which had 963,000 viewers when it premiered on February 24.

Related story

Dec 11 2000: Big Brother star to front Chained

webTitle: Portillo dangles tax carrot in front of Middle England

fields.headline: Portillo dangles tax carrot in front of Middle England
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo last night stepped up the drive to win back the voters of Middle Britain with a promise that a Conservative government will raise the 40% threshold for income tax and the point at which inheritance tax starts to bite.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo last night stepped up the drive to win back the voters of Middle Britain with a promise that a Conservative government will raise the 40% threshold for income tax and the point at which inheritance tax starts to bite.

With the general election campaign set to start officially in a week's time, Mr Portillo cited key middle income groups, including head teachers, police inspectors and senior nurses as the kind of people caught in a tax band once reserved for the significantly better-off.

In an article for the rightwing Spectator magazine, the shadow chancellor conspicuously declined to say exactly by how much he would raise either threshold, though he did restate other aspects of the Tory tax package aimed at pensioners and families.

He complained that Gordon Brown's budgets have allowed what is known as "fiscal drag" to pull an extra 650,000 taxpayers into the 40% bracket since 1997 - on top of the 2m such payers when John Major left office - by the tried-and-tested Treasury device of not raising thresholds.

Mr Portillo wants to reverse that trend and aides hint that that 40% threshold will have to be raised by about £3,000 a year, over and above inflation. It would cost the Treasury around £1.5bn at current rates.

"More and more people are being sucked into the higher rate bracket because of fiscal drag," he wrote. "Each year hundreds of thousands of people get pay rises above inflation and find themselves dragged into higher rate tax because the threshold is in creased only in line with prices."

He went on to accuse Labour of imposing stealth taxes on savers, pensioners and hard-working people, creating an over-taxed Britain which a Hague-led government will promise to relieve over a parliament.

"Supertax was designed to hit the very rich. But these days higher rate tax catches people who are on middle incomes," Mr Portillo explained. People earning £32,785, just 1.75 times average income, pay 40% tax.

Labour was again scornful of the Tory claims, saying that voters do not believe the Hague-Portillo pledge to protect essential public services while cutting taxes by £8bn.

Tony Blair and Mr Brown believe that voters want more spending on efficient public services more than they want tax cuts.

fields.headline: McDonald's attempts to woo back French
fields.trailText: 8.30am: McDonald's is opening up its kitchens to the French public as part of a massive charm offensive, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
McDonald's is opening up its kitchens to the French public as part of a massive charm offensive aimed at wooing back customers after a disastrous year in France.

The ambitious plan will see the American fast food giant open up over 400 restaurants across France for two weeks starting this Sunday.

Consumers will be given access to an exhaustive range of information on everything from McDonald's meat suppliers and the preparation of a burger to the way the company's PR agency has handled the crisis in public confidence.

It is the first time McDonald's has ever embarked on such an ambitious PR exercise and the scale of the project is a sign of just how far the company's reputation has fallen in France.

For many French people the golden arches have come to symbolise the destruction of French traditions.

When Jose Bove, a cheese-maker from south-west France, vandalised a branch of McDonald's last year he became a national hero virtually overnight.

"We think the best way to restore public confidence is to be completely open about the way we work," said a McDonald's spokeswoman.

"We want consumers to get to know McDonald's better. Mad cow disease and now foot and mouth have made it a pretty bad few years for any company that is involved in selling meat."

The initiative will be promoted by a major advertising campaign created by McDonald's French agency, TBWA.

McDonald's suppliers also have been persuaded to open their doors to the public.

Consumers will be able to visit the factories that produce McDonald's chips, beef burgers and buns as well as attending evening debates on the process of making a burger.

fields.headline: Telegraph polls
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Daily Telegraph belongs, along with that rich, ripe slice of Old England for which it speaks, toa world which is all at sea, where the certainty of its existence and identity have come to an end.
fields.body:
There was published yesterday a book called Widower's House by John Bayley, emeritus professor of English and the husband for 44 years till her death two years ago of the novelist Iris Murdoch. Its unexpectedly lurid highlights are already familiar from the serialisation in the Daily Telegraph: how after Iris's death John found himself being seduced by two persistent visitors - Margot, an "ample presence" who joins him under the duvet in a spare bedroom, and "scrawny" Mella, a former student, who having pretended to faint pulls him down on the bed. "At least we were fully clothed," the professor writes. "A couple of hours later we were not."

At the weekend the Sunday Times accused him, in effect, of making all this up. But according to Monday's papers Bayley denies that claim. He conceded, the Guardian reported, that he had strayed into he realms of fiction. Strictly speaking, Margot and Mella did not exist. They were composite characters, both real and unreal. The book was designed as a comedy on the theme of bereavement "and what happens when one is all at sea, when the certainty of one's existence comes to an end".

That this glimpse of a world which exists in a limbo where real life becomes indistinguishable from imagination and invention should have come to us by way of the Daily Telegraph makes it even more treasurable. For this is the world to which the Telegraph too belongs, along with that rich, ripe slice of Old England for which it speaks; a world which is all at sea, where the certainty of its existence and identity have come to an end. In some senses, the Telegraph's writers and readers live in much the same world as the rest of us. Tony Blair, Gordon Brown, and what the papers has taken to calling "the government (of which Keith Vaz is a member)" are as much a part of their reality as of our own. For them too, the trains run late and the weather is ghastly and foot and mouth is ravaging Cumbria and Man United are already effective winners of the Premier League. But other parts of their world are as fictional and fantasised as Margot and Mella.

The nation writhes under the yoke of a government as cruel and unprincipled as any since Nero. The countryside is up in arms, and would have marched on London last weekend in defence of its liberty and its livelihood and above all its right to hunt, but for foot and mouth - which some Telegraph letter writers believe may have been started by Blair and his cronies to stop the march happening. As for abroad, that is largely inhabited by eccentric and often dangerous people plotting not just our defeat but our extinction, and encouraged in that enterprise by so-called political leaders here who, lacking any kind of true Englishness, wish to destroy us by selling us out to those who wish to wreck the unity of our kingdom and sell us out to Brussels. (The exception is the US, which having elected George Bush is almost as OK as Old England. Also Canada, homeland of the paper's proprietor.)

The conspiracy is not Labour's alone. John Major was part of it, and traitors such as Michael Heseltine and Ken Clarke. Indeed, the rot set in long ago. The official persecution of the Sunderland trader whom they always describe as "the metric martyr" suggests we should probably never have abolished the groat or insisted that Bristol surrendered its ancient sovereignty by accepting London's time zone.

Why is it, then, that this evil, virulent gang, still has control of our destiny, and may even be given a second term if the government (of which Keith Vaz is a member) persists in its present wicked intention of staging an election in May? Yes, even Telegraph readers know that Labour is likely to win, and win big, very soon. Balanced reporters such as George Jones and Andy McSmith still get such unpleasant truths into the paper. Professor Anthony King is still allowed to intrude with his Gallup polls, warning last week that the Conservative party "is probably suffering from the greatest credibility gap in its long and distinguished history". As I read the Telegraph, and especially its columnist Janet Daley (every bit as tedious in print as she is on the Moral Maze), who has made this theme her own, it's because the British electorate, softened and brainwashed by years of socialist propaganda, not least from the BBC, is simply not up to it. It does not have the nous to see how it is being betrayed.

How does a once sane (more or less) daily newspaper get itself sucked into the fantasy world where the Telegraph lives today? John Bayley answers that too. "I wanted," he said, explaining his "fictionalised constructs" to Monday's Times, "to try to convey what it's like when a person has died and you are missing them terribly." There you have it. His Iris Murdoch; their Margaret Thatcher.

fields.headline: Big Brother wipes celebrity memory
fields.standfirst: Q&A: was Big Brother a fake?
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Vanessa Feltz can sleep a little easier today after the company behind Celebrity Big Brother decided to bin tapes of the show, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
Q&A: Was Big Brother a fake?
12m witness Turner's humiliation
Viewers revel in Vanessa's trauma
fields.body:
Vanessa Feltz and Anthea Turner can sleep a little easier today after the company behind Celebrity Big Brother decided to wipe all records of their week in the notorious TV house.

Peter Bazalgette, boss of Bazal Productions, said he felt morally obliged to get rid of anything that might cause future embarrassment to the six stars who took part in the show.

"We respect these guys for what they have done. They did it for charity and in a sense exposed themselves which makes them vulnerable.

"The tapes will be held briefly on a computer server somewhere, but we will wipe the server so they won't be kept," he said.

The decision will come as major relief for Ms Feltz, who became extremely distressed when she was nominated for eviction from the Big Brother House after just three days.

Millions of viewers saw her crack under the pressure when she was nominated for eviction.

She broke down in tears on several occasions; told Big Brother to "fuck off" and scrawled a series of words including "frustrated" and "incarcerated" on the kitchen table.

Although her fellow inmates appeared to cope better under the constant spotlight, they will be just as thankful that their most vulnerable moments will not be recorded in the annals of TV history.

Anthea Turner was visibly upset when she was nominated for eviction the first time and Keith Duffy will probably have paid dearly for remarks about his wife's sexual preferences.

Although viewers saw the most dramatic moments in the house, there are hundreds of hours of tapes on computer file at Bazal Productions.

Just like Big Brother the contestants were under constant surveillance from the cameras.

Mr Bazalgette said the company had not been put under any pressure by the celebrities to erase the tapes.

In an interview with MediaGuardian, Mr Bazalgette has also dismissed the conspiracy theories surrounding the show which gripped the nation for eight days.

He denied the contestants had mobile phones, were fed gourmet food and fine wines when the cameras weren't switched on, and declared that Chris Eubank was wrong to suggest the voting had been rigged.

He also revealed that counselling was offered to at least one of the contestants.

The decision will come as major relief for Ms Feltz, who became extremely distressed when she was nominated for eviction from the Big Brother House after just three days. Millions of viewers saw her crack under the pressure when she was nominated for eviction. She broke down in tears on several occasions; told Big Brother to "fuck off" and scrawled a series of words including "frustrated" and "incarcerated" on the kitchen table. Although her fellow inmates appeared to cope better under the constant spotlight, they will be just as thankful that their most vulnerable moments will not be recorded in the annals of TV history. Anthea Turner was visibly upset when she was nominated for eviction the first time and Keith Duffy will probably have paid dearly for remarks about his wife's sexual preferences. Although viewers saw the most dramatic moments in the house, there are hundreds of hours of tapes on computer file at Bazal Productions. Just like Big Brother the contestants were under constant surveillance from the cameras. Mr Bazalgette said the company had not been put under any pressure by the celebrities to erase the tapes. In an interview with MediaGuardian, Mr Bazalgette has also dismissed the conspiracy theories surrounding the show which gripped the nation for eight days. He denied the contestants had mobile phones, were fed gourmet food and fine wines when the cameras weren't switched on, and declared that Chris Eubank was wrong to suggest the voting had been rigged. He also revealed that counselling was offered to at least one of the contestants. webTitle: Women dissatisfied with care during childbirth

fields.headline: Women dissatisfied with care during childbirth
fields.trailText: Most women are dissatisfied with the care they get during childbirth and less than half would be happy to return to the same hospital to give birth again, according to a national survey published today investigating the experiences of 2,000 recent mothers.
fields.body:
Most women are dissatisfied with the care they get during childbirth and less than half would be happy to return to the same hospital to give birth again, according to a national survey published today investigating the experiences of 2,000 recent mothers.

Three-quarters said they felt anxious during pregnancy and frightened during labour. Six in 10 found the experience of giving birth more shocking than they expected.

Four in 10 said they were not allowed to move around during labour and take up positions they wanted and 43% said they did not have the type of birth they wanted. Only 8% of women had a completely natural birth, without the need for drugs or surgical interventions.

The survey by the website motherandbaby.co.uk was based on responses from 2,000 mothers who used the site and agreed to answer questions. Their average age was 29.

A quarter had a caesarean. Among those giving birth normally, 35% were induced, 45% had an epidural, 12% had a forceps delivery and 53% needed stitches.

Half of all new mothers said they had received poor postnatal care once they had taken their baby home and 79% said they were in pain after the birth for an average of two weeks.

The women were also dissatisfied with their care during pregnancy. Only 4% had the same midwife for all antenatal appointments and delivery.

Sarah Stone, editor of motherandbaby.co.uk, said: "Overstretched maternity staff simply don't have the time to provide the sort of quality care pregnant women need and expect. As a result, many women feel they have gone through a conveyor-belt birth experience to suit the hospital's agenda.

"Birth in Britain today has become a lottery - if you are lucky enough to give birth in a maternity unit with a full complement of staff and only a few women giving birth at the same time, then you'll probably have a more positive experience. Unfortunately, for most women, this is not the case."

 An opinion poll for the British Medical Association found 89% of the public are satisfied with the way doctors do their jobs. In spite of recent scandals such as the conviction of the serial killer GP Harold Shipman, public confidence in the trustworthiness of doctors was 2% higher than a year ago.

The annual poll of trust in the professions found 89% of people trusted doctors to tell the truth, compared with 86% who trusted teachers and 78% who had faith in vicars and judges.

fields.headline: Macedonia rejects rebel ceasefire offer
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText:
Macedonians waited anxiously last night as the
government sternly rejected a last-minute ceasefire
offer by the ethnic Albanian gunmen in the hills above
Tetovo, the country's second city.
fields.body:
Macedonians waited anxiously last night as the government sternly rejected a last-minute ceasefire offer by the ethnic Albanian gunmen in the hills above Tetovo, the country's second city.

"It is necessary to neutralise and eliminate the extremists," President Boris Trajkovski declared in a brief statement after a crisis meeting with his advisers. The statement came only minutes before his midnight deadline to the gunmen to lay down their arms and surrender.

The government had given the gunmen 24 hours to comply with the ultimatum issued at midnight on Tuesday. When it ran out last night, the president said the army was determined "to take control of the Macedonian side of the border".

His tough line was consistent with the policy the government has taken throughout the crisis of the last three years. It accuses the gunmen of trying to import rebellion from Kosovo and says they must withdraw completely.

But despite his tough comments, Mr Trajkovski still left the door open to talks with other ethnic Albanians to find a political solution to the com plaints of the sizeable Albanian minority in Macedonia. "The government is willing to seek a political solution, but only through parliament and other established institutions," he said.

In Tetovo itself, where the army has stationed tanks, artillery and extra troops in the past two days, there was no sign that any offensive was under way in the early hours of this morning.

The Macedonian government is squeezed between demands from the Slav majority for firm action against the gunmen and European diplomats who are urging them not to rule out talks. A high-level delegation of EU officials, including Javier Solana and Chris Patten, is due in the Macedonian capital, Skopje, today.

Earlier yesterday, the rebel's political leadership offered an unlimited ceasefire. The offer was made by Ali Ahmeti, the head of the political bureau of the self-styled National Liberation Army, in a television broadcast from Pristina in Kosovo.

The ceasefire offer did not include any promise of a pullback by the guerrillas who first appeared above Tetovo a week ago. The Macedonian government has insisted that the guerrillas must withdraw to Kosovo. It calls them aggressors and refuses to accept that many of them are Albanians who were born in Macedonia.

Mr Ahmeti said: "We open the road for dialogue so heads can cool down and to find the best solution."

He said the ceasefire was open-ended, but warned that in case of attack the struggle would continue. He added: "We are not for a war that would create rivers of blood between two nations, because the reason for dialogue would be lost in that case."

During 1998 and 1999 Mr Ahmeti, 42, was in charge of KLA logistics and gun-running and often travelled to Kosovo and Macedonia undercover. He is wanted by the Macedonian government on an international arrest warrant.

Significantly, Mr Ahmeti's statement did not demand that the gunmen themselves be seated at the table in any talks. It seemed to leave open the possibility that other Albanians, including established political parties in Macedonia, could represent them.

The Macedonian government has vowed not to talk to the gunmen whom it describes as terrorists, and they have been backed in their stance by senior western officials. But the rebels' offer of a ceasefire leading to talks in which other Albanians take part may be attractive to western officials who have said there must be a political solution to the crisis.

There were doubts in Skopje whether the army has enough troops to attack the rebels holding the high ground above the city rather than simply raining artillery shells and mortars at them as they have done in the last few days. According to western estimates, the Macedonian army, 90% of whose officers are ethnic Slavs, is only 20,000-strong and has outdated tanks. They have no fighter planes and only a few helicopters.

In a sign that the conflict could spill over to the Macedonian capital yesterday, a police officer was shot and killed when a group of policemen were attacked.

webTitle: Mutuality: it's a fresh way ahead

fields.headline: Mutuality: it's a fresh way ahead
fields.standfirst: The common good: This week's Guardian campaign for better public services is joined by Ed Mayo
fields.trailText: Ed Mayo: I call this the mutualisation of public services. It means that ownership and accountability passes from Whitehall to the direct stakeholders of public services
fields.body:
Three great myths have shaped public services. The first is the post-war welfare state, the promise of state-owned, state-run services. The second is privatisation, the idea that monopoly public services should be subject to market forces. The third is what we have now: the managerial state, delivering productivity gains through targets and beefed-up management.

Each myth has reached its natural limit. The model of the large, paternalistic state organisation no longer fits. Privatisation was supposed to be the answer, but people rightly remain suspicious of privatisation reaching into the heart of public services. The profit motive is strong at filling shop shelves but poor at delivering public goods: objectives like safety, dignity and wellbeing don't mesh well with financial incentives. The result is either poor performance or the government finds itself drawn into constant, expensive monitoring and intervention. The managerial state uses service agreements, targets and league tables so that funding can follow performance. But the tyranny of numbers, the way historically all large hierarchies attempt to control, ends up stifling creativity, innovation and entrepreneurship.

There is another way, which aims to achieve the kind of entrepreneurialism encouraged by privatisation but within the context of social ownership. I call this the mutualisation of public services. It means that ownership and accountability passes from Whitehall to the direct stakeholders of public services - those who work in them and those who benefit from them. There are two ways to do this. The first is to convert public services into non-profit enterprises.

Greenwich Leisure is a good example; it was set up by councillors at the London Borough of Greenwich when cuts hit in 1992. It is a cooperative in which 80% of employees have opted for an ownership stake. With a workforce of about 1,000, they have increased the number of leisure facilities in Greenwich and have trebled income in the last six years to more than £9m, while more than halving the cost to the local authority for the service. Greenwich Leisure has assisted the replication of the model in 13 other local authority areas from Bristol to Teesside.

The second approach is simply to get the public back into public services. This is a theme that Gordon Brown is warming up to. An example is Kingsdale school, in south London, where children are engaged in redesigning the school as it goes through a £9m new building works project. Workshops were held with children and staff and they were able to say what they wanted from a school building. Locker space was a concern for the children - it was their space, their stake in the school. Architects heard that corridors in the school are narrow, and become places of conflict. As children poured out from lessons, bottlenecks were a place for disruption and even fights. Design solutions that tackled these issues would improve wellbeing at the school. It has not all been easy, as those with power have to decide whether they can let go. But children and teachers are not just contributing to initial design in the school works project, they will also do the evaluation. For a school once on special measures, this will be a true test of progress.

Health, education, care, employment advice, parks and local authority services all offer similar seeds of a participatory civic renewal of public services. But just as there are signs of hope, in other areas mistakes are being made. Simply breaking up the leviathan institutions of the state is not enough. What is happening in housing shows this up most starkly; 200,000 homes are transferring every year from local authority control to registered social landlords and new social housing companies with little accountability to residents. With public sector delivery, there is accountability to government; with housing cooperatives, there is accountability downwards to tenants, but worst of all is to pass over housing to bodies that are accountable to neither. Cooperative housing is well developed in western Europe, especially Scandinavia where it is the main form of affordable housing. What is needed here is a new model of organisation, that cannot be categorised along the old divide between public and private sector; it is not driven by profit but by public purpose and social well-being, but it combines these with entrepreneurialism.

When the great institutions of the welfare state swept in, non-profit organisations which had pioneered much of the work were seen as yesterday's solution. At the time, the state was seen as the best way to embody the principles of self-help, integrity and mutual obligation. What we need now is a mixed economy of self-help, mutuality and state action.

fields.bodyText: Three great myths have shaped public services. The first is the post-war welfare state, the promise of state-owned, state-run services. The second is privatisation, the idea that monopoly public services should be subject to market forces. The third is what we have now: the managerial state, delivering productivity gains through targets and beefed-up management. Each myth has reached its natural limit. The model of the large, paternalistic state organisation no longer fits. Privatisation was supposed to be the answer, but people rightly remain suspicious of privatisation reaching into the heart of public services. The profit motive is strong at filling shop shelves but poor at delivering public goods: objectives like safety, dignity and wellbeing don't mesh well with financial incentives. The result is either poor performance or the government finds itself drawn into constant, expensive monitoring and intervention. The managerial state uses service agreements, targets and league tables so that funding can follow performance. But the tyranny of numbers, the way historically all large hierarchies attempt to control, ends up stifling creativity, innovation and entrepreneurship. There is another way, which aims to achieve the kind of entrepreneurialism encouraged by privatisation but within the context of social ownership. I call this the mutualisation of public services. It means that ownership and accountability passes from Whitehall to the direct stakeholders of public services - those who work in them and those who benefit from them. There are two ways to do this. The first is to convert public services into non-profit enterprises. Greenwich Leisure is a good example; it was set up by councillors at the London Borough of Greenwich when cuts hit in 1992. It is a cooperative in which 80% of employees have opted for an ownership stake. An example is Kingsdale school, in south London, where children are engaged in redesigning the school as it goes through a £9m new building works project. Workshops were held with children and staff and they were able to say what they wanted from a school building. Locker space was a concern for the children - it was their space, their stake in the school. Architects heard that corridors in the school are narrow, and become places of conflict. As children poured out from lessons, bottlenecks were a place for disruption and even fights. Design solutions that tackled these issues would improve wellbeing at the school. It has not all been easy, as those with power have to decide whether they can let go. But children and teachers are not just contributing to initial design in the school works project, they will also do the evaluation. For a school once on special measures, this will be a true test of progress.
