fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Costly lesson
I read your article on technology in the classroom (How to learn the hardware way, March 15) with the same kind of despair that I experienced traipsing around the BETT show in Olympia earlier this year. It made me feel like a Dickensian waif staring in the rich family's window watching them tuck into a slap-up meal. The new technologies have a lot to offer the classroom of the future, but the big drawback is that these wonderful devices come at a price.

The raw economic truth is that those of us in the bottom half of our two-tier education system are simply doing our best to keep our heads above water. Year on year our budgets are cut, even though our pupil numbers increase. We are told that all secondary schools have achieved a pupil-computer ratio of at least 8 to 1 and will be at 5 to 1 by 2004; the truth is that we are struggling to hold it at 13 to 1.

I'm afraid the cold reality for many of us at the chalk face bears little resemblance to the brave new world that you describe.
Jeremy Smith
jd.smith@ukonline.co.uk

I was interested to read about the interactive whiteboard (whiteboards replaced blackboards years ago) and that teachers are enthusiastic about it "not least because lessons can be prepared at home (where else?) on the laptop". Would this be the laptop that will cost me more than one-tenth of my annual salary? Government help with hardware is only available for maths teachers of 11 to 14-year-olds.
Victoria Paleit
Southmoor, Oxon

Flash flood
Nick Clayton (Second Sight, March 15) is absolutely right: it's time for the Flash Back(f)lash. To all the Flash animators out there I say this: you know that bit where it says "Skip Intro"? That's where I click, every time. And if there's no "Skip", I just hit the stop button in my browser and go elsewhere. Some of the worst offenders are the biggest companies in the world, and its time to name and shame.

Perhaps the Guardian should feature a regular chart of the biggest time wasters? I nominate Volkswagen, which has a golden opportunity to tell you everything about its cars, but tells you next to nothing.

The Campaign for Pure Text starts here.
Dr Robert McMinn
drbob@jigsaw24.com

Nick Clayton is right to believe that many web designers use Flash to indulge their egos at the expense of usability. But Flash itself is an extremely powerful technology, if frequently misused. It can be used to create very small files that play as they download; Flash movies can scale to fit any screen size or resolution; unlike HTML, Flash will play back more or less consistently whatever the browser or platform; and Flash can be used to create user interfaces that are more intuitive and responsive to use, not just pretentious intros. See the Flash showcase at www.macromedia.com for some excellent examples of Flashed sites.

I would also ask Nick to stop perpetuating the stereotype of the black-clad designer conning naive company directors into parting with cash for "spinning logos" and other gimmicks. Good design is central to usability and has a direct relation to the success or otherwise of commercial websites.

The web appears to be an immature medium because it is full of appalling sites created by companies who treat design as an afterthought, and believe that they themselves (or their IT department) can do a good job of it.
Mark Croxton
mark@croxton.co.uk

I would be the first to agree with Nick Clayton that there are a great many annoying and unnecessary Flash intros to websites.

However, Flash has many more uses than just creating pretty intros. Flash can do anything that can be done in HTML and far more. It can interact with databases, XML files, accept user input and is excellent for creating animated tutorials. As a web developer (no Nick, not all people who create websites are designers), one of the advantages of Flash is that it frees the website authors from having to worry about writing HTML/DHTML that will work in a myriad of different browser types and versions, which, in my experience, is one of the most time-consuming aspects of website authoring.

Also, there are more browsers now that have the Flash plugin than have Javascript enabled which makes it a surer bet for delivering any type of dynamic content.

I would also agree that many websites suffer from a lack of text content which for some sites is a problem. This, however, is not a result of using Flash. There are just as many websites with too many animated Gifs or Java applets, or even just plain images. This is down to the site design, not the tools used or methods in which that design was implemented.

Finally, I would also like to point out that although you can't put a Flash graphic into a search engine, you can't put any other type of graphic directly into a search engine either. Search engine placement is partly driven by the text content of sites, but that's not the only criterion.

I would also have to say that personally I think the web would be a very boring place if all sites entirely consisted of text content.

fields.headline: Sharing music's net loss
fields.standfirst:
Free music is still available on the internet, so who can supply it? Mike Anderiesz tells us Sharing music's net loss
More net news Free music is still available on the internet, so who can supply it? Mike Anderiesz tells us
fields.trailText: Free music is still available on the internet, so who can supply it? Mike Anderiesz tells us Sharing music's net loss
fields.body:
As the music is slowly stripped from Napster by a combination of court injunctions and record company persistence, thoughts are beginning to turn to the alternatives. Napster will probably hang in there for months yet, offering unlimited downloads from a dwindling collection of licensed tracks, but the genie of free music is definitely out of the bottle and thieves are not noted for their loyalty.

"Hey - has anyone tried Limewire?"

"Yep - it's rubbish, almost as bad as Bearshare."

Such exchanges are now common in the Napster chatrooms as users try to work out whether their craving for free music can be fed elsewhere. Naturally, there are already plenty of alternatives. The question is: are they any good and how long will they last before the record companies notice their existence and shut them down too?

For those who may have missed the Napster revolution, the key jargon to remember is Peer to Peer (P2P). When you download a file from the internet, it is usually stored on a server somewhere, taking up disk space either owned by a private company or donated to users by ISPs.

This system has served the web well since its inception. However, the growing availability of multimedia files (in particular music and video) causes a huge capacity problem. Not only are the files larger, but should they prove popular it is easy for users to jam that server with their download attempts.

This is already a major problem for the porn industry, with servers crashing on an hourly basis and ISPs - like Yahoo - imposing strict download limits on thousands of accounts. P2P avoids this problem by putting all the strain on the user. Companies like Napster simply provide a window; the tracks you download are coming directly from some other user's hard drive, and they in turn are uploading material directly from yours. When it works, it works brilliantly.

When it fails, it exposes your PC to greater risk from viruses, hackers and unexpected crashes. You have been warned!

Finally, do remember that the transfer of copyright material other than for personal use is illegal. However, as these programmes can be used for legitimate sharing of your own files (photos, music etc) we feel obliged to tell you what works and what will simply mess up your system. How you choose to exploit this advice is a matter for your own conscience. Bearshare www.bearshare.com is the most prominent new file sharer and, like the others, free to download. The interface is unusually drab despite the highly colourful website from which you download it.

Unfortunately, the main problem with Bearshare is that it doesn't seem to work! Despite multiple attempts I could not even make it perform a search, while its own bulletin board strongly suggests the problem does not end there. As one user put it, with remarkable restraint, "I appreciate the effort to help us, but I think I speak for a large group of people when I say that I can not download anything !"

Limewire ( www.limewire.com ) is a nicer looking interface with some useful gimmicks, for example, the ability to perform multiple simultaneous searches, each of which is tabbed in the main window. Also useful is the ability to define your minimum download speed, so if you have ADSL or cable and wish to avoid users with humble 56k modems, you can. The searches are quick and unusually productive (I found over 3,000 Madonna files in seconds plus most of the UK top 20).

However, 20 attempts to download the same track all ended in a connection failure, and the one success I did have (downloading a 15mb mpeg file) took over an hour to complete despite my ultra-fast ADSL connection. The prettiest file sharer around is probably Gnotella. It is also one of the easiest to use, accepting both Bearshare and Limewire users and clearly marking which clients are using firewalls, which may make the files harder to download. Once again you can perform multiple searches and the results were both faster and more plentiful than Limewire.

There's even a snazzy window to show how your transactions are eating up the available bandwidth. However, the success rate was appalling, with fewer than two files transferring from the 50 or so I tried, and it was appallingly slowly given both parties were using cable modems. The final site, Gnutella, has been around for a while now. It originally provided the core code for the first true alternative to Napster, but is now more of a community for other P2P engines.

The key advantage of using a Gnutella variant is that you can swap almost any kind of media file over them, including pictures (JPEGs and GIFs), MPEG or AVI video files or small application programmes as well as the most popular MP3 music format. For an introduction to P2P file sharing and a mix of some of the best engines, this is a good place to start.

The more you use P2P programs, the more you appreciate the sheer genius of Napster. Here was a fluid and functioning music sharing system, with a world class search engine, one of the best instant messaging facilities around, and a built in media player so you could preview files as they were downloading. In comparison, the new wave of P2P engines are slow, inaccurate and largely ineffective.

Admittedly, some of this is down to the nature of the files - an MPEG video is much bigger than an MP3 file, consequently the host you are trying to download from handles fewer simultaneous connections, each taking longer to deal with. There is, of course, another problem with most of these P2P programs. Once activated, the software will scan your drive for files you wish to share with fellow thieves (sorry, users). Unfortunately, once the world can see your own files, it also knows a fair amount about your personal habits. Got any embarrassing JPEGs? (be honest, now). Well, prepare to let colleagues, friends and file sharers see them too. Admittedly, there are ways of selecting which files you choose to share, but as many users will use the same folder for uploads and downloads, red faces are probably inevitable.

All in all, however, if this is the future of P2P, Metallica has nothing to worry about. Napster's children ain't half as dangerous as the old man was.

webTitle: Letters: I don't judge women MPs

fields.headline: I don't judge women MPs
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee's article on women MPs (Better than men, March 16) unfortunately misrepresented my research into their voting behaviour.
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee's article on women MPs (Better than men, March 16) unfortunately misrepresented my research into their voting behaviour. I do not argue that the women MPs of the 1997 intake are "indeed obedient" nor that they have recently "got a bit braver". Nor should my findings "please the mocking press gallery". The saving grace was that she got my name wrong, and so I could at least claim there was a Paul Cowley, coincidentally working on the exact same subject, going around spouting such things.

It is true that the new Labour women MPs have been substantially less likely to vote against their party than other Labour MPs. But I make absolutely no judgment about this. Voting against the party line isn't necessarily brave (although at times it can be); voting with the party line isn't necessarily a sign of obedience (although, again, at times it can be).

I am used to my research being used by those who wish to denigrate the new women MPs. But don't lump me in with them.
Philip Cowley
Department of politics, University of Hull
P.J.Cowley@pol-as.hull.ac.uk

fields.headline: We're tied on bonds
fields.trailText: The idea of issuing bonds for the London Underground (Analysis, March 20) is an excellent one, but runs up against a piece of Treasury orthodoxy that would not apply in other European countries nor in the US.
fields.body:
The idea of issuing bonds for the London Underground (Analysis, March 20) is an excellent one, but runs up against a piece of Treasury orthodoxy that would not apply in other European countries nor in the US. This is that any borrowing - funded by bonds or otherwise - by a public corporation is like borrowing by the government itself and must be controlled accordingly. That is why the PFI option for the tube is apparently attractive, because it takes the borrowing into the "private" sector. The fact that a PFI deal has to be underpinned by public subsidy - just as a bond would - is not relevant to the Treasury, as long as borrowing itself is by a private company.

Other countries recognise that such hard and fast divisions between public and private sectors are not only outdated but lead to solutions - like the PFI deal for air traffic control - which hardly anyone wants. Ironically, the Treasury itself has bowed to pressure in one or two areas - the Post Office and Manchester airport - to allow commercial borrowing by public sector bodies.

But it won't follow the logic of the argument by adopting the same financing rules as other European countries, which distinguish between government borrowing (central or local), and borrowing by public corporations which could (in extremis) be allowed to go bust.
John Perry
Director of policy, Chartered Institute of Housing
john.perry@cih.org

 There is no need, as suggested, for the Liberal Democrats to put revenue bonds in our manifesto. Revenue bonds to fund investment in the tube has been established party policy for at least three years. Bonds are the best way forward for London's tube. It is time the government accepted this fact and dumped the so called public private partnership.
Tom Brake MP
Liberal Democrat London transport spokesperson
cwlibs@cix.compulink.co.uk

fields.headline: Some Vazillations
fields.trailText: Homelessness tsar Louise Casey reassures us that the anti-begging campaign was a success (Letters, March 21). But as the temperatures drop again, my perception is of visible numbers of people back on the capital's streets.
fields.body:
Homelessness tsar Louise Casey reassures us that the anti-begging campaign was a success, because of the interest it generated in volunteering and gifts in kind (Letters, March 21). But as the temperatures drop again, my perception is of visible numbers of people back on the capital's streets. They probably wish the £250,000 spent on the campaign, and indeed the £10,000 raised, had been spent differently; I know I do. Cheryl St Clair
Chelmsford, Essex

 I feel a deep sense of gratitude at the decision to allow pubs to remain open until 1am for one day for the Queen's jubilee next year (In brief, March 20). But not as grateful as I would have been had Jack Straw done what he promised in December 1999 and modernised the licensing laws permanently.
Peter Gillings
London

 Jeff Noon's seminal 1996 cyberpunk novel Vurt opens with the line: "Sometimes it feels like the whole world is smeared with Vaz." I know sci fi often predicts the future but this is just too uncanny (MPs press Vaz to quit, March 19).
Mark Nelson
Chester

 Matthew Engel (March 20) foresees the emergence of a party called "the Liberals". That shouldn't be too difficult.
Cllr David Morrish
Liberal party national executive committee

 Has anyone noticed that the shorter and pointless readers' letters are sometimes published on teletext "Quotable Quote" pages? Wonder if this will be.
Pete Simmonds
Oadby, Leics

 Your decision to publish Patrick Eminet's letter (March 21) shows your column remains open to the juvenile, the coarse and the inarticulate. Well done!
Alan Maycock
Liverpool

fields.headline: Freemasons in free fall
fields.trailText: You report that "the Freemasons have hired their first-ever PR agency" (Freemasons shake hands with the media, March 19; G2, March 21). As far back as 1985 the United Grand Lodge of England hired a PR firm to counter the torrent of hostile publicity.
fields.body:
You report that "the Freemasons have hired their first-ever PR agency" (Freemasons shake hands with the media, March 19; G2, March 21). As I revealed in my 1989 book, Inside the Brotherhood, as far back as 1985 the United Grand Lodge of England hired a PR firm to counter the torrent of hostile publicity which had engulfed the funny handshake brigade following the book by Stephen Knight.

Profile Public Relations came up with a confidential report based on the premise that "in today's world the organisation which does not communicate effectively ceases to exist". The firm chided the fraternity for its self-defeating clandestinity and advocated a revolutionary programme of brochures, TV training sessions and "media survival kits".

Despite this, 16 turbulent years later, freemasonry in the UK has lost around 100,000 members, mostly through death, disillusion or boredom. Today the movement still has the insurmountable problem of justifying its arcane all-male rituals and secret membership lists. Meanwhile the hierarchy of Grand Lodge is threatened from within by dissident "rude mechanicals" who rightly regard it as thoroughly undemocratic.

Freemasonry's new spin doctors will have a hard job reversing the image of corruption and intrigue which continues to surround the brotherhood, especially when many brothers themselves know that this image closely resembles the reality.
Martin Short
London
martyshort@compuserve.com

The Forestry Commission, for example, has closed its entire land holding, a total of 2.4m acres, a measure it did not consider necessary during the 1967 outbreak. Thus, even in the north of Scotland, more than a hundred miles from the nearest outbreak, walkers are being denied access to the hills through forestry land. A response more commensurate with the real risk of disease transmission would surely have been simply to advise walkers to stay away from infected areas.
Dr Malcolm Nicolson
Hardgate, Clydebank

 Three cheers for Polly Toynbee's smoke-clearing article on the foot and mouth "crisis". Last year I stood at the funeral "pyre" of my 85-year-old mother, after she had been culled by the NHS. Admitted with a minor injury, while in hospital she sustained three other injuries which finished her off. These were due to the outbreak of inadequate care now spreading like wildfire across the nation's geriatric wards. If this government had their priorities in perspective, there would be, dare I use the word, some compensation.
Alan Clark
London

 Farmers are not asking for "more than anyone else". They are asking for this disease to be dealt with quickly, efficiently and above all effectively - and this is clearly not happening. If Polly Toynbee saw no burning pyres between Carlisle and Keswick, one of the richest parts of the county, then that's probably because the farms there are owned by the few big landowners and National Farmers' Union officials, whose slaughtered stock are driven away to burn out of sight. The government should know, as they sit over their suppers of cuddly lamb and organic vegetables, that the stench of burning flesh will follow them into the election - unless they complete their present task first, which is to govern their way out of this crisis.
Jane Ruthven Mayes
Alston, Cumbria

 Perhaps if opinion polling had been around in 1945, the public's response to the question "should the election be delayed?" would have produced a not dissimilar result to your survey (Blair defies voters' no to May poll, March 21). The 1945 general election went ahead despite the fact that we were still at war with Japan, and despite the fact that 2m servicemen had to have postal votes.

A few years later, two general elections were held during the course of the Korean war, and since 1969 many general elections have been held whilst a significant part of the UK was affected by the "troubles", a crisis which at times threatened mainland political life almost as much as it did in Northern Ireland. Considering these far more serious precedents there can be no justification for delay now, unless of course somebody wants to use the foot and mouth issue as a political football.
Colin Challen
Wakefield

 The last time a Labour government approached a general election, after the 1979 winter of discontent, it was against a background of corpses lying unburied. Is it better this time, or worse?
Geoff Andrews
Bath
g.andrews@ukonline.co.uk

 It's a relief to know that Maff are not responsible for breweries and parties.
Dr Paul Yeo
Birmingham

Private backers are responsible for funding all three works in the current series of sculptures for the Trafalgar Square plinth. In the case of Ms Whiteread's sculpture, the backers are the sculptor herself, Anthony d'Offay Gallery and Luhring Augustine Gallery. Ms Whiteread and Anthony d'Offay Gallery also asked us to make that clear. The RSA role was as the initiator and enabler of the scheme. Each gallery in turn has managed and funded each artwork, and there has been additional support from Arup engineers, who have    given their time free of charge.

In the case of Ms Whiteread's sculpture, the backers are the sculptor herself, Anthony d'Offay Gallery and Luhring Augustine Gallery. Ms Whiteread and Anthony d'Offay Gallery also asked us to make that clear. The RSA role was as the initiator and enabler of the scheme. Each gallery in turn has managed and funded each artwork, and there has been additional support from Arup engineers, who have given their time free of charge.

Mo Attoh, one of the public service workers who were featured in the first part of our survey, The common good, page 10, March 20, has asked us to make it clear that she works for the Barnardo's Gloucestershire Leaving Care Project, and not Barnardo's Homes. Modern Barnardo's has no homes. It runs a range of community projects helping vulnerable and disadvantaged young people and children. The note at the end of the piece about the 60/40 split in funding between social services and Barnado's applies only to the Gloucestershire Leaving Care project and not to Barnado's as a whole.

In a football league roundup, page 30 (Sport), yesterday, we said "Blackpool moved up to fourth in the Third Division table with Matt Lockwood's brilliant free-kick giving them a 1-0 win over ... Leyton Orient." Matt Lockwood did indeed score from a free-kick but he plays for Orient, who beat Blackpool 1-0 and not vice versa. Blackpool thus remain fifth in the table.

Homophone corner, from page 5, G2, yesterday: "If you are a footballer or an actor - to all intense and purposes people who do something dramatic - then in a sense it's part of the pantomime."

webTitle: Leader: Bush succumbs to Sharon's advances

fields.headline: In bed with Sharon
fields.standfirst:
Bush succumbs to seductive advances

Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Ariel Sharon's success in Washington is a setback for the Palestinians and a challenge for next week's Arab summit in Jordan.
fields.body:
Ariel Sharon's success in Washington is a setback for the Palestinians and a challenge for next week's Arab summit in Jordan. The Israeli prime minister, once ostracised by the US and famously described as "an obstacle to peace" by James Baker, was given a statesman's reception this time around. President George Bush and Colin Powell, his secretary of state, agreed that Israel's security concerns must come first, that a Clinton-style comprehensive Middle East peace deal was not worth pursuing, and even perhaps that Yasser Arafat not be given a White House audience until he definitively halts the intifada violence.

Mr Sharon astutely pressed all the Bush buttons. He stressed the importance of regional stability (to Mr Bush this means US oil supplies). He underlined the need to counter international terrorism (another Bush priority). He worried about weapons proliferation, particularly in respect of Iran (a developing Bush fixation). He gave a big thumbs-up to Mr Bush's pet project, missile defence (and prospectively procured a share of the hardware). And, echoing Dubya's briefing papers, he warned of the continuing dangers posed to all by Saddam Hussein's Iraq. Mr Sharon's message was both clear and clever. In all these key areas of US concern, Israel was not only America's ally. It was, to adapt Madeleine Albright's phrase, America's indispensable friend. Lost amid this deft flummery was unambiguous US insistence that Mr Sharon end the military and economic blockade of the Occupied Territories, hand over tax receipts due to the Palestinian Authority, halt further settlement expansion (as in Har Homa now), and resume the dialogue. Instead, Mr Bush says he will not "force peace". That suits Mr Sharon just fine.

Arab leaders must act quickly, if that is not too absurd a concept, to set aright this diplomatic capsizal. One immediate step should be the disbursement of the $1bn in aid promised to the Palestinian Authority last autumn but largely still withheld. Another is concerted pressure for a UN stabilisation force in the Territories, a proposal Israel wants the US to veto. The Arab summit might ask the EU to take the lead in the peace process. And, turning Israel's argument around, it could warn that if the US truly expects Arab support for revised "smart" sanctions on Iraq and an end to regional connivance in Baghdad's oil smuggling, it had better take a harder look at the remoulded Mr Sharon.

webTitle: Energis in row with Swiss partner

fields.headline: Energis in row with Swiss partner
fields.standfirst: Telecoms company claims double dealing over lock-up agreement
fields.trailText: Telecommunications group Energis was last night involved in a furious row with one of its shareholders after accusing the Swiss information technology group, Distefora, of breaking a lock-up agreement.
fields.body:
Telecommunications group Energis was last night involved in a furious row with one of its shareholders after accusing the Swiss information technology group, Distefora, of breaking a lock-up agreement.

Energis said it was taking legal advice after learning that Distefora had sold a large tranche of the Energis shares the Swiss company acquired when it sold its e-commerce services group Ision to the UK company late last year.

Energis paid Distefora €210m (£133m) plus 62m shares for its 75% holding in Ision. Yesterday the British company said that as part of the deal, Distefora had agreed not to sell the majority of its holding before October 2001 without written permission from Energis.

However, it said that it had learned on Tuesday night that Distefora had cut its holding to just below the 40m level.

"We did not give permission. We were not aware of Distefora selling shares which were subject to the lock-up agreement until that notification," said a spokeswoman. "We are seeking clarification and we are taking legal advice."

She said that the company had already received an undertaking from Distefora that it would not sell any more of its shares.

Distefora acknowledged that it had sold the shares but denied being in breach of its agreement with Energis.

"We reject the accusations from Energis as unfounded," chief executive Alexander Falk told Reuters news agency, adding that the shares had been sold in a way which did not hurt the share price and which served the interests of both companies.

According to the Energis spokeswoman, the deal included a "buffer" clause under which Distefora would have a claim on Energis if it had to sell the shares below a certain price level.

In the current circumstances "we will be resisting" having to make the buffer payment, she said. She declined to go into further detail.

Energis shares fell almost 13% to 279.5p yesterday to its lowest point for the year.

It was the FTSE 100 share index's biggest faller on a day when telecommunications stocks in general were sharply lower.

"Anything even slightly adverse is going to push the stock down, but there was always a stock overhang," said one industry watcher.

fields.headline: Rafael Martínez Nadal
fields.standfirst: A trusted friend of Lorca, he escaped death at the hands of Franco's forces to become a leading light of Hispanic life and letters in London
fields.trailText: A trusted friend of Lorca, he escaped death at the hands of Franco's forces to become a leading light of Hispanic life and letters in London
fields.body:
The Spanish writer, lecturer and broadcaster Rafael Martínez Nadal, who has died aged 97, was a close friend of Federico García Lorca, and his outlook was shaped by the brilliant generation of Spanish artists who blossomed in the 1920s. He met Lorca at Madrid's famous Residencia de Estudiantes in the 1920s. On July 13 1936, after the murder of José Calvo Sotelo, which made the generals' uprising imminent, Lorca entrusted to Nadal a bundle of manuscripts that included the remarkable homoerotic play El Público.

Born in Madrid, Rafael Nadal had a sickly childhood, but became a middleweight boxing champion, and then an active opponent of the 1920s dictatorship of Primo de Rivera, an enthusiast for the Second Republic of 1931 and a habitué of literary circles. In 1933, having com pleted his studies at Madrid University, he took up a one-year post at the University of Poitiers as lector, visiting London in 1934 and finally settling there after escaping from Franco's Spain in 1936.

During the second world war, under the pseudonym Antonio Torres, he broadcast a weekly programme to Spain for the BBC. Though the British government and BBC had a policy of appeasing Franco, he managed to retain credibility with listeners within Spain by attacking Hitler and Mussolini. Despite this softly softly approach he was suspended for four months in 1943, due to pressure from Britain's pro-Franco ambassador in Madrid, Samuel Hoare.

From 1936-76, Nadal worked in London as university lecturer, broadcaster at the BBC's Bush House (1940-44) and as Spanish affairs correspondent of the Observer (1944-53). In 1939, he had helped Stephen Spender on a translation of Lorca's poems, writing a lengthy introduction, but it was not until his retirement that his literary life really began. He worked with Kathleen Raine on her 1969 translation of Calderón's Life Is A Dream, and in 1981 he translated her poems into Spanish. In 1972, he finally published Lorca's openly sexual, unfinished play El Público. The reaction of the Lorca family was fierce: they sought to suppress publication, hating any reference to the playwright's homosexuality. There were essays and books on Lorca, but never enough, and many secrets of Lorca's private life go to the grave with Nadal.

Athletic-looking and handsome, with a big nose and thick glasses, Nadal was always extraordinarily affable and kindly. He put pleasure in life and loyalty to his friends above literary fame. He is survived by his wife, a son and daughter.

Jack Sage writes: Rafael Nadal said of his years at the University of Madrid and the Residencia de Estudiantes: "I had the tremendous good fortune to be a Madrilenian living through a period when our city was lavished with a wealth of talent..." Indeed, he rubbed shoulders with artists like Gregorio Prieto and Dalí; musicians and musicologists like Andrés Segovia, La Argentinita and Martínez Torner; thinkers and writers like Salvador de Madariaga, Dámaso Alonso and José Castillejo; and poets like Altolaguirre, Aleixandre, Cernuda, as well as Lorca.

This wealth of talented characters could not have failed to shape him; what he did not say is that he helped to shape them too, just as he has helped to shape our awareness of modern Hispanic culture and politics. He was arguably the most important of the brilliant generation of Spanish civil war exiles in Britain, and certainly the most energetic and colourful.

He died while preparing his fourth - as he loved to put it - "penultimate" work. Of his 52 or so published works, half-a-dozen are seductive vignettes in which he set out in colourful but subtle brush strokes to outline the personal qualities and quirks of creative people he knew - including, of course, Lorca. Several rank as substantial landmarks, including: Poems by F García Lorca, with English translations by Stephen Spender and JL Gili (1942); Lorca's El Público (the English version of his Spanish study, 1974; facsimile edition, 1976); Luis Cernuda. El hombre y sus temas (1983); Lorca, Así que pasen cinco años (1983); Antonio Torres y la política española del Foreign Office, 1940-1944 (1989); Ecos clásicos en las obras de Federico García Lorca y Luis Cernuda (1986).

From 1936-76, Nadal taught in the department of Spanish at King's College in the University of London. He had the rare virtue of being able to expound from intimate inside knowledge, in lectures and in scintillating conversations, the difficult poems of Lorca and others of that marvellous generation. If only because of that rare virtue, his determination to stand aloof from the current fascination with Lorca's homoeroticism, a critical fashion which he regarded as cramping, demands respect.

He had an unforgettable gift for reciting poetry with oratorical relish. Ever a live wire, his energy led him to deploy other talents, such as producing student play performances, from Cervantes to modern zarzuelas, the highlight of which was the first performance in Britain of the revered zarzuela by Tomás Bretón, La verbena de la paloma. Such was his enthusiasm that he typically managed to goad a hesitant student - me - to take charge of the musical direction.

It also led him to buy, in the 1950s, one of the much-used classic London Austin taxis which he referred to as his "old lady", and which he would gleefully drive around with demonic majesty.

A celebrated raconteur, though he was as good a listener as talker, his stories ranged from the hilariously self-deprecating to the hair-raising. Of the latter were those about his perilous escape from Franco's Spain, and how a nameless friend in a position of strategic power astutely decoded and responded to a Nadal telegram regretting his delayed arrival in circumstances which "you will understand" needed "urgent attention", thus producing in the nick of time a reprieve from a "nationalist" order to have him shot along with 22 other Republicans seeking to escape from the fascist forces.

 Rafael Martínez Nadal, writer, born December 28 1903; died March 5 2001

Of the latter were those about his perilous escape from Franco's Spain, and how a nameless friend in a position of strategic power astutely decoded and responded to a Nadal telegram regretting his delayed arrival in circumstances which "you will understand" needed "urgent attention", thus producing in the nick of time a reprieve from a "nationalist" order to have him shot along with 22 other Republicans seeking to escape from the fascist forces.  Rafael Martínez Nadal, writer, born December 28 1903; died March 5 2001

fields.headline: Will Carter
fields.standfirst: Master who carved out careers in two distinct crafts
fields.trailText: Will Carter, who has died aged 88, was a master craftsman - printer, typographer, calligrapher, carver of wood and slate - for whom good design was, in his own modest description, "a matter of seeing the simplest way of doing something, which is usually the best".
fields.body:
Will Carter, who has died aged 88, was a master craftsman - printer, typographer, calligrapher, carver of wood and slate - for whom good design was, in his own modest description, "a matter of seeing the simplest way of doing something, which is usually the best".

From an early age he loved letters in the literal rather than literary sense. He was not quite 12 when John Johnson, the Oxford university printer, gave him a packet of type in the hope that it might serve as the basis of "an amusing and useful hobby". The hobby became his livelihood, its practice a lifetime source of pleasure.

Carter was the son of a vicar at Upton, outside Slough, who moved to become a master at Eton. Educated at Radley, Will left school at 16, became an apprentice at a Woking printers, and in 1934 a designer at Heffers' printing works in Cambridge. In 1939, he married Barbara Digby. During the war he served in the Royal Navy, latterly in command of a two-masted Arab schooner.

He was impatient to command his own press and print in accordance with his own aesthetic. Thus, in 1949, supported courageously by Barbara, who was now expecting the third of their four children, he resigned from Heffers. The Rampant Lions Press imprint, born in a back bedroom in 1931, was reborn in the sub-basement of the house which they rented for a peppercorn from Magdalene College, Cambridge.

There he worked singlehandedly as a jobbing printer, responding to the individual challenge of each visiting card or bookplate. He seldom charged for design; only, sometimes, for an item he called GBA (general buggering about). Not until 1960 could he afford to give more than passing attention to printing books.

His masterpiece was probably William Morris's The Story of Cupid and Psyche in 1974, set in Morris's types and illustrated with the blocks engraved by Morris from Burne-Jones's designs. Carter printed the book jointly with his son Sebastian, who joined the press in 1966. Although they tended to work independently on projects, their complementary skills enriched production. Their partnership is seen to great effect in the catalogue they produced in 1982 for the exhibition at the Fitzwilliam Museum celebrating "A printing workshop through five decades". Apart from wood- and slate-carvings and 20 frames of jobbing printings, the catalogue lists 89 books. Thanks to Sebastian, the Rampant Lions Press is a continuing memorial to Will.

Barbara died in 1994, and Carter lived with his grief by working even harder. He will be remembered for the slate memorials he carved for others and for the circular commemorative breadboards. He had taught himself to carve wood in 1935 and continued almost to the end of his life. David Kindersley taught him to carve stone in 1948, and only a few months after he had cut his first letters on slate, he undertook the war memorial at Magdalene. Besides printing, Carter designed types and ornaments, notably the bold italic Klang, Dartmouth and, with Kindersley, Octavian.

He carved memorials for Percy Lubbock, Ruskin Spear, Edward Ardizzone, Allen Lane, the founder of Penguin Books, and Henry James in Poets' Corner. He also did the foundation stone for the British Library. Magdalene awarded him an honorary fellowship in 1977. He was appointed OBE in 1984.

Will retained the look of a wartime skipper, handsome, bearded, with aquiline features and a casual elegance of dress. He lived providently: the richness, he said, was in a way of life. His tall upright figure, often on his tall upright bicycle, was a feature of Cambridge life. He is survived by Sebastian and three daughters.

fields.headline: Gordon Brown
fields.standfirst: Scots rugby stalwart with a leading role in famous British Lions victories of the 70s
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown, who has died of cancer aged 53, had a memorable rugby career - capped 30 times for Scotland at lock forward and touring three times with the British Lions - and a soccer pedigree. Known in some circles as "Broon frae Troon", he was the son of a professional goalkeeper for Hibernian, Kilmarnock and Scotland.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown, who has died of cancer aged 53, had a memorable rugby career - capped 30 times for Scotland at lock forward and touring three times with the British Lions - and a soccer pedigree. Known in some circles as "Broon frae Troon", he was the son of a professional goalkeeper for Hibernian, Kilmarnock and Scotland.

Gordon, too, started his sporting life as a goalkeeper, playing soccer on Saturday afternoons after playing rugby for his school, Marr College, in the mornings. Eventually he graduated to his brother Peter's rugby club, West of Scotland.

At 17 stone and 6ft 5ins - very tall in those days, 30 years ago - he quickly made a name for himself as a ball-catcher in the middle of the line-out and was capped by Scotland against the Springboks in 1969. He went on to win 30 caps for Scotland between 1969 and 1976. As befits anyone hailing from Troon, he was also an accomplished golfer.

Nowadays we are always hearing about the supremacy of the southern hemisphere in rugby union, as if this has always been inevitable. It seems to have been forgotten that the 1971 Lions beat the All Blacks in New Zealand in the Test series and that the 1974 Lions defeated the Springboks in their series in South Africa.

At the very heart of those triumphs in the 1970s was Gordon Brown. Willie John McBride has rightly been given much of the credit for those achievements, as have backs like Gareth Edwards, Barry John, Mike Gibson and JPR Williams, but Brown, as McBride's lock partner, had much to do with it all.

He was renowned as a scrummager, he excelled in the middle of the line-out, and in open play he scored eight tries on the Lions' tour of South Africa in 1974. In his day, forwards were certainly not expected to score that many tries. That he did so was a tribute to his intelligence in anticipation and to his overall fitness. The fitness could be traced not only to the coaching of Carwyn James in 1971 and Syd Millar in 1974, but also to the training sessions he undertook with the Rangers soccer club at Ibrox.

He had worked as a building society branch manager, but in recent years Gordon was much in demand as an after-dinner speaker. Three years ago, resplendent in kilt and sporran, he made an uproarious speech at the Rugby Union Writers' annual dinner before 460 people at the Cafe Royal in London.

Only last month he attended a dinner at the Grosvenor House organised for his benefit. More than 1,000 admirers dined with him that night, among them McBride, Andy Irvine, Fergus Slattery and one of his oldest adversaries, the great Colin Meads from New Zealand. What a fitting send-off.

He is survived by his wife Linda and by a son and daughter.

fields.headline: Sea change
fields.standfirst: Tests show trading boat is oldest in Europe
fields.trailText: Britain's earliest trading foray into Europe has been backdated by three centuries after the belated discovery that a Yorkshire museum houses the continent's oldest heavy duty, sea-going boat.
fields.body:
Britain's earliest trading foray into Europe has been backdated by three centuries after the belated discovery that a Yorkshire museum houses the continent's oldest heavy duty, sea-going boat.

New methods of carbon-dating have cracked the mystery of an oak planked hulk the size of an articulated lorry, which was found in the river Humber mud 30 years ago but wrongly dated by archaeologists.

Described for 30 years as mid-bronze age - c1700BC - the paddle powered craft has now been traced to 2030BC after the painstaking removal of gallons of 1960s wood preservative which confused earlier tests. The development of accelerator mass spectrometry, a sophisticated form of carbon dating, has also helped to reveal the boat's distinguished place in history.

"The discovery is very significant, because it ties in with the first archaeological evidence we have of serious trade with Europe - in goods like Baltic amber and mid-European bronze," said Alex Bayliss, head of the project as scientific dating coordinator for English Heritage. "The importance of the dating is that such sewn-plank boats could have provided the transport for Britain to move towards the heart of Europe at that time."

Known as Ferriby 3, the boat was the third to be found on the Humber's tidal shoreline at Ferriby, beached or scuppered beside two later craft, whose dates have also been revised to between 1680BC and 1940BC. The sewn-plank method constructs an elegant but sturdy ship in the shape of a melon slice, with thick oak planks sewn together with twisted yew withies.

Sections are on show in Hull's maritime and East Riding museums, along with a reconstruction and one virtually complete, salvaged panel. No comparable boats from the same era are known in Europe.

The boat's distinguished new status was welcomed yesterday by its finder, Ted Wright, a fellow of the Royal Society of Antiquaries. He discovered all three boats at Ferriby, in 1937, 1940 and 1963, and unearthed them - a process described as "like getting slices of crumbly cheese out of glue".

"It's pretty exciting at the age of 82 to find out that you made one of the most significant discoveries in British archaeology," he said. "I'm also glad to see another milestone reached in our knowledge of the impressive capabilities of our early bronze age forebears."

webTitle: Haider rallies the racist vote in Vienna elections

fields.headline: Haider rallies the racist vote in Vienna elections
fields.trailText: The Austrian political system has been thrown into turmoil again by a new wave of xenophobia generated by the former Freedom party leader Jörg Haider.
fields.body:
The Austrian political system has been thrown into turmoil again by a new wave of xenophobia generated by the former Freedom party leader Jörg Haider.

Mr Haider, who remains the main force in the far-right party, is using the municipal elections in Vienna this weekend to resurrect his pet topics of immigration and "over foreignisation", stunning the party's senior partner in the government coalition, the People's party (OVP), into an embarrassed silence.

Freedom party (FPO) election posters filled with anti-foreigner innuendo have been plastered around the capital.

A firebrand populist, Mr Haider has riddled his speeches with anti-semitic comments and subliminal xenophobic messages of late, which have proved a considerable hit with voters.

Political commentators say that "Haiderism" is far from dead and Mr Haider's recipe for pulling in the voters appears to be working.

Recent polls have shown the FPO's support 10% down from the 28% it won in 1996, but in the past few days its standing has risen to 22%. Twenty percent of Austria's 8m people, a fifth of whom are foreigners, live in Vienna.

The Social Democrats, who govern Vienna in coalition with the conservative OVP, are expected to win on Sunday, but not before Mr Haider attempts to rally his far-right army of voters.

With one eye on a huge personal opportunity to regain the limelight this weekend, Mr Haider has abandoned the mountains of Carinthia, where he is governor, to boost his troubled party.

During the national election campaign in October 1999 he was attacked by human rights organisations for the FPO's "Stop the over-foreignisation" posters in Vienna.

Its message this time does not appear to be very different.

"Foreigners: I understand the concerns of the Viennese!" one poster claims on behalf of the FPO's leader in Vienna, Helene Partik-Pable.

Next to it is another saying: "Crime: I also want a safe life!"

The posters appear side by side throughout the city.

Mr Haider, famous for praising Hitler's employment policies and lauding SS veterans as "men of character", drew raucous laughter last month at a beer-hall gathering of FPO members by making fun of the first name of Ariel Muzicant, the head of Austria's Jewish community.

"How can a man with such a name have such dirt on his hands?" he said. He later accused Mr Muzicant of "unclean business practices".

What has disturbed his critics the most, however, is not his zenophobic outbursts, but the silence of the OVP.

"If I had said anything anti-semitic, then [Chancellor Wolfgang] Schüssel would have protested," Mr Haider wrote in a newspaper commentary last week, referring to his comments about Mr Muzicant.

Mr Schüssel's only response was to say that Mr Haider had expressed a "carnivalesque ribaldry".

Franz Fischler, the EU's Austrian agricultural commissioner, has entered the fray, saying he fears that Austria's reputation could be further damaged by Mr Haider's outbursts."

We should be most concerned about the fact that, obviously, in Austria, those who make such comments can be sure of getting applause," he said.

fields.headline: Mir today, gone tomorrow
fields.standfirst:
World hopes for a splash, not a crash as the doomed space station's return to Earth ends an era of Russian glory

Special report: space exploration
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: World hopes for a splash, not a crash as the doomed space station's return to Earth ends an era of Russian glory.
fields.byline: Amelia Gentleman in Moscow and  Tim Radford
fields.body:
The Russian space station Mir dropped in altitude by more than two miles yesterday, bringing it close to its final orbit and its last blaze of glory tomorrow morning as it plunges to a fiery end after 15 years in service.

With it will perish a Bible, a Koran, 11 tonnes of scientific equipment, more than 100 books left behind by astronauts, a "greenhouse" of experimental crops, personal items left by more than 100 visitors, uninvited fungi, a photograph of Yuri Gagarin, the first man in space - and the hopes and dreams of a nation.

The Russians, as leaders of the Soviet Union, were the first to launch a satellite into space, the first to put a man - and a woman - into orbit, the first to launch a group of people, and the first to keep humans in space for longer than a year.

But the end of Mir signals the end of Russian independence at the highest frontier of all; Russia's next adventure in space is as a junior partner in the Nasa-led International Space Station, now taking shape in orbit.

When Gagarin took to the skies almost 40 years ago, on April 12 1961, there was feverish delight, very different from the sober Soviet revolutionary parades for which workers were ordered out of their factories and onto the streets.

As the smouldering remains of Mir plunge into the Pacific Ocean tomorrow, around 06.30 GMT, Russia may once again be united by a wave of collective emotion - this time regret. A sense of pride in its cosmic achievements has been reawakened in time only to mourn a symbolic end to an era of space supremacy.

Sceptics describe Mir as a fault-ridden lump of rusting machinery. Supporters prefer to see it as "140 tonnes of intellectual metal".

There were crises and absurdities in Mir's recent history - including the accident-plagued year of 1997 and the undignified attempts to transform it into a hotel, film studio and gameshow prize - but an opinion poll yesterday showed that only 27% of Russians approved of the decision to abandon it.

So much was Mir a symbol of Russia's superpower status that MPs voted 298 to 3 in February to urge Mr Putin to save it.

Leftwing commentators said the deliberate sinking of Mir represented an unforgivable surrender to American interests. The communist newspaper Sovietskaya Rossiya compared the head of the Russian aerospace agency, Yury Koptyev, to the Taliban, saying that to sink Mir was a crime equivalent to the recent destruction of the ancient Buddha statues in Bamiyan, Afghanistan.

The speaker of the lower house, the communist Gennady Seleznyov, called on the government to begin at once planning Mir 2, a project abandoned in 1990 as expensive and unnecessary.

The offer last week by the president of Iran, Mohammad Khatami, to pay for Mir to stay in orbit and train Iranian cosmonauts was far too late to reverse Mir's death plunge.

The veteran cosmonaut Georgy Grechko, twice decorated as a Hero of the Soviet Union, said: "Anyone who worked in the space industry will naturally be in mourning on Friday ... Its destruction will be a great blow to the nation's pride."

Alexander Orlov, of the Mir Preservation Foundation, said: "Mir is as important to Russia as the navy once was to the British. It is the symbol of an epoch and its loss will be a massive psychological blow."

The aerospace agency, Rosaviakosmos, was more pragmatic. "What's the point of spending all this money on restoring an old station when we can spend it on a new one?" its spokesman, Sergei Gorbunov, said.

"The technology is outdated and we don't have the money for repairs. No research is being carried out on board and recent missions have been devoted exclusively to repairing Mir. There's no longer any point to Mir."

The space station's last moments have depended - and could still be affected by - the "weather" in space.

But the dice are already loaded: Mir's altitude is being gradually lowered to let the highest wisps of the upper atmosphere begin slowing, at a height of 137 miles. A Progress spacecraft carrying almost 4 tonnes of fuel will act as the agent of death.

At 00.33 GMT tomorrow, controllers in Moscow will send a signal to start the Progress's engines to slow Mir down and alter its orbit.

At 30 miles altitude the buffeting of re-entry will begin to split the ship into As many as 1,500 pieces. About 20 tonnes of debris is expected to splash down at 125mph, scattered along a narrow stretch of empty ocean between New Zealand and Patagonia.

That is, if the controlled descent is indeed controlled. There have been loudly voiced fears that the equivalent of a fully equipped laboratory, hotel and gymnasium could fall almost anywhere, and the Russians have taken out a £140m insurance policy.

But space experts think the odds are against any calamity. "It's a matter of statistics," the Nasa orbital debris office said. "The world is a big place, and even 6.1bn people go a long way."

What goes up into orbit almost invariably comes down, and there has been at least one uncontrolled re-entry a day for the past 40 years. A Russian nuclear-powered satellite left a trail of radioactive fragments over Canada in 1978, the US Skylab hit Western Australia in 1979, and the Russian Salyut 7 station landed in South America in 1991. There have never been any injuries.

If all goes well ... decks

... and if it doesn't

Britain

 A civil defence master plan is ready in case Mir crashes in Britain: local authorities and police will cordon off crash sites and call paramedics

Australia

 Radio and TV to broadcast emergency information if Mir approaches

 Farmers and gardeners told not to touch any space junk

 Sydney residents will be able to watch Mir's final orbit of Earth tonight

 Several Australian flights will be over the South Pacific as Mir descends, including Qantas flight to Buenos Aires. Airlines are monitoring the situation

New Zealand

 The authorities are trying to warn tuna fishermen from American Samoa working in the crash area

 Local police will be warned if space debris approaches

 Local astronomer says people should be able to keep or sell any space debris they find

 At least three international flights have been rerouted

Japan

 Last populated area under Mir's path before the space station breaks up

 Okinawans told to stay indoors

 Emergencies minister promises every precaution; police, firefighters and medical crews on alert

 At-risk areas told to prepare for the worst

 Chance of Mir hitting Japan put at 100m-1

Germany

 Catastrophe plan and 24-hour coordination centre set up despite remote chance of a hit on Berlin

 200 firefighters on standby in Berlin, ready within minutes. Airport fire crews to help

 Berlin hospitals ready for 1,000 patients

 Worst-case involves Mir hitting Kaufhaus des Westens - Europe's second-biggest department store - on Saturday morning

 Ministry denies that it is scaremongering

When Gagarin took to the skies almost 40 years ago, on April 12 1961, there was feverish delight, very different from the sober Soviet revolutionary parades for which workers were ordered out of their factories and onto the streets. As the smouldering remains of Mir plunge into the Pacific Ocean tomorrow, around 06.30 GMT, Russia may once again be united by a wave of collective emotion - this time regret. A sense of pride in its cosmic achievements has been reawakened in time only to mourn a symbolic end to an era of space supremacy. Sceptics describe Mir as a fault-ridden lump of rusting machinery. Supporters prefer to see it as "140 tonnes of intellectual metal". There were crises and absurdities in Mir's recent history - including the accident-plagued year of 1997 and the undignified attempts to transform it into a hotel, film studio and gameshow prize - but an opinion poll yesterday showed that only 27% of Russians approved of the decision to abandon it. So much was Mir a symbol of Russia's superpower status that MPs voted 298 to 3 in February to urge Mr Putin to save it. Leftwing commentators said the deliberate sinking of Mir represented an unforgivable surrender to American interests. The communist newspaper Sovietskaya Rossiya compared the head of the Russian aerospace agency, Yury Koptyev, to the Taliban, saying that to sink Mir was a crime equivalent to the recent destruction of the ancient Buddha statues in Bamiyan, Afghanistan. The speaker of the lower house, the communist Gennady Seleznyov, called on the government to begin at once planning Mir 2, a project abandoned in 1990 as expensive and unnecessary. The offer last week by the president of Iran, Mohammad Khatami, to pay for Mir to stay in orbit and train Iranian cosmonauts was far too late to reverse Mir's death plunge. The veteran cosmonaut Georgy Grechko, twice decorated as a Hero of the Soviet Union, said: "Anyone who worked in the space industry will naturally be in mourning on Friday ... Its destruction will be a great blow to the nation's pride." Alexander Orlov, of the Mir Preservation Foundation, said: "Mir is as important to Russia as the navy once was to the British. It is the symbol of an epoch and its loss will be a massive psychological blow." The aerospace agency, Rosaviakosmos, was more pragmatic. "What's the point of spending all this money on restoring an old station when we can spend it on a new one?" its spokesman, Sergei Gorbunov, said. "The technology is outdated and we don't have the money for repairs. No research is being carried out on board and recent missions have been devoted exclusively to repairing Mir. There's no longer any point to Mir." The space station's last moments have depended - and could still be affected by - the "weather" in space. But the dice are already loaded: Mir's altitude is being gradually lowered to let the highest wisps of the upper atmosphere begin slowing, at a height of 137 miles. A Progress spacecraft carrying almost 4 tonnes of fuel will act as the agent of death. At 00.33 GMT tomorrow, controllers in Moscow will send a signal to start the Progress's engines to slow Mir down and alter its orbit. At 30 miles altitude the buffeting of re-entry will begin to split the ship into As many as 1,500 pieces. About 20 tonnes of debris is expected to splash down at 125mph, scattered along a narrow stretch of empty ocean between New Zealand and Patagonia. That is, if the controlled descent is indeed controlled. There have been loudly voiced fears that the equivalent of a fully equipped laboratory, hotel and gymnasium could fall almost anywhere, and the Russians have taken out a £140m insurance policy. But space experts think the odds are against any calamity. "It's a matter of statistics," the Nasa orbital debris office said. "The world is a big place, and even 6.1bn people go a long way." What goes up into orbit almost invariably comes down, and there has been at least one uncontrolled re-entry a day for the past 40 years. A Russian nuclear-powered satellite left a trail of radioactive fragments over Canada in 1978, the US Skylab hit Western Australia in 1979, and the Russian Salyut 7 station landed in South America in 1991. There have never been any injuries. If all goes well ... decks ... and if it doesn't Britain  A civil defence master plan is ready in case Mir crashes in Britain: local authorities and police will cordon off crash sites and call paramedics Australia  Radio and TV to broadcast emergency information if Mir approaches  Farmers and gardeners told not to touch any space junk  Sydney residents will be able to watch Mir's final orbit of Earth tonight  Several Australian flights will be over the South Pacific as Mir descends, including Qantas flight to Buenos Aires. Airlines are monitoring the situation New Zealand  The authorities are trying to warn tuna fishermen from American Samoa working in the crash area  Local police will be warned if space debris approaches  Local astronomer says people should be able to keep or sell any space debris they find  At least three international flights have been rerouted Japan  Last populated area under Mir's path before the space station breaks up  Okinawans told to stay indoors  Emergencies minister promises every precaution; police, firefighters and medical crews on alert  At-risk areas told to prepare for the worst  Chance of Mir hitting Japan put at 100m-1 Germany  Catastrophe plan and 24-hour coordination centre set up despite remote chance of a hit on Berlin  200 firefighters on standby in Berlin, ready within minutes. Airport fire crews to help  Berlin hospitals ready for 1,000 patients  Worst-case involves Mir hitting Kaufhaus des Westens - Europe's second-biggest department store - on Saturday morning  Ministry denies that it is scaremongering Patrick Barkham and Jonathan Watts Useful links US government Mir tracking Rosaviakosmos (Russian space agency) Rosaviakosmos Mir information (in Russian)

webTitle: Women dissatisfied with care during childbirth

fields.headline: Women dissatisfied with care during childbirth
fields.trailText: Most women are dissatisfied with the care they get during childbirth and less than half would be happy to return to the same hospital to give birth again, according to a national survey published today investigating the experiences of 2,000 recent mothers.
fields.body:
Most women are dissatisfied with the care they get during childbirth and less than half would be happy to return to the same hospital to give birth again, according to a national survey published today investigating the experiences of 2,000 recent mothers.

Three-quarters said they felt anxious during pregnancy and frightened during labour. Six in 10 found the experience of giving birth more shocking than they expected.

Four in 10 said they were not allowed to move around during labour and take up positions they wanted and 43% said they did not have the type of birth they wanted. Only 8% of women had a completely natural birth, without the need for drugs or surgical interventions.

The survey by the website motherandbaby.co.uk was based on responses from 2,000 mothers who used the site and agreed to answer questions. Their average age was 29.

A quarter had a caesarean. Among those giving birth normally, 35% were induced, 45% had an epidural, 12% had a forceps delivery and 53% needed stitches.

Half of all new mothers said they had received poor postnatal care once they had taken their baby home and 79% said they were in pain after the birth for an average of two weeks.

The women were also dissatisfied with their care during pregnancy. Only 4% had the same midwife for all antenatal appointments and delivery.

Sarah Stone, editor of motherandbaby.co.uk, said: "Overstretched maternity staff simply don't have the time to provide the sort of quality care pregnant women need and expect. As a result, many women feel they have gone through a conveyor-belt birth experience to suit the hospital's agenda.

"Birth in Britain today has become a lottery - if you are lucky enough to give birth in a maternity unit with a full complement of staff and only a few women giving birth at the same time, then you'll probably have a more positive experience. Unfortunately, for most women, this is not the case."

 An opinion poll for the British Medical Association found 89% of the public are satisfied with the way doctors do their jobs. In spite of recent scandals such as the conviction of the serial killer GP Harold Shipman, public confidence in the trustworthiness of doctors was 2% higher than a year ago.

The annual poll of trust in the professions found 89% of people trusted doctors to tell the truth, compared with 86% who trusted teachers and 78% who had faith in vicars and judges.

webTitle: Iron Age hoard of jewels found

fields.headline: Iron Age hoard of jewels found
fields.trailText: A man using a metal detector has found a hoard of spectacular Iron Age jewellery, a kilo of pure gold worth up to £500,000, scattered across a ploughed field on a farm near Winchester.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A man using a metal detector has found a hoard of spectacular Iron Age jewellery, a kilo of pure gold worth up to £500,000, scattered across a ploughed field on a farm near Winchester.

British Museum experts regard the jewellery as the most important Iron Age find in decades. A coroner's treasure trove will be held in Winchester today on the gold, possibly a ritual offering made in the last century before the Roman invasion in 43AD. It will then be formally valued, to determine the compensation due to the finder and the land owner. The British Museum will have six months to raise the money to acquire the jewellery.

One of the necklaces is unique, made in the style of Celtic gold and silver torcs - collars found in Ireland, the West Midlands and East Anglia - but using a Roman and Greek technique of interlinked gold wire ring chains. The continental ones are delicate and light, the Winchester one a display of wealth.

The gold was found last Autumn by Kevin Halls, who has spent years investigating a farm near Winchester, with the permission of the land owner, but has never found anything more exciting than a common Roman brooch.

He struck gold on the first day he took his detector into a field he had never tried before.

Jeremy Hills, from the British Museum, said: "We now know what the site was not: not a cemetery, not a Roman villa, nor a barrow or earth work. I hesitate to say druids, but this was a time when lavish gifts were made to the gods in the fields and oak groves."

fields.headline: The thrill of the chase
fields.trailText: The Hunt | The Cops | The Human Face
fields.body:
I felt myself fluff up and nestle down happily like a hen on an addled egg for The Hunt (ITV). Absolutely no teeth are needed which, for a hen, is handy. We are in upper-crust country. In the local the yokels are making a book on how long it will take the squire to have his way with Amanda Holden. Not, the clever money says, very long.

Cream has been poured over this trifle with a lavish hand. The skies are enormous and opalescent. There is a lot of galloping along the skyline. The fox actually is quick and brown. The hounds pour out like spilled milk. Piers Haggard directs. There are some perfectly respectable actors involved. Sometimes you wonder how they can face themselves in the mirror but actors never seem to have any problem doing that.

So tally-ho, off we go! Sarah (Amanda Holden) and Rob (Philip Glenister) have moved from London to a country estate. If you wonder where they got the money, and I always do wonder, Rob promotes rock concerts. The cock of this particular walk is the Hon Hugh (Adrian Lukis): banker, bonker, and dashed good-looker. He looks lovely in hunting pink and even better in the buff. Hugh never can resist the thrill of the chase and zeroes in on Sarah, a rather snappy little blonde, pale as a peeled twig.

Which brings me to the sad fact that Amanda Holden is seriously undergunned for the part. Observe how she tries to inflame the Hon Hugh by twiddling her hair. She is not helped by the dialogue, which seems to be hacked out of hardboard. I particularly enjoyed Lady Diana's autocratic "Enough! I want to show Rob the escritoire!"

More next week, if you can stomach it.

The sad thing is that The Hunt is in direct competition with The Cops (BBC 2), the best thing on TV at the moment. You need a sweet tooth for The Hunt. You need teeth for The Cops. It is drama that looks and sounds like documentary. You never catch anyone acting. You can look away casually then turn back quickly, when they least expect it, and still not catch them at it. The camera noses here and there like an eager but confused dog. The dialogue sounds improvised. The story whizzes past your ear like a bullet. Nothing is explained, you have to work at it.

For instance, it started with Roy and Mel, whom we already know, which is just as well, arriving at some kerfuffle at the Caffreys'. "What's happening here then?" says Roy. "You can fuck off", is the instant rejoinder. The inspector arrives when things have calmed down a bit. He says, "What's happening here then?" You could hit him.

It is a small world. Cops and robbers are on first name terms. They have their own language. The law-abiding seem to live on a different planet. As the girl in the back of the police car said, staring out of the window, "The world looks different from in here."

The Cops is hardly a recruiting poster for the police, but truth and gallows humour come off it in great waves. It is quite wonderful and - stick with it - it gets better.

In The Human Face (BB C 1) John Cleese confessed, with more candour than common sense, to a couple of hair transplants. Really? Your eyes rose irresistibly. This week he was enthused by the theory that beauty is a matter of proportion: 1 to 1.618. This is the dullest discovery since America. Parkinson struggled to look interested. Cleese has the dazzling deafness of the true enthusiast. I've shared tables at all-night cafés with men like that.

It would, however, be a mistake to shake your watch crying, "Heavens, is that the time!", because suddenly Cleese will bring a haymaker up from the floor. Pierce Brosnan was complaining what a burden it was to be a thing of beauty. "It pisses me off when they say I'm pretty. I always wanted to be rugged. I thought I'd be a much more talented actor if I had a broken nose." "Would you", asked Cleese, "like me to punch you now?" And the great thing is, with Cleese, he just might.

Barry in EastEnders (BBC 1) is one of life's major losers. He has cloudy, grand ambitions and a supportive and brighter wife, Nat.

Barry: "I want to be someone."

Nat: "You are!"

Barry: "But I want to be someone else."

If that appeared anywhere but in a soap, it would make it into a book of quotations. Attributed to Carey Andrews. Carey, you never know nowadays do you, is a woman.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Loach In Los Angele | Changing Places | Analysis
fields.body:
Ken Loach has devoted his career to peering under stones the authorities would rather leave unlifted. What he found there brought such revelatory dramas to our screens as Cathy Come Home and My Name Is Joe. Now he is focusing on the immigrants who maintain the infrastructure of America's megalopolis. Loach In Los Angeles (11.30am, Radio 4) comes from the set of Bread And Roses, a grim portrait of the invisible army of Latino cleaners who service the city's skyscrapers.

In Changing Places (4.0pm, Radio 4) Howard Stableford finds himself galloping slightly desperately in the wake of Mary Smith. When the Wills cigarette factory in Bristol closed down, all the associated businesses went with it. That turned the Knowle West estate into a wasteland and Mary's son into a drug addict. Having organised a successful anti-drugs enterprise she has now launched a building company to resurrect derelict properties.

The new series of Analysis (8.30pm, Radio 4) finds Ian Hargreaves trying to get to grips with the phenomenon predicted by Andy Warhol in 1968. To a greater degree than ever, the horizon seems filled with desperate nonentities struggling for 15 minutes of fame. Hoi polloi has been fascinated by celebrity since Moses dragged the tablets down from Mount Sinai. But the people chosen for attention in the past have done more than grab a tabloid headline.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: The Maltese Falcon | Fahrenheit 451 | 45 Minutes
fields.body:
Films

The Maltese Falcon
(John Huston, 1941)
5pm, TCM

Bogart snapped up the Sam Spade role after George Raft decided he didn't want to work with the then inexperienced Huston. The result is sublime film noir, with Spade, on the trail of his partner's killer and the eponymous antique, confronting one of the great screen villains: Sidney Greenstreet's Gutman.

Fahrenheit 451
(François Truffaut, 1966)
9pm, The Studio

It's the temperature at which paper burns, significant in a film set in a world where firemen are employed to destroy books. One such state employee, Oskar Werner, goes about his work with gusto until teacher Julie Christie suggests he try reading one (she also plays his wife, sleeping while he illicitly reads). Cerebral sci-fi, adapted from Ray Bradbury's novel.

Logan's Run
(Michael Anderson, 1976)
9pm, TCM

More sci-fi, this briskly paced tale set in a future where people live inside a beautiful bubble city, a millennium dome of the senses. The downside is that citizens get terminated at the age of 30. Security guard Michael York, 29, naturally decides to do a runner before his birthday, and equally naturally takes Jenny Agutter with him. Peter Ustinov plays an old boy on the outside.

Arlington Road
(Mark Pellington, 1999)
10pm, Sky Premier

Politics lecturer Jeff Bridges has his doubts about new neighbours Tim Robbins and Joan Cusack from the time he finds their son staggering wounded down the street. But Bridges is himself a loose cannon, grieving for his FBI-agent wife who was killed in a bungled raid, and preaching a radical agenda at college; so is he paranoid, or are the cheesy couple across the street really terrorists? Pellington keeps us guessing for quite a while, and although the climax is a tad obvious, this is a tense and intriguing thriller that takes a hard look at the turn-of-the-millennium US.

Shopping
(Paul Anderson, 1994)
10.30pm, FilmFour

Anderson's debut feature is a high-speed story of inner-city disaffection, as expressed through the thrill of ram-raiding. Jude Law, knocking 'em dead in Enemy At The Gates, is leader of the gang, newly released from jail and driving straight into a heap of trouble. Rival Sean Pertwee and local gangster Sean Bean are after him, world-weary cop Jonathan Pryce is watching closely and there are problems with the girlfriend (Sadie Frost). Not much analysis from the man who went on to make Mortal Kombat, but it roars along to a booming conclusion in the Retail Land shopping centre.

Sports

45 Minutes
8pm, BBC Choice

As many people have discovered to their cost in the past, it's very hard to make a consistently funny programme about football. The BBC must think they've cracked it, as 45 Minutes is well into its second series. Matt Elliott joins Joe Mace and Lisa Rogers in the studio today, with Shovel from M People, the show's roving reporter, in Germany to meet Steffen Effenberg, the Bayern Munich captain.

fields.headline: Water cure
fields.standfirst: Loch Flemington
fields.trailText: Loch Flemington.
fields.body:
The overnight snow last week would automatically have found me tracking badgers in the woodland above the house, finding out where various members of the clan had been to feed, and whether any early cubs had put in an appearance. Another visit would have been down the river a field away from the house to follow otter tracks, while keeping well away from the otter's holt under the half-exposed roots of the largest alder.

However, due to the foot-and-mouth situation, it was not to be. Instead we drove to Loch Flemington, east of Inverness, as the wildlife can be watched while parked on the road. When the window came down there was a sound that momentarily made me forget about straw ramps and disinfectant, as male frogs were calling from the shallow water only a few feet away.

The loch may be a local Mecca for bird watchers, but it is also rich in other fauna, including frogs, toads, palmate newts and great crested newts. The loch is also one of the few water bodies in the Highlands that have breeding coot and moorhen, which is surprising as they are both so common elsewhere in Britain.

There are other surprises: both little and Slavonian grebes nest there. On our visit we did not see the Slavonian grebes as they are still in their winter quarters on the sea, but the little grebes were there, and two were trilling away close to a sedge bed where no doubt they will build their floating nest. The commonest duck were the wigeon.

However, it was the three goosanders that stole the show; when a pair of wigeon went past it showed just how large these sawbills are. I just hope they are spared the gun, as in the past many have been shot under licence for allegedly harming fish stocks.
