fields.headline: Print the legend
fields.standfirst: In a country as extreme as America, it can be hard to tell myth from reality. Jonathan Jones is unsettled by a new exhibition
fields.trailText: In a country as extreme as America, it can be hard to tell myth from reality. Jonathan Jones is unsettled by a new exhibition.
fields.body:
Something happened to photography in art galleries in the late 1970s. Artists rejected the idea that the camera recorded reality, that its mission was to tell the truth, that the great photographer found an image in the tumult of life. The camera does lie, they said, all the time, and what we will do is expose that and explore the camera's power to create not factual records but fictional narratives of real life. So Cindy Sherman photographed herself as a Hitchcock heroine and Jeff Wall placed a vast, naked old woman towering over students in a quiet and efficient college library, in a mythic backlit vision of contemporary society. Artists became makers of static cinema.

This fabulist turn in photography has almost become a cliche. Yet Settings and Players, a museum-quality show of American work in the commercial gallery White Cube 2, makes it interesting once more.

The row over the photographs at the Saatchi Gallery by Tierney Gearon and Nan Goldin (who shows wonderful images here of drag stars' dressing rooms) demonstrated how compulsively we spin narratives out of photographs. The suspicions of the police and the News of the World can be seen as a narrative completion, as they imagined scenarios and possibilities - what happened next. The photograph is unresolved, a moment snatched from a story, a "still" as Sherman called her early pictures of herself in cinematic scenarios. The narrative can only be completed by you, the viewer, in your imagination. This means that the pictures in Settings andPlayers make us complicit in a special way: we engage in a collaboration of desire, as we flesh out the implications of the picture.

Philip-Lorca diCorcia's Tim, 27, Orange County, LA, $30, and Gerald Hughes (aka Savage Fantasy), About 25 Years Old, Southern California, $50, tell us in their titles that they are images of rent boys. The pictures are monumental scenarios in which something is about to happen: Tim nervously pausing before entering a room, his profile flooded with light, Gerald framed in the doorway - both of them on a threshold, making a choice, pondering a fate.

Larry Sultan's picture of a naked young man smoking on the sidewalk in the middle of the night takes us into a world of fabrication and obscurity. The mystery here lies in the relationship of the photographer to his subject. The photographer stands in the shadows, spying on the smoker. Is this a lover's view, or a killer's? Just as disconcerting is Sultan's image of young people having sex in the lounge of a family home. Or is it a porn film set? Richly kitsch-modern, with wood-style panelling, a raw stone column effect and a stippled beige sofa with a pile of cushions in which the boy's short-cropped head is visible next to the girl's leg, this room would be homely enough were it not brightly lit like a film set.

This is the true art of suburbia. It's the vacancy of the materials - a barbecue, a payphone in the night - that makes these pictures slip so easily into fantasy. Sultan's picture Early Evening, Los Angeles has an old man looking out of his home into the evening gloom, except the twilight is unnaturally held off by electric light, the garden theatrically lit up, the flowers taking on dazzling hues in the artificial illumination. You think of a culture that holds off darkness, that pushes away time synthetically; in LA, even nature gets a facelift.

This is a valid documentary picture of contemporary American life. Americans do light up their gardens and breed flowers with super-intense, synthetic hues. This is a fictive photograph, but it is also a realistic photograph of a culture in which fiction has replaced reality. Philip Roth has written of the despair of the novelist, whose job is to make up fictions that compete with the fantastic facts of American national life. American photographers didn't turn to fabulism for academic reasons, but because it was the only way to capture a country that constantly represents and mythifies itself. Richard Prince finds a solution in re-photographing images - found photos from adverts or magazines - to depict a colonised America whose contours were defined long before he got there.

The weakest things in the show simply look as if the maker has seen one too many David Lynch movies: Anna Gaskell's pictures are contrived, kinky exercises. But the best - and there are a lot of outstanding pictures here - find mournful, ready-made narratives in the American landscape. Gregory Crewdson's panoramic views of gardens, apparently photographed from the roof of the house, take in an entire social world. In his picture of a family sitting down to a meal in a garden surrounded by dense forest - a patch of civilisation in the wilderness - the teenage son stands and watches a pall of smoke coming out from under a shed roof.

The country in these pictures is so mythologised that it defies all the European photographic traditions. It comes prepackaged as a great novel. In William Eggleston's images of the South, people going about their lives seem compellingly part of some grand, terrible destiny. A student smoking, a toilet seen down a dark hallway lit in hellish red, a building photographed in half-shadow, seem full of devastating significance. Eggleston has said he thinks of his photographs as "parts of a novel I'm doing".

If Richard Prince is American photography's Bret Easton Ellis, Eggleston is its William Faulkner. His South is a ripe, charismatic place. With their startling colour and radical arrangement of space, his pictures have an atmosphere you can taste, a tension you can feel. In Sumner, Mississippi, Cassidy Bayou In Background, taken in 1969 or 1970, a black man in a white jacket stands behind a white man in a black suit, both men in the same pose, hands in pockets, watching something we can't see. A car stands waiting, its driver glimpsed through the windscreen. Behind them trail anonymous woods, leading to a stretch of silver water. We don't know who they are, or why the car has stopped here.

The powerful thing about a narrative image, whether it is a painting or a photograph, is its incompleteness. Eggleston's pictures are enigmatic fragments of some vast novel of class, race and power in America, and we probably don't want to know how it ends.

 Settings and Players: Theatrical Ambiguity in American Photography is at White Cube 2 , London N1 (020-7930 5373), until April 14.

fields.headline: Arthur Smith
fields.trailText: Although I speak no Italian, 25 years ago I spent an hour learning by heart the first lines of Dante's Inferno. I wanted to get the feel of the rhythm of the great work, and to find a way of impressing the trio of Italian au pairs I had fallen in love with.
fields.body:
Although I speak no Italian, 25 years ago I spent an hour learning by heart the first lines of Dante's Inferno. I wanted to get the feel of the rhythm of the great work, and to find a way of impressing the trio of Italian au pairs I had fallen in love with. My love of Dante continued: the first show I did at the Edinburgh festival was a revue called Swingalongadante, and subtitled, Dahlings, It's the Divine Comedy.

This intimate knowledge of the most famous work of Italian literature meant I was eager to view Botticelli's drawings of it at the Royal Academy. Dante's epic journey took him through the inferno and purgatory before arriving at paradise. The exhibition had a room for each and it was immediately noticeable that hell was packed with art-lovers while paradise was more or less empty. I saw a sign announcing soberly, "Purgatory is in the room opposite the main entrance." It was, naturally, half full.

Back in overcrowded hell most people were gathered round the second circle, reserved for the lustful. The most striking of Botticelli's eloquent illustrations was that of Dante and Virgil in their gaudy outfits in the Eighth Circle of Hell, where pimps and seducers were being beaten by large-breasted devils, or toiling in human excrement. Next to me, a man wearing an expensive gold watch was looking nervous. The sensational nature of these images, vividly drawn 500 years ago and dreamt up 200 years before that, makes one reconsider the debate about violence in the cinema.

And it made me remember my attempted seduction of the Italian au pairs. "Nel mezzo del cammin di nostra vita," I told them confidently, "mi ritrovai per una selva oscura che la diritta via era smarrita." One of them quoted a later line: "Lasciate ogne speranza, voi ch'intrate!" They laughed. Abandon hope all ye who enter here. Looking at Botticelli's lurid visions now, though, I reflected that I'd rather be a failed seducer than spend eternity in shit.

"Until the 70s, academic research consistently showed that men and women regarded supposedly male qualities of intelligence, leadership and cool detachment as superior to more emotional female traits. And no wonder, too, that plenty of red-blooded young women, who might have preferred a real man, are beginning to wonder whether this was really such a good idea."

webTitle: Arts: Portrait of a female orchestra conductor

fields.headline: In a class of her own
fields.standfirst: Charlotte Higgins meets Susanna Malkki, a conductor making it in a man's world
fields.trailText: Charlotte Higgins meets Susanna Malkki, a conductor making it in a man's world.
fields.body:
You wish it weren't true. But there it is: it's a shock to see a blonde, slight 31-year-old woman on the conductor's podium. Susanna Malkki is Finnish, a product of the same Helsinki conducting class, headed by the inspirational Jorma Panula, that has produced many of today's top conductors. Panula's unfussy, ungrand approach - "he says that the conductor is there to help, but not get in the way" - has worked for Malkki. Though she has not yet reached the giddy heights of fellow alumni Sakari Oramo, Esa-Pekka Salonen and Jukka-Pekka Saraste, a string of high-profile bookings from European and British orchestras mark her out as a name to watch.

Malkki started out on the other side of the podium, as an orchestral cellist. "I've learnt probably half of what I know as a conductor through being a player in orchestras, watching," she says. The only professional musician in a Helsinki family of gifted amateurs, she started the violin at five and switched to cello at nine, because it was "more me". By 1995, having studied at the Sibelius Academy in Helsinki and the Royal Academy of Music in London, she had a career lined up as a principal in Sweden's Gothenburg Symphony Orchestra.

"But I had always been interested in conducting," she says. "As an orchestral player I'd always analysed what worked and what didn't. Even after my cello studies the idea was still in my head. So I applied to the conducting course at the Sibelius Academy. But I didn't have any experience . . . It's difficult to say why they chose me. Maybe they saw I had something in my eye - even though my hands were not quite working."

Malkki then spent a hyperactive period as an orchestral cellist in Sweden and a student conductor in Finland. "It was interesting," she says with typical dryness. Eventually one part of her life had to give - and so, in the last year of her studies, she gave up the Gothenburg job, and stuck to conducting, the only woman in her class. It was the thrill of controlling the entire orchestra, as opposed to being a tiny cog in the wheel: "I am fascinated by being in charge of the whole picture, and putting all the pieces together. There are so many details to find and colours to produce." She is wary about trying to define what's so special about the Helsinki course, talking about a firm grounding in technique, a happy, non-competitive atmosphere, and the availability of an orchestra to practise on "rather than a couple of pianos".

In 1999, when she was working towards her final diploma, she got a break. She was conducting Thomas Adès's opera Powder Her Face at Helsinki's annual new music festival, Musica Nova. "Tom came to the performance and he was very pleased with it," she says. "Later that year he needed an assistant when he was doing the opera at the Almeida theatre in London and on tour. I ended up conducting some of the performances." This is a modest summation of the facts: there are those who say that she did a better job on Powder Her Face than the composer himself - her rendition was tight, disciplined, with not an inch of spare flesh on the bones of the music.

From here sprang Malkki's relationship with the Birmingham Contemporary Music Group, the ensemble she conducted for the opera performances. Adès is a fan; Simon Clugston, the group's artistic director, is clearly very impressed with her. "I think she's got a great career coming," he says. "She has a fantastic technique, the sort that allows her natural musicianship to come through. She's very strong and forthright. And conducting is one of the last bastions of male dominance."

Does Malkki accept that her career represents a pretty tough life choice? That orchestral musicians and audiences alike can be conservative - unwilling to accept a woman on the podium? "The history is like that, of course," says Malkki. "But I want to believe that a good musician recognises another good musician. I really believe that it should be about music. I'm happy that I live now, rather than 50 years ago. That's all I want to say about it. I think that if I forget about it then others may forget about it too."

Is she affected by the fact that she has no female role models (she says she admires many conductors, including Carlos Kleiber, Simon Rattle and Furtwängler? "No, it doesn't bother me," she says, "because I know why there aren't any. You can't divide this subject from the rest of history and society. The orchestra is a microcosm of society - very hierarchical; it would have been unthinkable for a woman to conduct orchestras when women could not even play in them. It's more important to look forward than to think in the mud, in the past.

"It is fantastic being young and doing everything for the first time, even though it's very tough and very hard work. It's like diving into new waters all the time." Lucky for us that if anyone will swim rather than sink, it is Malkki.

 Susanna Malkki conducts the Birmingham Contemporary Music Group on Sunday at the CBSO Centre, Birmingham. Box office: 0121-616 2616.

The only professional musician in a Helsinki family of gifted amateurs, she started the violin at five and switched to cello at nine, because it was "more me". By 1995, having studied at the Sibelius Academy in Helsinki and the Royal Academy of Music in London, she had a career lined up as a principal in Sweden's Gothenburg Symphony Orchestra. "But I had always been interested in conducting," she says. "As an orchestral player I'd always analysed what worked and what didn't. Even after my cello studies the idea was still in my head. So I applied to the conducting course at the Sibelius Academy. But I didn't have any experience . . . It's difficult to say why they chose me. Maybe they saw I had something in my eye - even though my hands were not quite working." Malkki then spent a hyperactive period as an orchestral cellist in Sweden and a student conductor in Finland. "It was interesting," she says with typical dryness. Eventually one part of her life had to give - and so, in the last year of her studies, she gave up the Gothenburg job, and stuck to conducting, the only woman in her class. It was the thrill of controlling the entire orchestra, as opposed to being a tiny cog in the wheel: "I am fascinated by being in charge of the whole picture, and putting all the pieces together. There are so many details to find and colours to produce." She is wary about trying to define what's so special about the Helsinki course, talking about a firm grounding in technique, a happy, non-competitive atmosphere, and the availability of an orchestra to practise on "rather than a couple of pianos". In 1999, when she was working towards her final diploma, she got a break. She was conducting Thomas Adès's opera Powder Her Face at Helsinki's annual new music festival, Musica Nova. "Tom came to the performance and he was very pleased with it," she says. "Later that year he needed an assistant when he was doing the opera at the Almeida theatre in London and on tour. I ended up conducting some of the performances." This is a modest summation of the facts: there are those who say that she did a better job on Powder Her Face than the composer himself - her rendition was tight, disciplined, with not an inch of spare flesh on the bones of the music. From here sprang Malkki's relationship with the Birmingham Contemporary Music Group, the ensemble she conducted for the opera performances. Adès is a fan; Simon Clugston, the group's artistic director, is clearly very impressed with her. "I think she's got a great career coming," he says. "She has a fantastic technique, the sort that allows her natural musicianship to come through. She's very strong and forthright. And conducting is one of the last bastions of male dominance." Does Malkki accept that her career represents a pretty tough life choice? That orchestral musicians and audiences alike can be conservative - unwilling to accept a woman on the podium? "The history is like that, of course," says Malkki. "But I want to believe that a good musician recognises another good musician. I really believe that it should be about music. I'm happy that I live now, rather than 50 years ago. That's all I want to say about it. I think that if I forget about it then others may forget about it too." Is she affected by the fact that she has no female role models (she says she admires many conductors, including Carlos Kleiber, Simon Rattle and Furtwängler? "No, it doesn't bother me," she says, "because I know why there aren't any. You can't divide this subject from the rest of history and society. The orchestra is a microcosm of society - very hierarchical; it would have been unthinkable for a woman to conduct orchestras when women could not even play in them. It's more important to look forward than to think in the mud, in the past. "It is fantastic being young and doing everything for the first time, even though it's very tough and very hard work. It's like diving into new waters all the time." Lucky for us that if anyone will swim rather than sink, it is Malkki.  Susanna Malkki conducts the Birmingham Contemporary Music Group on Sunday at the CBSO Centre, Birmingham. Box office: 0121-616 2616.

webTitle: G2: Jenny Colgan on Los Angeles

fields.headline: Gone west
fields.standfirst: A room with a pool at the beach - perfect for the scriptwriter of Invasion of the Alien Surf Nazis
fields.trailText: A room with a pool at the beach - perfect for Jenny Colgan, the scriptwriter of Invasion of the Alien Surf Nazis.
fields.body:
I have an apartment! I have an apartment! I have an official Los Angeles address! OK, it's not 90210, but it is within two digits. This is a massive relief, as there is approximately one square mile of the whole of LA where you can actually live without a car, so I was limited in my search.

It isn't the biggest place I've ever seen - it may not, perhaps, even be the biggest cupboard I've ever seen- but it is 20ft from the Pacific ocean, and it does have a pool (somewhat redundant, arguably, when you're 20ft from the Pacific ocean).

How expensive, you say? Well, la la la hum hum ... OK, well I'm here to write a screenplay, and in screenplay terms, this would have to be the kind of film where aliens invade America disguised as Nazis, riding on the back of sharks and genetically modified dinosaurs, only to be defeated in combat by the president, who is also disabled, but was once a fighter pilot, who then dies of a terminal illness, then it turns out he was dead all along. Yes, it's very, very expensive. But walkers can't be choosers, and also - hey! I don't care! - it has a dishwasher, it's sunny, and it's 10 minutes from Macy's. Please come visit me. Please. (Bring driving licence.)

My latest brilliant plan was this: everyone is in a car, so the roads are unbelievably dangerous, but nobody is on the pavements because everybody is in their cars so, hey presto, they could become my personal bicycle paths!

Good idea, huh? I went down to chat to the wee bike man on the beach.

"How much would it cost to hire a bike for six weeks?" He did some rough work on a piece of paper.

"Ah, $130 (£91)."

"Huh. How much would it cost to actually buy one of the bicycles?"

"$100 (£70)."

I looked at him, and he stared back intently, as if daring me to point out the obvious. I screwed up my eyes. "If I bought one, could I sell it back to you in a couple of months' time?"

For the first time, he smiled. "Are you sure you just don't want us to give you some money?"

In the end I bought a shiny new purple one from Sears for the dollar equivalent of £50, less than dinner for two in London - (an apt comparison, as I have no one to go to dinner with yet, and won't, either, unless I manage to shift my butt from the sun loungers). I abandoned the pavement idea pretty quickly because no one walks on them - no one fixes the holes in them either - but am steeling myself to one day make a left turn into the traffic. Also, traffic lights are on the far sides of junctions, and the lines are invisible in the sun, causing me to make several dramatic reverse screeching-wheelie stops. Excellent!

My problems remain, however, with scale. I had thought London was big. On a visit to meet up with a friend of a friend of a friend's flatmate, I checked my map and decided to take a nice easy meander down the coastline to Hermosa Beach, a mere two beaches away.

Thirty five miles and one very sore bottom later, I realised I was going to have to rethink this independent cyclist plan. I should have realised there was something going on when I had to make a detour of LAX. The power station should have given me a little clue too. However, it means I have one lifelong experience under my belt - yes, I have cycled Route 66.

Currently, I am reading Redmond O'Hanlon's book about exploring the Congo, which is perfect for travelling - it makes me intensely glad I inherited the gene that made me want to come to sunny LA and sit by the pool eating toasted cheese sandwiches, rather than force my way up a crocodile and snake-infested river in a war zone, eating monkey stew and tending my supperating ulcers. Phew!

And my next big exciting thing - ta dah - is that I've been invited to a dinner party by a hot shot Hollywood producer. A real producer dude, who makes real films you would have heard of and everything.

Yikes. It almost makes up for missing Vanessa Feltz crying for three hours on live TV, or whatever the hell has been going on back home. But what do you wear to dinner with a producer? A ballgown? A swimsuit? Nothing at all? God, I wish I hadn't read that bloody Don Simpson memoir...

 Jenny Colgan is seeking fame and fortune in Los Angeles. She will be reporting fortnightly on her progress.

webTitle: When parents move in with grandparents

fields.headline: Hi, mummy - I'm home!
fields.standfirst: You thought your kids had left the nest for good. But then marriage, children and financial straits forced them to move back.  Sophie Radice on what life is really like with three generations under one roof
fields.trailText: You thought your kids had left the nest for good. But then marriage, children and financial straits forced them to move back. Sophie Radice on what life is really like with three generations under one roof.
fields.body:
When most of us leave home in our late teens, it is a case of never looking back. You are on your own in the big, bad world of trying to find somewhere to live. Later, when you settle down and start to think about having a family of your own, there is a general expectation that you will have moved further up the property ladder and have found yourself a suitable-sized home.

What if that has not happened? With rising house prices and a dearth of council property or affordable rented accommodation, it seems that some of us are looking at the once unthinkable prospect of moving back in with the parents - at least until we, the young parents or parent, find our financial feet.

So what is it like to live in an intergenerational household? My friend Jenny would know because she has been doing it for six years in Seville, Spain, where such arrangements are commonplace. She and her husband Carlos share a large apartment with her mother- and father-in-law and have two children aged six and four.

When she visits her friends and relatives in London, she has little that is positive to say about her domestic situation. There is no privacy. There is constant interference with the way she brings up her children. And she has to eat with the in-laws three or four nights a week.

"My mother-in-law completely dominates in the kitchen," she relates, "and, of course, any notions I might have about healthy eating and what my children might need to eat are dismissed out of hand."

Her husband does not see the problem; for him it is simply part of the accepted Latin way of life. "All that babysitting," he points out. "Which comes at such a price," she sighs.

It is not just the "Latin way", however. In this country before the 1960s, when council rental was rare and mortgages hard to come by, intergenerational living was expected, endured and even enjoyed until the married offspring could afford to rent or buy their own place. Such family arrangements were a rich source of comic tension in the radio sitcom The Glums and the strip cartoons of Giles in the Daily Express, but Sheila Foreman, now 62, who lived with her parents-in-law in Manchester with her first child, finds it hard to remember much light relief in her and her husband's situation as a young married couple with a baby.

"I can honestly say that it was the worst time of my life," she recalls. "There I was, wanting to start a new life away from my parents, and I found myself stuck with a new set of parents with new sets of rules.

"If it was difficult for me, it was even worse for my husband who just carried on having the same old rows and irritations - only now he had me on his back making things even worse between him and his mother. What was really awful was that we should have been grateful to them because they were letting us stay in their house practically rent-free."

Oddly enough, though, her own experience has not put her off intergenerational living. Sheila's son, daughter-in-law and four-year-old grandson have lived in her and her husband's house in north London for the last two years.

"Property prices being what they are in Britain's big cities," she explains, "they really couldn't afford anything in an area with decent schools and parks. Peter, my husband, and I discussed it at length and decided that we couldn't stand by while we seemed to be kicking around this house and they were crammed in somewhere too small. We weren't quite ready to sell the house to release capital for them either. So we decided to invite them to live here."

The Foremans wisely put a small bathroom and kitchen in the lower half of the house, "so that, even if they decide they can't stand it any more, we will be able to close it off and rent it out". It seems like an obviously beneficial arrangement for the younger couple who make a contribution to all bills and pay a minimal rent, but what is in it for the senior couple?

"Well, it helps that we are dotty about our grandson, Toby," says Sheila. "We each look after him one day a week and I really think that it helps keep us young and forward-looking. All of us are pretty laid-back and I think that is the real difference between my situation as a young parent and my son's."

The Foremans' domestic arrangement has a definite logic, but how well does it work for Sheila's son, David, 33, and his wife, Gemma, 32?

"When I talk to my friends," says Gemma, "I realise that it is really unusual to get on so well with your parents-in-law. The situation really takes the pressure off our marriage too, because we are able to go out and be alone together at least once a week. I know it might sound like we are really spoiled and getting everything out of it, but we try and help them as much as we can with shopping and cooking. There is also an unwritten agreement that this kind of help will increase as they get older."

The relationship is so close that David and Gemma even go on holiday with his parents. But for most of us the idea of living with our parents, parents-in-law or children and children-in-law (let alone their children into the bargain) would be like being sentenced to an eternal Christmas of forced jollity, domestic tension and scary psychodramas. Phillipa Buchan, 38, and her partner might agree that this more closely describes their experience of moving in with her mother when Phillipa was pregnant.

"My mum and I thought it would be a great solution, and so I persuaded Richard - against his better judgment," admits Phillipa. "Mum gets rather lonely at times and I thought that it would be lovely to have her to help with a new-born baby. Mum had a large spare room; our council flat was awful. We were full of optimism and thought that we were being really inventive in creating a new solution to family living."

Phillipa gave up her flat, redecorated what used to be her old room and the small room nearby for the baby. But her mother, who had been so keen for her daughter and partner to move in, seemed to get cold feet. She started creating obstacles and conditions.

"The reality of us being there seemed to make mum very uncomfortable," Phillipa recalls. "Actually, I don't think she was lonely at all, but had created a very nice quiet life for herself which, quite understandably, she wasn't willing to give up. I think she thought of herself as suited to co-operative living - but as soon as she saw me claiming my room back it filled her with dread. We fought all the time, and we soon all realised that it wasn't going to work - particularly with a baby around.

"Luckily, a friend offered us her flat to rent and I jumped at the chance. Mum is an excellent gran and sees my daughter at least once a week. There are no hard feelings about the whole dreadful idea. I just don't know what we were thinking of."

David Little, family therapist and GP, agrees that this kind of intergenerational living would not suit all families: "For many of us, it would just be too difficult not to fall back into old patterns of either childish or parental behaviour. And what if your child-rearing ideas differ from your parents or parents-in-law? How do you make sure that the grandparents feel that they are not being taken advantage of? How do you ensure that the younger couple do not feel that their life is not being interfered with or taken over by people of a different generation? There might also be a problem with the non-blood relation feeling left out and dominated by the rest of the family ... There are so many potential minefields."

Of all of Dr Little's list of possible problems, the one which most intergenerational households seem to agree is the most sensitive is the question of different attitudes towards child-rearing. Even the easy-going Foremans disagreed sharply over breastfeeding. Gemma breast-fed Toby for two years, which Sheila found excessive. "Sheila didn't breast-feed herself," says Gemma, "and so couldn't help regarding me as a cave-woman even in the early months. As I went on and on with it, I think she found it quite obscene and would try to introduce Toby to bottles of formula milk and dummies when she was looking after him."

So, if you are a parent or grandparent who is toying with the idea of this kind of arrangement, what would Dr Little advise before making a decision? "Careful thought, a good deal of discussion about exactly how the financial and domestic divisions will work, thinking ahead as to what it might mean in 10 years' time - and, most importantly, a very, very big house."

webTitle: G2: Alice Thomas Ellis on grandmothers

fields.headline: Don't make me cuddle you
fields.standfirst: Why do grannies only come in two handy flavours - sweet old lady or harridan?  Alice Thomas Ellis refuses to be a stereotype
fields.trailText: Why do grannies only come in two handy flavours - sweet old lady or harridan? Alice Thomas Ellis refuses to be a stereotype.
fields.body:
One of my dearest friends once remarked, with quiet but intense conviction, that she had not one grain of cuddly granny in her. She died before she got the chance to test the truth of her assertion but I think she was right. The word "cuddly" could not be applied to her: beautiful, brilliant, witty ... all manner of adjectives, but not cuddly.

The very word implies that the older woman had put on weight, probably through sheer inertia, having nothing more to do than sink down in the inglenook and act as a receptacle for babies when their mothers are busy doing something productive. My friend was as lean as a whippet and busier than her children. She would doubtless have dearly loved her grandchildren, but she would not have had much time for cuddling. Besides, the babies' mother would have objected to her dropping cigarette ash on them.

I associate two images with the word grandmother: one is the sweet-faced lady with white hair and the other is of the autocratic harridan with the ivory-knobbed cane. Both occur in old-fashioned fiction, but I have never met anyone resembling either. My fellow grandmothers appear to me only as mothers with added worries and are usually addressed by their Christian names or some infantile mispronunciation.

I never really had a grandmother myself since one died when my mother was only 13 and the other soon after I was born. This last, my paternal grandmother, appears in photographs as a fearsome old party with that unyielding Victorian embonpoint, an insincere smile and pince-nez. Not cuddly at all. Thus I have no real idea of how a grandmother was wont to comport herself, though her role has clearly altered over the years.

At one time, so we are told, if she did not live within the bosom of the family, she lived next door or, at the most, a few streets away and was always available with a store of accumulated folk wisdom to offer counsel and advice, or to step in and take over the running of the house and care of the children if mother was indisposed. In literature, she was seldom resented (unless she was perceived in the role of mother-in-law), but held in close regard.

Things are different now that families are often dispersed over continents and have to go to and fro on aeroplanes in order to re-unite, though if, as frequently happens, the mother is still at school and living in the same house, then grandmother obviously has a useful part to play. But people who can afford it would rather send their children to nursery school than entrust them to grandmama, who might anyway be otherwise engaged, running her own accountancy or design firm.

Besides, it is now customary for everyone to have his or her theory about child-rearing and the always somewhat doubtful notion that age is invariably accompanied by wisdom is out of style. fields.headline: It's my baby too
fields.standfirst: This week a man went to court to stop his partner's abortion. So how do men really feel about termination?  Dave Hill reports
fields.trailText: This week a man went to court to stop his partner's abortion. So how do men really feel about termination? Dave Hill reports.
fields.body:
Stop me if you have heard this one before. A woman and a man are having a sexual relationship. One day the woman finds out that she is pregnant. Neither is overjoyed. But their feelings differ sharply over what should happen next. She considers an abortion but decides against it.

He, though, favours termination. He may feel angry, even that he has been tricked; if he is a father already he may feel he has enough children; if young, free and single he may not relish commitment. But he goes along with the woman's wishes. That is not simply because, as a man, the decision to abort is not his to take. It is also because he regards pregnancy as primarily women's business.

Nor is this a straightforward case of shirking of responsibility. In his mind, it is her baby far more than it is his. In the end he believes it really is her right to choose.

This is a crude typification but not without a ring of truth. Do we know - or care - enough about how men feel about abortion? To what extent do - and should - their wishes influence their partners? And is there a case for giving men more legal rights over abortion decisions than they currently possess?

In a highly publicised court case, Stephen Hone, 24, from Coventry, applied to the high court for an injunction preventing his girlfriend Claire Hansell from having an abortion, due to take place yesterday. She is 12 weeks' pregnant and it may be several days before her side of the case is put before the judges. Hone's legal case, brought after he contacted the Pro-Life Alliance, is that Hansell has been examined by only one doctor instead of the two required by the 1967 Abortion Act and that no questions were asked about her physical and mental state or why she wanted a termination.

Hone's moral case is that Hansell had wanted to have a child but changed her mind after she became pregnant, without consulting him. Whatever the substance of that claim, it illustrates the sentiments sometimes harboured by men about exclusion from decisions about abortion.

Ann Furedi of the British Pregnancy Advisory Service says that even in loving relationships "men might be more inclined to think of abortion as the solution to an unwanted pregnancy than women, whereas women might be more ambivalent".

Lisa Hallgarten, who is education development officer for Education for Choice, a charity which provides resources on abortion for teachers and young people, confirms the picture: "You find that, in general, young men are much less resistant to the idea of abortion than young women. Most say they would want their girlfriends to have an abortion if the situation arose."

Yet if men, on the whole, are more willing to consider abortion, they still tend to put women's preferences first. That is true even when they would rather the pregnancy continue but the woman would not. According to Bella Scott, a BPAS counsellor: "Usually the woman's feelings have taken precedence. And whatever that decision is, the men are usually extremely supportive and caring towards their partners."

Things have changed since the 70s. Furedi says: "While men are now encouraged to share responsibility for contraception and childcare, which used to be seen very much in terms of women's rights, where abortion is concerned the view often persists that men should be shut out."

The BPAS is keen to encourage men's involvement, although little research has been done into how this might be achieved. However, Dr Ellie Lee, a lecturer in sociology at Southampton University, learned more about how men think from her studies on women's decisions on abortion. "There has been a massive change in the way men want to be involved in all areas of fertility and that shows very clearly in what women say."

Lee found that women put their partners' views centre stage: "When I asked women why they had requested an abortion, they all talked about their relationships and how their partners had reacted. What partners think is key to the decisions women make. There is no reason to believe it is less of a big deal for men. It is clear that they feel at an emotional level the same way women do, and like to be involved in the process."

This was true of Richard Lawrenson, a designer in his mid-30s. Ten years ago, he and his girlfriend of the time found out she was pregnant. Although together for a year, it was, he says, "by no means clear that we would stay together for the rest of our lives". They hadn't planned a child. Yet Richard recalls many conflicting feelings: "Like most men, I just hadn't thought about it. Suddenly, all sorts of scenarios race through your mind. I couldn't help thinking about what names we might choose, or what it would be like to go to a football match with a little boy who looked just like me. I veered between feeling great compassion towards my partner, and being incredibly selfish."

But he always knew, deep down, what his position was. "I wanted to be involved in the process of reaching a decision, but I also recognised that, in the end, the decision should ultimately be hers."

This seems an ideal guiding principle. Men's feelings matter, but to contemplate giving them legal powers to force women to either have abortions or not is appalling and absurd. As Lee says: "The appeal to men's rights is that a pregnant woman should be obliged to do something with her body that no one else is obliged to do. For a third party to be able to compel a woman to save a foetus goes way beyond existing principles of medical law. Clearly men can be hurt if a woman's decision on abortion isn't the one they want, but I think that should be seen as part and parcel of what goes with a relationship. Conflicts always occur, and it is always far better to resolve them through consenus."

So how did things work out for Lawrenson's relationship after the termination? "There was a period when things did feel a bit awkward, but it wasn't what spoiled things in the end. In fact, having the abortion allowed it to run its course, and carry on at the pace we wanted. It ended later, but for other reasons."

However, ultimately, the question of rights is indivisible. In Furedi's words: "If it comes to the crunch, the decision has to be between a woman and her doctor. No one else."

webTitle: Pass notes on the Queen of Denmark

fields.headline: No 1844
fields.standfirst: Margrethe, Queen of Denmark
fields.trailText: Margrethe, Queen of Denmark
fields.body:
Dramatis personae: Margrethe, Queen of Denmark; Prince Henrik, husband of the Queen; Hugo Kesteloot, a professor; assorted gravediggers.

I hope this isn't going to be one of those impenetrable Pass notes in which function is sacrificed to form. Shut up spoilsport. The play's the thing.

I take it something is rotten in the state of Denmark. Got it in one buster, but leave the quotes to me.

What's the prob? Thou know'st 'tis common; all that live must die, passing through nature to eternity.

I'd twigged that. But surely the much-admired Queen Margrethe can't be blamed: O most pernicious woman! O villain, villain, smiling, damnèd villain!

My God, you mean to say she's bumped her husband off? Worse, she stands accused of bumping off large numbers of the Danish population by encouraging them to smoke.

Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead? Almost certainly, but more worryingly female mortality is much higher in Denmark than the EU average.

Drowning? No, cancer and heart disease. In the latest issue of the Lancet, Belgian professor Hugo Kesteloot blames the high level of smoking among Danish women and the malign influence of the 60-year-old Queen, who has ruled since 1972.

She smokes? Like a chimney. She was dubbed the "Ashtray Queen" when she smoked during a visit to asthmatics in an old people's home.

What's the solution? Get her to a nunnery, pronto.

What does Claudius, sorry Prince Henrik, say? "Let people die from smoking if they want. It's their business."

How has the Queen reacted? She dismissed the article as "sensationalist" at a press conference in which she smoked two cigarettes.

Clearly not a Queen of shreds and nicotine patches. OK, you win. The rest - apart from the sound of a nation coughing - is silence.

fields.headline: Stagecoach wins trains fight
fields.standfirst:
FirstGroup fails to win commuter line

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Brian Souter's bus and train company, Stagecoach, is to be awarded a new 20-year franchise to continue operating its South West Trains franchise from London Waterloo after a bitterly contested fight with FirstGroup.
fields.body:
Brian Souter's bus and train company, Stagecoach, is to be awarded a new 20-year franchise to continue operating its South West Trains franchise from London Waterloo after a bitterly contested fight with FirstGroup.

After some misgivings, Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the strategic rail authority, has recommended Stagecoach's name to the government for the £3.5bn key commuter line. A formal announcement is expected before the announcemement of the election.

The SRA, publicly embarrassed by its indecision over a new franchise for the East Coast mainline, has been under pressure from ministers to announce some good rail news before the election.

SWT has been running the franchise for the past four years with mixed results. Early on, it almost brought the service to a standstill when it sacked 76 drivers.

It operates 1,700 trains each day from Waterloo in central London, and has considerably more experience in running commuter services than its rivals for the franchise, Great North Eastern Railway, and Great Western Trains, both long distance operators.

The awarding of the franchise has been a political hot potato for the government. FirstGroup managed to get some support but faced considerable local hostility in the south west, where its services are still suffering from Railtrack's failure to repair the track. The company has also been providing bus services between Bristol, Exeter and Plymouth for several months infuriating passengers.

SWT has impressed the SRA by its straightforward bidding process. It has promised to start replenishing its fleet with 1,200 new coaches from August next year. National Express, another big train and bus group, yesterday threatened to take legal action against Railtrack to win compensation for six months of disruption since the Hatfield crash.

Phil White, NE's chief executive, said that Railtrack's tem porary speed restrictions had taken £2 m off NE's reported £34m operating profits on its trains last year.

He said that a 10% gain in passenger revenues in the first nine months of 2000 had turned into a 14% deficit in the last quarter. Passenger numbers are down 3% in the first 10 weeks of the year.

Mr White said: "We are driving Railtrack hard on this. We believe they have taken their eye off the core business of running the track and signalling for its customers."

He said that negotiations were continuing with Railtrack on a daily basis. He admitted that the company's rail problems had been compounded by the poor state of new rolling stock delivered by Adtranz and Alstom.

The company reported a 35% growth in revenue across the business in Britain, the US and Australia. Headline profits rose 11% but pretax profits after goodwill write-offs and exceptional items were £65m, down from £89m.

NE's new dividend is being increased by 14% to 20.7p.

webTitle: EC safety moves over silicone breast implants

fields.headline: EC safety moves over silicone breast implants
fields.trailText: Health guidelines on the use of silicone breast implants are to be issued by the European commission, but national health services will still have to decide their own policies, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Health guidelines on the use of silicone breast implants are to be issued by the European commission, but national health services will still have to decide their own policies, it was announced yesterday.

Officials in Brussels said recommendations would be published within a month to ensure that women seeking the controversial implants are given counselling on the risks of the procedure .

Erkki Liikanen, the EU enterprise commissioner, said there were no grounds to ban the use of silicone implants - although they have been outlawed in the US.

But Mr Liikanen, who oversees the commission's medical devices directive, promised MEPs he would look at whether Brussels had the power to order an age limit for the operation and the creation of national registers.

"He didn't say no to anything," said a delighted Bill Miller, the Scottish Labour MEP who has led a six-year campaign on the issue. "He gave a clear signal to manufacturers and clinic owners and surgeons that he is going to demand greater clarity on the products and their safety. It's a big step towards a complete ban and to legal action against manufacturers."

Thousands of British women have breast implants each year, some to increase the size of their breasts and others for reconstruction after cancer surgery. Implants are made from materials including silicone and soya bean oil.

Concerns have been raised about the silicone variety although studies to determine whether they are linked to cancer and auto-immune diseases have been inconclusive.

The EU already has legislation on the safety of medical devices, including breast implants. So far there is no sign that the commission will follow the example of the US, where the food and drug administration banned silicone gel implants for most women in 1992 because of safety concerns and lawsuits.

"This is a watershed in our campaign," Mr Miller said. "Europe has recognised that there is a problem with silicone implants and is going to do something about it.

"This is a victory for the hundreds of women though out the UK and Europe who have worked tirelessly to make sure other women do not repeat their painful experience of implant surgery."

fields.headline: No dot on the landscape
fields.standfirst:
Getmapping goes back to drawing board

More net news
fields.trailText: An internet company backed by the Queen is to drop the dot.com suffix to its name, following poor sales through its website.
fields.body:
An internet company backed by the Queen is to drop the dot.com suffix to its name, following poor sales through its website.

Aerial photography specialist Getmapping.com will be known simply as Getmapping and emphasise the strengths of its old-economy business, said chief executive Tristram Cary.

"I cannot deny that sentiment is against dot.coms at the moment and we hope that this move will underline the fact that we're not just an internet company," he said.

Getmapping.com floated on Aim last April when investors were still chasing internet shares. The company - whose shot of Edinburgh castle, at the top end of the Royal Mile, is pictured left - grabbed the headlines when it emerged that the Queen was a shareholder through the Privy Purse. The price of Getmapping's shares has dropped drastically, meaning that the royal stake has fallen in value from £900,000 to around £70,000.

Results for the year ending December 2000 released yesterday show a turnover of £1.4m and a pretax loss of £2m.

fields.trailText: Accenture, the new economy business service formerly known as Andersen Consulting, posted record UK revenues yesterday and expressed confidence despite declining hi-tech stock prices.
fields.body:
Accenture, the new economy business service formerly known as Andersen Consulting, posted record UK revenues yesterday and expressed confidence despite declining hi-tech stock prices.

Ian Watmore, UK managing partner of the global business, said that the bursting of the dot.com bubble had actually benefited the partnership by enabling it to continue recruiting staff in a tight labour market and to focus on solid companies with revenues which exceeded costs.

"We still see growing demand for our services across the board," he said. "We are watching stock markets like everybody else, and see gloom on the other side of the Atlantic, but to date that hasn't translated into falling demand for our underlying services."

Accenture's revenues in the UK last year were $1.13bn (£787m), an increase of 19% over 1999. On a global basis, the Asia Pacific region accounted for the largest percentage gain in overall rev enues of $10.3bn, with growth of more than 20%.

Mr Watmore said that after a first-quarter lull, following the millennium computer bug scare, the firm enjoyed strong growth in business related to the digital economy last year.

This included IT outsourcing deals from blue-chip companies such as Sainsbury, which demonstrated the breadth of Accenture's exposure to the hi-tech economy, and the signing of alliances with Microsoft and BT.

"We always try to do business across a diverse range of businesses, including the more recession-proof industries as well as the more rollercoaster industries," he said.

"[Hi-tech] stock prices have obviously fallen massively yet there are still many respectable business out there like Nokia - demand for handsets is still massively up, just not as massively up as they were. These companies are still growing and need information support services."

Accenture started a rebranding exercise at the beginning of this year including TV and newspaper advertising and sports sponsorship to ingrain the company's new name, adopted after the high-profile divorce from Arthur Andersen, in the public mind.

It is now seeking to reinvent itself as the "market-maker, architect and builder of the new economy".

With more than 7,000 people in 46 countries, the firm says it is building a network of businesses to meet the full range of client needs, including consulting, technology, outsourcing alliances and venture capital.

A partial public flotation of the firm is being considered.

Globally, the firm has five units. The products unit, which includes the company's retailing and manufacturing clients, registered the strongest growth rate in 2000, increasing its revenues by 21% to $2.1bn, followed by communications and hi-tech, which grew by 18% to $3bn. Revenues for the financial services and government units increased by 3% each, to $2.7bn and $811m. The resources unit remained unchanged at $1.7bn.

webTitle: Fear and suspicion seep into the capital

fields.headline: Fear and suspicion seep into the capital
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: A Macedonian policeman was shot in the back and killed and a colleague was seriously wounded yesterday as they patrolled an area of Skopje largely inhabited by members of the ethnic Albanian community. Police said later they had arrested three Albanians in connection with the attack.
fields.body:
A Macedonian policeman was shot in the back and killed and a colleague was seriously wounded yesterday as they patrolled an area of Skopje largely inhabited by members of the ethnic Albanian community. Police said later they had arrested three Albanians in connection with the attack.

There was no immediate confirmation that the murder was motivated by ethnic politics, but it raised fears that relations between groups in the capital, where one-fifth of the population is Albanian, could be breaking down.

Since fighting broke out in recent days between state forces and Albanian insurgents in northern Macedonia, tensions in Skopje have risen. "People are retreating into their communities and if you have friends from the other side, they look at you in a different way now," an Albanian journalist said.

More and more Albanians were expressing support for the gunmen in the mountains, he added.

Young Albanians due to be called up by Macedonia's largely conscript army were also starting to hide, fearing they might have to shoot at their own people.

Although outwardly the streets of Skopje seem calm, with pavement cafes full, there is a feeling that the next few days could be decisive.

The joint declaration against violence which leaders of the country's two main Albanian political parties signed on Tuesday in the presence of Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy chief, has not eased the tension.

Many Albanian Macedonians feel the two parties have been sidelined as the government presses ahead with its offensive against the gunmen who still oc cupy a number of villages above the northern town of Tetovo.

The government has wide support among the Macedonian majority of Slav descent for its strategy. Even journalists on Dnevnik, which is considered the most moderate and least nationalist of the Macedonian-language newspapers, refer to the gunmen as "terrorists".

A senior Dnevnik editor expressed concern that Mr Solana might be trying to broker a dialogue with the gunmen, even though the Macedonian government has insisted it rejects it.

"We must get our flag up on the citadel above Tetovo, and the army has to put it there," the editor said.

Thousands of Albanians have been fleeing the Tetovo region and other parts of Macedonia. Since last week bout 5,700 Macedonians have crossed into Turkey, a favoured destination where many have relatives, the Anatolia news agency reported yesterday.

The refugees, mostly ethnic Turks and Albanians, were travelling in buses, most of them via Bulgaria, and had passports. Turkey does not require visas for Macedonians.

Thousands are also fleeing Macedonia westwards into Albania proper, from where many of them travel to Kosovo.

Prefabricated houses near the Bulgarian border, used to house Kosovan refugees in 1999 and Turks fleeing communist Bulgaria in 1989, were being prepared for those who did not have a place to stay, officials said.

Aid agencies have said that several thousand members of Macedonia's majority have also fled to Albania, Bulgaria and Kosovo to escape the turmoil in their country.

During the 1999 Kosovo conflict, Turkey took some 20,000 Kosovan refugees.

fields.trailText: Pretoria takes back farm order
fields.body:
Pretoria takes back farm order

The order to expropriate land from the white South African farmer Willem Pretorius has been withdrawn to "promote negotiated settlements as far as possible". The farmer has asked the courts to compel Pretoria to withdraw it permanently. AP, Lydenburg

Ukraine corpse 'not journalist'

German DNA tests have shown that a mutilated body found in Ukraine in November is not that of the missing journalist Georgy Gongadze. AFP, Munich

Billions to face water shortage

Water shortages may affect about 3bn people in 48 countries in less than 25 years from now, an international desalination conference in Singapore heard yesterday. AP, Singapore

Opposition leaders held

Pakistan's military government arrested more than 20 opposition leaders yesterday, capping a two-day crackdown in which 1,600 activists were rounded up. AP, Lahore

webTitle: Britain and US help drive against Albanians

fields.headline: Britain and US help drive against Albanians
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Nato members stepped up their support for Macedonia in its battle with ethnic Albanian guerrillas yesterday, providing military assistance and taking tougher measures on the Kosovan side of its border.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor and Martin Kettle in Washington
fields.body:
Nato members stepped up their support for Macedonia in its battle with ethnic Albanian guerrillas yesterday, providing military assistance and taking tougher measures on the Kosovan side of its border.

In another attempt to apply pressure on the Albanian extremists, the UN war crimes prosecutor for former Yugoslavia, Carla del Ponte, disclosed that she was investigating allegations against Albanian armed groups in Kosovo and the self-styled Liberation Army of Presevo, Medvedja and Bujanovac (UCPMB), which wants to take control of a part of southern Serbia.

It is the first time the court has acted against Albanians suspected of perpetrating violent incidents since Nato forces entered Kosovo in June 1999. Mrs Del Ponte announced her decision after talks with Yugoslav and Serbian justice ministers.

The US and Britain said they were supplying the hard-pressed Macedonian forces with advice and intelligence. Unmanned American and German reconnaissance aircraft will soon be joined by similar French drones.

Macedonian officials said that information from the drones and other sources was helping the country prepare an offensive to force the rebels out of half a dozen villages in northern Macedonia where they receive food and other support from fellow ethnic Albanians

But further signs of a deepening difference of approach in the US and Europen responses to the insurgency in northern Macedonia emerged last night: the Pentagon said it would not send more troops, while Britain's defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, said Britain would consider any Macedonian request for military support.

The difference was evident at a Pentagon press conference given by Mr Hoon and the US defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, which underscored the more cautious approach to the Balkans being adopted by George Bush's administration.

"We have no plans to send troops to Macedonia," Mr Rumsfeld told reporters. "The answer to your question is no."

Five thousand US troops are based in eastern Kosovo, some of whom have now been deployed along the border with Macedonia. But observers say their previous reluctance to stop armed Albanian extremists infiltrating Macedonia has contributed to the trouble.

Mr Hoon said the question of military aid to Macedonia was "not on the agenda for the moment"; Nato's key task was to ensure more vigorous patrolling on the Kosovan side of the border to prevent Albanian extremists crossing into Macedonia.

"But clearly, were Macedonia to make a direct request for assistance, then we would be willing to consider that," Mr Hoon added. Britain has already sent 10 military advisers to Macedonia.

Further differences emerged when the two defence ministers were asked whether Macedonia should be regarded as "a vital security interest" for the US. Mr Rumsfeld, who is a leading sceptic about US commitments in the Balkans, said: "Those are decisions that are made by the president of the United States, not me."

Mr Hoon, on the other hand, praised Macedonia as "arguably the most successful" of the former Yugoslav states, and said Britain would not like to see it become "another tinderbox".

Lord Robertson, Nato's secretary general, said yesterday that the North Atlantic Council - the alliance's policy making body - had endorsed the need to reinforce the 42,000 peacekeeping troops of K-For in Kosovo, whom he described as "extremely stretched".

Yesterday Spain agreed to send about 130 more soldiers, but no other country has responded to the request for reinforcements made 11 days ago by K-For commanders, Nato sources said.

It was reported yesterday that German K-For peacekeepers were involved in a gun battle on the Kosovo-Macedonia border, the troops opening fire after trying to question a group of gunrunners. There were no reports of casualties.

The German troops seized a consignment of weapons but the smugglers fled in the darkness, a defence ministry spokesman said. Two mules were killed in the crossfire.

In a separate incident on Tuesday night, K-For troops stopped men and mules carrying weapons near the border, a US military spokeswoman said.

The troops seized two AK-47 rifles, three machine guns, three bolt-action rifles, a sniper rifle, four anti-personnel mines, a rocket-propelled grenade, 12 mortar bombs, and a quantity of ammunition.

"Ultimately," Lord Robertson said in a statement, "the solution to problems in the area can only be found through political means."

The Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, said yesterday that the west's tolerance of ethnic Albanian rebels had helped encourage the conflict in Macedonia.

"Passive reaction by the west to the spread of the Kosovo conflict to the Albanian-populated regions [of Macedonia] ... only helps the separatists go unpunished and be more radical in their actions," Mr Ivanov said in the Macedonian capital, Skopje.

Tomorrow he goes on to meet EU foreign ministers at their Stockholm summit.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: MPs move on Chinook case
fields.body:
MPs move on Chinook case

The Commons public accounts committee is to seek the help of the Lords committee set up to review the case of RAF Chinook helicopter crash on the Mull of Kintyre in June 1994 to have the official verdict set aside. Two air marshals overruled a board of inquiry and fatal accident investigation, blaming the pilots for the crash in which 29 people died.

Fans on racist chants charge

Five men from Greater Manchester appeared before Bradford magistrates yesterday charged with racist chanting during Bradford City's match with Manchester City on Saturday. The cases were adjourned until April 18.

BA computer working again

Computer problems that led to delays and cancellations over the past week for BA flights has been sorted out, the airline said yesterday.

Ulster murder case arrest

Police investigating the murders of David McIlwaine, 18, and Andrew Robb, 19, from Portadown yesterday arrested a 36-year-old man from Ballymoney, Co Antrim./B>

Tube strike called off

The train drivers' union Aslef yesterday called off next week's 24-hour strike on London Underground, but other tube workers are to go ahead with it.

Doctor cleared of misconduct

Nasser Mohammad Ali Amer of Southampton, was yesterday cleared by the General Medical Council of professional misconduct. The doctor was accused of indecent assault on a patient.

fields.headline: AOL motoring to European growth
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: AOL Time Warner is hoping that Europe will provide a motor for growth in its internet operations during the next few years - and is considering various options to help achieve that, including a local float, partnerships and acquisitions.
fields.body:
AOL Time Warner is hoping that Europe will provide a motor for growth in its internet operations during the next few years - and is considering various options to help achieve that, including a local float, partnerships and acquisitions.

Speaking after a presentation to analysts and investors in London, Michael Lynton, the president of AOL International, told Reuters that the Netherlands, Italy and Spain were three most exciting European markets for the group.

"We could potentially do an initial public offering to gain a European currency and we may also look for partners. However, we have the luxury of being part of a big corporate parent with a lot of cash and resources," Mr Lynton said.

"Aside from the countries we are in, the Netherlands, Italy and Spain are the most appealing. The rest hold little interest for us," he added.

AOL, which merged with the market-leading entertainment group Time Warner last year to create the world's largest media conglomerate, saw the number of internet subscribers in its European businesses - primarily Britain, Germany and France - rise by 40% to 4.6m last year.

Despite concerns over internet revenues in the present economic climate, Mr Lynton insisted that there had been no slowing of the strong increase in subscribers in Europe during the year. The group hopes to deliver similar growth rates during the next 12 months.

Arguing in favour of the attractions offered by the European market, AOL International's president noted that internet penetration in the territory was still only about 50% of that achieved in the United States, at some 30% of the adult population. Mr Lynton also noted that European surfers were spending more time online as local internet providers were slowly moving to flat-fee access.

AOL has been able to offer flat-fee access in Britain only after a hard-fought battle to win wholesale concessions from BT. Flat-fee access in Britain has doubled the average time an AOL subscriber spends online to one hour a day since its introduction, three months ago. The group hopes to negotiate similar deals in France and Germany.

webTitle: Hugo Young on Europe and Labour

fields.headline: Europe is a great, black hole for Labour politicians
fields.standfirst:
Election strategists must mark their territory before the Tories snatch it

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Election strategists must mark their territory before the Tories snatch it.
fields.body:
Manoeuvring to get away from an early election, William Hague distracts attention from what the contest will be about. He's playing a good hand, exploiting the government's inflexible haste without looking as though he's running scared. Plainly Mr Blair is about to switch the argument. Having said for three weeks that a May 3 election can happen because foot and mouth is under control, party managers are getting ready to say the opposite: that the election must happen now because the plague may not be any better under control in September. Delay now and you delay for ever, they've begun to murmur. There's a lot of disingenuous electoralism here, which Hague would be negligent if he did not challenge.

But it's not the biggest electoral issue inside the Conservative party. That place belongs to Europe. Europe, in fact, looms into focus all round. For the government, today's EU summit in Stockholm is one of many well carpentered planks in the bridge to May 3. Among the Tory high command, meanwhile, there are rumblings of anxiety about whether the issue will play as they have planned. For the country as a whole, the role of the election as prelude to a euro referendum deserves to be better understood.

Mr Hague has always seen Europe as big. Along with crime, asylum and tax, it's one of the four issues he thinks he can make sing. But some of his colleagues are no longer so sure. The so-called liberalising tendency in the party, adherents of Michael Portillo and/or Francis Maude, give voice to other thoughts. These people may be only marginally less Euro-sceptic than Hague is, but they're more sceptical about the impact of Europe on voting, and much more worried about the impact of another Labour landslide on the battle they really care about, the referendum.

The election, they know, is lost. But the referendum is not. Yet an election perceived to have been lost after a campaign that majored on Europe would send a calamitous signal. Unlike other Eurosceptics, Tory anti- Europeans do not have a strategy directed at preventing the referendum taking place by persuading Blair he can never win it. Hague's putative successors, if not Hague himself, are banking everything on the referendum as midwife to the rebirth of their party. But they face an election that threatens to pulverise their credibility. Another Labour landslide would make a referendum not merely likely but, I believe, politically very hard for the government to duck away from. If Hague has been smashed on Europe, it would also be decidedly easier to win.

They aren't recognisable as belonging to something called the Tory left, so they weren't fastidiously much offended by Hague's nationalistic garbage on the subject of Britain becoming "a foreign land". But many top Tories were taken aback by how badly that keynote speech went down, even with the Sun. Stockholm, they intend, will add to the unfavourable comparison with themselves. It will be flourished as proof of constructive engagement. It looks as though France, for Mr Jospin's own electoral reasons, won't allow Stockholm to be a Blairite triumph, with full-scale opening up of gas and electricity markets. But there will be enough to make the British case. The financial markets will like another dose of liberal reform, building on last year's Lisbon summit. The relentless ratcheting from one obscure EU meeting to another, which is usually the obsession only of anoraked aficionados, will be presented by the Blair machine, with justice, as progress in the right direction. Such is the unglamorous nature of EU business. But with an election coming, there are few limits to the sparkle that inventive propagandists will be able to bestow on the driest material.

If Hague chooses to make the frontal anti-EU case, all this will be a telling riposte. It can be used to distinguish the men of business from the man of Euro-madness. But that is not the only prospect on offer. If Portilloism gets its way, and Europe recedes from the Tory agenda, the challenge to Mr Blair becomes trickier. How will he use the issue of Europe in an active not reactive way? How far will he voluntarily go to make this election, in part, a quest for a mandate to hold the referendum and win it?

The easy answer is to say: no distance at all. Safety-first politics still dominates most Labour thinking, however luscious the majority the opinion polls seem to foretell. There's hardly a single Labour politician who can persuade him or herself that pushing Europe up front would win extra seats. An unnoticed lacuna in politics, indeed, is the absence of knowledge, let alone enthusiasm, concerning Europe of most Labour MPs. The place is a great black hole, which may not engage their active hostility but would find them at a loss in a gloves-off debate with the many sharp Tory Eurosceptics whose obsession has equipped them with formidable, if selective, expertise. Labour is mildly pro-European. It has yet to become the party of Europe.

On the other hand, the proliferating Tory divisions and confusions - not just Hague v Clarke but Portillo v Hague - present an opportunity which it would be criminal for a European prime minister to miss. Irrespective of how far Mr Hague chooses to jump towards the unacceptable extreme, Mr Blair has his own unique chance to define his victory as a victory, among other things, for his Europe policy, and thereby advance the referendum further into the realm of practical politics.

I have no doubt he wants to hold the referendum. Most people underestimate his personal commitment to resolving the misbegotten turmoil the Europe question has brought to modern British history. That's not to say he definitely intends to take the plunge. The gamble could look too great. But the election offers a massive opening to change the terms of trade and remake the odds. If the result is big, it needs to look like a signal for the next and bigger contest. The framework of the campaign is therefore vital. If Hague fails to oblige by offering an open target, let's hope Tony Blair doesn't shrink from inventing his own resonant language for popular endorsement. Seize the day.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: You left us investigating the disappearance of Sin Simon, the New Labour apologist whose column in Monday's Telegraph was so maddeningly absent.
fields.body:
 You left us investigating the disappearance of Sin Simon, the New Labour apologist whose column in Monday's Telegraph was so maddeningly absent. The sighting of Sin in Birmingham Erdington was, it turns out, genuine, with a beady-eyed turncoat twitcher spying him knocking on the doors of constituency party faithful this weekend.

But what brings Mr Tony's media lackey home to the city that spawned him? A sudden stab of nostalgia for grass roots opinion, or a quite spectacular piece of electoral manoeuvring by Millbank? We are a little clearer on this after Friday's last-minute announcement by current MP Robin Corbett that he would be standing down at the election. And we are clearer still when we discover that Sin is counting on the backing of lovable general secretary Margaret McDonagh, despite strong local support for fellow shortlister Andrew Hood.

Ah, it fair takes you back to 1997, when Millbank parachuted on message candidates into "unexpected" vacancies up and down the land. Why, not so long ago Sin himself dragged his carpet-bag to south Wales, only to pull out of the race at the eleventh hour. We ring him to reminisce and discuss his future, but he is too busy to talk. Still, plenty of time.

 Much has been made of Camden's council tax rate which averages an unashamed £1,000. But where else can one lurch from the bitter pain of opening one's dreaded bill to the unadulterated joy of discovering that a complimentary fold-out year-planner has been included? It may not be laminated, it may not be free from adverts for funeral parlours, but by golly it's a start on the long road to reconciliation with residents.

 Negotiations with website supremo Oofy Wegg-Prosser over our imminent web debut appear to have hit a wall, with the missing photograph of Diary pundit Steptoe threatening to bring down the whole deal. With Matthew Norman off radar I am unable to find a picture of our affable tipster, and Oofy's patience is tried. After various stalled discussions and some deep breaths, he asks, "What sort of dog is Steptoe?" Whatever you are thinking, Oofy, unthink it. Steptoe has been maligned enough by Andrew Neil without having to endure the indignity of faked internet pictures. "I'd just like to know the brand of dog," he continues evenly. I'm sorry, I can't. Matthew would never forgive me. The web must wait.

 Like a benevolent Godzilla, Diary vicar Steve Chalke surfaces from a period of silent reflection to send us a book about his Faithworks organisation. When last we spoke, having steered shy of mentioning he ran Faithworks when he chaired a debate on it on his GMTV show, Steve was kind enough to provide us with a sermon on conflict of interest. Something about looking to the mote in your own eye, but we'll move on. In his accompanying letter, Steve is typically charitable. "The column is as good as ever," he begins cryptically. "I know you've taken an interest in the Faithworks campaign so thought I'd drop you a copy of the book that is being handed out on the tour." You're kind, Steve. And yes to the lunch invitation.

 No room for edited highlights or video grabs celebrating DTI minister Kim Howells's early career in X-rated progressive cinema, although I can now verify his claim to have kept his (beige) towel on. The above will now appear next week. Meanwhile those with the stomach for it can expect something of a special tomorrow from the UK Press Gazette awards, the traditionally unedifying gathering of the journalistic community.

 2am breaking news: it's too upsetting to go into in full, but the Diary is being held to ransom over its own domain name. Webmaster Oofy Wegg-Prosser is not involved, and we have been told to remain calm, but what a blow it is.
