webTitle: Pure logs out of free net games

fields.headline: Pure logs out of free net games
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Pure Entertainment Games yesterday underlined the difficulties for games companies trying to build profitable businesses on the internet by announcing the closure of its Freeloader.com site for gamers.
fields.body:
Pure Entertainment Games yesterday underlined the difficulties for games companies trying to build profitable businesses on the internet by announcing the closure of its Freeloader.com site for gamers.

The announcement caught the market by surprise, after a series of bullish statements over the past three months about Freeloader's prospects. It wiped 78% off Pure's shares.

Freeloader offered free play to gamers if they clicked on adverts. The concept attracted 750,000 registered users in Britain. The chief executive, Bob Dewar, predicted in December that profitability would be reached earlier than expected.

A slowdown in advertising spend and additional expenditure needed to push the international sites to breakeven forced Pure to cut its losses. Around 40 jobs will go.

In a statement Pure said it did not see "a fundraising exercise to be a realistic option in current market conditions". Talks with other companies about a sale had come to nothing. "The directors therefore believe that it is in the best interests of the company's shareholders to close the website."

No-one from the company was available for comment. The shares closed down 11.25p at 2.75p.

Several companies have been exploring digital delivery of games. Slow net connections, delays to broadband and the absence of business models to make the activity pay have stifled their attempts.

fields.body:
 Just the ticket

Tickets to sporting events, theatres and concerts at more than 5,000 US venues, plus online personals, will be offered at AOL Time Warner internet destinations through a strategic alliance with Ticketmaster .

 Click-off T

he New York-based leading online advertising network, DoubleClick, is to cut its workforce by 10% to 1,850 and make strategic changes to its media business to improve efficiency. Shares were down at $10 in early trading on the Nasdaq, near a 52-week low of $8.

Silence

The second-largest listed software exporter in India, Infosys Technologies, would not comment on a UBS Warburg report predicting lower sales growth in the year ending March 2002 because of a US slowdown.

webTitle: It's the sell-season on analysts' stock

fields.headline: It's the sell-season on analysts' stock
fields.standfirst: Even the FT sees need for humility
fields.trailText: The City's analysts have had a trying week. First there was a curious leader in the Financial Times suggesting the time had come to "Shoot all the analysts". Its grounds for urging their despatch to the great investment bank in the sky were threefold - a) they are used to drag in corporate finance business, b) big companies use them to manage and massage expectations and c) they are over-optimistic with share price forecasts.
fields.body:
The City's analysts have had a trying week. First there was a curious leader in the Financial Times suggesting the time had come to "Shoot all the analysts". Its grounds for urging their despatch to the great investment bank in the sky were threefold - a) they are used to drag in corporate finance business, b) big companies use them to manage and massage expectations and c) they are over-optimistic with share price forecasts.

The pink 'un then thundered on about some of them being "extremely rich" and "wearing suits... worth more than most of their clients' portfolios" and urged them to "learn a little humility and get back to analysis".

What is more, in his recent report to the Treasury, Paul Myners suggested that fund managers develop their own teams of analysts to ensure independent and objective research. He suggests that the pension fund trustees, who ultimately pay the research bill, are probably being short-changed.

And the image of analysts as little more than highly-paid poodles was reinforced by new reports yesterday that JP Morgan's number-crunchers had been ordered to seek approval both from the companies they are analysing and their banker colleagues should they be considering a change in their recommendations.

The bank was swift to deny that any pressure was being exerted - it was not about getting approval, it said - just about communication, and a laudable determination not to make any factual errors. The bank, it goes without saying, simply would not countenance changing recommendations because of company pressure.

Many analysts do now earn unjustifiably large rewards. Quite a number also have unjustifiably large egos. But, by and large, they are second-class citizens in comparison to their revenue-generating corporate finance colleagues.

With a little effort it might even be possible to sympathise a bit with their predicament - but then we are presented with a fine example of the sort of nonsense they increasingly come up with.

Take Merrill Lynch's brand new assessment of glassmaker Pilkington. Merrill's finest analytical brains have just downgraded the stock from "buy" to "accumulate".

Just how, precisely, do they suggest in vestors "accumulate" Pilkington shares without buying them? Is there a secret Ofex swap shop where investors can trade share certificates like Panini stickers?

Maybe the FT is right - and the time has come to unholster the Uzi.

Not so green

Greenpeace yesterday took the City by storm, invading the London stock exchange: not with direct action but with a seminar for fund managers and energy analysts.

And to the environmentalists' astonishment the City slickers not only turned up in large numbers but found considerable areas of agreement and mutual interest.

As one Greenpeace official pointed out: "We are always looking for where the power lies and we have found it, not with the politicians as we thought, but in the City where money is controlled through pension funds."

Greenpeace wants cash switched away from the traditional oil and gas groups and put into "green" companies. They liken the oil majors' failure to invest in new sources of energy to IBM missing out on the personal computer boom.

But it seemed a tad unfortunate that BP was singled out for criticism. Sure, it has acted heavy-handedly over environmentalist resolutions at its annual general meeting and has perhaps raised expectations too far with its new "green" logo and accompanying sloganeering.

It also remains committed to growing its core oil and gas operations, but some seemed to have forgotten that it is arguably the biggest solar power company in the world as well.

Ironically the attacks came on the day BP announced plans to bring hydrogen fuel cell buses to the streets outside the stock exchange.

But the true significance of Greenpeace's day in the City was a realisation on both sides that research and action on climate change and renewable forms of energy have proceeded a lot further than most realised.

The environmentalists seemed astonished to hear that some institutional investors regarded companies such as Johnson Matthey (through its fuel cells technology), Ballard Power and Vestas Wind Turbines as the hottest stocks since the best days of internet fever.

Many in the Square Mile have woken up to the growing threat to a range of companies from global warming. But green campaigners need to be aware that the markets are fickle, and fashions change.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: Of mice and men
fields.body:
Of mice and men

XTL is an Israeli-based biotech company which recently floated (at the second attempt) in London. Its main business involves irradiating mice to destroy their immune system, then implanting human tissue so that drugs can be tested. Although nuking mice is its main business, the company's annual results this week managed to avoid any mention of the furry wee critters. When we approached him on the subject, chief executive Martin Becker was a touch evasive when asked how many mice he had. "A minimal number." Mmm, but how many? "I simply don't have those figures to hand." Are we talking thousands here, or tens of thousands? "I don't go round counting mice. We are trying to minimise our use of mice." Minimise? "I'm not prepared to comment on this," replied Martin, his temper starting to fray. "We would rather not use animals at all. I have not met a scientist who enjoys working with experimental animals. You are trying to sensationalise this." Certainly not. If we were trying to sensationalise this we'd call you a serial mouse-murderer.

 Good news for Argentina's economic revival. Its recovery plan is being backed by the region's International Monetary Fund director, Mr Loser.

 A new turn of events in the desperate attempt by bulge bracket bankers Morgan Stanley Dean Witter to muscle into the credit for working on a merger between two Swedish finance houses - to the chagrin of JP Morgan and Merrill Lynch, who did most of the work on the deal. fields.headline: Boost for Sheffield
fields.trailText: Government plans to spread wealth and employment from prosperous to hard-up regions were boosted yesterday when a US computer company chose Sheffield as its European headquarters.
fields.body:
Government plans to spread wealth and employment from prosperous to hard-up regions were boosted yesterday when a US computer company chose Sheffield as its European headquarters.

Insight, which markets hardware and software, is to create 1,757 jobs over the next six years in the city and surrounding area through a £67m investment - sweetened by £16.5m in state aid on top.

The Arizona-based company, set up by brothers Eric and Tim Crown more than 10 years ago with $2,000, now turns over £2bn, employs 3,400 and is ranked among the top 100 fastest-growing US groups.

Ministers view the investment as a vindication of their efforts to sustain Britain as the preferred port-of-call in the EU despite worries over its absence from the euro.

Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary whose department is putting up £15m grants in a region rated amongst the most deprived in the EU, said: "This is a key step on the road to delivering full employment in every region of the country."

Graham Hall, chairman of Yorkshire Forward, the regional development agency, said the project was the largest-ever single inward investment into Yorkshire and Humberside.

fields.headline: 22,000 jobs under threat
fields.standfirst: Procter & Gamble plans worldwide redundancies
fields.trailText: Procter & Gamble, the consumer goods company, is planning a huge cost-cutting exercise which could result in up to 22,000 job being lost around the world.
fields.body:
Procter & Gamble, the consumer goods company, is planning a huge cost-cutting exercise which could result in up to 22,000 job being lost around the world.

The Ohio-based company, which makes Crest toothpaste and Pampers nappies and announced 15,000 layoffs two years ago, employs 5,600 people in Britain. It has manufacturing and administrative facilities in the Newcastle area, Surrey and Kent. Wall Street analysts expect any job cuts to affect the group's worldwide operations.

Procter & Gamble said yesterday that an internal taskforce had been set up to look at saving money around the world. Linda Ulrey, a company spokeswoman, said: "The taskforce is looking at where we can implement cost reductions."

She refused to confirm reports in the Wall Street Journal that the company was considering cutting between 10%-20% of its 110,000-strong workforce. However, several analysts and headhunters said they expected job cuts within the next few months.

Marian Baker, a spokeswoman for the firm in Newcastle, refused to comment on "speculation or rumour". Alan Lafley, the company's chief executive, is to hold one of his regular webcasts for UK employees "shortly".

Shares in the company had fallen almost $3 (£2.10) to $63 in early trade yesterday in a weak market. They have dropped from a high of $118 in January 2000.

Wall Street analysts welcomed the plan to cut more cost from the company. In a note to investors, Jim Gingrich, an analyst with investment bank Sanford Bernstein, said Procter & Gamble needed to cut costs to remain competitive, "something they clearly are not today". He said that a reorganisation was likely to include management, marketing and sales divisions.

James Mead, a former company executive turned headhunter, said calls from the company had increased substantially over the past few weeks.

Several analysts suggested that the company had not yet decided on a headcount total for the job cuts and may not do so until its next board meeting in April.

Procter & Gamble has struggled with sluggish sales growth even before the downturn in the US economy. Sales rose only slightly last year before falling 4% in the first six months of fiscal 2001.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: UK firm pledges 25% growth
fields.body:
UK firm pledges 25% growth

International Power, the UK-based generator, plans to almost triple its global capacity and deliver annual earnings growth of up to 25% over the next four years, it said yesterday.

The group, demerged from National Power last September, said it was considering plans to build three or four power stations in California, where power blackouts have been caused by electricity shortages. This emerged as the firm announced a 22% pro forma rise in pretax profits in the last nine months of 2000 to £167m - before exceptional charges of £99m due to the demerger and withdrawal from China.

Johnston still hopeful on RIM

Johnston Press, the regional newspaper group, yesterday said it still hoped to enter into talks for the takeover of Regional Independent Media, owner of the Yorkshire Post.

Johnston is part of an alliance including Guardian Media Group and led by Gannett, which has made two approaches to RIM with a view to breaking up the business. The last made an offer in the £450m-£550m range.

"We represent a very credible option for RIM, and are continuing a desultory dialogue," said Johnston chief executive Tim Bowdler. Regulatory approval to buy titles from RIM will run out on November 1. Johnston reported a 21% rise in pretax profits to £66.5m for last year on revenues of £292m.

Boeing moves from Seattle

Boeing announced yesterday that it is to move its headquarters out of Seattle and named the leaders of its three largest operations as chief executives in part of a restructuring.

The company is looking at Chicago, Denver or Dallas-Fort Worth for its new corporate centre, saying it would make a final decision by early summer. The new headquarters will employ about half the 1,000 employees at present working in the Seattle offices, Boeing said.

Potter magic helps Ottakar

The success of children's character Harry Potter helped sales at bookshop chain Ottakar shoot up last year, the company said yesterday. Like for like sales throughout its stores for the year to January 27 rose 8% to £60.6m. Overall, turnover at the group rose 18% to £86.3m, while pretax profits rose from £780,000 to £2.8m.

webTitle: Age-old habits caused deadly vCJD cluster

fields.headline: Age-old habits caused deadly cluster
fields.standfirst:
Farmers, butchers and shoppers all played a part

Special report: BSE
fields.trailText: The government is to order new checks on farming methods, food preparation and the eating and buying habits of consumers in the 80s, after new evidence that shows they all played a part in mixing the lethal cocktail that developed into new variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (vCJD) - the human form of BSE.
fields.body:
The government is to order new checks on farming methods, food preparation and the eating and buying habits of consumers in the 80s, after new evidence that shows they all played a part in mixing the lethal cocktail that developed into new variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (vCJD) - the human form of BSE.

Scientific advisers are to review the results of an eight-month investigation into the deaths of five people from vCJD in a small area of Leicestershire to see if it can explain the rapidly mounting death toll. Ninety Britons have died of the disease since March 1995, seven more have been diagnosed with it. Experts are reluctant to predict the eventual toll.

A catastrophic combination of factors in the early and mid-80s - including the use of older dairy cattle for beef, traditional slaughtering techniques used in smaller abattoirs and the sale of such meat to high street butchers rather than supermarkets - was blamed for a cluster of deaths linked to the village of Queniborough between Autumn 1998 and last September.

While doctors yesterday tried to reassure local people that the likelihood of others falling victim to the disease was small, national experts were worried that the Leicestershire victims seemed to have contracted the disease years before BSE was finally identified in 1986 - a decade before the epidemic was at its height in 1992-93 and well before measures designed to protect the public from the risk of infection were in place.

Dr Philip Monk, consultant for communicable diseases for Leicestershire health authority, and his colleague Dr Gerry Bryant outlined a number of key elements to their theory at a meeting in Queniborough.

The beef involved came from locally reared cattle and be cause they were a by-product of dairy herds, they were fed meat and bonemeal, derived from cattle and sheep remains, to fatten them up. This is regarded as a key factor in spreading BSE through the national herd.

Traditional slaughtering methods used in small abattoirs were also to blame, the doctors said. The messy splitting of cattle heads to remove the brains could have cross-contaminated other meat.

Four out of the five victims may have been exposed to beef from a butcher's shop where meat could be contaminated with brain tissue.

They did not name the butchers but in one case exposure had taken place before December 1982. The doctors also said that just one infected cow may have been responsible for infecting at least three of the victims.

The other butcher thought to be involved ceased trading in 1989. This suggests incubation periods of between 10 and 16 years. Other studies have suggested the range may be between four and 40 years.

Dr Bryant said: "No one was doing anything illegal. These were totally legitimate practices before BSE was realised."

Professor Robert Will, head of the national CJD surveillance unit in Edinburgh welcomed the report last night but added: "It worries me; if there was transmission to the human population when BSE was extremely rare then the question is, are we going to see a lot more from when there were much higher levels of exposure?"

He still believes the use of mechanically recovered meat, machined off the spinal cord to be used in cheap food and not banned until 1995, may still be a factor.

Other investigations are already under way to test apparent links between victims in Stockport, Lancashire and Doncaster. There may also be linked cases in six other areas - Stockton-on-Tees; south Wales; Chester-le-Street, Durham; Walton-on-Thames, Surrey; Eastleigh, Hampshire and Strathclyde, Scotland.

The Department of Health welcomed the report but pointed out that the use of brains and other offals had been banned from food in 1989.

However, Harriet Kimbell, consumer representative on the government's spongiform encephalopathy advisory committee which supervises both BSE and vCJD issues, said vigilance was still needed as spinal cord had been found in imported carcasses from Spain, Italy, the Netherlands, Germany and Ireland recently.

Victims
Links between the five who died

 Stacey Robinson

A 19-year-old single mother who had lived in Queniborough but moved away just before her death, she was the first to die in August 1998. She was initially diagnosed as suffering from post-natal depression.

 Pamela Beyless

Pamela Beyless, a bank worker, lived four miles from Queniborough but visited her grandparents, who live there. She first fell ill in March 1996 and after a two-year decline, died in October 1998, aged 24.

 Christopher Reeve

The 24-year-old farm worker died last October, less than a year after first displaying symptoms. He lived in Rearsby but worked in nearby Queniborough. He was a friend of Stacey Robinson's brother.

 Glen Day

The 35-year-old van driver lived with his parents in the village. He died within weeks of Pamela Beyless, whose grandparents were neighbours. He may also have worked alongside Christopher Reeve. The village historian, Rosemary Smith, described him as a "kind and loving chap".

 The unnamed victim

The 19-year-old man, who had links with the Queniborough, area, died in May last year. He is thought to have lived within three miles of the village. His family have requested that he not be identified.

Process

The inquiry focused on how some local butchers used to process carcasses, often using traditional techniques that were centuries old.

Butchers removed the brain from the beast - which was legal at the time - as they recovered meat from the head. The carcass was then boned and jointed. This meant that other meat could become contaminated by potentially infectious brain material.

The inquiry also looked at techniques used at abattoirs. Cattle were slaughtered using a "captive bolt stunner", which drives a bolt into the animal's head. Many abattoirs also used a pithing rod - a rod inserted through the hole made by the stunner, which can prevent the animal kicking reflexively. Even before yesterday's report, fears had been raised that pithing could spread BSE-infected tissue. Last year, the EU said the technique should not be used.

Larger abattoirs tended to hose the carcass but smaller ones would only wipe it down to remove unwanted tissue, raising the risk of cross-contamination of meat with brain and nerve tissue.

In the early 80s there was no legal requirement to hose down a carcass; indeed some slaughtermen believed that it made the meat go "sour".
Steven Morris

webTitle: Pay rise for vets as supply runs low

fields.headline: Pay rise for vets as supply runs low
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Britain is running out of vets to cope with the continued outbreaks of foot and mouth because after each contact with infected animals vets have to be quarantined for three days to avoid passing on the disease to the next lot of animals they inspect.
fields.body:
Britain is running out of vets to cope with the continued outbreaks of foot and mouth because after each contact with infected animals vets have to be quarantined for three days to avoid passing on the disease to the next lot of animals they inspect.

To lure more vets away away from private practice to help cope with the foot and mouth crisis the government yesterday increased the daily rate paid to vets from £150 to £250. To avoid resentment from its own staff, who get paid considerably less but who have been working 14 hours a day since the outbreak began, bonuses have been added to their pay.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, told MPs that one of the biggest hold-ups in dealing with the crisis was the continued shortage of vets. Every vet that went to a new suspected outbreak had to be "clean" - having not been in contact with diseased animals and so not likely to pass on an infection.

If foot and mouth was diagnosed then the vet became "dirty" and could not go near livestock for fear of infecting them. The virus could live for three days in the pharynx at the back of the throat and if vets got close to clean animals then it could be spread. This meant if there were 46 outbreaks in a day that number of clean vets were used up and could not be used again on the farms for three days.

One of the biggest criticisms of the government has been the time lag between farmers reporting the disease and animals in distress and a vet arriving and ordering their destruction. Maff was doing its best to solve this problem, Mr Brown said.

The ministry had 220 vets of its own at the beginning of the crisis and now had 700 but it was still not enough. Nearly 100 volunteers had come from overseas, more were coming, and the government was trying to convince some of the 22,000 vets in private practice to "come over". The problem was that many of these specialised in small animals and were in towns well away from where they were needed.

The government has also recruited 120 final year students from veterinary colleges to work on the outbreak, with a further 80 to come when they have finished exams.

fields.bodyText: Britain is running out of vets to cope with the continued outbreaks of foot and mouth because after each contact with infected animals vets have to be quarantined for three days to avoid passing on the disease to the next lot of animals they inspect. To lure more vets away away from private practice to help cope with the foot and mouth crisis the government yesterday increased the daily rate paid to vets from £150 to £250. To avoid resentment from its own staff, who get paid considerably less but who have been working 14 hours a day since the outbreak began, bonuses have been added to their pay. Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, told MPs that one of the biggest hold-ups in dealing with the crisis was the continued shortage of vets. Every vet that went to a new suspected outbreak had to be "clean" - having not been in contact with diseased animals and so not likely to pass on an infection. If foot and mouth was diagnosed then the vet became "dirty" and could not go near livestock for fear of infecting them. The virus could live for three days in the pharynx at the back of the throat and if vets got close to clean animals then it could be spread. This meant if there were 46 outbreaks in a day that number of clean vets were used up and could not be used again on the farms for three days. One of the biggest criticisms of the government has been the time lag between farmers reporting the disease and animals in distress and a vet arriving and ordering their destruction. Maff was doing its best to solve this problem, Mr Brown said. The ministry had 220 vets of its own at the beginning of the crisis and now had 700 but it was still not enough. Nearly 100 volunteers had come from overseas, more were coming, and the government was trying to convince some of the 22,000 vets in private practice to "come over". The problem was that many of these specialised in small animals and were in towns well away from where they were needed. The government has also recruited 120 final year students from veterinary colleges to work on the outbreak, with a further 80 to come when they have finished exams. What's going on? webTitle: Fears linger in vCJD stricken community

fields.headline: Fears linger in stricken community
fields.standfirst:
Locals find little reassurance in official explanation

Special report: BSE
fields.trailText: For more than two years, residents of Queniborough - a few minutes drive out of Leicester - had worried that they had been cruelly picked out to suffer more than other parts of Britain from the human form of BSE.
fields.body:
It was half-day closing in Queniborough, a few minutes drive out of Leicester. The village was deserted, the local butcher's shop shut and the two pubs had long called last orders on lunch. There was no hint yesterday that this was the centre of a nine-month hunt for the killer that had claimed five people living within a few miles between autumn 1998 and autumn 2000.

For more than two years, residents had worried that they had been cruelly picked out to suffer more than other parts of Britain from the human form of BSE.

Queniborough, population 2,300, is not a particularly pretty village, the 17th century thatched cottages rubbing shoulders with nondescript housing on a main road.

But the people who live here and within a five-kilometre radius in the Wreake and Foar Valley hope they may have helped unlock some secrets of the harrowing disease that has claimed more than 100 victims.

It was difficult to tell what people dreaded most when they arrived yesterday morning for a public meeting of the Leicestershire health authority at Syston rugby club half a mile from the village.

It may have been the suggestion that more people might yet die from the fatal condition that can strike at least 10 years after infection or, for some, it was the nightmare of having to relive their experiences.

They listened quietly as doctors explained their hypothesis that a catastrophic combination of farming methods, traditional and sometimes messy slaughtering and butchery techniques and people's own eating habits had exposed local people to the prospect of a dreadful death.

The present butcher, David Clarke, has been in the village since the early 1980s but it was from his predecessor that at least one local family, who saw their daughter slide towards an awful death, had bought their meat.

Mr Clarke, said: "It is terrible what has happened but it is not only in this area. It is in other parts of Britain. Awful.

"You can't blame anyone, butchers were using methods that were traditional, that everyone used. No one had ever heard of BSE; no one knew there was any danger.

"When I started there was food rationing. You needed all the food you could get; the head was regarded as a bonus. No one knew of the dangers of spinal cord and so on."

Arthur Beyless, whose daughter, Pamela, died in October 1998 aged 24, told yesterday how the family had travelled miles from their home on the outskirts of Leicester to pick up frozen meat from the Queniborough butcher's because his wife's parents lived in the village and recommended the shop, then run by a butcher called Ian Bramley.

Mr Beyless said: "I don't believe he would have knowingly chosen anything he could not eat himself. We bought in bulk, it was not just that we bought the odd joint."

The family had given up eating beef during Pamela's illness. But Mr Beyless, 54, a milkman, said he was still worried for his wife Jane and his sons, Steven, 31, and David, 29.

Rosemary Smith, daughter of another former butcher in the village, told how she used to deliver meat to Mr Beyless. "Butchers' practice in this area would be no different to anywhere else in the country or in the world. If people wanted brains they could have brains."

Many locals were not completely reassured by the report and still think other causes may be responsible for helping spread BSE and vCJD. Ms Smith suggested manganese in the soil. "I think more research should be done, we should not shut the door."

Robert Pendleton, 74, suggested the use of chemicals to fight the warble fly that attacked cattle could be to blame. "In our day, we had organic food and that is where it needs to go back to."

Teenager Anja Gooding said: "I am not reassured. I don't eat beef anymore anyway. People are worried, people really want to know what is happening."

Last night more residents were going to the local primary school to hear the full story. Meanwhile, Stephen Dorrell, the constituency MP, admitted that there was an irony in that he had been the health secretary who had to announce the probable link between BSE and vCJD in the Commons on March 20 five years ago.

He said: "This explanation does not break radical new ground and that is good news. It reinforces the emerging picture from work all over the country."

fields.headline: Fidelity loses faith in Colt
fields.trailText: Holders of Colt Telecom shares should take note. The company's biggest shareholder has been selling stock and nobody seems to know why.
fields.body:
Holders of Colt Telecom shares should take note. The company's biggest shareholder has been selling stock and nobody seems to know why.

Yesterday it emerged that Fidelity, the fund management group which founded and provided seed corn funding for the company in the early 1990s, had sold 5.3m shares last week, reducing its stake to 47%.

Colt attempted to play down the sale, with a spokesman for the company saying that investors should not read anything into it and that Fidelity remained "a committed long-term shareholder".

Analysts were far from convinced. Dealers said the telecoms team at Merrill Lynch were running around frantically trying to find an explanation for the sale, on which Fidelity was refusing to comment. While sector watchers said that there could be a rational explanation, dealers wanted to know why Fidelity had decided to sell stock for the first time, now.

Given the poor performance of the shares in the past 12 months the timing of the sale looked odd, they said.

Traders reckon that further sales by Fidelity cannot be ruled out and this is likely to hit the near-term performance of the stock. Colt finished down 98p at 767p.

Elsewhere, it was very much a case of easy come, easy go. The FTSE 100 gave back all of Tuesday's gains as the market registered its disappointment with the Federal Reserve's decision to cut rates by 50 basis points rather than 75.

With stronger-than-expected US consumer price data damping hopes for a further aggressive easing, the FTSE 100 fell 106.1 points to 5,540.7 and 79 blue chips stocks ended in negative territory.

Traders were not surprised by the market's reaction. "The Fed was damned whatever did. A reduction of 75 basis points would have smacked of panic, yet a cut of 50 was never going to be enough," one market man said.

Once again the usual sus pects were doing most of the damage to the index.

Energis led the telecom sector, closing 41.5p lower at 279.5p with Vodafone surrendering 3.5p to 203.5p after analysts at ABN Amro lowered their forecasts. British Telecom was also making the journey south, falling 28.5p to 494p - a three year low.

Over in the tech sector things were little better. Logica (down 112p to 993p), Misys (off 23p at 527p), and CMG (37p lower at 640p) were all hit by downgrades from Merrill Lynch. The FTSE Techmark 100 finished 72.65 points lower at 1,976.65.

Banking stocks were also out of favour with Barclays falling 38p to £20 and Royal Bank of Scotland losing 92p to £14.30p after the competition commission threatened the banks with a windfall tax.

Elsewhere, controls and au tomation group Invensys declined 10p to 129p on renewed speculation that a profits warning is on the cards. The company is scheduled to issue a trading statement before the end of the month.

About the only blue chips going up were classic defensive issues like BAE Systems, up 6.5p to 324.5p, BG, 1.75p higher at 270p, and Safeway, which added 2p to 312p.

Lower down the market, a few tales were doing the rounds. Independent Insurance was undermined by speculation that the company is plotting a rights issue. The stock fell 1.5p to 156p. In the meantime grocer Somerfield rose 2.25p to 88.5p as talk of an imminent profits warning was quashed. The company revealed yesterday that its chairman and chief executive had recently been buying shares at the 88p level.

On a more fundamental tack, cruise company P&O Princess gained 6p to 296p, following strong figures from US rival Carnival. The name Carnival also popped up in a tale concerning Airtours, off 7p at 279p. Late in the session dealers reported talk that Carnival was looking to place some of its 25% stake with institutions.

fields.headline: At this price?  Fish
fields.trailText: Fish, the restaurant chain established by entrepreneur Tony Allan, was almost responsible for the death of the Queen Mother a few years ago.
fields.body:
Fish, the restaurant chain established by entrepreneur Tony Allan, was almost responsible for the death of the Queen Mother a few years ago.

Her Majesty choked on a fishbone at a smart London restaurant which was supplied by Fish's wholesale arm. "We were almost part and parcel of killing her," recalls Mr Allan.

That arm has since been shut down, and apart from a small business farming scallops in Scotland, the company concentrates on its rapidly expanding chain of cheap and cheerful diners, named Fish!

Six Fish! restaurants are up and running, with another 22 to be opened by October 2002 at a cost of £500,000 each. They offer simple dinners in light and airy surroundings, for £15 to £25 a head.

Mr Allan reckons fish dishes are increasingly appealing to casual diners because they are healthy and unfussy - recent events have been helpful in luring consumers away from eating meat and preparation of the food is cheap.

The company yesterday announced a 12% fall in pretax profits to £2.2m although the comparative figures are misleading - the group has sold a series of one-off restaurants, including the highly regarded Bank canteen in Aldwych.

The shares have been weak, however, falling from 300p to 143.5p over the last year. Some analysts are worried the group is being too ambitious, and that forecasts have got out of hand - house broker Collins Stewart predicts profits of £2.8m this year, then £5m next year.

A couple of unsuccessful restaurants could prevent the firm from reaching those targets. The record is good so far - but one outlet, in Battersea, London, has been disappointing and required changes.

The economic climate is cooling, which could have a negative effect on sales.

Although the Fish! concept is a good one, it is doubtful whether this is the right time to invest in such an ambitious project. With groups such as Belgo and City Centre Restaurants facing problems, these shares are too risky.

fields.headline: Plummy tones grip Scots capital
fields.trailText: Glaswegians have always scoffed at the plummy tones of their neighbours. Now they have fresh ammunition, thanks to a scientist who has confirmed that Edinburgh folk are increasingly likely to sound like their English cousins.
fields.body:
Glaswegians have always scoffed at the plummy tones of their neighbours. Now they have fresh ammunition, thanks to a scientist who has confirmed that Edinburgh folk are increasingly likely to sound like their English cousins.

The influx of sassenachs into Scotland's capital has created a generation of schoolchildren who speak with an unmistakably English twang, says Jim Scobbie, who is researching the effect that different accents have on each other.

"The emphasis on the pronunciation of certain vowels is changing," explained Dr Scobbie, a research fellow in the department of speech and languages at Queen Margaret University College, Edinburgh.

"If a child is talking posh, they will elongate the vowel. Posh is more English and the one explanation for the growth in the use of these longer vowels is that the younger generation could be being influenced by the increase in the middle class English accents.

"There's a large immigrant population from England in Edinburgh now and of course that has an impact."

Dr Scobbie, who said he himself speaks with an "embarrassingly mild" Glaswegian accent, also believes that Estuary English - as spoken by the cast of EastEnders and occasionally Tony Blair - is influencing other Scots, with children replacing the "th" in words such as "with" with a "v" sound instead.

"The typical Scottish rolling R is almost gone these days," he said. "Some people still do it, but overall it tends to be much softer nowadays and may be disappearing altogether."

But he added that high profile Scots had helped to popularise traditional accents.

"These changes have been going on for hundreds of years, and are offset by the fact it's more acceptable to speak with a Scottish accent," he said.

webTitle: Detectives smash big gun running operation

fields.headline: Detectives smash big gun running operation
fields.standfirst: Special report: gun violence in Britain
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard smashed a gun running operation yesterday with the arrest of six people who were being questioned over an arms cache which included heavy machine guns, mortars and hand grenades.
fields.body:
Scotland Yard smashed a gun running operation yesterday with the arrest of six people who were being questioned over an arms cache which included heavy machine guns, mortars and hand grenades.

The seizure came after a chase across London and the discovery of a workshop equipped to repair and adapt an array of weaponry.

Detectives believe the guns and ammunition, which were manufactured in the US and are thought to have been imported from Europe, were intended for criminal gangs which specialise in drug dealing, contract killing and armed robbery.

It is not thought the seizure is terrorist related.

"The weapons were undoubtedly intended for criminals at the top of the tree, involved in professional crime," a detective said.

Armed officers began covert surveillance on a cemetery in Benfleet, Essex, on Tuesday afternoon, following an investigation by the Metropolitan police serious and organised crime command.

Two men were arrested as one allegedly tried to sell the other a machine gun for cash. Two accomplices who were watching from a Mercedes sped off when officers pounced.

They were followed and arrested after a chase across east London that ended when they were surrounded in Bethnal Green.

On Tuesday evening, armed officers raided a house in Woodford Green, Essex, recovering four heavy machine guns, a MP40 machine pistol, numerous hand grenades, ammunition, high explosive and mortars. Officers then went to another address in Essex, where they found a workshop for repairing and adapting firearms.

Six men were being questioned at different police stations in Essex and east London last night.

"This was an intelligence-led operation targeting individuals who we believe are involved in the trafficking of heavy weaponry in London," said Detective Chief Superintendent John Coles, who is in charge of the investigation.

"We believe we have recovered weapons, ammunition and explosives, which were intended to be sold to criminals who would use it in the commission of armed robberies, contract killings and drug related shootings."

Police believe drug gangs were likely customers, and will investigate whether the suppliers were linked to Yardie criminals in London.

The Met revealed in January that a network of unlicensed gun dealers had been linked to almost all the Yardie style killings which have blighted inner city areas in London, the West Midlands and Manchester, in recent years.

Police believe drug gangs were likely customers, and will investigate whether the suppliers were linked to Yardie criminals in London. The Met revealed in January that a network of unlicensed gun dealers had been linked to almost all the Yardie style killings which have blighted inner city areas in London, the West Midlands and Manchester, in recent years.

webTitle: Rural myths catch military connection in their net

fields.headline: Rural myths catch military connection in their net
fields.standfirst:
Causes Stories dismissed as rumours and xenophobia but one may be true

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Rumours, conspiracy theories, urban myths and allegations about foot and mouth are now spreading through Britain even faster than the disease itself. Most are immediately dismissible, several impossible to check, and at least one is being   investigated seriously by the authorities.
fields.body:
Rumours, conspiracy theories, urban myths and allegations about foot and mouth are now spreading through Britain even faster than the disease itself. Most are immediately dismissible, several impossible to check, and at least one is being investigated seriously by the authorities.

Cover up

Foot and mouth has been here months. Yesterday timber and railway sleeper dealers appeared on Radio 4's Today programme detailing calls from the Ministry of Agriculture before Christmas asking for the price of timber to burn foot and mouth diseased animals.

Fact: Staffordshire animal health office, part of Maff, rang round merchants in the autumn asking for quotes for timber for pyres as part of an annual contingency plan on how to deal with swine fever and foot and mouth outbreaks. This is a requirement of all EU countries. It happens every year.

Animal liberation

It is rumoured that animal lib activists have deliberately spread the disease because they are so dissatisfied with industrial farming.

Fact: The Hillside animal sanctuary near Norwich is Britain's leading animal sanctuary with more than 800 rescued farm animals. As a campaigning animal welfare organisation but with no history of militancy, several Hillside members went to Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland, in December to investigate the conditions animals were being kept in. However, they did not go into the pig farm. Following phone calls from farmers to the police alleging that Hillside members then went on to other farms and spread the disease, the sanctuary has been placed under a restriction order, and checked for signs of foot and mouth. None has been found.

Military meat

This theory centres on the fact that Ministry of Defence in Northumberland regularly imports cheap meat from countries round the world evading normal customs practices. It is said some of the meat - which may have carried the virus -was sold as pigswill to the farm at the centre of the outbreak.

Fact: This, or a version of it might be true, and is under investigation. Certainly the main theory that MAFF is working on is that infected imported meat found its way into pigswill that was not cooked properly and then caused the outbreak.

Porton Down

The story going the rounds is that that the substrain of the type O virus now in Britain is not the same as any that hasbeen found elsewhere in the world.

Fact: The Ministry of Agriculture says it is the same type and substrain. A spokesman at Porton Down, the biological and chemical defence section, said yesterday: "We have never worked on foot and mouth." Deliberate spread

One rumour in south-west England is that sheep dealers re-sold animals they knew were infected.

Fact: There is no evidence that dealers knew sheep were infected.

Immigration

It is said that illegal immigrants brought the virus with them, either on their clothing or in food, like dried meat.

Fact: No evidence whatever. "Pure xenophobia" according to the Ministry of Agriculture.

Vets and journalists

The myth is that reporters as well as vets and farmers who have been to many farms with foot and mouth have passed on the disaese.

Fact: Anyone in close contact with the disease could pass it on. Almost all cases have been directly linked to animal movements, or movement of vehicles or people between farms. Since the outbreak the most stringent disinfection regime has been operated and vets who have been close to infected animals have to wait three days before going on to another farm. Journalists are not allowed on infected farms.

Biological warfare

It is being said that foreign terrorists and specifically Saddam Hussein's agents have spread the disease.

Fact: It seems unlikely and would require someone collect the virus, incubate it, place it in aerosols, come to Britain and spray the virus into cattle or pig pens.

Wild animals

It is said that wild animals - starlings, hedgehogs, wild boar, deer and foxes - are spreading the disease and are all to be wiped out by SAS marksmen.

Fact: The chief vet has denied there is any connection between the spread of the disease and wild animals. Any bird feeding on a dead carcass could theoretically pick up the virus but it is extremely unlikely, because the carcasses are disinfected as soon as possible after death, and are not emitting any virus anyway. The military is keen to help with the outbreak but the Ministry of Defence has denied that the SAS is stalking wild boar in Essex or anyway else. Jim Scudamore, the chief vet, specifically ruled out trying to kill any wild animals because it was likely to disperse them, further increasing any chance of infection.

webTitle: Police to exhume body of Hanratty, the A6 killer

fields.headline: Police to exhume body of Hanratty, the A6 killer
fields.trailText: Police will exhume the body of James Hanratty today in an attempt to prove through DNA evidence whether he was guilty of the A6 murder.
fields.body:
Police will exhume the body of James Hanratty today in an attempt to prove through DNA evidence whether he was guilty of the A6 murder.

The move by Scotland Yard is aimed at resolving Britain's longest running case of alleged miscarriage of justice, which the criminal cases review commission has referred back to the court of appeal to consider new scientific evidence, including DNA.

The hearing is expected to take place later this year, possibly in September.

Hanratty, 25, was hanged in 1962 for murdering Michael Gregsten and raping his lover Valerie Storie, before shooting her and leaving her for dead. He had disturbed the pair in a field, his trial was told.

Scotland Yard officers will carry out the exhumation at Carpenders Park cemetery in Bushey, Hertfordshire, early today.

The remains of Hanratty's aunt, Annie Cunningham, are also to be exhumed, police said.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, had issued licences for the exhumations earlier this month.

Hanratty claimed that at the time of the murder, which took place in Deadman's Hill on the A6 in Bedfordshire, south of Bedford, he was 250 miles away in Rhyl, north Wales.

Campaigners for Hanratty have tried to prove that he was no more than a petty criminal.

Press Association

fields.headline: Marchioness findings due
fields.trailText: The captain of the dredger that collided with the Marchioness pleasure boat 11 years ago, with the loss of 51 lives, may be free to carry on serving as a ship's officer despite facing severe criticism in a public inquiry report due tomorrow.
fields.body:
The captain of the dredger that collided with the Marchioness pleasure boat 11 years ago, with the loss of 51 lives, may be free to carry on serving as a ship's officer despite facing severe criticism in a public inquiry report due tomorrow.

Captain Douglas Henderson, master of the Bowbelle at the time of the disaster in August 1989 on the Thames, could have been stripped of his master's certificate as a result of the public inquiry.

But the report on the tragedy is expected to draw back from making this recommendation.

Mr Henderson was tried in 1991 on a charge of failing to keep a proper lookout. The jury failed to reach a verdict, as did another jury at a second trial and he was acquitted. He is understood to be currently serving as a mate on a non-British vessel in north European waters.

Mr Henderson was one of a number of witnesses who gave evidence to Lord Justice Clarke's inquiry which was held at the end of last year following a 10-year campaign for a full investigation by survivors and relatives of those who died in the disaster.

The inquiry, expected to cost £6m, will finally establish the circumstances of the collision, including its exact location and the system of lookouts on both ships.

Steps have already been taken to improve safety on the Thames with the coastguard taking over search and rescue responsibilities on the river from next year. Lifeboats will also be stationed on the Thames for the first time from next January, when the Royal National Lifeboat Institution will establish three stations, at Gravesend, Tower Pier and Chiswick.

The river is busy with passenger traffic, with the government encouraging use of the water as an alternative to London's jammed roads, but "juggernaut" dredgers like the Bowbelle are no longer on the Thames.

Lord Justice Clarke also chaired an inquiry into the identification of the dead from the Marchioness after relatives discovered that the hands of some victims had been cut off for finger printing.

A separate report on this will also be published tomorrow.

webTitle: Six Finns who can spread Anfield fear for England

fields.headline: Six Finns who can spread Anfield fear for England
fields.trailText: The striker who made his name for Wycombe in the FA Cup earlier this month is well placed to comment on Finnish football after playing for VPS Vaasa between 1998 and 2000. Here he gives his insider's guide to the men who threaten England's World Cup hopes.
fields.body:
The striker who made his name for Wycombe in the FA Cup earlier this month is well placed to comment on Finnish football after playing for VPS Vaasa between 1998 and 2000. Here he gives his insider's guide to the men who threaten England's World Cup hopes.

Jarkko Wiss

I remember playing against Jarkko a few times and England will have to keep a close eye on him because he'll get into the box from midfield and is capable of scoring. He's shown that since he arrived at Stockport County. Jarkko's got good energy and he's a hard-working lad who can tackle and pass.

Shefki Kuqi

Shefki's a big, strong striker with a decent touch. He was among the leading scorers in Finland and the two goals he got for Stockport last weekend show he's finding his feet here. His aerial strength makes him a real threat. Shefki speaks Finnish with an accent because he was born in Kosovo.

Mikael Forssell

Mikael left HJK Helsinki for Chelsea not long after I arrived and it was big news out there. I could tell from the couple of times I saw him that he had good skill and technique and he's shown on loan at Crystal Palace this season that he has a big future. A far less physical striker than Shefki but very dangerous.

Petri Helin

Another Finn who has come to England, joining Second Division Luton Town. Petri's a right-back or right wing-back who's fit, strong and hard-working. He's not afraid to get forward but I seem to remember from his time at Jokerit that he's a more natural defender.

Jari Litmanen

Jari had left Finland before I got there but his profile in the country was huge and I saw him on plenty of commercials. Ice hockey is the No1 sport in Finland and the players are treated like gods, so for Jari to be maybe even bigger than some of them tells you how popular he is. His career at Ajax, Barcelona and now Liverpool has been followed very closely by the media.

Sami Hyypia

Sami wasn't as big as Jari in Finland but he was catching up by the time I left, having left Willem II Tilburg in Holland for Liverpool. I think his profile's got even bigger since. I don't know Sami personally but to me he epitomises what the Finns are about: they're hard-working guys who are far from prima donnas and they can certainly deal with the physical stuff.

fields.headline: A woman with a vision
fields.standfirst: Head of the government's children and young people's unit Althea Efunshile wants to see a society where young people have a valued voice, writes Linda Steele
fields.trailText: Head of the government's children and young people's unit Althea Efunshile wants to see a society where young people have a valued voice, writes Linda Steele.
fields.body:
You would think that a woman with two teenage children would have had quite enough of listening to young people. But not Althea Efunshile. The head of the government's children and young people's unit says she wants to listen more to young people. Indeed, she wants us all to. She wants nothing less than a cultural, societal shift.

The unit, she says, is "trying to change a culture of institutions, of government of local organisations". She wants "to change a culture in society, where the voice of young people is a valued voice and we are developing as citizens from an early age, so that they actually feel that they have a stake in society."

This, says Ms Efunshile, at one point, is her vision - although actually it is one of several for her and the unit set up last year. Her "vision for the service and what it might lead to is more joined-up services on the ground" because "that's where children fall between the gaps", she explains. (You might well wonder if the New Labour mission for social renewal, inclusion and civic responsibility, has produced more visions than Joan of Arc.)

And Ms Efunshile is, of course, onboard and on-message. But, while she's neither particularly demonstrative nor excitable, her intelligence and firm but friendly articulacy do suggest a woman who's not in the business of mouthing government platitudes because it's her job. The language may be inspirational New Labour but the commitment seems her own.

She has, she says, "a passion for improving the lives of children and young people". And she cites a history of doing just that, first as a teacher and then as a youth worker who worked her way up to one of the top jobs in children's services. Before, as south-east London Lewisham council's director of education, culture and lifelong learning, she oversaw a project where "disengaged" young people (think truants hanging round Lewisham's unlovely shopping mall and you might begin to get the picture) were "contacted by youth workers". A long-term programme, that included residentials, led to "demands on statutory agencies", a budget and youth conference run by young people, and an anti-racism pack, which participants saw as a big priority.

That kind of involvement - messy, unpredictable, complicated but exciting - is what she wants for the work of the unit and the local partnerships between the public, private and voluntary sectors, which will be spending the lion's share of the children's fund. "My idea of youth participation is about getting them to make decisions," she says.

This is clearly what she is hoping for from the youth advisory forum, announced today by prime minister Tony Blair and minister for young people, Paul Boateng. The forum will draw upon a group of up to 100 10- to 17-year-olds. It will be chaired by the rather older and abrasive Mr Boateng - let's hope the children are an assertive bunch - so that "the voice of young people will be directly relayed back into government. Because Paul Boateng, as the minister for youth, sees himself as the champion of youth across government," explains Ms Efunshile.

Not everyone who works with children, however, sees Mr Boateng in quite the same light. His role as minister in a Home Office dedicated to tackling Britain's "yob culture" has left some muttering that he would be better titled the minister for locking up young people.

Mr Boateng, to be fair, has at least been talking up the need to pay attention to young people. "I want to hear young people's voices across government live and clear. Our new advisory forum will, for the first time, bring children and young people to the centre of policy-making and development on decisions that directly affect their lives."

How much attention ministers will pay to their junior advisers remains to be seen. But Ms Efunshile points out, not entirely unreasonably, that consultation is not the same as agreeing to do everything you're asked to do. And she is also aware that it needs to be made clear that "boundaries" will be set, because "it's not fair to give young people the impression that whatever they say is going to happen will happen, because it's not mature and it's not what happens with any other group."

So, apart from lessons in realpolitik, what else is promised for youths? The unit's strategy, Tomorrow's Future: Building a Strategy for Children and Young People, has been published today. It is underpinned by "four strategic issues", says Ms Efunshile. These are: continually improving services; coordination and leadership (including coming up with an overarching youth strategy across central government); prevention, with a focus on local needs and that old favourite, the "bottom-up" approach; and making sure that services are "designed around the needs of children and young people", rather than fitting youths to the services.

The unit will be "outward focused", with some of its 35 or so employees - Ms Efunshile is looking to "augment" the number of staff - acting as links and development workers with the local partnerships. Part of its work will be publicising, partly via the web, "what works best", including good examples of how the children's fund is being used.

She wants to promote, largely through the children's fund, "a change, where resources are spent at the preventive stage, rather than waiting until young people are in crisis." And, aware of criticisms that this government is obsessed with novelty, leaving impoverished and adrift the fundamental services that underpin our welfare state, she adds: "It isn't just about additional resources for additional whizzy projects on the ground. It's also about influencing and impacting on mainstream services, so that mainstream services themselves are rethinking and refocusing how they use their resources and the shape of their services, and how they relate to each other."

The fact that the unit works across government, and that both the statutory sector and the voluntary sector have to be included in the local partnerships, should allay fears that local government is being sidelined, says Ms Efunshile. Specific concerns among social workers that Mr Boateng would boost the role of charities at the expense of social services won't be realised if she is to be believed.

But she warns that no one should assume their place at the table. The partnerships will need a "dialogue" and "a strategy for talking to young people" in order to get their tranche of £380m over three years, says Ms Efunshile. The unit will be "hard edged", with a close eye kept on outcomes - including reduced crime, health inequalities and truancy and improved educational performance.

Refreshingly, however, she is not after a quick fix. "With some of these things, you're not going to see changes overnight. There won't be unrealistic expectations placed on partnerships, in terms of objectives and measures and targets but we do want a focus in terms of what the children's fund will be doing."

And the outcomes Ms Efunshile most wants to see? Well, they are the grand visions of New Labour: improvements in the life chances of young people and the eradication of child poverty in 20 years. But she has her own personal wish and that's for "a changed culture, where the voice of young people is actually heard and is impacting on services at both a local and a government level".

"My idea of youth participation is about getting them to make decisions," she says. This is clearly what she is hoping for from the youth advisory forum, announced today by prime minister Tony Blair and minister for young people, Paul Boateng. The forum will draw upon a group of up to 100 10- to 17-year-olds. It will be chaired by the rather older and abrasive Mr Boateng - let's hope the children are an assertive bunch - so that "the voice of young people will be directly relayed back into government. Because Paul Boateng, as the minister for youth, sees himself as the champion of youth across government," explains Ms Efunshile. Not everyone who works with children, however, sees Mr Boateng in quite the same light. His role as minister in a Home Office dedicated to tackling Britain's "yob culture" has left some muttering that he would be better titled the minister for locking up young people. Mr Boateng, to be fair, has at least been talking up the need to pay attention to young people. "I want to hear young people's voices across government live and clear. Our new advisory forum will, for the first time, bring children and young people to the centre of policy-making and development on decisions that directly affect their lives." How much attention ministers will pay to their junior advisers remains to be seen. But Ms Efunshile points out, not entirely unreasonably, that consultation is not the same as agreeing to do everything you're asked to do. And she is also aware that it needs to be made clear that "boundaries" will be set, because "it's not fair to give young people the impression that whatever they say is going to happen will happen, because it's not mature and it's not what happens with any other group." So, apart from lessons in realpolitik, what else is promised for youths? The unit's strategy, Tomorrow's Future: Building a Strategy for Children and Young People, has been published today. It is underpinned by "four strategic issues", says Ms Efunshile. These are: continually improving services; coordination and leadership (including coming up with an overarching youth strategy across central government); prevention, with a focus on local needs and that old favourite, the "bottom-up" approach; and making sure that services are "designed around the needs of children and young people", rather than fitting youths to the services. The unit will be "outward focused", with some of its 35 or so employees - Ms Efunshile is looking to "augment" the number of staff - acting as links and development workers with the local partnerships. Part of its work will be publicising, partly via the web, "what works best", including good examples of how the children's fund is being used. She wants to promote, largely through the children's fund, "a change, where resources are spent at the preventive stage, rather than waiting until young people are in crisis." And, aware of criticisms that this government is obsessed with novelty, leaving impoverished and adrift the fundamental services that underpin our welfare state, she adds: "It isn't just about additional resources for additional whizzy projects on the ground. It's also about influencing and impacting on mainstream services, so that mainstream services themselves are rethinking and refocusing how they use their resources and the shape of their services, and how they relate to each other." The fact that the unit works across government, and that both the statutory sector and the voluntary sector have to be included in the local partnerships, should allay fears that local government is being sidelined, says Ms Efunshile. Specific concerns among social workers that Mr Boateng would boost the role of charities at the expense of social services won't be realised if she is to be believed. But she warns that no one should assume their place at the table. The partnerships will need a "dialogue" and "a strategy for talking to young people" in order to get their tranche of £380m over three years, says Ms Efunshile. The unit will be "hard edged", with a close eye kept on outcomes - including reduced crime, health inequalities and truancy and improved educational performance. Refreshingly, however, she is not after a quick fix. "With some of these things, you're not going to see changes overnight. There won't be unrealistic expectations placed on partnerships, in terms of objectives and measures and targets but we do want a focus in terms of what the children's fund will be doing." And the outcomes Ms Efunshile most wants to see? Well, they are the grand visions of New Labour: improvements in the life chances of young people and the eradication of child poverty in 20 years. But she has her own personal wish and that's for "a changed culture, where the voice of young people is actually heard and is impacting on services at both a local and a government level".

webTitle: Government to launch 'safe houses' for runaways

fields.headline: Government to launch 'safe houses' for runaways
fields.trailText: A national network of "safe houses" to accommodate the thousands of young people under the age of 16 who run away from home is to be created under proposals outlined by the government.
fields.body:
A national network of "safe houses" to accommodate the thousands of young people under the age of 16 who run away from home is to be created under proposals outlined by the government.

The idea is one a series of social exclusion unit initiatives aimed at stepping up provision for the 77,000 youngsters who flee family problems, bullying or drug problems each year.

The government admits there is inadequate support for most runaways, who are given little help in tackling the problems which made them run away.

The problems have been exacerbated by the closure of refuges for young people in Leeds, London and Cardiff - now there is just one, in central London, which provides just five places.

The unit also proposes setting up teams of special advisers to counsel runaways, and drawing up a national runaways strategy to drive up standards of services across the country.

Launching the report, the prime minister, Tony Blair, said better ways had to be found of tackling the issue of runaways: "We have to make it less likely that young people run away in the first place - and if they do run, ensure their immediate safety."

The report says although most young people who leave home do so only briefly, a quarter sleep rough and one in 14 survive through begging, drug dealing and prostitution.

Ian Sparks, chief executive of the Children's Society, said: "It means that in future years, these children will have safe alternatives to living on the streets, being put at risk of dangerous and predatory adults, or being exposed to drugs.

"This initiative opens a new era of protection for isolated, unsupported and frightened children at risk on the streets."

Madeline Ismach, director of National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children London, said: "We need to stress that it's also very important to work with young people to prevent them running away in the first place."

The proposals are contained in a consultation paper, Young Runaways. Consultation finishes on 22 June.

webTitle: 'Government not doing enough to tackle social exclusion'

fields.headline: 'Government not doing enough to tackle social exclusion'
fields.trailText: Poverty experts have cast doubt on an upbeat report from the Social Exclusion Unit which claims that the government is on course to tackle social exclusion.
fields.body:
Poverty experts have cast doubt on an upbeat report from the Social Exclusion Unit which claims that the government is on course to tackle social exclusion.

The report, Preventing Poverty, sets out a number of key results including a fall in rough sleepers, school expulsions, teenage pregnancies and young people out of work, as evidence that efforts to tackle deprivation were working.

Prime minister Tony Blair, in a foreword to the report, says "the early results are impressive" and formed a "new basis for regeneration of our poorest neighbourhoods".

But poverty experts were sceptical. Ruth Levitas, reader in sociology at the University of Bristol, said: "The only way you can really tackle social exclusion is a major reduction in inequalities and the only way you do that is major redistribution.

"They are beginning to do that but it is not nearly enough. The redistributive effect of the budget was tiny."

She added: "Getting people into work does not necessarily lift them out of poverty. If you think about social inclusion being the ability to participate in social activities as opposed to getting into work then biggest barrier to is poverty."

Key results picked out by the report include:
 A fall in the number of rough sleepers by more than a third between 1998 and 200;
 A 15% cut between 1998 and 1999 in the number of young people not in education, employment and training;
 An increase from 16% to 31% in teenage parents in training, education or employment;
 A drop in school exclusions of nearly a fifth between 1997 and 1999.

Peter Lee, lecturer at the Centre of Urban and Regional Studies at the University of Birmingham, said: "There is a danger with government policies that the economically inactive are being trapped within communities.

"There is a lack of understanding about the relationship between the housing and employment markets. If that relationship is not understood fully people will just leave targeted areas, if they get a job leaving the area untouched."

John Hills, director of the Centre for the Analysis of Social Exclusion, welcomed the government's anti poverty measures, but pointed out that their effects were too early to gauge.

"The government can claim that it has introduced measures which should tackle social exclusion," he said, "but it will be some time before we really see the effect of that on the ground and longer still before we see the effects of that on."

He added: "They certainly seem to be moving in all the right areas. The question is whether they are doing enough. The latest information on income distribution relates to Labour second year in office and that at that point relative poverty was still rising."

Aaron Cahill, regeneration policy officer at the National Housing Federation, said: "It is vital that the rising curve of resources for neighbourhood renewal, such as the Neighbourhood Renewal Fund and Sure Start, is continued. If it isn't, we're looking at little less than a boom and bust approach to resourcing social inclusion.

"The government itself acknowledges that approaches to neighbourhood renewal needs patience, commitment and resources. The next spending review will be the test of how serious this government - if re-elected - is about this agenda."

fields.headline: Managers back Eriksson
fields.trailText: England's club managers have shown their support for Sven-Goran Eriksson by making him honourary president of the League Managers' Association.
fields.body:
England's club managers have shown their support for Sven-Goran Eriksson by making him honourary president of the League Managers' Association.

The LMA made no secret of its disapproval of Eriksson's appointment as the first foreign coach of the national team after its own recommendations to the Football Association were ignored.

But the LMA chief executive John Barnwell, backed by his members, said: "We have to concede that club managers have perhaps not always given the England coach as much co-operation as they might have done. I hope that is a thing of the past. Sven can be assured of our full assistance and co-operation."

England Under-21s have called up Charlton's Paul Konchesky and the West Ham goalkeeper Stephen Bywater to the squad for the European Championship qualifier with Finland at Oakwell on Friday .

The Leeds striker Alan Smith has pledged his future to the club by signing a five-year contract worth £4.2m, picking up a four-fold increase on his previous £4,000-per-week salary.

The Wimbledon manager Terry Burton has been given a two-match touchline ban and a £2,000 fine by an FA disciplinary committee for comments he made to a linesman.

Leicester City have completed the signing of the Norwich City utility player Lee Marshall in a £600,000 deal.

Everton have signed Roma's central defender Alessandro Zamperini on a two-month trial after the 18-year-old impressed in 76 minutes' reserve-team action on Monday.

Swansea are inviting a group of Kenyans to the Vetch Field to perform a voodoo dance after Uri Geller said there were "black spirits" at the ground.

webTitle: Warm-up game leaves Pakistan frozen out

fields.headline: Warm-up game leaves Pakistan frozen out
fields.standfirst: Connell 44, Bhutia 60, Preece 90
fields.trailText: The surroundings may have bordered on the surreal, with snow swirling down from the Pennines on a freezing wind, but history was made here last night as Pakistan's national team played their first ever game in this country.
fields.body:
The surroundings may have bordered on the surreal, with snow swirling down from the Pennines on a freezing wind, but history was made here last night as Pakistan's national team played their first ever game in this country.

The tourists are more accustomed to the oppressive heat of their training camp in Islamabad, a city basking in 30C temperatures and 43% humidity today. Once recovered from this dose of winter chill, they will play Coventry City on Sunday before their English coach John Layton attempts to negotiate safe passage through a World Cup qualifying group which includes Thailand, Sri Lanka and Lebanon.

Qualification remains unlikely yet the enthusiasm is there to be tapped; last night's match, played as part of Bury's Kick Racism Out of Football campaign, was televised live in Pakistan to an estimated audience of 5m.

In anticipation of the fixture, the Second Division club distributed leaflets throughout Asian communities from Oldham to Bradford. The traditional hamburger joints were replaced with takeaway curry stalls while the Pakistani crescent moon and star fluttered in the stands.

"We are hoping that the Asian people who came to see their national team will see what a safe, friendly environment there is here at Bury and will come again," said the Shakers' chairman Terry Robinson. Bury took their first step along that road last sea son when they became the first British club to sign an Asian player - the Indian international Baichung Bhutia. The striker, a star to rival David Beckham in his homeland, was a whirl of clever spins and neat passes on the Gigg Lane quagmire.

"It will be a slow process attracting Asian support because they do not have a strong affinity with football," added Robinson, "but we feel this is a worthwhile exercise."

Quite what the millions watching back in Pakistan made of the defeat remains a mystery. Pakistan are currently ranked 191st out of 203 in the world. From such minnow status they look up to the footballing giants of Djibouti and the Seychelles while hardly scoffing at the impudence of lowly Nicaragua and Guam.

Last night they were made to look as ordinary as that sounds by a Shakers XI of barely reserve-team strength. With cricket Pakistan's main sport, the tourists have a smaller pool of talent to draw on than the Second Division club.

Yet their style showed flashes of class while they struggled to come to terms with the conditions. Zafar Majeed and Gohar Zaman were nimble down either flank and Mohammad Riaz, marauding forward from midfield, missed the best chance of a bad-tempered first half before Lee Connell speared Bury ahead. Bhutia bundled home Bury's second and, by the time the player-manager Andy Preece curled an injury-time third, Pakistan were betraying heavy legs as the 741 "away" fans in the 1,292 crowd continued their boisterous party.

"Football is only played in four or five centres, but every one has heard of the likes of Beckham and Michael Owen," said the tourists' assistant coach Akhtar Mohy-ud-Din.

"What we need is a more competitive structure because at the moment we only have two competitions - the President's Cup and the National Championship. There are 24 teams in each tournament, but the events are only held over a period of 20 days." At least the grassroots appear to be quietly taking hold; Pakistan's Under-19s recently beat India for the first time in over 40 years. There were enough glimpses here to suggest a footballing future.

Bury (3-4-1-2): Garner; Nelson, Swailes, Halford; James (Gunby, 70min), Connell, Jarrett, Peyron; Bhutia; Preece, Littlejohn (Martin, 64).

Pakistan (4-4-2): Jaffar Khan; Asad Ullah (Amir Shahzad, 66), Sarfraz Rasoop (Amir Riaz, 90), Asghar Mohammad, Ibsar Ullah; Gohar Zaman, Mohammad Riaz (Barbar Mehmood, 82), Hasoon Yousuf, Zafar Majeed (Attiq-ur-Rehmmon, 59); Mohammad Asshad, Mohammad Essa.

Referee: S Mathieson.
