webTitle: Does loss of power mean the death of the town hall?

fields.headline: Does loss of power mean the death of the town hall?
fields.standfirst: Roy Hattersley visits Birmingham - home of old, and new, civic virtues - to examine the health of local government
fields.trailText: Roy Hattersley visits Birmingham - home of old, and new, civic virtues - to examine the health of local government.
fields.body:
Modern local government began in Birmingham when the mayor and corporation bought the town gasworks and water company and used the profit from light and heat to rebuild the crumbling sewers. The mayor was Joseph Chamberlain and the corporation believed in his Civic Gospel of Improvement. For more than a hundred years, councillors of England's second city continued to act with what Chamberlain called "sagacious audacity" - which to them meant a continual increase in expenditure and activity.

At the height of its powers, the City of Birmingham owned hospitals, a bus and tramway company, more houses than any other landlord in the West Midlands, and a bank. It was the statutory police authority, managed what were wrongly called state schools, paid "relief" to the sick and unemployed and subsidised amenities of its own choice - parks, concert halls, allotments and museums - from rates which it levied at its own discretion. Birmingham councillors were not universally loved, but they were respected as men and women of authority.

Ever since the days of Joe Chamberlain's Liberal caucus, party politics has been an essential ingredient in Birmingham local government. Labour has been in tight control for 17 years. Now there are 67 Labour councillors, 28 Conservative and 18 Liberals. There are also five members of Justice, a group of Muslims who demand "freedom for Kashmir". Whatever relevance their policy has to municipal government, they reflect the ethnic pattern of the city's population. The 1991 census identified 13.5% of the population as Asian. Half were of Pakistani origin.

It is fashionable to suggest that strict party discipline has brought the council into disrepute. Sir Richard Knowles, Labour leader for 10 years, has a different explanation: "We have lost popularity because we have lost power." Whatever the reason for their disenchantment, the people of Birmingham are not enthused by municipal politics. The turnout in the last local election was 28%. The public consultation which preceded the city budget attracted audiences of five in Liberal Yardley and 20 in Tory Sutton Coldfield.

None of the meetings produced an outcry against the abandonment of, or reduction in, the caring services. The closure of day centres provoked barely a murmur of protest. Perhaps Birmingham has accepted the view of Sir Michael Lyons, Birmingham's chief executive and once a Labour councillor: "What the council is expected to do is just not sustainable on present resources." Or it may be that the people no longer expect local government to meet their real needs.

Birmingham local government is still big business. Its annual budget is more than £2bn. Some 43,000 employees crowd its payroll. But it has lost many of the powers which directly affect the lives and welfare of its citizens. Some council services were nationalised by Labour. Others were privatised by Conservatives. Both parties hedged about council powers with so many regulations that, over great areas of policy, local government became no more than an agent of Whitehall and Westminster. Ministers call the tune because they pay the piper. Birmingham raises 11% of its revenue from council tax. The Treasury provides 63%. That equation makes independence impossible.

Education is the one remaining service which gives city councils a popular appeal. The appearance of power deceives. "In reality," says Albert Bore, the council leader, "we are no longer an education authority. We neither directly provide the service nor set the standards".

Professor Tim Brighouse, the chief education officer, makes the same point in less apocalyptic language. "It is our duty to secure the provision of an education service. But it is a moot point how much we provide ourselves". The government's statement on The Role and Function of Local Education Authorities does not spare municipal feelings. It is not the authority's "role to run or intervene in schools".

Sir Richard believes that we are witnessing "the slow death of local government". Mr Bore insists that councils still have a meaningful role. "But it is not the role we have played over the last 100 years." Why, he asks, "do we have to be a direct provider of services? Once there was nobody else around. Now there is. We can engage others to provide what we want". He has a new civic gospel to replace what he calls, without noticeable nostalgia, "50 years of municipal benevolence". In pursuit of its objective he is promoting the biggest voluntary abdication of power in municipal history.

Radical

If all goes to plan, by 2002 Birmingham will have privatised its meals-on-wheels and half of its home-care service, transferred its elderly people's homes to a trust and split the direct labour department into four separate - and almost certainly privately owned - operations. More radical still, the entire stock of corporation houses (88,000 in all) will have been given away - together with their debts, which exceed £650m.

The extent of the Labour leader's aspiration has alarmed even David Roy, the leader of the council's Conservative minority. He neither balks at the privatisation of welfare services nor bridles at what amounts to the closure of the direct labour department, and he believes that the council employs "far too many people for the work we now do". But he "feels profoundly uncomfortable about selling all the houses". John Hemming, the Liberal leader, goes even further in his opposition to what he describes as "the contract culture" - the mistaken belief that municipal enterprise is inherently inefficient. From the luxury of opposition he argues that the council should keep the housing stock but run it more efficiently.

Improved efficiency, rather than greater democracy, was the object of Margaret Thatcher's local government reforms. Market forces were to exert their influence on councils through a system of compulsory competitive tendering which required, in effect, more and more services to be handed to private enterprise. Labour replaced competitive tendering with an obligation for councils to obtain "best value" - without always setting out the criteria against which best value is judged.

The scheme is now to be extended by what are known as public service agreements. Birmingham is negotiating with the government to determine 12 specific targets. They range from improving primary school results to reducing the numbers of domestic burglaries. A successful PSA, combined with what is called a best performance plan, will earn the city an extra grant of something like £28m. It will also give Whitehall a new influence over Birmingham policy. But the council shows little sign of resenting or rejecting Whitehall's ever increasing authority. The solution it proposes to the escalating housing crisis is a negotiated deal with central government built on the promise to reduce the city's powers.

Until the mid-seventies, Whitehall frantically encouraged council house building with lavish subsidies. Then the mood changed. Margaret Thatcher was not only against council house building, she was the enemy of "the council house culture". In the most socially significant decision of her premiership, she gave municipal tenants the "right to buy". Seventy five thousand Birmingham families took up the offer. The best properties were sold first and the worst were not sold at all. The council was left with the oldest and most dilapidated houses - and debts of £650m.

Estimates of how much it will cost to rehabilitate the housing stock vary from £1bn to £4bn. This year Birmingham received £80m from the housing investment programme. Almost half will be used to subsidise private properties. "As things now stand," says Mr Bore, knowing that he is stating the obvious, "the situation gets worse not better". His remedy - the sale of the whole housing stock - may work. Tony Blair is as opposed to council tenancy as Margaret Thatcher once was. Birmingham hopes that the government will clear its housing debt as the price of ending municipal dependency.

A year ago, after pressure from dissatisfied tenants, 3,000 properties on the Lea Bank estate were transferred to the ownership of an independent trust. Mr Bore plans to set up 12 more registered social landlords and divide the housing stock between them, assuming that tenant ballots endorse the change of ownership. The results of the polls are not in much doubt. The choice will lie between a pound a week rent increase linked to a programme of repair and renovation and a rent freeze which guarantees continued dilapidation. Seventy five per cent of tenants receive housing benefit. They can vote for a rent increase in the knowledge that it will be paid by the government.

Birmingham's Labour left argues that the government should clear the debt and leave the houses in council ownership. Perhaps it should. But the only hope of the Treasury paying off the debt lies in the council abandoning its role as landlord. Mr Bore could reluctantly accept the end of municipal tenancy as inevitable. But he endorses the government's determination to move the ownership of low-cost, rented houses from corporations to independent trusts. He has "thought very carefully" about the merits of council tenancy and decided that it "does not produce a proper social mix". His socialist heresy does not end there. Mr Bore has come to the conclusion that Birmingham's direct labour department is, by its nature, uncompetitive.

Sir Michael describes the soon-to-be privatised department as "always too big for an in-house operation" and "the victim of long-term poor management". That is only part of the story. Too often decisions have been taken in the interests of its employees rather than its customers - the people of Birmingham. Every estate echoes with unverifiable stories of petty fraud - repairs recorded as completed but not done. But the real problem is more fundamental. The public works department will lose £8.5m this year, and an estimated £14m next, because the council refused to accept the disciplines required for commercial survival.

Right-to-buy legislation reduced Birmingham housing stock by almost half. So, to protect the direct labour workforce, the council increased its repair and maintenance programme to a level which was neither affordable nor sustainable. Then the government insisted that all local authority contracts should be won by competitive tender. The direct labour department bid for its traditional work at hugely optimistic prices. A private builder who made such errors would have gone out of business within a year.

So would a privately owned care home that accepted the wage levels and conditions of service which the unions have negotiated with Birmingham council. Care assistants working for the social services department are paid double time and given a day's holiday in lieu if they work on Sunday. Staff who telephone in sick on Sunday morning receive the same compensation for "working" unsocial hours. The corporation cannot afford, but dare not abandon, such largesse. A private company will, the theory goes, reduce labour costs in ways no council could contemplate. In Birmingham, the civic ethic now embraces the disciplines of the market.

The enterprise culture was imposed on schools when "local management" forced the education authorities to compete against private providers for the supply of everything from exercise books to accountancy. Prof Brighouse is gratified by how little advantage Birmingham's headteachers have taken of the new freedom. He ought not to be surprised. The revival in the city's education system is, at least in part, the product of his six years in the city. Prof Brighouse describes his job, crushed between David Blunkett's increasingly detailed demands and the growing autonomy of individual schools, as "looking down the wrong end of a telescope at a Swiss watch with a spanner in my hand" - which does not suggest enthusiasm for the new regime. Labouring under that disadvantage, he has transformed Birmingham's education.

In his last major act as council leader, Sir Richard commissioned Ted Wragg of Exeter University to head an enquiry into "the present and future needs of education in Birmingham". It was a courageous decision. Sir Richard knew that the council's young Turks blamed him for a reduction in the education budget to £70m below the standard spending assessment, the government's estimate of what the city needed to invest in the future. The Wragg report's first recommendation was that "the council should give education top priority and appropriate standing". When the time came to appoint a new chief officer, Prof Brighouse seemed the right man to lead the renaissance. Education spending rose to £20m above the spending assessment. Improved examination results moved the city from virtually the bottom to a third of the way up the national league tables. No one is sure which has had the greater effect - money or Prof Brighouse's quirky but dynamic personality.

Education, once the city's neglected service, now pioneers new methods of promoting literacy and numeracy - including the University of the First Age, which offers extra teaching for 11 to 15-year-olds in conditions they find congenial rather than constraining. More important, at a time when teachers feel underpaid and undervalued, Prof Brighouse has lifted staff-room morale. His open antagonism to Chris Woodhead, the hugely disliked former chief inspector of schools, helped. So did his successful libel action against John Patten (a brief, but greatly despised, secretary of state) and the decision to donate his damages to school improvements. But it was the way in which he spent his early weeks in the job that won his spurs. He visited schools and talked to teachers. Even within its modern limitation, local government works best when it fulfils its historic destiny to be personal and intimate.

New civic gospel

.Prof Brighouse has made "partnership" with the government work. It is a special use of the word since one of the partners dictates how the other will behave. A white paper, Modern Local Government, leaves no doubt which of the partners is in charge. "There is no future in the old model of councils trying to plan and run most services". Instead they will be required "to promote the economic, social and environmental wellbeing of their areas". Birmingham has grasped - perhaps it even anticipated - one element in that stern injunction and elevated it to a new civic gospel. The idea that the corporation should actively encourage commercial development came upon the council gradually and was accepted by some councillors reluctantly and by others not at all.

Twenty-five years ago, in a contest which was more about prestige than prosperity, Birmingham beat London in the race to become home to the National Exhibition Centre. Its success was never in doubt. But, situated on the southern boundary, the NEC has not made much of a contribution to the city's economy. It was valued as a status symbol. At one meeting, where the triumph over London was discussed, the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra was offered as another example of provincial superiority. Everybody agreed that it needed a new concert hall. Nobody could think of a way to raise the money.

Someone suggested an approach to the European Community. Initial enquiries suggested that, although the regional development fund would not invest in a concert hall, it might provide money for something bigger and better. The result was the International Convention Centre in which the development fund invested £49.7m. The chamber of commerce and the local CBI thought it could be built next to, or as an extension of, the Exhibition Centre. But the council wanted it in the city centre. While Birmingham was still negotiating with Brussels, the old Victorian concert hall - not half a mile from Chamberlain Square and the town hall - burned down. The city centre was transformed. Almost a third of the council registered the Labour group complaint that Sir Richard was wasting time and money which should have been devoted to education.

The convention centre whetted the council's appetite for commercial development. Over 15 years the EU invested another £175m on tearing the city apart and putting it back together again, as well as more than £100m in social fund programmes for neighbourhood regeneration. The National Indoor Arena was built next to the ICC. The city took a third share in a Hyatt hotel which was thought necessary to accommodate the expected flood of visitors. Since then hotel building has become a Birmingham growth industry. Few pumps have ever been primed so successfully. Brindley Place and the associated restoration of the canal basin is now a civic showpiece of shops and offices. Seven thousand new jobs have been created in the area, as many as there will be at Rover's Longbridge factory in 2002.

The city's commitment to urban regeneration came to practical life in the spring of 1988 at a meeting between representatives of national and local government, business and the various planning professions. It was held at Highbury, once the home of the Chamberlains - a venue which was either prophetic or paradoxical depending on whether the new policy is regarded as a continuation of or a break with Birmingham's municipal tradition. From then on all plans for city generation were called "Highbury". The stated purpose of Highbury was "to explore the relationship between economic activity and investment and the physical environment". The council undertook to create the physical conditions for commercial growth in the city centre. Whether all the participants realised it or not, the civic gospel was taking on an economic dimension.

The results have been a spectacular success for local government as "facilitator" rather than provider. Three potential developers - Hammersons, Henderson's and Land Securities - competed with each other for planning permission to regenerate part of the old Bull Ring. The council persuaded them to come together in a partnership which will create 8,000 new jobs. The Alliance consortium, as it is now called, is part of the massive regeneration initiative in which the city council "brokers" partnerships between the private and public sectors. From the old GPO sorting office, which has become a vast shopping mall, to Fort Dunlop which now advertises "hotels, sports, eating, shops", Birmingham's economy is changing. The 200,000 jobs which were lost between 1975 and 1985 (more than in Scotland and Wales combined) are gradually being replaced as service industries take over from manufacturing. The council - or at least its leader - is changing to accommodate the new world.

Mr Bore's enthusiasm is instinctive. He is a technocrat by profession and, despite his leftwing past, a tycoon by temperament. Ironically, the Liberal and Conservative council leaders are beginning - despite their business backgrounds - to express fears that too much municipal time and effort is being spent on the city centre at the rest of Birmingham's expense. The Labour group has never disguised its doubts. Last May, Mr Bore was re-elected leader by a majority of one vote. The nature of the challenge that all but unseated him was confirmed by the quality of the near successful pretender. No one thought that Kevin Stacey had more ability than Mr Bore - just that he was different.

The dissatisfaction may be diminished by the publication of A New Partnership for Governance, a consultation paper on the future of local government in Birmingham which addresses old problems in new language. The determination "to tackle the deep seated problems of social exclusion" are an echo of Joe Chamberlain's belief that "an extension of the functions and authority" of Birmingham corporation would assist in "equalising the conditions of men". In common with the mood of the moment, Birmingham believes that "social exclusion is about much more than just material deprivation or lack of work and income".

That is not a recently acquired opinion. Long before such theories were fashionable, Birmingham was forming neighbourhood councils to provide a forum for popular discussion and dissent. Two years ago, a democracy commission, under the chairmanship of Sir Adrian Cadbury, ex amined ways of ensuring "greater democratic participation" in the city's affairs. A New Partnership for Governance is the extension of the same objective. It invites comments on everything from the way in which the neighbourhood renewal fund - planned to spend £44m in Birmingham in the next three years - should best be used, to the desirability of "greater use of referendums in making local decisions". It refers, in passing, to the national government's plans for greater local democracy. Birmingham has never thought it necessary to accept anyone else's advice.

Birmingham will soon have to decide if it is to be led by a directly elected executive mayor - one of several options which the Local Government Act requires it to consider. It could choose an elected council leader supported either by a cabinet or a council manager. Only a mayor will satisfy Birmingham's civic pride. England's second city will want to elect the first provincial executive mayor. The ghost of Joe Chamberlain still haunts the council chamber.

Cynics assume that Mr Bore hopes for the job. He is too intelligent to assume that, with his council record, he can win the Labour nomination. His support for an executive mayor is more political than personal, for he believes that he or she "would give a direction to activity which a leader cannot provide". Sir Michael, the chief executive, makes the same point in a less metaphysical and more critical form. "The idea of electing a mayor scores highly if you want to run the council like a business. It scores badly if the council is to be democratic local government". Running the council like a business is an increasingly popular notion in Whitehall as well as in Birmingham.

Businesses are, at least theoretically, unpolitical institutions and critics of the executive mayor idea suspect that it is intended to take party politics out of local government. Birmingham may become the testing ground for the idea that a man or woman without an acknowledged ideology is more likely to meet a city's needs than councillors who are elected on the party ticket. The bookmakers' favourite to become Birmingham's first mayor is Carl Chinn, a lecturer in community history, star of local radio and once a bookmaker himself. He stood in the 1983 general election as an independent in order to draw attention to what he regarded as discrimination against the turf accountant's trade. Apart from a couple of years in the Social Democratic party he has no political experience. That, and his high profile, make him, on some people's calculation, the man most fitted to lead England's second city when the new municipal constitution is in place.

Behind closed doors

Birmingham has already embraced half of the white paper's local government reforms. Departmental committees (in which members of all parties participated) have been replaced by a "cabinet system", in which an executive runs the city. The new system has irritated Labour traditionalists and infuriated Liberals and Conservatives who feel excluded from city management. The government's enthusiasm for municipal cabinets is based on its determination to end the system in which decisions were "taken behind closed doors by political groups, or even by small groups of key people within the majority party". In Birmingham, cabinets have produced exactly that result.

In other councils, the cabinet includes members of all parties. Not in Birmingham. Other cities allow journalists to attend cabinet meetings. Birmingham does not. The logic of the "scrutiny committees", which examine the performance of each department, requires them to be chaired by opposition members. In Birmingham they come from the majority Labour group. Undisputed power does not seem to have enthused every Labour council for the municipal task. Anita Ward, the majority whip, is examining the practicality and legality of "fining" absentees from council meetings by reducing their annual honorariums.

That is a sad commentary on a system which too often focuses more on arguments about council perks than the great issues of municipal government. Birmingham voters are clearly dubious about the value of local government. If the councillors themselves have doubts about the point of attending the council meetings, the whole system is in danger of death by neglect - at least in the great once all powerful cities where what we think of as local government was born.

Birmingham Facts & figures

 Granted city status in 1889

 Population around 1,013,400

 Ethnic minorities form 21.5% of population with Pakistanis forming the largest single ethnic minority group (1991 census)

 In February, seasonally adjusted unemployment figure stood at 34,162

 Birmingham has biggest housing department in England and Wales, managing 88,000 council houses

 State education was pioneered in Birmingham in the 1850s and there are now three universities and more than 450 schools in the city

 Birmingham has the largest public lending library in Europe

 Of the 11 constituencies that serve Birmingham, 10 are held by Labour MPs and one by the Conservatives

Birmingham councillors were not universally loved, but they were respected as men and women of authority. Ever since the days of Joe Chamberlain's Liberal caucus, party politics has been an essential ingredient in Birmingham local government. Labour has been in tight control for 17 years. Now there are 67 Labour councillors, 28 Conservative and 18 Liberals. There are also five members of Justice, a group of Muslims who demand "freedom for Kashmir". Whatever relevance their policy has to municipal government, they reflect the ethnic pattern of the city's population. The 1991 census identified 13.5% of the population as Asian. Half were of Pakistani origin. It is fashionable to suggest that strict party discipline has brought the council into disrepute. Sir Richard Knowles, Labour leader for 10 years, has a different explanation: "We have lost popularity because we have lost power." Whatever the reason for their disenchantment, the people of Birmingham are not enthused by municipal politics. The turnout in the last local election was 28%. The public consultation which preceded the city budget attracted audiences of five in Liberal Yardley and 20 in Tory Sutton Coldfield. None of the meetings produced an outcry against the abandonment of, or reduction in, the caring services. The closure of day centres provoked barely a murmur of protest. It could choose an elected council leader supported either by a cabinet or a council manager. Only a mayor will satisfy Birmingham's civic pride. England's second city will want to elect the first provincial executive mayor. The ghost of Joe Chamberlain still haunts the council chamber. Cynics assume that Mr Bore hopes for the job. He is too intelligent to assume that, with his council record, he can win the Labour nomination. His support for an executive mayor is more political than personal, for he believes that he or she "would give a direction to activity which a leader cannot provide". Sir Michael, the chief executive, makes the same point in a less metaphysical and more critical form. "The idea of electing a mayor scores highly if you want to run the council like a business. It scores badly if the council is to be democratic local government". Running the council like a business is an increasingly popular notion in Whitehall as well as in Birmingham. Businesses are, at least theoretically, unpolitical institutions and critics of the executive mayor idea suspect that it is intended to take party politics out of local government. Birmingham may become the testing ground for the idea that a man or woman without an acknowledged ideology is more likely to meet a city's needs than councillors who are elected on the party ticket. The bookmakers' favourite to become Birmingham's first mayor is Carl Chinn, a lecturer in community history, star of local radio and once a bookmaker himself. He stood in the 1983 general election as an independent in order to draw attention to what he regarded as discrimination against the turf accountant's trade. Apart from a couple of years in the Social Democratic party he has no political experience. That, and his high profile, make him, on some people's calculation, the man most fitted to lead England's second city when the new municipal constitution is in place. Behind closed doors Birmingham has already embraced half of the white paper's local government reforms. Departmental committees (in which members of all parties participated) have been replaced by a "cabinet system", in which an executive runs the city. The new system has irritated Labour traditionalists and infuriated Liberals and Conservatives who feel excluded from city management. The government's enthusiasm for municipal cabinets is based on its determination to end the system in which decisions were "taken behind closed doors by political groups, or even by small groups of key people within the majority party". In Birmingham, cabinets have produced exactly that result. In other councils, the cabinet includes members of all parties. Not in Birmingham. Other cities allow journalists to attend cabinet meetings. Birmingham does not. The logic of the "scrutiny committees", which examine the performance of each department, requires them to be chaired by opposition members. In Birmingham they come from the majority Labour group. Undisputed power does not seem to have enthused every Labour council for the municipal task. Anita Ward, the majority whip, is examining the practicality and legality of "fining" absentees from council meetings by reducing their annual honorariums. That is a sad commentary on a system which too often focuses more on arguments about council perks than the great issues of municipal government. Birmingham voters are clearly dubious about the value of local government. If the councillors themselves have doubts about the point of attending the council meetings, the whole system is in danger of death by neglect - at least in the great once all powerful cities where what we think of as local government was born. webTitle: Ferdinand and Gerrard offer cures for old English frailties

fields.headline: Ferdinand and Gerrard offer cures for old English frailties
fields.trailText: For more than 50 years the underlying flaw in so many England teams has been the regularity with which the ball is given away. It was as true during last summer's European Championship as it was when Hungary won 6-3 at Wembley in 1953.
fields.body:
For more than 50 years the underlying flaw in so many England teams has been the regularity with which the ball is given away. It was as true during last summer's European Championship as it was when Hungary won 6-3 at Wembley in 1953.

Too rarely has an England manager had the luxury of a central defender who is sufficiently comfortable on the ball to bring it forward and make constructive passes. And as was all too obvious in Euro 96 England were desperately in need of a midfielder with the strength and the vision to alternate successfully between defence and attack.

Maybe Sven-Goran Eriksson is about to come up with a solution when his team meet Finland at Anfield on Saturday.

As the bitter east wind blew a chilly cocktail of sleet and snow across the fairways surrounding England's Cheshire hotel yesterday two young men had people wondering whether they could bring back the attacking qualities of Bobby Moore or Roy McFarland to the defence and combine it with echoes of Alan Mullery or Colin Bell in midfield.

Eriksson s first competitive match as England coach promises to be a pivotal occasion for Rio Ferdinand of Leeds United and Steven Gerrard of Liverpool.Certainly there has never been a more appropriate time for a renaissance in these positions.

Internationally the pair are tyros. Although the 22-year-old Ferdinand has won 11 caps, five of these have been as a substitute. Gerrard's England appearances would now be approaching double figures but for groin and thigh strains that have restricted his career so far to a match and a half.

Gerrard, at 20, looks more of an England natural, although Ferdinand, originally hailed as the country's most natural libero since the term entered football's language and subsequently written off as a might-have-been, has reason to be optimistic about gaining a regular place in Eriksson's defence.

The position alongside Sol Campbell at centre-back is up for grabs following Tony Adams s retirement from international football and Ferdinand's all-round game has improved since his £18m transfer from the Wendy house at West Ham to a solid northern mansion at Leeds.

"Maybe at West Ham I did go a bit stale," Ferdinand conceded yesterday. "I certainly think that joining Leeds has added an edge to my game. I don't go forward willy-nilly any more. I have to be patient."

Gerrard has an equally clear idea of the state of his game. "'I'll play anywhere but ideally I'd like to play central midfield," he declared. "I feel much stronger than I did a year ago."

It is crucial that Gerrard solves his physical difficulties before he is much older. Regular strains are serious enough in a footballer of 30; in a player only just out of his teens they cast a longer shadow.

Gerrard is convinced that his problems are easing but it is too soon to say if this is mere wishful thinking. Even now he might have to rule himself out of Saturday's England game and he is not even thinking about Albania.

He is still living from game to game. After coming off the bench for the last 35 minutes at Anfield on Sunday he travelled to France to see the specialist who is striving to keep a balance between his playing regularly and getting the rest the injury requires.

"If I had played the full 90 minutes on Sunday I would not have been here for training today," Gerrard admitted. "And had I tried to play other games when I was 70 to 80% fit I would probably have been forgotten by now. I d rather miss a match than play when I'm below 100%."

A lot depends on Gerrard getting his percentages right. His ability to carry the play into the heart of the opposing half and use the ball productively is a quality that could do so much to take England to next year's World Cup. His appearance on his home ground in an England shirt would be a bonus compared to which the state of David Seaman's back, which felt a little better yesterday, is barely an item.

fields.headline: Independent 'nearing profitability'
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Independent and Independent on Sunday have narrowed their losses to €3.5m (£2.2m) last year from €7m in 1999. By David Teather.
fields.body:
The Independent and its sister title the Independent on Sunday narrowed their losses to €3.5m (£2.2m) last year from €7m in 1999 the company said yesterday.

Brendan Hopkins, chief executive of the British business of Independent News & Media, said the titles had already begun to break even in some weeks and would be profitable by year end.

The main factors for the improving performance during 2000 were higher advertising revenues, ahead by 12.5%, and the move from Canary Wharf tower to a nearby office block which has led to a €5m saving.

The company warned that it had experienced a flat first 10-12 weeks of the year and said worldwide advertising spend was patchy.

In Australia and New Zealand, where the company has operations, the market matched the first quarter of 2000. In Ireland, the performance continued to improve while in South Africa it dipped.

The group reported an increase in pretax profits of 13% to €155m, slightly below some analysts' forecasts.

The note of caution on the outlook dragged shares in the company 10% lower to 162.5p. Revenues were 15% better at €1.34bn.

Mr Hopkins said newspapers had proved to be more robust than many had predicted. "We are not seeing the kind of advertising fallout that TV companies are seeing. Three years ago everyone was writing the industry off, but there are some very good news stories for newspapers."

Growth in the Irish economy continues to be amazing Mr Hopkins added.

He said the Belfast Telegraph in Northern Ireland which the company acquired last year was experiencing strong growth in recruitment advertising.

fields.headline: Royal Opera House gets it right
fields.standfirst:
Boulevard Solitude
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Boulevard Solitude
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: *****
fields.body:
For once the Royal Opera has done something right. It may not yet have succeeded in selling enough tickets for its new production of Boulevard Solitude, prompting tabloid accusations that the company is putting on "difficult" modern opera that no one wants to see. However, that is a marketing failure rather than a problem of the work or of the staging. Covent Garden has done eloquent justice to the piece that launched Hans Werner Henze's career in 1952 and is now being seen in London for the first time in 39 years. It is one of his best works, and as a tribute to the composer in the year of his 75th birthday its revival could hardly be more appropriate.

Grete Weil's libretto is an updating of Abbé Prévost's 1731 tale Manon Lescaut to France at the end of the second world war. The names are the same as in both Massenet's and Puccini's versions, but the emphasis has been shifted: in Boulevard Solitude it is the knight, Des Grieux - not Manon - who is the central character. Manon is much more prey than predator here, lethally manipulated by her own brother and helpless to do anything about it. Yet the tragedy of the lovers is presented with almost icy objectivity: there are no great passionate outbursts, no moments of soul-baring angst or opportunities for self-pity.

It is very much a product of the postwar years, keeping its emotions tightly in check. When the action threatens to become deadly serious, an element of surreal farce is introduced to sweep that away. Henze's music, by turns coolly neoclassical, delicately atonal and raucously parodic (there are some fine pastiches of Kurt Weill and excursions into jazz), maps those changes unerringly. A model of economy, the work lasts just 80 minutes, and not a note is wasted.

Nikolaus Lehnhoff's pro-duction is also wonderfully unfussy, yet it mixes realism and stylisation in a way that precisely corresponds to the turnabouts in the music. The railway station of the opening scene is grandiosely realised in Tobias Hoheisel's sets; the detail is precise but without ever being busy. The whole thing makes a hugely impressive package that is gorgeously sung, at least by the tenor Par Lindskog as a haunted Des Grieux, and Alexandra von der Weth as a lissom, alluring Manon. The rest of the cast are best described as efficient rather than special. Berhard Kontarsky conducts; the orchestral playing is first-rate.

This is an achievement the Royal Opera can be genuinely proud of. It deserves a full house for every performance.

In rep until April 4. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

webTitle: Why not everyone should hog hedge funds

fields.headline: Why not everyone should hog hedge funds
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The man credited with creating what were to become known as hedge funds was a sociologist, Alfred Winslow Jones, in 1949.
fields.body:
The man credited with creating what were to become known as hedge funds was a sociologist, Alfred Winslow Jones, in 1949.

Today it is George Soros, the Hungarian-born financier, who is most closely associated with their high risk and speculative notoriety, after he forced the pound out of the exchange rate mechanism.

Other headline stories, such as the international bail-out of Long Term Capital Management two years ago, have saddled hedge funds with the image of involving betting on the markets which can go wrong with dire consequences.

Yet a recent report from the National Association of Pension Funds, which represents the industry, discusses this "valuable addition" to the range of products in which pension funds might invest.

This is because not all hedge funds are the same and, according to some market experts, investing in some types of hedge fund when markets are falling might be the way to make money, seemingly against the odds.

Alexander Ineichen, an analyst at investment bank UBS Warburg, pointed out that this ability to beat falling markets was one reason hedge funds began to be noticed. In 1990, for instance, Mr Soros's noted Quantum fund was up 30% when the overall US market fell by 3%.

While times have changed for Quantum and Mr Soros, the NAPF notes that the flexibility hedge funds enjoy in their investment strategies means that they can can "produce attractive returns in economic and market conditions in which traditional investments - equities and fixed interest bonds - are depressed".

There are four main types of hedge fund:

 Market neutral or relative value, which try to exploit market inefficiences or mispricing;

 Event driven, which invest on anticipated mergers, bankruptcy or corporate reorganisations;

 Long/short, which allow fund mangers to buy some assets but sell others they do not yet own;

 Tactical trading, perhaps the most volatile of all, which speculate on the future direction of markets.

Hedge funds are not for everyone.

Nick Fitzpatrick, who is head of global investments at Bacon & Woodrow, which advises leading institutions on their investments, said: "We're not advising clients to invest in hedge funds because we consider them unproven."

The way hedge funds perform during the present market turbulence might be crucial if they are to win greater acceptance.

fields.headline: God Only Knows
fields.standfirst:
Vaudeville Theatre
London
Rating: *
fields.trailText:
Vaudeville Theatre
London
Rating: *
fields.body:
God may know how Hugh Whitemore's preposterous new play made it into the West End, but I certainly don't. The producers must be banking on a miracle to get them through.

It begins like this. Two couples, the Mintos and the Cokers, are not really enjoying their annual holiday together. Partly it is because the location is a remote Tuscan barn where, conveniently for Whitemore, but not for the Mintos and the Cokers, the phone has been cut off. The characters keep telling us loudly what silly-billies they are to have forgotten to bring their mobiles.

Charles Minto has swapped his old wife for a newer, younger model called Eleanor, Vin Coker drinks too much red wine, and there are too many long nights to fill playing the Italian version of Monopoly. Something has to happen or we would all leave the theatre; so, of course, it does. There is the sound of a nearby car crash and a very het-up Derek Jacobi stumbles in, dazed and bleeding and wearing his pyjamas. He claims to be an English academic, Humphrey, who is working for the Vatican archive and has stumbled across a 2000-year-old document that proves that the resurrection never really happened. The Mintos and the Cokers do not take this on faith - largely, I think, because of the pyjamas.

Humphrey tells the holiday- makers that his discovery has so enraged the Vatican that he has been drugged and forcibly detained in hospital but he has escaped by masquerading as a central-heating engineer and is now being pursued across Italy by ruthless clerics determined to murder him so that nobody will discover that Christianity is a sham.

There is no respite from Humphrey's increasingly agitated ranting as he sets out to demolish all arguments for Christianity while invoking sinister Vatican organisations such as P2. Soon the couples fear for their lives, but how can they tell if Humphrey is telling the truth or has simply escaped from a lunatic asylum?

Whether you believe him or not all comes down to faith, and it is the nature of belief that is the subject of Whitemore's play. Unfortunately, he handles neither the arguments nor the thriller element well. It is less drama than drunken after-dinner debate as all the good reasons not to believe are handed to Humphrey while the others stand around like stooges providing the punchlines for his monologue.

By the end of the evening, Humphrey has become such a bore and so irritating that I was seriously reconsidering my commitment to atheism.

Booking until June 9. Box office: 020-7836 9987.

fields.headline: Can you dance to Shostakovich?
fields.standfirst:
Richard Alston Company
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Richard Alston Company
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Richard Alston often seems to be motivated more by musical obsession than by a desire to make life easy for himself as a choreographer. The first of his two new works, Tremor, is set to Shostakovich's Third String Quartet, a score more naturally suited to solitary listening than to the glare and activity of the stage. The second, Fever, is set to the more obviously dance-friendly Monteverdi, but to a recording of the composer's Madrigals and Sinfonias by the Concerto Italiano, under Rinaldo Alessandrini.

It is no accident that the titles of both works suggest a fiercely physical response to their scores, for Alston is rarely less than passionate. Yet both works tell us more about the way Alston translates notes into steps than about the stories he may hear in his scores.

Alston's programme note eloquently describes Shostakovich's quartet as a work of bright surfaces and dark shadows, subtly conveying the terrors of life under Stalin. Yet the drama he conveys in his choreography tends to be one of scale and texture rather than graphic body language. In the opening movement a passage of near-unison dance fragments into separate lines as the dancers ricochet against the increasingly jagged phrasing of the strings. At the close, when a single violin plays against the murmuring of the other instruments, the dance pares down to a duet so intimate it barely takes up space.

Only in the dark central section is there the feel of a narrative subtext as Pari Naderi and Lee Clayden's duet becomes fraught with backward glances, tiny knocking rhythms of feet and warding gestures of the arms. But while this passage chimes with hints of danger, it is not enough to create a theatrical whole. Shostakovich's quartet is long and episodic, and because Alston avoids imposing his own logic on to it, the dance lacks dramatic momentum.

The same is true of Fever. The tone of this work ought to be very different, drenched as it is in golden light and set to Monteverdi's rushes of sound. Early in the piece Naderi rapturously arches her upper body as if trying to drown herself in the music. Following her lead, the rest of the dancers mould themselves languorously against each other, or shiver in sudden frenzies of movement. But Fever rarely takes us beyond each beautiful, supercharged moment; it rarely makes us curious about what is coming next. This is partly a product of its musical purism, but it is also partly a problem created by the youthfulness of Alston's company. Apart from Naderi and the excellent Martin Lawrence, we don't seek out individual dancers in the choreography. As performers they add little drama to the stage. They are still just bodies making shapes to music.

Until tomorrow. Box office: 020-7960 4242.

Yet the drama he conveys in his choreography tends to be one of scale and texture rather than graphic body language. In the opening movement a passage of near-unison dance fragments into separate lines as the dancers ricochet against the increasingly jagged phrasing of the strings. At the close, when a single violin plays against the murmuring of the other instruments, the dance pares down to a duet so intimate it barely takes up space. Only in the dark central section is there the feel of a narrative subtext as Pari Naderi and Lee Clayden's duet becomes fraught with backward glances, tiny knocking rhythms of feet and warding gestures of the arms. But while this passage chimes with hints of danger, it is not enough to create a theatrical whole. Shostakovich's quartet is long and episodic, and because Alston avoids imposing his own logic on to it, the dance lacks dramatic momentum. The same is true of Fever. The tone of this work ought to be very different, drenched as it is in golden light and set to Monteverdi's rushes of sound. Early in the piece Naderi rapturously arches her upper body as if trying to drown herself in the music. Following her lead, the rest of the dancers mould themselves languorously against each other, or shiver in sudden frenzies of movement. But Fever rarely takes us beyond each beautiful, supercharged moment; it rarely makes us curious about what is coming next. This is partly a product of its musical purism, but it is also partly a problem created by the youthfulness of Alston's company. Apart from Naderi and the excellent Martin Lawrence, we don't seek out individual dancers in the choreography. As performers they add little drama to the stage. They are still just bodies making shapes to music. Until tomorrow. Box office: 020-7960 4242.

webTitle: Markets give thumbs down to Fed rate cut

fields.headline: Markets give thumbs down to Fed rate cut
fields.standfirst: Footsie falls by more than 100 points as Europe fears US recession
fields.trailText: World stock markets dived again yesterday, as investors gave the United States Federal Reserve the thumbs down for failing to jump-start the American economy with a sharp reduction in borrowing costs.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson in New York and Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
World stock markets dived again yesterday, as investors gave the United States Federal Reserve the thumbs down for failing to jump-start the American economy with a sharp reduction in borrowing costs.

Worried that the 0.5 percentage-point cut to interest rates which the Federal Reserve announced on Tuesday would not stop the US economic slide, European investors headed for the exit, following Wall Street's lead.

The FTSE 100 index of top shares fell more than 100 points to finish at a 27-month closing low of 5,540.7.

In Paris, the CAC 40 index of leading shares fell 114.64 - or 2.2% - to 5,023.76 points, while the DAX index at Germany's Deutsche Börse was down 169.4, or 2.9% at 5,612.76 points.

After closing down 238 points at a two-year low on Tuesday, the Dow Jones industrial average declined a further 156.83 to 9,563.93 in midday trading.

"We're in a bear market quite definitely, and rate cuts aren't working," said one senior London equity salesman.

Investor disappointment spread to Europe, where hi-tech and telecommunications companies were hit by declining confidence.

Shares in Finland-based Nokia fell 5% as the mobile telephone manufacturing group's annual meeting failed to provide a lift to investor enthusiasm. BT, France Télécom and Deutsche Telekom were also among those to fall sharply during the day.

Drugs and consumer companies were among those hardest hit by yesterday's blue-chip sell-off. Procter & Gamble fell after reports that it may be forced to cut up to 20% of its workforce, while Johnson & Johnson's share price declined as investors worried about the impact of a recession.

Electronics group 3Com also reported a worse than expected quarterly loss.

Pressure is now mounting on the European Central Bank to rescue the markets by cutting interest rates at its meeting next week.

German business confidence has collapsed to an 18-month low, according to figures published yesterday.

Yesterday's selling was largely prompted by continuing disappointment that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, had not opted for a bigger interest rate cut this week.

Adding to the market's woes, new American inflation figures raised the spectre of "stagflation" - rising prices alongside falling output.

The US consumer prices index - which tracks the cost of goods and services paid by consumers - increased by 0.3% in February, more than expected by most analysts.

Art Hogan, the chief market analyst at Jefferies and Co, the brokerage, said: "There is both irrational disappointment that the US Federal Reserve could have done more - which would have meant that the outlook was even bleaker - and a more rational concern based on the fundamental news coming from companies themselves."

In spite of the difficulties of the past week, the US market was braced for more bad news. The quarterly earnings season, when companies report the outlook for future performance, is only halfway through.

webTitle: BP under attack on two fronts

fields.headline: BP under attack on two fronts
fields.trailText: BP yesterday came under fire from fund managers and environmentalists for "crushing" shareholder debate while committing itself to greater openness at next month's annual general meeting.
fields.body:
BP yesterday came under fire from fund managers and environmentalists for "crushing" shareholder debate while committing itself to greater openness at next month's annual general meeting.

The AGM looks set to be even more turbulent than last year's after BP confirmed its chief executive Sir John Browne had increased his pay package from $6.4m (£4.5m) to $7.1m. His remuneration has been heavily criticised by shareholders despite BP quadrupling in size over recent years.

The world's third largest oil company yesterday faced claims of hypocrisy for adopting a sunflower logo and "beyond petroleum" slogan while increasing its investment in oil and gas.

The criticism came as Greenpeace took its ecological message to the heart of the City with a seminar at the London Stock Exchange.

There were stinging remarks from Friends Ivory & Sime, Britain's biggest socially responsible investment managers. Its director of corporate responsibility, Craig Mackenzie, said it was a great irony that BP had committed itself to openness but had prevented two of four activist resolutions coming to its AGM.

Stephanie Tunmore, climate campaigner at Greenpeace, successfully submitted resolutions to BP's AGM last year only to find similar ones rejected this year on the grounds of legal technicalities. "They made it very difficult for us [this time round]," she said.

A drop in demand for petrol over the next 20 years owing to greater market penetration of low-emissions vehicles could erode BP earnings by up to 5% according to Innovest, a group of analysts commissioned by Greenpeace.

A BP spokesman rejected the findings of the report and other criticisms saying the company was being unfairly targeted by Greenpeace.

It was untrue that BP had rejected the resolutions for technical reasons. He pointed out that turning its back on oil and gas exploration required a change to the company's founding articles of association.

fields.headline: Tonight, Matthew, you shall be Kafka
fields.standfirst:
Kafka's Dick
Theatre Royal
York
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Kafka's Dick
Theatre Royal
York
Rating: ****
fields.body:
When Franz Kafka instructed that his work should be burned on his death, he never guessed that he would live on to become an adjective indiscriminately used to describe queuing at the post office, Railtrack's emergency timetabling arrangements or the Arts Council's funding of regional theatre. York's Theatre Royal was excluded from the recent injection of money into the ailing reps, apparently on the basis that it didn't need any cash. It's a funny way to reward success; and Elizabeth Jones, the chief executive responsible for the 10-year crawl towards solvency, has resigned in protest at the decision.

It would be a neat irony for her to exit with a Kafkaesque conundrum that shows every sign of an ambitious regional house in good order. Alan Bennett is always a sure- fire seat-filler; and if you add a top TV celeb such as Matthew Kelly to the mix you might as well start queuing for returns now. For those who had principally come to see the presenter of Stars in Their Eyes pretend to be someone else for a change, it was an evening of surprises: firstly, that he doesn't figure until after the interval; secondly, that there is an extended critical debate on the nature of literary posterity to sit through; and thirdly, that it was thoroughly enjoyable.

Kafka's Dick brings the tubercular Czech bouncing back to life to engage in a literary spat with his executor, Max Brod, guardian of Kafka's posthumous reputation and history's most ineffectual firelighter. It is one of Bennett's least-often revived works, having something of the air of a Beyond the Fringe sketch that got out of hand. Although it makes a significant point about our tendency to prefer speculating over a writer's private life to reading their work, the audience were in paroxysms of pleasure over the moments that are pure Bennett rather than sub- Tom Stoppard.

Damien Cruden's witty production and Nigel Hook's set design colourfully enhance the play's surrealism; and there's a further Freudian twist to the Oedipal friction between Kafkas senior and junior, in that they are portrayed by two Matthews, Kelly and Rixon, who are father and son in real life. A triumphant event for the Theatre Royal - though perhaps one should report instead that it was balls-breakingly bad, on the offchance that this will persuade the Arts Council to relent and give the theatre some money.

Until April 7. Box office: 01904 623568.

webTitle: Theatre review: Out In The Open

fields.headline: Out In The Open
fields.standfirst:
Hampstead Theatre
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Hampstead Theatre
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Inside Jonathan Harvey's fat new play there is a thin one signalling to be let out. As we know from Beautiful Thing, Harvey writes cracking dialogue; but here, a potentially rich play suffers from redundant dialogue and over-indulgent direction from Kathy Burke.

The setting is a Dalston garden over a summer weekend, where Harvey unites two potent dramatic myths: that of the ubiquitous dead gay man, from Kevin Elyot's My Night With Reg, and that of the romanticised ex-partner, from Alan Ayckbourn's Absent Friends. Tony is struggling to get over the death of his lover, Frankie, six months earlier, by starting an affair with a young Mancunian, Iggy. But he is impeded at every turn, first by Frankie's mother, Mary - determined to keep her son's memory alive - then by his lodger, Kevin, and a lesbian friend, Monica, who know that Iggy is infinitely more than a harmless pick-up.

As plots go, it is a perfectly good one. And Harvey clearly understands the tenacity of grief. But Harvey is the victim of his own facility. In the first act he brings on Mary's boozy mate, Rose, who is full of amusing fantasies about her encounters with the famous. The only problem is that this Dalston Mistress Quickly is superfluous to the plot. And, though we soon grasp that the sentimentalised Frankie was a faithless hypocrite, it takes an age for everyone else to make the same admission and for Tony to realise that it is time for him to move on.

The good bits of the play are highly enjoyable, though. Foremost among these is Linda Bassett's performance as Mary - a particularly well-written character. Mary dispenses food and radiates garrulous cheer while clinging to false memories of her dead son out of loneliness and guilt. Harvey grants her many of the play's best lines. Given a Mykonos-holiday sarong by Monica, Mary waltzes around in it, crying, "It'd make a lovely picnic rug. Or a baby's blanket." She exudes chatty, cheerful, joint-smoking bonhomie, but Bassett also suggests a woman who will fight like a tigress to protect the image of Frankie.

There is also a fine moment at the end when the colour seems to drain from Bassett's still, stricken features; but it is symptomatic of Harvey's and Burke's talent for excess that they prolong a perfect image and back it with Orfeo's operatic lament for Eurydice.

Radically cut, this would be a very good play; and one might admire even more the performances of Mark Bonnar as Tony, of Michele Austin as his thick-skinned actress chum and of Sean Gallagher as the devoted, drunken lodger.

Harvey certainly can write: what he now needs is to meet a play-doctor who will put him on a strict dramatic diet.

Until April 14. Box office: 020-7722 9301.

fields.headline: Lastminute moves
fields.standfirst:
More net news
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Brent Hoberman, Martha Lane Fox and Allan Leighton, the trio at the helm of troubled etailer Lastminute.com, yesterday moved into the market in an attempt to bolster its share price.
fields.body:
Brent Hoberman, Martha Lane Fox and Allan Leighton, the trio at the helm of troubled etailer Lastminute.com, yesterday moved into the market in an attempt to bolster its share price.

Messrs Hoberman and Leighton both bought 127,273 shares at 39.2857p each - roughly £50,000 worth - shortly after the price had fallen to a record low. Ms Lane Fox stumped up £10,000 for 25,454 shares.

Dealers acknowledged that the purchases were a show of faith in the maligned dot.com but said the jury remains out.

The last set of quarterly figures rang alarm bells in some quarters because they were reported in a less transparent way than previously. This made it difficult to see how the underlying business was performing.

Lastminute itself insists the business is on track, even if the share price is not. The shares fell 2p to 39.5p.

webTitle: Betting on a sure fire loser

fields.headline: Betting on a sure fire loser
fields.standfirst:
It's risky, but some of the bolder day traders have found ways of making a killing on a falling market

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Amid the investor stampede to sell stocks as the markets plummeted last week, one firm on the fringes of the financial services industry announced it had done its best day's business in more than 25 years. After a fall of more than 250 points on the Dow Jones index on Wednesday spread betting firm, IG Index was inundated with calls and emails from private investors wanting to make money by betting on further misfortune hitting the markets.
fields.byline: Simon Bowers, Neil Hume and Jill Treanor
fields.body:
Amid the investor stampede to sell stocks as the markets plummeted last week, one firm on the fringes of the financial services industry announced it had done its best day's business in more than 25 years. After a fall of more than 250 points on the Dow Jones index on Wednesday spread betting firm, IG Index was inundated with calls and emails from private investors wanting to make money by betting on further misfortune hitting the markets.

"Our phones were ringing non-stop and the internet was firing away madly," a spokesman said. "At 4am one customer placed a £50-per-point bet on the Dow falling and, by the end of the day, took home more than £15,600. People were frantically looking for opportunities to make a profit from market volatility." The number of customers betting on a further fall in the market increased fourfold, he said.

While the more cautious private investors have retired from the markets to nurse their losses, a hardcore of bold - some would say foolhardy - day traders insist there is plenty of money to be made amid plummeting stocks, profit warnings and redundancy announcements.

Until recently, it has been difficult for private investors to speculate on a fall in shares. But the advent of innovative online investment methods and up-to-the-minute financial news has opened up opportunities for "shorting" the market - that is, speculating on a fall - to any investor with modest savings and a modem.

Edward Kalfayan, a retired businessman turned private investor who trades from two screens in his bedroom in Wimbledon, south London, said the current bearish environment is an ideal opportunity to abandon traditional brokers in favour of financial spread betting firms which offer bets on a fall in market indices, as well as on a rise. "If there is still an adjustment to come, spread betting is the best way to capitalise on a downward move," he said.

Because of the highly-leveraged nature of spread bets, a small stake can produce colossal returns if investors correctly anticipate dramatic market shifts. A broker at one spread betting firm said that investors are increasingly learning to look at dips in the market as opportunities, though most bets are still placed on stocks to rise. "Recently, the biggest winners are people who went short of the Nasdaq anything up to six months ago," he said. "They have made a lot of money - up to £20,000 or £30,000, off a £5 or £10 stake."

When taking out a spread bet, customers specify how much they wish to bet per point move in the market. For example, a down bet on the Nasdaq of £5 a point, followed by a 100 point fall, would result in a £500 profit - 100 times the original £5 stake.

Stock market historian David Schwartz said that historical patterns suggest that the British stock market has been due to drop to a long-term trend line for some time. "History tells us that shares don't do very well after an enormous rise. In the UK, we ended 1974 at the bottom of an awful bear market, the worst we have ever had, but we have been going up almost ever since," he said. "We have just had the greatest stock market bubble in modern history on the Nasdaq. And when bubbles burst, the index virtually always goes down to the long-term trend line - which is around 1,400 to 1,500 on the Nasdaq."

However, such theorising is of limited value to short-term investors looking for returns on volatile stocks. Mr Kalfayan decided to place a heavy bet on a fall in the markets in January, but lost out after the US Federal Reserve's dramatic cut in interest. "The index shot up like an Indian rope trick," he said. "I don't want to go into figures, but I lost a packet."

Another increasingly popular alternative to conventional investments are equity contracts for difference (CFDs). Like spread bets, CFDs expose holders to the fluctuations in shares without requiring them to buy or sell physical stock. A CFD is an agreement to exchange the difference between an underlying stock price at the beginning and end of a contract. Like spread betting, CFDs are also exempt from capital gains tax.

John Newman, of Sucden, which offers CFDs via the web and telephone, said a growing number of his clients are covering losses on their physical shares by selling CFDs in matching holdings. He said the proportion of sell CFDs had risen by more than 50%, although they were still not as popular as buys.

Further opportunities for private investors to sell short are offered at InvestIN Securities, in the heart of the City, which allows day traders direct access to markets where they can sell physical shares short. "If they transfer more than $20,000 into an account we give them access to a screen which is exactly the same as the one used by Goldman Sachs in Wall Street and in London," said Steven Coles compliance officer at InvestIN Securities. "They are able to short stocks on the Nasdaq as long as they follow the rules and they are making money."

Hedge funds are another potential form of insulation against market losses. Despite being closely associated with George Soros, the Hungarian born speculator who crippled the pound during the ERM crisis, a number of major investment firms are beginning to offer such products for investors.

Proceed with caution, though, is the warning from the financial services authority to investors thinking of putting their tax-free savings into this most exotic type of individual savings plan.

The regulator is concerned that the rush to invest before the end of the tax year may cloud investors' judgment about such funds which can involve higher risks.

Among the firms beginning to offer the hedge funds, more usually the preserve of the rich, are Credit Suisse First Boston, Deutsche Bank, Jupiter and Henderson.

Chris Demarco, managing director at CSFB, agreed with the FSA's point that these products were attractive for people who already have other types of investments.

He pointed out that such products could be useful investments as they do not only involve strategies which require buying stocks - being "long" in market jargon. "Hedge funds can be better when markets are going downwards and sideways because they are not obliged to be long," Mr Demarco said.

What is spread betting?
Simon Bowers

A spread betting firm picks an index - for example, a share price, a cricket innings score, or the price of gold - and forecasts a range within which it expects the index to fall at a specified moment in the future. This is called the spread.

If a punter feels confident the index will fall below the offered spread, he or she places a "down bet". And if he or she feels the index will rise above the spread, an "up bet" is placed.

The extreme element to spread betting comes from the way winnings and losses are calculated. Unlike conventional betting, returns are not determined by fixed odds; instead they depend on how far the index deviates from the spread. If a punter correctly anticipates a dramatic move in the index, the winnings - calculated by multiplying the stake by the amount deviated - can be enormous.

Equally, if the index soars away in the unfavoured direction, astronomical losses can be run up, well in excess of the initial stake.

Industry estimates put the number of spread betting punters in Britain at 100,000, a rise of 70,000-75,000 in just three years. While the most popular bets on offer are for sporting events, the bulk of many company revenues comes from financial spreads. Because of this, all spread betting is regulated by the financial services authority.

Many private investors have been attracted to spread betting as an alternative to conventional trading because of the tax avoidance benefits it can offer. As with other forms of gambling, spread-bet winnings are exempt from income tax, and can save investors from slipping into a higher tax band - a fact many spread-betting companies are keen to highlight. Winnings are also free from capital gains tax.

But the advent of innovative online investment methods and up-to-the-minute financial news has opened up opportunities for "shorting" the market - that is, speculating on a fall - to any investor with modest savings and a modem. Edward Kalfayan, a retired businessman turned private investor who trades from two screens in his bedroom in Wimbledon, south London, said the current bearish environment is an ideal opportunity to abandon traditional brokers in favour of financial spread betting firms which offer bets on a fall in market indices, as well as on a rise. "If there is still an adjustment to come, spread betting is the best way to capitalise on a downward move," he said. Because of the highly-leveraged nature of spread bets, a small stake can produce colossal returns if investors correctly anticipate dramatic market shifts. A broker at one spread betting firm said that investors are increasingly learning to look at dips in the market as opportunities, though most bets are still placed on stocks to rise. "Recently, the biggest winners are people who went short of the Nasdaq anything up to six months ago," he said. "They have made a lot of money - up to £20,000 or £30,000, off a £5 or £10 stake." When taking out a spread bet, customers specify how much they wish to bet per point move in the market. For example, a down bet on the Nasdaq of £5 a point, followed by a 100 point fall, would result in a £500 profit - 100 times the original £5 stake. Stock market historian David Schwartz said that historical patterns suggest that the British stock market has been due to drop to a long-term trend line for some time. "History tells us that shares don't do very well after an enormous rise. In the UK, we ended 1974 at the bottom of an awful bear market, the worst we have ever had, but we have been going up almost ever since," he said. "We have just had the greatest stock market bubble in modern history on the Nasdaq. And when bubbles burst, the index virtually always goes down to the long-term trend line - which is around 1,400 to 1,500 on the Nasdaq." However, such theorising is of limited value to short-term investors looking for returns on volatile stocks. Mr Kalfayan decided to place a heavy bet on a fall in the markets in January, but lost out after the US Federal Reserve's dramatic cut in interest. "The index shot up like an Indian rope trick," he said. "I don't want to go into figures, but I lost a packet." Another increasingly popular alternative to conventional investments are equity contracts for difference (CFDs). Like spread bets, CFDs expose holders to the fluctuations in shares without requiring them to buy or sell physical stock. A CFD is an agreement to exchange the difference between an underlying stock price at the beginning and end of a contract. Like spread betting, CFDs are also exempt from capital gains tax. John Newman, of Sucden, which offers CFDs via the web and telephone, said a growing number of his clients are covering losses on their physical shares by selling CFDs in matching holdings. He said the proportion of sell CFDs had risen by more than 50%, although they were still not as popular as buys. Further opportunities for private investors to sell short are offered at InvestIN Securities, in the heart of the City, which allows day traders direct access to markets where they can sell physical shares short. "If they transfer more than $20,000 into an account we give them access to a screen which is exactly the same as the one used by Goldman Sachs in Wall Street and in London," said Steven Coles compliance officer at InvestIN Securities. "They are able to short stocks on the Nasdaq as long as they follow the rules and they are making money." Hedge funds are another potential form of insulation against market losses. Despite being closely associated with George Soros, the Hungarian born speculator who crippled the pound during the ERM crisis, a number of major investment firms are beginning to offer such products for investors. Proceed with caution, though, is the warning from the financial services authority to investors thinking of putting their tax-free savings into this most exotic type of individual savings plan. The regulator is concerned that the rush to invest before the end of the tax year may cloud investors' judgment about such funds which can involve higher risks. Among the firms beginning to offer the hedge funds, more usually the preserve of the rich, are Credit Suisse First Boston, Deutsche Bank, Jupiter and Henderson. Chris Demarco, managing director at CSFB, agreed with the FSA's point that these products were attractive for people who already have other types of investments. He pointed out that such products could be useful investments as they do not only involve strategies which require buying stocks - being "long" in market jargon. "Hedge funds can be better when markets are going downwards and sideways because they are not obliged to be long," Mr Demarco said. What is spread betting? Simon Bowers A spread betting firm picks an index - for example, a share price, a cricket innings score, or the price of gold - and forecasts a range within which it expects the index to fall at a specified moment in the future. This is called the spread. If a punter feels confident the index will fall below the offered spread, he or she places a "down bet". And if he or she feels the index will rise above the spread, an "up bet" is placed. The extreme element to spread betting comes from the way winnings and losses are calculated. Unlike conventional betting, returns are not determined by fixed odds; instead they depend on how far the index deviates from the spread. If a punter correctly anticipates a dramatic move in the index, the winnings - calculated by multiplying the stake by the amount deviated - can be enormous. Equally, if the index soars away in the unfavoured direction, astronomical losses can be run up, well in excess of the initial stake. Industry estimates put the number of spread betting punters in Britain at 100,000, a rise of 70,000-75,000 in just three years. While the most popular bets on offer are for sporting events, the bulk of many company revenues comes from financial spreads. Because of this, all spread betting is regulated by the financial services authority. Many private investors have been attracted to spread betting as an alternative to conventional trading because of the tax avoidance benefits it can offer. As with other forms of gambling, spread-bet winnings are exempt from income tax, and can save investors from slipping into a higher tax band - a fact many spread-betting companies are keen to highlight. Winnings are also free from capital gains tax.
