fields.headline: Banks rattled by tax threat
fields.trailText: A punitive tax on high street banks was thrust on to the political agenda yesterday as a way to counter excess profits amassed by any anti-competitive behaviour in the business banking market.
fields.body:
A punitive tax on high street banks was thrust on to the political agenda yesterday as a way to counter excess profits amassed by any anti-competitive behaviour in the business banking market.

In its long list of possible "remedies" to the complex monopoly that high street banks are accused of running in the provision of banking services to small business, the competition commission also suggested a capping of charges to customers and steps to make it easier for businesses to move their accounts.

The commission's report, which will not be finalised until June and is yet to conclude whether any of these solutions will be necessary, unsettled shares in the sector, where Royal Bank of Scotland - which has a market share of greater than 25% - was the fastest faller, losing 6%.

It also prompted some criticism in the City that the commission was causing confusion by setting out "hypothetical" solutions - which are themselves an attempt by the commission to tackle accusations it has faced in the past of being too secretive during its investigations.

Tim Sweeney, director general of the British Bankers' Association who in today's New Statements hits out against the government for treating banks like utilities, said: "This is a hypothetical solution to a hypothetical problem."

The market was particularly unnerved by the re-emergence of a tax on "current or past excess profits" which was feared during the controversial Cruickshank inquiry into banking competition but failed to materialise.

Derek Morris, chairman of the competition commission and leading the inquiry, acknowledged the imposition of any tax would be outside his powers, and neither could he recommend how any tax was used. He also said such an approach might not be feasible.

Mr Morris did insist that he and his team of investigators were yet to conclude whether the complex monopoly operating in the provision of small business banking services - primarily Royal Bank, HSBC, Barclays and Lloyds TSB - was against the public interest.

This crucial public interest factor will be determined in the coming weeks, and will involve an analysis of whether the current practices of the big banks result in prices charged by banks being "significantly in excess to costs".

The banks pointed out that until the commission had found their behaviour was against the public interest all the remedies were "hypothetical". Ian Fletcher, head of policy at the British Chambers of Commerce, said there would be great disappointment if no action resulted from the inquiry.

The commission said it was unlikely to find small players in the market operating against the public interest.

This leaves the emphasis firmly on the "big four" - and possibly on Bank of Scotland and Clydesdale Bank.

fields.headline: Bank voted 7-2 for standstill
fields.trailText: Hopes of a British interest rate cut next month faded yesterday after minutes of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee meeting held earlier this month showed seven out of nine members voting to leave the cost of borrowing unchanged.
fields.body:
Hopes of a British interest rate cut next month faded yesterday after minutes of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee meeting held earlier this month showed seven out of nine members voting to leave the cost of borrowing unchanged.

Sushil Wadhwani and DeAnne Julius both argued for a quarter point reduction to 5.5%, citing the deteriorating world economy and the fact that underlying inflation, excluding mortgages (RPIX), was likely to remain below the government's 2.5% target.

The rest of the committee said that domestic demand remained robust and further pre-emptive rate cuts risked a return to the boom-bust cycle.

"A cut in rates now, though in other circumstances desirable to move RPIX back to target, might instead lead to a further stimulus to consumer spending in the short term and a further worsening of household balance sheet positions thus increasing the scale of adjustment which would be required if sentiment were to change," the minutes said.

"Were these domestic upside risks to diminish, or the downside risks inherent in the world economic outlook to crystallise, it could become easier to take steps in the short run to move inflation to target without adding to the risks in the medium term."

Ross Walker, economist at Royal Bank of Scotland, said that the vote, plus figures showing that domestic demand continued to grow strongly, suggested a rate cut next month was unlikely.

Philip Shaw, at Investec, said: "A number of factors could yet serve to change the MPC's mind. Evidence of a significant fall in industrial confidence from this week's CBI monthly trends survey could potentially tilt the balance."
